name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the economic governance review of packages six and two (RSP 2014/2938)

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, thank you for giving me the opportunity to set out briefly the main elements of the review of economic governance that the Commission published on 28 November. The Commission has already had an opportunity to discuss this topic with the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) on 2 December. I am looking forward to discussing this important topic further with you today and in the period to come. Let me start by recalling that the economic and financial crisis revealed important weaknesses in the original economic and monetary union set-up. In response, Europe has taken action on a number of fronts. Action has been truly impressive, especially compared with what was considered feasible just a few years ago. The euro area has been significantly bolstered by the setting up of a strong permanent firewall in the form of the European Stability Mechanism to ensure financial stability. We have created a banking union to address the fragmentation of the financial sector and to facilitate access to financing. Finally, we have strengthened our economic governance in order to reinforce economic and budgetary coordination.  The six-pack and the two-pack are the core elements that have led to the strengthening of economic governance. They have led to a strengthening of budgetary surveillance under the Stability and Growth Pack, the broadening of the scope of surveillance to include the area of macroeconomic imbalances as well as countries experiencing difficulties with financial stability, and to the codification in legislation of integrated economic and budgetary surveillance in the form of the European Semester.  In line with the legal requirements in the various pieces of legislation, the Commission has concluded a review of these new instruments. Broadly speaking, the review clauses require us to assess three elements of the six-pack and two-pack. First of all we have to assess the effectiveness of the regulations; this means to what extent the new rules have been effective in achieving their objectives. Secondly, we need to evaluate the impact of the rules on enhancing closer coordination of economic policies, and finally how the rules on the new economic governance have contributed to sustained economic governance in the European Union.  Due to the limited time span since its entry into force, experience with the application of the new governance system has been limited and a number of specific instruments remain untested. This concerns more specifically the excessive imbalances procedure. Furthermore, the system has so far been applied in specific economic conditions during and in the aftermath of the severe crisis. This limits the possibilities for judging the effectiveness of the systemʼs preventive role.  For these reasons the review the Commission published in November is short and factual and takes stock of the application of the new instruments since they have been in force; that is, autumn 2011 for the six-pack, and 2013 for the two-pack. It discusses separately the issues of fiscal surveillance, macroeconomic imbalances and the framework for countries experiencing difficulties as regards financial stability. It also briefly discusses the interlinkages between the various elements.  The review also highlights some improvements introduced by the six-pack and two-pack reform. Notably it has deepened and widened economic governance and has contributed to achieving progress as regards fiscal consolidation and correcting macroeconomic imbalances.  Finally, the Commission’s review identifies some possible areas for improvement. This relates mainly to the complexity of the system with regard to overlapping instruments, as well as to the complexity of some of the specific instruments themselves, for instance in the Stability and Growth Pack. Complexity could pose challenges for transparency and implementation.  The Commission’s assessment also points to the need for increased ownership of the necessary reforms in the Member States, which could help step up implementation of the reform recommendations under the European Semester. This would improve outcomes in terms of growth, imbalances and convergence.  Finally, the review highlights the need for better involvement of national parliaments and stakeholders to ensure better legitimacy and accountability. Our system of economic governance can only reap its full potential if it has ownership of all relevant stakeholders. This includes notably this Parliament as the key institution to ensure the democratic legitimacy and accountability of EU-level economic policy decisions.  The Commission therefore sees the review document as a starting point and a basis for dialogue and debate on the appropriate way forward in the coming months. I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As the European People's Party, we naturally welcome today's exchange. We support the Commission in taking a positive view of the existing legislation on the six-pack and the two-pack. We are seeing a trend that budget deficits are slowly recovering in most Member States of the European Union. We also support the Commission in regularly calling for far-reaching structural reforms from the Member States. We also believe, of course, that economic policy reforms are the right way forward. We support the Commission in saying that the Stability and Growth Pact in its current form is sustainable and future-to-be. This also means that the Commission should not hesitate to apply existing rules. The Stability and Growth Pact is the starting point for a successful, competitive and promising European economy. Anyone who advocates fundamentally weakening the Pact denies the mistakes of the past. The times of debt-making and fine-moneymaking have not brought success in the medium or long term – on the contrary. We have seen a spiral of a debt and financial market crisis. It is humbug to say that compliance with the Stability Pact prevents investment and growth in the Member States. The Stability Pact is not a growth hurdle. The Stability Pact reminds Member States of their obligations to use their budget funds in a sustainable, efficient and forward-looking manner. These are sometimes certainly unpleasant truths. Nor can a positive investment climate be induced unless reforms are tackled at the same time. Any examination of flexibility must be addressed under this premise. The credibility of the Stability and Growth Pact must not be jeopardised. There must be no distinction between large and small Member States. We therefore expect the Commission to act in the interests of the stability of Europe. And we expect the Commission to show a clear edge towards member states unwilling to reform and are reluctant to reform.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Madam President, Mr. Vice-President, here we are, at the first meeting of this Parliament, to discuss this important theme of economic governance. In the previous Parliament, we made an unprecedented step forward in banking, laying the groundwork for the banking union. Basically, the opportunity we now have, in this Commission of the last chance, is that of putting in place measures that will not only overcome the financial crisis, but also avoid a crisis of the political Union. For this reason, the work we are opening here is of major importance. However, you present the six-pack and two-pack balance sheet in a short and factual way, without taking into account the state of under-inflation and serious social crisis, or the under-growth of the euro area and the Union as a whole. It seems to me, however, that if the legislators have given us an appointment, it is not simply to hear this summary. I must admit that you published a document that, on the same day, It seems to me that there are more forward-looking ideas, with the annual growth review, which recognises the seriousness of the situation, and in particular of this social crisis, which focuses on both supply and demand, which acknowledges the existence of a lack of investment and the risk of stalling in several sectors and which invites Member States with budgetary room to use them. Finally, with regard to the multilateral dimension of the European semester, you underline the need to put the economies of the Member States into perspective. Unfortunately, in a way, I have the impression that this mindset is not reflected in your assessment of the six-pack and the two-pack. You are telling us that they have not been tested in normal times. This is obvious, since these rules had been adopted in an exceptional context, to deal with an exceptional situation. However, the result is clearly not there. We must ensure that the debate that begins remains multidimensional. When the Heads of State and Government confirmed this end-of-year meeting last June to evaluate the six-pack and the two-pack, they also gave you a mandate to define the flexibility margins of economic governance. We are waiting for you on this point. We hope that the document you put on the table will not define new rules, but will move from a logic of strict rule to a real steering of economic policy. It is not the same thing.  I hear that some people are very attached to the rules. So are we. But we know their limit, since they cannot be applied, that they infringe on the sovereignty of the Member States and promote anti-European sentiment, that they are too complicated to allow this appropriation which you have mentioned. We expect you on this interpretation, on this possibility of flexibility and, above all, we know that the roadmap is once again open for this famous report of the four presidents, in which the European Parliament wants to play its full role. Because everyone is telling us that if we do not move forward together on economic governance, Europe will be offended. The Europe of last chance is where it must be done, despite a certain paralysis and the impression, at times, that the debate between the Member States is now limited to exchanges of bird names. We believe that we need to get back to work, to start talking to each other normally, to understand each other and that, in this situation, you are waiting for the good ideas of Parliament and the goodwill of the Council. We hope to live up to the challenge.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I very much welcome the fact that we have this debate today. It is a debate on the two- and the six-pack, but in a more general sense it is also a debate on the success of economic governance in the European Union. If you look at it from this broader perspective, it is clear that this debate is a debate about the failure of this kind of governance. Because in the beginning there were rules that were clear, simple and transparent. It was the rule that there should be no more than 60% of debt, that there should be no more than 3% of new debt, and that there is a principle of non-assistance, that each state should be liable for its own debts and that no state should stand up for the debts of another state. These rules did not last. They were softened in 2005 in the reform of the Stability and Growth Pact and replaced by more complex rules, by less transparent concepts such as a structural deficit, the precise definition of which, I believe, few Members are able to reproduce. This structural deficit should now have been reduced by at least 0.5 percentage points from year to year, even by up to 0.8 percentage points for states that are in an excessive deficit procedure. But we haven't seen anything like it. The reduction in the structural deficit has taken place in small and smallest units, far from the target of 0.5 percentage points per year. Then, in 2010, the non-assistance clause, the crucial building block of the Stability and Growth Pact, was also broken. Instead, the ESM was created. In the form of the EFSF and the ESM, shadow budgets have been created at EU level, where new debt has been built up that is not attributed to individual states. The two-pack has been introduced, the six-pack has been introduced, the European Semester has been introduced, a very complex set of scoreboard indicators has been introduced, so that you can now justify any form of fiscal policy on the basis of any indicator, so that the rules are degenerated into complete arbitrariness. Ladies and gentlemen, that is the wrong way to go! It will make everything more opaque, complex and arbitrary, opening up opportunities for states to continue to operate irresponsibly, as we see at the moment, particularly in France. We must return to the one and crucial regulation, that is the principle of non-assistance. If we return to the principle of non-assistance, then each state will have its sovereignty, its fiscal and economic policy decisions to take as it can itself take responsibility for, given that it and only it will have to pay its debts. Then you do not need economic governance, then you do not need to make any recommendations. Then we can simply focus on reminding the states that debts that these states make must be paid by these states and the taxpayers of those states, and by no one else. This is enough as an incentive to return to reason and responsibility within the eurozone.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, today we are discussing the evaluation of the so-called six- and two-packs. These are the two measures put in place in recent years to extend and strengthen the Stability and Growth Pact. The Commission's evaluation of this is full of fine analyses, but it avoids the main point of discussion, namely whether and how much flexibility can be applied in maintaining budgetary rules. The Commission has indicated that it will take a position on this in January. Today, therefore, I can only rely on the omens of the past few weeks. And those omens are anything but favorable.  President Juncker himself said in a French newspaper last week that this Commission sees the enforcement of budgetary rules as a political decision. The additional delay that France received last month in order to get its budget in order makes it clear once again where that institution can lead. The French postponement goes against the agreements that were laid down less than two years ago, less than a year ago, in the two packages we are debating today, the six-pack and the two-pack. In its own evaluation of these packages, the Commission states that additional delays are only allowed if a country has made good progress on reforms but is facing an unexpected economic setback. However, in its assessment of the French budget for 2015 at the end of last month, the Commission made it clear that France has done far too little to get its budget and economy in order and reform. This delay was therefore not based on the budgetary arrangements we have made with each other in the euro area, as the Commission itself points out. The decision to postpone smacks of political clapping.  The first ten years of the euro have shown what happens when the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact become a political plaything. What is needed in the budgetary rules is not 'more political' and not 'more discretion' and not 'more flexibility'. Instead, the new investment plan should be seized upon as a stick behind the door to strengthen the rules. Only those countries that adhere to the Stability and Growth Pact, and only those countries that have implemented a majority of the country-specific recommendations should have access to the investment money of that plan. In this way, countries will not only be penalized if they do not comply with the rules, but also a reward in the form of additional investments if they do comply with the agreements. This is fair, efficient and clear, and we are strengthening budgetary rules, the European economy and confidence in the European Union.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, any assessment of the economic governance programme would have to start with one very simple and serious thing: it was to say that it failed. It failed because the new rules were not effective, because the impact on economic policies was more unemployment, it was less growth, it was more macroeconomic imbalances, and because there was no economic consolidation of the euro area.  Therefore, the Commission's economic governance proposal was a failure. It's garbage. It's garbage and it's toxic waste. What you should do and the Commission was to start over, start from scratch. And I will tell you, Commissioner, what the objectives of the economic governance programme of these two specifically were: to control debt. Is it more controlled? No! Increased. Control the deficit. Is it more controlled? No! That control also failed. Consolidate the European economy. Failed! There are more imbalances. Reduce spending. The only way to reduce spending was to destroy what remains of the welfare state. So it failed. Have more stability. Failed. Have more growth. Failed. A budget treaty that is a total failure, because it is permanent austerity.  Now the Commission is talking about flexibility, of allowing Member States to deduct in the deficit calculation the investment they can make. We always stand for it. You've always refused. And now they are presenting, now that our accounts are destroyed, now that the member states on the periphery do not have a cent to invest, because all the cents go to the interest on the debt, now you come with flexibility. Flexibility for who? Commissioner, any assessment has to be serious, and to be serious, it has to take into account the results, not blind goals. The results are simple: economic and social destruction of the European Union. Those are the results. Commissioner, do one very simple thing: tear it up. Tear. It's garbage. Start from scratch, please.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the Commission claims that the first years of experience with the updated framework have been rather successful and that they provide evidence that the reform of the fiscal rules has indeed played a role in achieving progress as regards fiscal consolidation. Frankly, we cannot share that view at all. It is of the utmost urgency that the Commission shifts the narrow current focus on a mechanical reduction of structural deficits towards a different perspective. Today, putting debt levels – both private and public – on a sustainable track by making massive budget cuts to basic welfare systems across Europe has dramatic social consequences and is damaging the European recovery. The current policy response has actually increased debt levels instead of reducing them. We see therefore the current framework as a self-defeating framework. Not only are the rules not serving its purpose but they are also bringing Europe towards its third recession. We are in urgent need of a genuine counter-cyclical approach. We have already shown how the rules cannot even be effectively implemented as they are designed. The discretionary flexibilities have now become the rule instead of the exception, as these ends are being systematically and inefficiently used after the social and economic damage has already been done.  It is also massively short-sighted of the Commission to claim there is no need to review the Macroeconomic Imbalances Procedure. The current procedure puts most of the burden on the deficit countries. We need to provide a more systematic approach. The Greens, therefore, are disappointed that the Commission considers the current economic governance framework a success and feels that there is currently no need for a revision. We believe that in order to achieve a genuine counter-cyclical approach, we need a legislative proposal that could codify, in a revised six-pack, a qualified treatment for investments generating large societal and environmental benefits. We also believe that there should be a particular treatment of the debt incurred for recapitalising the banking sector. Commissioner, the average debt in the euro area is 90% of GDP. However, around one-third of that debt finds its origin in support measures provided by Member States to the banking sector since 2008. This debt is unfair and unsustainable, and its treatment should be urgently revised. We also see a need for codifying in the legislation some key concepts, such as the conserved structural balance, which at the moment is totally discretionary. There are no clear rules about it. In Spain, for instance, the potential output – as estimated by the Commission – implies an unemployment rate of around 20%. We do not think such a rate reflects the potential of the economy. We would therefore advocate a more complete definition of the concept reflecting a wider theoretical background. We are also in favour of completing the scoreboard for macroeconomic imbalances by adding social indicators. In his hearing, Commissioner Moscovici committed himself to including those social indicators, so I would really like to see that implemented. On the application of the rules, I have to say that in recent days the Commission asked Spain, for instance, to further reduce its deficit by making additional cuts of EUR 4 billion. The country suffers from massive unemployment. Half of the unemployed do not receive any kind of support. Can the EU continue ignoring that reality when revising national budgets using its current rules? This is socially blind and economically suicidal. That is why, dear Commissioner, we, the Greens, believe that the legal revision is urgently needed in order to exit the current stagnation.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I wholly expected Mr Dombrovskisʼ speech to present a glorifying story of how the six-pack and the two-pack have helped lift Europe out of depression and Mr Dombrovskis, once again you did not fail to deliver. After all it is Christmas – Members of this House – and it is Christmas when parents tell all their children lots of fairy tales about what good there is in the world when we know there is bad outside, and in this Chamber once again you told us lots of fairy tales. Because, as you have heard from Members around this House, the main point of the six-pack is control. Control of government budgets; control of the decision-makers on spending; control of the peoples of Europe and their democratic, elected governments. Debt up, stability down, no growth, only poverty throughout Europe, and at Christmas that control, and the story of Christmas, should show you why Europe is going wrong. Because millions of Europeans will be celebrating Christmas by telling their children that Father Christmas will be delivering presents for them – and at Christmas, if the EU had control of Father Christmas, the story would be totally different.  First of all Father Christmas would not be allowed to drive more than 4.5 hours without having a 45-minute break under EU directives. It may well be that even Rudolph would have to be fitted with a tacograph; certainly under EU directives he would have to have a stamp of the EU flag on the backside. Under various animal directives it would be certain that he could not even use the reindeer and if there was not a directive, there would be calls from the Members of this Chamber for an intergroup to be set up on the protection and prevention of abuse of Santa’s reindeers. EU inspectors would ask whether Father Christmas had indeed complied with all the regulations.  Just as the EU would ruin Santa Claus, you have ruined the story of Christmas for millions of Europeans, their families and their children. (Applause)

name: Bernard MONOT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, after the Union has put in place fiscal and stability pacts, how effective is your economic and financial governance? The French patriots make the same observation as you and condemn the abysmal debt, the consequence of the privatization of public money by the world capital markets. This chronic over-indebtedness makes citizens future debt slaves. Tomorrow, our foreign creditors will demand even more social austerity, more privatization, fewer public services and less sovereignty, at the expense of domestic demand. See the economic and social tragedy you have caused in Greece and Cyprus with your structural reforms! Yes, each Member State, in order to remain free, must indeed reduce its deficits and its public debt, but economic efforts must focus on bad spending: the exorbitant cost of mass immigration, the cost of the permanent rescue of the euro - 17 billion euros a year for the past four years in France - the cost of social fraud, etc. Sovereign states need national instruments - control of borders, their currencies, their budgets, banks, national priority, etc. to return to balance in public accounts without austerity. Everything that your federalist Europe has confiscated precisely. It is by abandoning your imaginary world and thanks to our patriotic economic model that the Europe of nations will return to sound public finances, jobs and economic growth. The United Kingdom does not need the six-pack, nor the two-pack, to have a lower level of debt than France and above all economic growth of more than 3% this year. Mr Juncker is in the interest of strengthening the rules of budgetary rigour to rectify the excessive deficits of others, even though the EU has 30 billion euros in unpaid debts in 2014, a budget ratio of 20%. Ask Mr. Arthuis what he thinks!

name: Esther de LANGE
text: Mr President, thank you also to the Vice-President of the European Commission for his comments here this morning. He has already been criticised for the fact that the document we are talking about is short and factual. I would like to congratulate him on that, because I think his analysis is abundantly clear: either 'the rules of the six and two-pack have worked', or 'we have not had enough time to assess them in practice'. Then I say, 'if it ain't broke, don't fix it'. We drew up these regulations in the previous period when the euro was hanging above the precipice. I think this European Parliament should be proud that we had the courage to take these steps. Because if we had had the macroeconomic imbalances from the beginning, for example the procedure for macroeconomic imbalances – that is, by the way, about imbalances in Member States, let us be clear about this – we might have avoided the dramatic situations that we have seen in a number of Member States. But what I think is really the most important thing is that we can talk to each other at the moment about a text. That text is clear, but let us also take a look at the practice. The British say so beautifully – perhaps I should not quote the British in this debate, but the proverb is magnificent – 'the proof of the pudding is in the eating'. We can talk to each other about a text, but at the same time the rules we are discussing here are already stretched in practice, then we are already working to get the foundation under that healthy euro. So the EPP will also judge this Commission on whether it maintains the agreements that I believe we have made in the previous period with regard to a number of Member States. I won't name names, but we all know which country is the elephant in this meeting room. The proof of the pudding is in the eating. Not only talk about texts, but also shows in practice that you support them. We will assess the Commission on that. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, the two speakers of the European People's Party have told us about the need to respect the agreed rules and rules of economic governance. They seem to be missing out, however, that in European law, in addition to the rules of economic governance, there are also rules on rights – for example the Charter of Fundamental Rights – which are being violated through the supposed application of economic governance, which, instead of leading to debt sustainability, ends up increasing debt and increasingly violating social rights. So I ask you: Can we sacrifice social rights on the altar of so-called fiscal consolidation?

name: Esther de LANGE
text: "blue card" answer. – Yes, it took a while for the question to come up. It was more of an explanation. Let me, if he does not believe me, refer to Draghi's words. He says that if you want to be part of that euro, there are a number of agreements attached to it. Not because we want to be so mean or because we are figure fetishists, but because those rules are the anchor of trust in our entire economy and the foundation under that euro. So whoever says "A" has to say "B." If you want to be in the euro, you will have to stick to agreements. It's that simple. And of course you look at the implications of that. But whoever says "A" has to say B, too. One can't do without the other.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: Madam President, no, the European adjustment did not work. It has been six years since the crisis began, and the European Union is now contrasting with the other international blocs. The European economy is stagnant, in some areas it is in deflation, there are 25 million unemployed, there is unbearable public debt and internal imbalances are enormous. Politically, we're on the verge of collapse.  The anti-crisis engine predicted in the single currency was monetary policy, but it is exhausted. Interest rates are close to zero, and yet the economy does not react. And in this frightening situation, the European Commission, when it thinks about the economy for 2015, proposes a neutral, non-expansionist fiscal policy, only slows austerity.  In the face of this, I ask: in an area that no longer has exchange rate policy, monetary policy has been neutralized by the crisis, what would have more to happen for the Commission to propose a countercyclical fiscal policy? Jean-Claude Juncker's investment plan is clearly welcome, but unfortunately there is no artificial stimulus to compensate for the lack of economic activity. At the moment, looking at the six-pack, we see that what is provided for in the law is that the adjustment process can deviate from the trajectory in three circumstances: if there is a severe slowdown in the economy, if there is an external shock that does not depend on the will of the Member States, and if structural reforms are implemented to strengthen competitiveness. But real structural reforms, not short-term cuts. And I ask: has this been what the European Commission has applied? No. All adjustments to the timing of the adjustment of public accounts have been presented with a political concession. It's not a political concession, it's in the text of the law, and that's what we have to focus on, and that's what we have to change the agenda about. Because without economy and without a job, there are no balanced public accounts. And this is a truth that is clear from the outset, which has been followed in other economic blocs and which Europe refuses to accept, for the sake of an ideology which has already proven that it does not work. Please change the schedule.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Mr President, it is not easy to get derailed budgets back in order. For example, we are now seeing it in Belgium, where, for the first time in 25 years, the government is trying to put that budget in order with new recipes, a government that is cleaning up the budget and not raising taxes for that purpose. It is even more difficult to implement structural reforms, but they are still necessary if we are to grow our economy and we want to help people get jobs again. There is no confidence in the future. There's a lot of opposition. You have all noticed this also from the many strikes that are currently taking place in Belgium. Trust is the key word here. Without trust, no social peace. Without trust no investments. Without trust no growth and no jobs. But that trust will only come when we keep course, when we implement what is agreed, effectively. A $300 billion investment plan may sound like a nice one, but we might as well throw that money away if we don't reform at the same time and eliminate the deficits. That is why I fear that the European Commission is too positive in its evaluation of the two-pack and the six-pack. Yes, deficits have fallen, but at the same time – as Mr Lucke also pointed out – the euro area debt ratio has increased and new debt is undermining that confidence that is so desperately needed. So relaxing the rules is a luxury that we unfortunately cannot afford. We must continue to reform, we must continue, we must keep our course because that is what is needed to secure the future of our children.

name: Michael THEURER
text: Madam President, dear colleagues! On average, the indebtedness of the member states was too high even before the introduction of the euro. Even before the economic and financial crisis, it was too high. It is still too high now. It is therefore strange that some Members of this House are demanding more debt in order to combat excessive old debts. This cannot be the right way to go, but we must get out of the debt trap, and that can only be done through structural reforms. Anyone who introduces a common currency also needs institutions to assert the Community interest. This is exactly what two-pack and six-pack have done to tighten up the Stability and Growth Pact, which, incidentally, was first broken by Gerhard Schroeder and the red-green federal government in Germany and by the French government. Those who do not abstheise the rules undermine the stability of a common currency. The crucial moment is that we enforce the rules and here, Commissioner Dombrovskis, we have hopes for you. In Latvia, they have shown how structural reforms can put a country back on a growth path. Moreover, the countries of Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain have also made great efforts, and the population has tightened its belt. Meanwhile, a light can be seen at the end of the tunnel. Countries have returned to a growth trajectory. The crucial question now is: what are the countries of Italy and France doing? Here, the Commission must ensure that the rules also apply to the large countries and not just to the small ones, that they are applied together, and we want to insist on this. And we expect you, Commissioner Dombrovskis, to enforce this with the Commission. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Would you agree with me that when you think of a six-pack, you think of someone like Cristiano Ronaldo? It is a very athletic thing. But when I think of the EU, it is not really a six-pack. Instead I look at this tired, old, flabby, slow, useless thing which is very much like what I might see when I get up in the morning. It is certainly not Ronaldo – nowhere near it. Would you agree that is a fair assessment of the EU and its physique?

name: Michael THEURER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Whether or not the term Sixpack is now a wise name remains to be seen. But one thing is quite clear: what strikes me in the European Union is that we do not believe in ourselves. When we talk to people in other countries of the world, in India or in the Pacific Asian region, they point to us and say, "What do you have in Europe? You have infrastructure, you have excellent universities, you have a great health care system. If you can't get back on the growth path, who will?" What bothers me is that we are discussing the currency. The euro is neither the cause nor the solution to the problems. We need to get into the real economy, we need technology, we need innovation, we need growth. Then it's like a six-pack with a well-trained athlete.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: My fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. I understand that this is a very important issue. I also feel your responsibility, but this is a long debate. And please accept from me that I will give you one blue card per Member. So I am no longer giving my fellow Members who later indicated their blue card claim an opportunity.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: Madam President, for us, economic governance, with the six-pack and the two-pack and the Budgetary Treaty, is another mechanism set up to align the Member States with the interests of the large companies that actually rule this Europe. It is the objective reality that points us to the classy nature of this European integration. Austerity, budgetary rigour, so-called structural reforms only serve the same as always, which feed on the crisis and the exploitation of those who work.  I have three questions. Firstly, how do you explain that the overwhelming majority of Member States, 24 out of 28, have been illegal in the face of those rules which seem completely unsuitable to us?  Secondly, the Commission says that there is progress. Overall, debt and deficit are falling. If so, why are we still in the crisis and with no prospect of getting out of it? Thirdly, how do you explain that, throughout this crisis, member states outside the euro have outperformed the euro area? In other words, countries that have chosen to maintain their monetary sovereignty grow more and owe less.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Commissioner! You have presented a review of the rules that we have reformed here. It was a very controversial legislative package at the time.  Your review paints the situation in pastel. In fact, the rules that we have adopted here are not such that you would dare to apply them in a really consistent manner and even to establish transparency as to whether these rules are currently being applied. If we look at whether the structural deficits of the euro countries have really fallen as agreed at European level, we have to note that out of 18 countries, 14 have not been able to fulfil their remedial measures, which were actually agreed. But now some colleagues are presenting – as if this problem does not exist at all – that the rules must only be applied harshly. If they did, they would lead Europe into recession. That is why it is right that you have given a little more space. At the same time, however, you cannot stand up and say that the rules are all fine.  Secondly, there are colleagues who say that we need to return these more complex rules to simple, simple rules, which are then simple and harsh. But they are pro-cyclical. That is why the answer to the problems of implementing the tightened Stability and Growth Pact rules is a common economic policy in the euro area, in other words an end to tax competition, and also a very clear common fiscal policy, where the states that are stronger economically invest more so that others have more room to rehabilitate their budgets.  But what does the Council of The Member States do? The Council of The Member States is not carrying out this common economic policy, but is leaving Mr Draghi in the rain at the ECB. He is trying to stabilise the eurozone with further measures and what I am accusing you of, Commissioner, is – not that you could simply change that, with the Investment Pact you are going in the right direction – but that you do not clearly mention all these problems by name and place responsibility where it belongs, namely to the Council, which is not prepared to make the necessary common policy in Europe. , which we need for the euro. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Giegold, you said that the simple rules are pro-cyclical. If we have a state that has a balanced budget, it can increase new debt by 3% according to the simple rules. With a government ratio of around 20%, this means that government spending can be increased by about 15%. What is pro-cyclical about this? Under these rules, there is precisely the possibility of making expansionary fiscal policy.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Lucke, I would like to thank Mr Lucke for his The problem was not the situation when the economy was not running. Indeed, the euro countries have always complied with or even surpassed this 3%. The problem was that we didn't have rules that made sure that the debt-to-GDP ratio was reduced when it ran. In this respect, the old rules, with the 3% and 60% that you have advocated here, were precisely primitive, simple and sham solutions, because they did not contain any obligations during the good phases. Therefore, frankly, your execution was too easy, and your refocusing only on the bad phase was just as one-sided.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, at the moment I am speaking on behalf of the 21% of Italians who went to vote at the last European elections. These people, oppressed by the crisis and taxes, gave me the vote to come here and tell you that we no longer want the Stability Pact, that we no longer want budgetary constraints and that we do not want the Accountants of the Commission and on behalf of the markets to govern the choices on the fiscal policies of the Member States. People would like a policy that can look an excessive spread, speculation, business banks, hedge funds and tell them, "I'm sorry, but here we make the rules and not you." The well-being of the majority of citizens with these taxations comes after the interests of speculators, and we cannot accept that. The Stability and Growth Pact is utopian. Stability in high-debt countries we have seen as leading only to poverty, unemployment and selling off by sovereign states of ownership and rights towards an abstract entity called the market and representing the interests of 1% of the population. The remaining 99% are disillusioned and no longer believe in politics. So much so that he largely no longer goes to vote and lives in a system he despises. The only thing we can do good and right with the Stability Pact, the six pack, the two pack and above all the Fiscal Compact is this (the speaker tears up a piece of paper) and since you do not have the moral and intellectual honesty to do so, really as the Luxleaks case and other paradoxes have shown, and that time has now run out. , in Italy we will lead the Italians to vote for our referendum on the euro and this will be an opportunity to expose the many hidden truths about democracy bypassed by the financial dictatorship, giving the real opportunity to rebel, showing who is to blame for the crisis, who brought our country into the single currency, rigging the accounts and who stole the public management of the money , bringing it from the sovereign right of a nation of peoples to the sovereign right of the market and private banks and speculation, by financializing the system. Look me in the eye when I tell you! We represent those people who will never give up on being slaves to finance, debt and above all technocracy.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Dear Congressman Valli, You have used harsh words, which is worth considering first and foremost, before you reconsidere your next speech, and as Mr. Congressman knows, the voice is spreading in all directions, and it is not necessary for the Commissioner to turn 180 degrees just to be able to look at you.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, more gains for fewer and stronger, greater, permanent unemployment and poverty for more, with tools the Stability Pact, the European Semesters, the "diptychs" and "six-fold" measures, the EU 2020 Strategy. It's not a mistake or a temporary necessity. It is the raison d'ê being of the European Union. You need unemployment and flexible working for low wages. Wages crumbs for profits you subsidize with new funds, savage taxes, theft and demolition of social security. You need profits, because competitiveness without them does not exist. You are reviewing so-called economic governance for faster and more effective enforcement of unpopular measures, iron supervision and discipline, lasting memoranda for all states. Tighten the noose on the peoples, to move the economic machine that still does not start, despite the popular sacrifices and the billions you feed it. The crisis is in the matrix of your system. You know you don't change. And those who say they're going to transform you from slaughterhouse to paradise are shamelessly lying. Folks need to know. These are the powerful and not the monopolies, the European Union, its governments and parties sitting on their necks. So no fear, no waiting. Before they take the last bite, attack now for a way out that serves popular interests.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, your comments confirm this: the problem is not to revise the rules that were put in place at the height of the crisis to clean up economic and budgetary policies in the Union, but rather to apply these rules, to apply them fully in the letter as in spirit. It is a matter of credibility: the credibility of the Union and in particular the governance of the euro area, which has set even more ambitious objectives in this area, with the budgetary pact, and the credibility, Mr Vice-President, of the new Commission. Following my epp colleagues, and in particular Mr TheUrer, I would like to warn here that the rules must apply equally in all Member States, regardless of their size. I would remind you that the need for new legislation - six-pack and two-pack - was to be adopted because the original rules - the Stability and Growth Pact - were not implemented. In 2003, it turned out that the two largest economic powers in the Union - Germany and France - have, at the same time, come out of the way. They asked - and obtained without great difficulty - flexibility and interpretation of the rules that emptied them of their content. The conclusion reached is that the Union could not function on the basis of an unspoken principle which, for States, is not too big to fail but somehow too big to be blamed - too big to be punished. If we do it again today, if the Commission is inflexible in the face of Greece and Portugal, but trembles with the countries we say are bigger than Spain, then the whole system will collapse. In the end, we will inexorably fall back into the situation we wanted to avoid at all costs, the situation in which financial operators and rating agencies decide the fate of our economies instead of politicians. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: the blue card. – In fact, the situation is quite different in individual countries, but I would like to ask you this question: should the principle that, first of all, in the context of the recovery of the economy, the recovery of the budget, social benefits, salaries, refunds, and only then new programmes, before new programmes are implemented?

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: "blue card" answer. Mr. Ropé, you assume that the problem is already solved. When, unfortunately, a country has lived for many years beyond its means and has been forced to seek the help of its partners, the first thing it must do is put its situation and public finances in order, with the help of its partners. Only then, once wealth can be created again, it becomes possible, at that time, to redistribute purchasing power.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: Madam President, my response to the Commissioner is to say: Yes, the new economic governance framework has solved some problems but has also created other problems. Europe is now trapped in a kind of stagnation: high unemployment, high debt, also the risk of deflation; and second, Europe is divided by big economic social divergences which are also becoming political divergences. The Commission has recognised the situation in the recent Annual Growth Survey, but now the Commission should address these problems by adjusting this economic governance framework. I believe that the first adjustment is to create more room for manoeuvre for investments in the Stability and Growth Pact and, first of all, to make sure that Member States’ contributions to these new funds for strategic investment are neutralised with regard to the Stability and Growth Pact. Secondly, we need to have a more balanced macroeconomic surveillance looking not only at the economic problems but at the social problems. Finally, Mr Vice-President, frankly I do not believe there is a real solution to bring down these divergences we have in the eurozone if we are not able to move ahead with this agenda to complete economic and monetary union. This is about finishing the banking union but also about bringing up a real fiscal capacity in the eurozone. So this is also a task for you, Mr Vice-President. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Do you not agree with me that the European nations outside the euro are doing relatively well, whereas those within the euro are not? The euro is a political currency created by the Commission for its own political ends, and until the euro is removed and ditched, there is no chance of the people of southern Europe ever recovering. I recommend to the whole House that the Commission admit its mistake with the euro and ditch the currency. The lady over there has said it before: it is absolutely obvious that this is the problem.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Coburn, I really believe there is a problem – but the problem is not with the euro. I think the euro can be a major force in the European Member States. The problem is with the organisation of the economy and monetary union, which is unbalanced. This is clearly identified now, and that is why we need to complete the banking union to have a proper economic coordination with surplus countries and deficit countries pushing for growth. We also need to build up fiscal capacity. This is what is missing now.

name: Ashley FOX
text: Madam President, every debate on economic governance I attend makes me more grateful that the United Kingdom is not part of the euro. In my view it is profoundly undemocratic for the Commission to tell Member States what they should tax and what they should spend. But that is the consequence of entering into a single currency. And it is increasingly clear that the euro single currency is not working for the very diverse economies within its borders. As a result, millions of young people across the EU are not working either. Youth unemployment is 40 % in Italy, 55 % in Spain, 58 % in Greece. That is a tragedy for millions of families. The Stability and Growth Pact is right to control spending and borrowing in euro area countries, but it needs to be accompanied by an appropriate monetary policy and this is impossible for the ECB to achieve. Whatever the Commission might say about economic governance it does not acknowledge the fundamental flaw that exists in the construction of the euro. A single interest rate is never going to be appropriate for all members of the euro area. And I would say to Mr Dombrovskis, if you want the euro area to flourish you and the Commission are going to have to bring up the subject of fiscal transfers, because you cannot have a situation where you fix the interest rate, you fix the rate of exchange for all the euro area members, and you then tell governments in Greece and Italy what they can spend and tax, without transferring money from rich euro area members to poorer ones – and that is something you are too afraid to address. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr Fox, I accept that you criticise and say that something is not good, but I do not understand the contradiction in which you find yourself: you contradict the need for monetary unity, at the same time you are part of the European Union. What would be the solution for you? Because to criticize is simple. Don't come up with solutions. Since I started the session, your group just does this. You are in the European Union, we need monetary unity for good governance.

name: Ashley FOX
text: blue-card answer. – I think that monetary union between a small number of Member States who had converged economies – for example Germany, the Netherlands, Austria and Finland – could have been a success. The problem is that the euro was set up as a political project instead of as an economic project. If it is going to work, then you either have to let those states that cannot keep up with the Deutschmark, such as Cyprus and Greece, go in an organised manner, or rich countries are going to have to pay them very large sums of money, as happens in the United States. It is one or the other. Mr Dombrovskis does not wish to discuss either of those two solutions.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: Madam President, I think that it is too early to judge whether the two-pack and the six-pack need revision. I would remind you that it is only two years since we were negotiating the final details of the two-pack. In my view a clear target for revision is how we count public debt. Should we also include debt from public enterprises? I think we should, and this will be one of the main ideas in our future debates.  Talking about the revision of economic governance in Europe, we have also to consider regional and local governments with fiscal and legislative powers. The deficit targets for those administrations have to be proportional to their share of government spending. Only in this way will we ensure that there is no discrimination between different levels of government. This is especially important in countries where most social spending is done at regional level but tax-collection powers are still monopolised by the central government.  I also have the feeling that maybe Europe should look more at the United States of America – at how the federal USA was built and how they created a monetary and fiscal union. I ask myself whether the no-bailout clause should be analysed in our future framework for economic governance.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Madam President, when the crisis began, the Commission hastened to blame it for the lack of rigour in the compliance with the stability rules by the Member States. It forgot that Germany had been among those states in breach of budgetary stability rules and that among the complying States, with low deficits and low public debt – that is, with an already precarious labour market – was Spain, which today, because of its policies, has 25% unemployment and the second highest external debt in the world. These are the consequences of their governance. Therefore, the evaluation can only be negative. European workers don't want any more reforms, less social protection, more evictions, more poverty. We do not want this governance, which is also reviving fascism in Europe. The Commission's role must be to achieve the productive and social convergence of european peoples and not to be complicit in markets and the emptying of democracy.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I want to say at the outset that the Greens are convinced that in order to face the challenges of the 21st century, Europeans must stand together and act together. This includes, to strengthen us, a common currency. We believe that this common currency should be kept and the question is therefore: are the instruments we have today to ensure the cohesion of economic and monetary union appropriate and are they being used correctly? In terms of the nature of the instruments we have, it is clear that when we have a pay budget discipline and a revenue competition, the only adjustment variable is spending. Having maintained budgetary discipline, as defined today, without tax harmonisation will lead us to a perpetual reduction of the role of public authorities in society. We do not think this is a good thing, so fiscal discipline must be complemented by fiscal convergence and, also, by setting binding social and environmental targets. When you are required, as a government, to balance your budgets but also to reduce poverty and your ecological footprint, this leads you to make budgetary adjustments of a nature other than those we are seeing today. Triple discipline, therefore: social, environmental and budgetary. Finally, the semester is widely used today to encourage structural reforms aimed at reducing, on the one hand, the role of the state, I have mentioned, and, on the other hand, the direct and indirect costs of labour, by putting workers in competition with each other. We believe that the semester should instead be used as an instrument of cooperation between Member States to enable convergence towards the highest level of our social, environmental and democratic standards. This is what needs to be done if we are to review the European Union's economic governance package, which for us is a necessary but now inappropriate and misused instrument.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: Madam President, modifying the terms of economic coordination across Europe is just another attempt to save the Currency That Does Not Work. The structural reform that we hear so much about often just means pay cuts and less stable employment. It will not save the Currency That Does Not Work, because Greece can never be Germany and Italy is not the Netherlands. Emperor Nero famously fiddled while Rome burned. Rome is not burning today, and that is a tribute to the stoicism of the Italian people, but the Currency That Does Not Work is putting the social fabric across southern Europe under very great strain – not only in Italy. The talent of the people is the biggest resource that we have, and therefore unemployment is the biggest waste. Yet the Currency That Does Not Work leads to people who have no work.  Many across this Chamber who belong to groups and institutions that still pay lip service to the Currency That Does Not Work know, in their heart of hearts, that I am speaking the truth. It is time for you to speak up, for you to put the interests of the people before the grand and flawed ideology of ever-closer European integration. Those of you who are economically literate and knowledgeable know these things. You have been too quiet for too long, and now is the time for you to show some courage. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: blue-card question. – Mr O’Flynn, I would agree with you and many others who say that the current status quo is not economically viable. Having a common currency without common fiscal, social and environmental policy is not working. But there are two answers to that inconsistency: either we step back to the disintegration of the monetary and economic union into nation states, which is what you advocate, or we resolve it the other way by more integration on the social and fiscal side, which is what we advocate. How do you react to that?

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: blue-card answer. – I think you are speaking the truth there. It is one or the other. But I would point out to you that the social solidarity levels needed across the nation states do not exist. I remember German reunification; West German people moaned a bit about the cost of reunifying, but, because they were reunifying with fellow Germans, they bore that cost and were happy to do so. The Germans will not pay indefinitely for the Greek people or other people in southern Europe. If the social solidarity were there, that would be the right answer, but it rests with nation states across our great continent.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President! I asked Commissioner Moscovici in the ECON Committee during the debate on Twopack and Sixpack about how seriously he takes compliance with the rules of economic governance, in particular compliance with the Stability Pact and the resulting sanctions, given that the sanctions are now automatic. He said he would take this very seriously, then re-energised the media and said that he would wait until March next year to find a solution for France, Italy and Belgium, which are now considered problematic in the area of convergence criteria. For me, this is a contradiction in itself. This is not a serious matter, and I wonder: what are the use of complex rules of economic governance, what is the use of a stability pact, what is the use of a two-pack and a six-pack, what is the use of us rules that are not respected and whose compliance is subsequently not sanctioned? What will happen by March next year? The French Minister for Economic Affairs has already shown us that he will unleash the French economy. It will bring a package for more growth. He will unleash the liberal professions, he will privatise, he will sell state participation, etc.  Economists doubt it's all too small, it's not a big deal, it's not going to lead to growth. Italy had a general strike last weekend – citizens took to the streets against labour market reforms and budget laws. I say to you that the best economic governance measures do not benefit us if they are not complied with and if compliance with them is not sanctioned.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: Madam President, dear Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, today it is time to evaluate the 'Two-Pack' and the 'Six-Pack' here. I think the positive results are evident. Looking at the situation of eurozone countries, significant progress has been made in fiscal consolidation processes and progress has been made in reform processes. Most countries have undertaken or started undertaking important reform processes. In addition, it has been shown that those countries that are most ambitious in their fiscal consolidation processes and those countries most ambitious in their reform programmes are today the countries that grow the most and are today the countries that create the most jobs. But it's not enough, ladies and gentlemen. We have to keep moving forward. We need to be more forceful with those countries that do not comply, because the non-compliances of these countries affect the rest of the eurozone countries. But moreover, as the Vice-President has said, it is necessary to give this whole process greater transparency, it is necessary to give this whole process greater democratic legitimacy. Because at a time when progress needs to be made on the long-awaited and necessary economic union — ultimately political union — is when European citizens, and especially the citizens of the euro area, feel further removed from Europe. And I have no doubt that the lack of democratic legitimacy of this process has anything to do with it. It is therefore time to move towards greater democratic legitimacy of both the Two-Pack and the Six-Pack.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, when the crisis erupted in 2009, the black hole in the political side of monetary union was unveiled with the cruelty of urgency. We then introduced all these concepts that the European novlangue loves: the troika, the European semester ... But behind these words lies a policy: austerity for the greatest number and the largesse in the allocation of public funds for banks. Six years after the crisis, it is time to take stock and, if we look the truth in the face, it is a failure. The Union's macroeconomic choices have been the instruments of a devastating austerity policy, and even more so, Mr Lamassoure - he has left - where these rules have been applied. The euro area is still in crisis: Europe has seven million more unemployed, a third more than at the beginning of the crisis, the debts of the states have not been reduced, the investment deficit is estimated at 300 billion euros per year and deflation is lurking in the Union. But, above all, the gap between the Member States is widening, which is a paradox of the rules of convergence, which actually lead to divergence. Today, we are in a ubuesque situation, characterized by extremely low interest rates, a large and available amount of liquidity, and a private investment deficit that wipes out potential growth. And you want to maintain that governance framework that prevents Member States from reviving their economies! And you are stubborn, Mrs van Nieuwenhuizen, to keep countries in crisis with their heads under water. However, Jean-Claude Juncker seems to have understood this urgency by proposing, at the heart of his investment plan, flexibility in the assessment of the public deficit, especially for the contribution of the Member States. But it is now essential to radically reform European governance tools, to prioritise investment, to integrate social criteria, particularly that of employment, and to move towards fiscal convergence. Of course, macroeconomic rules are required and the rules are obviously made to be respected, provided they are effective. In this case, however, the rules of convergence, stability and growth have so far only led to divergence, recession and chaos tomorrow.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Madam President, and Commissioner Dombrovskis in particular, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work on this They really impressed me today. You have accounted here for all the packs we have, the two-pack, the six-pack, the fiscal pact and all the pacts. You have listed the successes that these measures have achieved so far. I have written down all the successes on this white sheet of paper. It's completely empty. You have come to mark the successes of four years of measures, without giving a single figure! You did not give a number! You are not standing here today in front of 100 Members, but in principle in front of 500 million citizens of the European Union, and you say that these are your successes. I think that is extraordinarily thin and little. The rest, the vast majority of this House, is calling for the rules to be respected. The rules must be respected. Mr Theurer, a colleague from the FDP, has just called for the abolition of tax competition – an extraordinarily liberal approach, Mr Theurer. All the measures that are being taken here fail. And if you have the opportunity to say what the successes are, present us with a blank sheet of paper. We are on the wrong track!

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: Mr President, what I am missing in the debate is a feeling that this is important to us. People are talking about the Member States that are not doing their jobs. We are talking about the Commission dropping the rules. People are talking about more flexibility. In fact, we should think it is normal for Member States to have their budgets in balance, for Member States to do everything possible to modernise their economies, to keep their social system up-to-date, so that future generations can also enjoy adequate pensions and social protection. But apparently that's not normal. Apparently we need a six-pack and a two-pack to make this clear. That is precisely the essence. We must do everything, together here, to strengthen the six-pack and two-pack and to increase its democratic legitimacy. Because we cannot get around one truth: we will have to balance our budgets, we will have to implement reforms to make our economies more competitive than today. This failure – which has been done in the past by several Member States – is actually unjust and puts our future generations at risk. That is precisely what is at stake here, namely what the Commission will have to do in the coming months and weeks to strengthen that six-pack and two-pack so that those countries effectively balance their budgets and make further progress in terms of growth and job creation.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: Madam President, there is a black rapper named Tupac - I don't know if they know him - and he said something that comes to the case: "To pull the trigger to kill a black man is to be a hero: a hungry mouth less for social assistance. First send them drugs, let them hand it out to their brothers, give them guns and let them kill themselves." It seems that, like black people in the United States, it is not difficult to condemn the countries of the South and European workers. The fiscal pact, the Stability and Growth Pact, is like the leech that the old doctor used as a wrong remedy in the face of circumstantial doom and, moreover, has become the universal method that drags Europe into the disaster of austerity, not to mention the threat of economic punishment to which he comes up with something different: again to suck people's blood. This European Union, which has been endowed with rules which, being agreed between the few and behind almost everyone, are now presented as something written in stone, is nothing more than a pretext for legalizing something that is no longer legitimate or effective in dealing with the crisis and its causes. That is why—and finally—I invite you to look in the mirror, lese it is not that your reflection of him has disappeared.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not believe that a simple review of economic governance is sufficient to raise the deep crisis in our continent and the cause of the recession of recent years is precisely the European regulations that have strangled every possibility of development. The six pack and the two pack are the tragic completion of a path taken since 1997 with the application of the Stability and Growth Pact, a name that unfortunately today sounds like a mockery, since stability has become a precarious downward balance and we have seen no trace of growth. I invite my fellow Members to take a few hours during the Christmas holidays to read the essay by an Italian professor and former minister, Giuseppe Guarino, which we delivered to everyone last week in Brussels. With specific arguments and the concrete facts mentioned therein, you will be able to understand how all these successive regulations are in fact contrary to the objectives enshrined in the European Treaties: objectives of development and development sacrificed to budgetary rigour and constraints. Let us therefore start from the spirit of the Treaties and then eliminate all the absurd demands that are being slaughtered.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, for the past five years the public debt crisis has plagued countries in Europe and especially in the South. On the one hand, the European Union has failed to deal with the crisis at an early stage and has demonstrated in its position that double standards apply within the union framework. So there are countries that accuse other countries of irresponsibility, countries that oversee others and that require them to have iron budgetary discipline by catalysing all notions of national sovereignty and democracy. All economic governance measures, in particular the two-fold and six-fold package, are aimed at an enhanced surveillance process, in a perpetual economic prison where everything depends on numbers and statistics to the detriment of the citizens of the countries. I assure you that it is absolutely foolish to try to convince our people that everything is for their own good. The Greek people, like the peoples of Italy, Spain, Portugal and soon others, cannot be plunged into economic impoverishment because you are subject to the demands of financial institutions and banking interests. Finally, let what we promise be put into practice: sustainable development, social prosperity, the fight against unemployment; as a Europe of peoples and not of economic sizes.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. First of all, I wanted to say at the outset that I believe that a system of fiscal discipline is absolutely necessary within a monetary union in which countries retain their fiscal powers and, at the same time, there is no system of fiscal transfers. We must therefore develop a system of discipline based on transparent rules. I would like to remind you that the crisis in Europe occurred not because the euro was introduced, but because some countries or some banking systems in some countries were simply indebted beyond measure. On the other hand, there was no obligation to be indebted anywhere. At the same time, I would like to say that three years of experience with the six-pack and the two-pack show that some adaptation of these instruments is necessary. Firstly, I would like to draw attention to the fact that this is a system that is too complex and complex – not for experts, but for the public. This type of system opens the door to different interpretations; i will give an example of endless discussions about the degree of flexibility within the fiscal rules. The system must therefore be simplified to make it more understandable to ordinary people as well.  Secondly, the system is too much based on policy decisions. This concerns not only the political mechanism for introducing the excessive deficit procedure, but also the discussion of whether to extend the deadlines for the submission of relevant documents for certain countries, i.e. the largest countries. I believe that if we have legal rules, they should not then be the subject of a political vote.  Thirdly, I would also like to stress that the most important thing is national ownership - national ownership. We must not allow politicians to point to Brussels all the time and say: it is Brussels that is forcing us to impose some kind of fiscal discipline. No, fiscal discipline must be enshrined in national law, in a consistent manner for the entire European Union, and then politicians will have a duty to implement national laws and regulations.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, if the provisions of the two pack and six pack were designed to contain debt and promote growth and if the situation is so bad in all respects today, I ask you, what has yet to happen to understand that something is wrong? We do not want to trample on the rules – I say this to all concerned colleagues – but we want them to be the useful and functional ones to achieve this objective. We want intelligent flexibility, that is, useful flexibility, with good investment, good spending, useful for increasing GDP. Flexibility is not the opposite of credibility, as some authoritative people have said in recent days. If anything, it is the opposite of the obtuse, obsessive and counterproductive rigidity that has led to this.  The application must be sensitive, flexible. If it is only automatic and accounting, then let us govern ourselves from a computer not from a Political Commission. That is why I say to you, also on behalf of the 40% of Italians who voted in the last Italian elections, that we will ask for flexibility, not only for the Juncker Plan but also for the cofinancing of projects approved by the European Union under the 2020 Agenda not out of that context. No more obsessive ideology that neglects other instruments, fiscal policies, growth policies and that is enough to attack Italy. Someone asked what Italy is doing. I answer what he does. Italy is making reforms, Italy is complying with the rules. But he wants an intelligent economic policy that helps achieve the goal. We do not want favouritism but an intelligent, rigorous and forward-looking policy.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, the review of the six-pack and two-pack comes at a politically sensitive time. At a time when the European elite wants us to believe that the economic crisis is coming to an end and has come to a halt, we see that two fundamental problems are still there. 1) France, Italy and Belgium are structurally out of their public finances. Unfortunately, the enforcement of the agreed criteria is postponed for political reasons. This inaccuracy further undermines the credibility of the euro area administration. 2) There are still countries in the euro area and in the currency union that do not actually fit into it. For example, the recent attempt by Mr Samaras and Mr Venizelos to call early elections shows that a country like Greece would be better off outside the euro area. Then the country with its own currency can devalue and, in combination with a partial debt write-off, can really build hope for the future. The country's current debt burden in the eurozone outweighs the sky vault that titan's son Atlas had to bear. I fear that the political elite here is not listening to my advice. As a result, we will be muddling through for many years with very high unemployment and that European economies outside the euro area will perform much better, as they do now.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul The purpose of the so-called two-pack and the six-pack was to stabilise our economic and financial system. And the reasons for these compulsions were also obvious. The countries of Europe had almost systematically lived above their means when the 30 happy years after the Second World War came to an end. Politicians in all countries joined in the hope that the happy time would come back. It did not, and instead it was in debt and created a debt burden that would in the long run be unsustainable.  At the same time, there was technological development and globalisation that, in the historically extremely short time, gave the banks and the financial world an advantage that Rudolf Hilferding, when he wrote the book Das Finanzkapital in 1910, could hardly have had a clue. The issue that we are all now struggling with in one way or another is how to move forward.

name: Georgios KATROUGKALOS
text: Mr President, I would say this to the Commissioner: the Commission itself admitted some weaknesses in the legislative package, such as limited transparency. One could easily add the hijacking of economic governance by informal groups without accountability, such as the Eurogroup; the total eclipse of both national parliaments’ and the European Parliament’s definition of fiscal reforms; and many others. All these aspects are important, as they clearly show a system which undermines the budgetary sovereignty of Member States without subjecting it to a new democratic process. There is, however, a more dramatic and crucial flaw in the new rules. Instead of recognising that austerity is counterproductive, they have imposed additional fiscal constraints which will exacerbate economic stagnation, a rise in unemployment and a permanent division of the EU into creditor and debtor countries. It is up to the European peoples to reverse this downward spiral and to reinstitute the European social model, and in the forthcoming elections it may be the Greek people who will be the first.

name: Petr MACH
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the Commission says it now has better rules. But there's one problem, no one's following the rules. Consider France, there is a deficit of over 4% of gross domestic product in France, and you pretend that it does not exist.
