And when someone tries to follow your rules, it's at the cost of stopping economic growth and the cost of rising unemployment. You are trying to treat one bad political decision – the introduction of the euro single currency – by dictating strict budgetary rules. It can't work. I therefore call on the European Commission: prepare an amendment to the Treaty on European Union so that it can be legally exited from the euro area. You know that parties that do not want the euro are winning in Greece, Italy and elsewhere. Then Italy, Greece, will be able to leave the eurozone, the Czech Republic will not have to enter. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, mr Member, do you not recognise that the difficulty lies in the fact that some of these rules are pro-cyclical in nature and that it is therefore right to allow the States in difficulty to adjust, and that it is in the interest of everyone, including those who are in surplus situations? What are your responses, and what are you following, to Mr Draghi's speeches, which call on us to mobilise aggregate demand within the euro area?

name: Petr MACH
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – If the European Central Bank says it wants to stimulate the economy, it always means that it wants to abuse the monopoly in monetary policy, that it wants to do inflation, and that it wants to solve problems at the expense of all people who use money. I think that rather than trying to solve problems through the central bank, it is really better to let countries that do not like the euro leave the euro zone.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I thought I would see Commissioner Moscovici, who cannot be said to have done much when he was Minister of the Economy in France, to reduce the deficit, but I am told that he admires the Greek statuette in the Parthenon Museum in Athens. When he returns to this parliament, he will be able to measure the decadence of European civilization, looking at the hideous paintings that are displayed in the corridor, including those that degrade the image of Christ and his mother. But back if you will - to the more prosaic questions! The six-pack and the two-pack are a system of binding texts, which put the budgetary policies of the Member States under the commission's tutelage. Several speakers stressed the complexity and failure of this system, which needs to be reformed or, better, abolished. But in any event, this will allow the provisions that States have had the imprudence - to say the least - to ratify to ratify, and I am thinking in particular of the famous TSCG, the treaty on stability, coordination and governance. Of course, we have heard Mr Juncker's statements that these provisions can be applied flexibly, with the aim - I think - of calming the protests of parliaments and, even more, of the peoples of Europe. Because the results are known: it is the destruction of pension schemes, the all-out social regression and the destruction of the productive apparatus. I have heard Mr Lamberts, who wants coordination to be done upwards, but there is no point, ladies and gentlemen, in making it up in Europe if Europe is open to all the winds of unbridled competition.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: Mr President, we have a system of economic governance in the European Union that works. For now, the problem is not the construction of the system, but, on the contrary, the problems that have arisen in the implementation of this governance system. Firstly, national parliaments in some Member States are not drawn into this process with regard to the finalisation of draft national reform programmes, convergence or stability programmes which are transmitted by governments to the European Commission. Secondly, although some Member States agree with the recommendations made on the necessary economic and budgetary policy changes, they do not take the necessary measures to implement these recommendations. Finally, there are public statements on the insufficient flexibility contained in the two packages, six and two. I believe that the economic governance system in the European Union is not the real problem, but the loss of competitiveness in some Member States and the lack of firm determination on the policies needed to stimulate productivity and competitiveness through investment, efficient allocation of resources and continuous progress of technologies. (The speaker agreed to answer a question from the removal of the blue card in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Regulation).

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Blue card question. I wanted to ask my colleague whether he really believes that eurozone economic governance works when at the end of 2013 only 4 out of 17 countries met the criteria of the Stability and Growth Pact. I think that, rather than speaking by hear, it would be appropriate to go and look at the numbers and statistics from time to time.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: Answer to a question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Thank you for asking. When you're stuck in public debt, when you've lost competitiveness, you only have one solution: to restructure. For this you need solidarity, in the sense that the other partners agree to give you some time to take the necessary reforms and do the right thing in that country.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: Mr President, the fiscal crisis of the spring of 2010 made clear the economic problems of the Union, which needed better economic governance. From this came the "Six-Pack" and the "Two-Pack", which we are discussing today and which aim to control the fiscal policy of countries. However, it was not until the financial crisis of the first half of 2012 that Europe assumed that its economic problems were even more serious and that it essentially needed to have a common economic policy, a project from which the banking union emerged. But this path has only just begun. We need a strong fiscal union and I would therefore like to denounce that these fiscal rules which we are discussing today maintain an exclusively national approach to budgetary policy. We cannot analyse each country's fiscal policy by studying only the effect of its budgets on that Member State. We need Europe to internalize the effects of fiscal policy across the Union, not just in each of the countries. We must therefore review these fiscal rules and the whole coordination of the Union's economic policy in order to take account of this comprehensive approach to national economic policies. And we also need to reform the Stability and Growth Pact, not only to give the system more flexibility but, essentially, to incorporate this European analysis, in order to incorporate this comprehensive approach to the effects of each country's budgetary policies on the Union as a whole. Mr Dombrovskis, we cannot say that the current system is working. The results don't support it. We need more flexibility and a European fiscal policy project.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Mr. President! The six-pack has been in force since December 2011, i.e. a full three years. This six-pack was introduced in support of the Stability and Growth Pact, because no one took it seriously. So let's look at the results. In these three years of the six-pack, debt has risen from 110% to 135% of GDP in Italy, from 70% to 95% in Spain and from 80% to 95% in France. These countries do not take the six-pack seriously. Let us take France as an example. In 2010, France said: "In 2012, we will meet the 3% deficit limit." Then, in 2012, France said, "We will keep it in 2015." In 2014, this was postponed to 2017. And there are no sanctions! The French Finance Minister, Mr Sapin, says: "The Commission has no right to reject our budget. Sovereignty lies only with the French Parliament." Now Mr Sapin is to be controlled by his predecessor, Mr Moscovici, who is now Commissioner. That's a joke!

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the Committee on Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) at the moment is working on a report for better integration of the single market pillar in the European Semester. I believe the single market is a key to achieve growth and is something we have really lost focus on, as the Member States have failed to implement some very good directives, very good recommendations, and this is where we are failing. Also, the annual report on single market integration was not provided by the Commission. Where is it? The European Parliament would like to propose a number of analytical tools: barometers – we have to measure our performance, everyone has to see how we are performing; methodology to measure reduction of administrative burden. This is where we are failing. Too much red tape – it is too difficult. Let us measure it to find out what needs to be done. Furthermore, I would like to stress the importance of the implementation of the European Semester, otherwise there is no need to work on a single market pillar. I also want to mention a crucial aspect of the role of national parliaments. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Mr President, the Commission's assessment is rough and politically driven to give a signal of the full success of the eight trouble-free legislations in the euro area, thus justifying austerity and neoliberal policies. The ability of states to borrow from international markets is assessed as an achievement, but there is no concern about the stagnation that the European economy has entered over the last seven years. It is also referred to as an achievement to reduce budget deficits, but there is no mention of the social costs of this policy. Fundamental factors such as the recession, high unemployment rates particularly among young people, the poor population and the extent of the gap between the centre and the region are absent from the Commission's assessment. The Left does not accept that the Commission should define the strategy in the economic policy of the Member States. There is no democratic legitimacy for that. Our goal is the decent living of man. This means a strong social state, safe jobs and solidarity.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Madam President, I thank the Commissioner for a very good introduction. There are two points that must be highlighted.  First of all, the road to undermined social security, increased unemployment, lost competitiveness as well as social unrest goes via spending money you do not have. If deficits were the solution, and if deficits could stimulate economic growth and employment, we would not have the crisis we are facing today. It is not consolidated budget policies that have caused the problems. The cause of the problems is the belief that you can solve economic problems by increased deficits and increased debt burdens. That is false, but that is exactly what we have seen. Secondly, there is the review of the Stability Pacts. It might be good to do this, but even better would be to do a real review in those cases where the Commission is dealing with deficit countries which have postponed their structural efforts and are not living up to the rules. Credibility is about being credible. The European Union must be credible; the Commission must be credible; the Stability Pact must be credible. If we undermine their credibility by letting the big Member States run away, not only from their commitments, but also from their rules and responsibilities, it will cost us all credibility. It will not help solve any problems, but it will create even more and make the crisis even deeper. Be credible and sick to the rules. (The speaker agreed to take 2 blue-card questions under Rule 162(8))

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – Mr President, Mr Hökmark, I understand that you believe in these rules, and you mention the need to reduce the deficit and debt. However, the deficit can even fall, cutting public spending and eliminating the welfare state. That's what's been done. What I ask you is: what measures do you see to bring down debt, because debts keep rising? And that's what's going to keep happening, it's the debt rising. If you have so many measures like this, how do you plan to lower debt without restructuring it?

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card answer. – Ms Matias, I must say that the threat to the welfare state comes from policies which you are now defending – the belief that you can spend money you do not have – because that brings you to the real, draconian austerity that we have seen in a number of Member States. It has led to a lack of investment in industry, in enterprises, and a lack of jobs. See the reality, look around you. Where have we succeeded and where have we failed? We must see to it that we can be credible all over the European Union.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, I will be very brief. I believe that you have stigmatized public budget deficits, Mr H-kmark, and you can, to some extent, accept your opinion. But do you not think that these deficits are, in fact, the consequence of something even more serious, namely the deficits in the trade balance? These trade deficits are actually caused by the fact that the European market is open to a set of countries that do not practice ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Gollnisch, look around in the world: where you see free trade, you see prosperity. Where you see protectionists of your kind, you see lack of prosperity. There is nowhere in the world where you have managed to develop economies and societies – a civilisation – without openness. Look at the Member States of the European Union. Those who have dealt with the crisis are the free traders. I will not ask you to join these forces, because I know that you belong to some other … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Paul TANG
text: Let's say it's bad weather, it's blowing hard, the rain comes out of the sky with buckets and every now and then a bolt of lightning comes out of dark clouds. Would you expect the plane to land on autopilot? No, of course not. And the European economy is still in bad weather. Inflation is too low for debt-burdened households, unemployment is too high, growth is low and confidence is shaky. The Commission has carried out a mid-term review of the budgetary rules in the two- and six-pack, but is therefore on autopilot. The bad weather for the European economy is not taken into account, let alone whether the budgetary rules fit into these bad weather conditions. And then one specific point. In the budgetary framework, the structural deficit is a very important concept. It is in theory a great concept and in practice a lousy size. It's like flying with a broken altimeter. Research shows that different institutions, the IMF, the OECD and the European Commission, give a different estimate of the structural deficit and in the course of the year the estimate can change considerably. This is at odds with the importance now given to this concept and does not ensure a soft landing of the European economy.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to raise this matter from the political point of view of Europe's credibility and the European project, which is what many of us have been elected to. The Six-Pack and the Two-Pack have to gain that credibility. It is true that this is not the time to reform something so recent, but it is time to see some of its failures, such as discrimination in its implementation according to countries , which undermines European credibility in this – and also the lack of vigilance, because it is a mistake to think that in Spain, for example, structural reforms have been given: patches and sacrifices have been given. There will also be no credibility, Commissioner, if we are not also talking about more Europe in terms of energy union, the single market , which in Spain does not even already have a Spanish single market - the capital market, etc. And finally, solidarity will not be believed either if we do not raise the problem of Eurobonds, while talking about control.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Mr President, first of all let me say that I am quite happy that we can discuss this subject, that we are discussing the rules that were approved a few years ago and which I believe are increasing the probability that countries will run better economic policies. Policies that are good for the countries, but also good for all of us. Also policies that help us to stop the debt crisis. And here let me remind my British colleagues that the debt crisis has by no means only affected the countries from the euro area, but also many other countries outside of the euro.  I was surprised to hear that many people said that the rules have failed. I guess what we can see failed for sure were the pre-crisis economic policies of many states, the policies that were generating higher deficit, the policies that increased debt-to-GDP ratios, were increasing expected expenditure and were calling for credibility and tolerance for bad economic policies. If we are trying to find someone who is responsible for the current high unemployment and weak economic growth, these are, in my opinion, the suspects.  What should be done now? I do not think we should focus on changes to a framework that has been in place for only a short time and has so far, I believe, worked quite well. We should be careful about considering changes that undermine credibility. We should bear in mind that an increase of one percentage point in the interest rate will increase the budget deficit by 1% on average. Also, depreciation of the currency, which is quite often proposed by our British colleagues, will also hurt the fiscal balance. In the future we can discuss many things, among others how to make countries respect more the country-specific recommendations, how to calculate a better structurally adjusted balance or eventually how to pay more attention to non-euro area countries.

name: Alfred SANT
text: Sur President, l-arranġamenti tas-six u tat-two-pack huma mfassla biex jiżguraw li l-linji direttivi taż-żona euro qed jiġu rispettati. Huma jipprovdu metodu meqjus bil-kejl tiegħu biex inkunu nistgħu ngħarblu r-riżultati finanzjarji u ekonomiikei miksuba. Madankollu, il-proġett tal-euro għad jonqsu funzjoni direttiva li hi waħdanija, magħquda u 63. Ikollna għalhekk nistaqsu dwar kemm l-assigurazzjoni li qed niġu mogħtija tista' tkun biżejjed soda. Għax sal-lum, fil-qalba tal-proġett tal-euro, għadhom jippredominaw fatturi politi大i, mhux ekonomiikei. Dawn joħorġu mill-capital enormi li ntefaq biex jinbena l-proġett. Huma fatturi li jiddependu wkoll mill-battibekki multilaterali li jseħħu bejn il-parteħipanti ewlenin fil-proġett huma u jirreaġixxu għall-interessi nazzjonali varji li jk qiunuegħda mpoġġija 'l bogħod minn xulxin. Is-superstruttura pożittivista li ddaħħlet fil-proġett.... he's 'benchmarks', 'scorecards' u ma nafx xiex aktar... qed isservi biex tgħatti din ir-realtà. Forsi wkoll, qed taffa大大ja s-sintomi u mhux il-kawżi veri li jispjegaw kif topera s-sistema tal-euro. Biex dan l-operat jinbidel u jsir trasparenti, fil-profil attwali taż-żona, trid isseħħliqa qawwija lejn struttura politika federali, ħaġa li tidher politikament diffiħli ħafna.  Għalhekk, waqt li jkunu qed jitħaddmu is-six-pack u t-two-pack u l-għodod l-oħra, se tibqa' tqum mistoqsija sempli大i ħafna: dawn il-mekkaniżmi, li fil-livelli kollha qed jiġu applikati lil ekonomiji nazzjonali differenti, qed jirrispondu għall-interessi ta' għajxien u ta' tkabbir taż-żona euro kollha kemm hi? Jew qed jirriflettu aktar l-interess nazzjonali ta' hawk Stat Membru? Mhux possibbli li twieġeb għal din il-mistoqsija bla ambigwità. Din l-impossibiltà tirrifletti difett profond u sistemiku fl-għanijiet tal-mekkaniżmi kurrenti ta' sorveljanza u control. Minħabba f'hekk wisq nibża' li l-governanza ekonomika taż-żona euro se tibqa' għal li ġej... (Il-President waqqaf l-intervent tal-kelliem)

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Mr President, I think there is a danger that we will confuse the mechanisms with the substance, that is to say, criticise the 'two pack-six pack', essentially wanting to break the thermometer so as not to see the fever that may be warning us of an economic or budgetary disease. I think we're generally doing well. There are concrete successes: Ireland has come out of the memorandum, Portugal has come out of the memorandum, Latvia and Lithuania have done a good job and taken the ticket to the euro, Cyprus is generally doing well, as far as I am told; unfortunately my country, Greece, is still trying but has not succeeded. But I will tell you that Greece's problems, because I was 35 years a journalist and publisher, I was watching them both before the euro and before the 'two pack-six pack' and before the stabilisation mechanisms, and I will tell you that in general they were the same; i.e. we were giving large pensions, we had an excessively rich welfare state that could not be financed by the private sector of the economy and I will tell our friends the British anti-Europeans and Eurosceptics, who say that in Greece we have huge problems because of the euro, that we used to give pensions to Greece that were 100 or even 120% of the last salary, while in the UK pensions – because I had read about them – were in the order of 35 to 40% of the last salary. The problems therefore existed before; we cannot attribute them to the euro. On the contrary, the euro makes it easier for us to restructure debt in the future, it makes it easier for us, as in the case of Ireland, to reduce borrowing costs in the future, while, with the measures taken by Mr Draghi, the euro becomes less powerful and facilitates the export effort of countries such as Greece. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Marco VALLI
text: Blue card question. I wanted to ask a very simple question. If you believe that the euro is a sustainable currency for your country, Then I wanted to ask you whether the interest rate that your country is now paying, which seems to me to be around 9%, is sustainable at a time when it is under pressure from the financial crisis, when Germany is perhaps paying 0% or even negative rates. Is the euro sustainable without progressing towards a single interest rate, for example?

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: "blue card" answer. – I would like the interest rate paid by our country to be equivalent to the interest rate paid by Ireland, which has ten-year government bonds below 1.5%. And because Ireland is, anyway, very dynamic as an economy, let us go to the interest rates of Portugal, which is comparable to Greece, which at the moment, if I am not mistaken, is around 2.9%. It is a fact that interest rates in Greece have risen at the moment, precisely because the markets are not sure whether we will try to complete what we are doing. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I was astonished to hear you say that the euro had helped Greece to restructure its debt. Is it not rather the case that it was the goodwill of the creditors that led to debt restructuring, who renounced your demand of EUR 100 billion, and that Greece would have been able to pay its debts if it had had its own central bank and currency?

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: "blue card" answer. – At the moment Greece's debt is public, it is no longer in the private sector, so we have a political and moral obligation to pay. We'll pay in the long run, of course. There is a debate about going from 30 years to 50 years to facilitate, but there are two basic conditions: to have stable primary surpluses and to make the necessary structural changes. So I think that's how both sides will win, Greece will modernise and its creditors will get paid.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Thank you very much for the word. Dear Mr President, Listening to this debate, I have repeatedly wondered if any of us MEPs, Commission officials, go into a café or anywhere where they meet a tra00 of European citizens and ask whether this two-pack, pack of six, understands these terms at all, well, if one person in a hundred will understand that. Yet this debate has contributed – and I thank the colleagues who have made it clear – that this is essentially a matter of measures to manage the crisis attributed to the eurozone crisis or the eurozone.  But there is one thing that has been mentioned less today – and I would like to draw attention to this, I am also essentially asking the Representative of the European Commission a question – what they have done and what they intend to do in addition to the sentences described, so that social dialogue, so that the understanding of individual actors, is better at this.  My guess is that the real problem with this line of measures, called the six or two-pack, is that societies did not understand what it was about, and therefore it was difficult to find a partnership with them. My question, then, is what do you intend to do to make sure that social dialogue really accompeds this process. Thank you very much!

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: Mr President, I would like to highlight three issues for Vice-President Dombrovskis. My first comment is that I believe the very nature of economic governance forces us to look beyond this six-pack and two-pack into areas such as, for example, the banking union; even if it is not an element of economic governance we all know that it can bring stability to the system and also influence the capacity of the EMU to deliver. So when identifying the areas for improvement within economic governance, I think we have to have this broader perspective.  My second comment is on rules versus procedures, and my colleague Mr Niedermayer alluded to this issue. I think that the economic governance framework has indeed put many rules in place but their success hinges on the right policy choices. We also know that citizens, when looking at the outcome of economic governance, do not differentiate between the policy choices – mostly made nationally – and the rules on which the system is based. This can of course raise doubts about the viability of the system as well as its democratic credentials. So I think that while respecting the rules, we also have to have better tailor-made policy choices and also we have to carefully assess and hopefully fill in the legitimacy gap.  The third point is on growth. I think, in particular today, that any economic governance needs to have a strong growth perspective, and structural reforms are of the essence here; and yet the governance framework does not provide for a mechanism to foster those reforms. Contractual arrangements which were proposed by the four presidents two years ago had until recently disappeared from the radar. The Eurogroup conclusions from December seemed to reopen this issue, so I hope that we will also have a strong commitment as a catalyst for structural reforms. I also hope that the Commission will push in this direction and will play a leading role in this issue.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: Mr President, Commissioner, when it is necessary to assess and revise measures with such serious macroeconomic consequences, the scope of the assessment must of course be broad enough to allow for a coherent analysis. Now, for the six-pack and the two-pack, what assessment do we have? From a technical communication from the Commission, which addresses the evolution of public deficits, one point is all. Little or nothing about assessing the impact on economic growth. Nothing about the evolution of unemployment. Nothing about the evolution of social rights. And nothing about poverty assessment. However, for the daily lives of the vast majority of Europeans, the evaluation of the two-pack and the six-pack is clearly quite different: it is budgetary austerity, it is a frontal attack on social rights, a significant increase in poverty and the questioning of fundamental rights such as universal access to health care. The evaluation must therefore be followed by the determined and socially just reaction. Europe, while controlling its public deficits, must once again become a lever for social progress and hope. In this regard, we could create a new social eight-pack, which should above all include a policy of assumed public investment, where the private sector does not take its responsibilities - the latest FIGUREs from the ECB have shown - but also, obviously, an effective and coordinated taxation of large capital and corporate profits. A major employment effort, the introduction of a European minimum wage and an effective fight against social and environmental dumping would be other foundations. Austerity, as is now evident, has not worked. The social setback was planned but it is, unfortunately, cruelly at the rendezvous. Economic failure, on the other hand, ends up discrediting the strategy - if we can call it that - of blind austerity. A comprehensive assessment would have the merit of producing obvious conclusions. We must quickly change course and reinvest in values of progress and social justice. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Bernard MONOT
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, Mr Bayet, dear colleague, I fully agree with your statement, but what are your party in France and your President waiting for to apply these fabulous rules?

name: Hugues BAYET
text: "blue card" answer. "Dear Colleague, I thank you for your question but, unfortunately, as soon as you speak, it is always to criticise the French Socialists. I myself am a Belgian socialist and I am here to do a job in the interest of Europe and not to answer the Questions of the National Front about their eternal enemies, namely sometimes the Socialists, sometimes the Liberals.

name: Lara COMI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that today's debate is one of the most important that we can deal with as Members of the European Parliament. And, just as MEMBERS of the European Parliament, we were elected by the citizens to change the situation. We are not here to protest without proposals. We must achieve clear objectives, otherwise we will not follow the mandate that the citizens have given us. On 25 November, the Holy Father sent us a clear message, a clear message that was shared by 99.9% of this House, which was: 'more Europe, a fairer Europe and the need to keep the reality of democracies alive'. This message was shared, in words, with statements by all the groups with only two or three against. This means combining economic growth with stability.  But in a time of crisis, growth comes first, otherwise it will not come out. Without growth we continue to have stability and it becomes almost like a noose around the neck. And if for growth we have to use more debt – only, and I really say, alone and as an Italian I can understand its concerns – for investments, why not do so? I am convinced that investment is the springboard for real growth and that would really create jobs. I fully support Juncker's plan for fiscal union. In Italy it would really solve many problems given the taxation that we have. You see, some Italians are here in Strasbourg complaining about the European Stability Pact. But often you look elsewhere and you don't look at your own house: we start to settle the accounts in our own house, amending the internal stability pact that does not allow mayors to spend the money they have. There is also discussion of unemployment in Germany, where there is the euro, unemployment in England where there is no euro, and in this case they are much lower rates than ours. I will conclude by saying that we tell the ECB that we have (The President withdraws the speaker)

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, I, in turn, address both the representatives of the European Commission and my colleagues. I begin with a statement: There is no grey; It's white or black. The vision of the Common European House presupposes common convergence in the economic standard of living of Europeans. And Europeans are from one end to the other. I understand those who insist that the debts of one Member State should not be carried on the shoulders of another Member State. However, I stress that in economics things are not zero-sum but they are also prosthetics. In other words, we can, through collective management, co-decide rules, but these rules do not mean that they must be completely the same for all Member States. I also stress to my colleagues that I do not expect much from those who want to break up the European Union. But my disappointment is from those who say that we share the same vision for Europe, but leave out European citizens – or a part of European citizens, whether they are in the South or in the North. So we end up having country specific recommendations but we don't have country specific medicine. And one specific example: We have a banking union but we do not have a common single deposit guarantee plan. So that is what I expect everyone to be sensitive to in the European South.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Mr President, Commissioner, dear and dear colleagues, coordination, sharing, synchronism, maximum transparency are fundamental in the governance of the European Union, but prevention is crucial. I grasp here the popular saying is better to prevent than remedy, and this is a way of saying, Portuguese: troika, never again. With this legislation, the six-pack and the two-pack, we have strengthened credibility and trust in the space, in the institutions, of the European Union. It allows you to identify problems and fix them before they turn into unsolved imbalances. Prevention and corrective measures promote responsibility and, consequently, solidarity.  Accumulating deficits and increasing debt unsustainably has a price we all pay, and especially future generations. But we need a flexible and intelligent interpretation of the six-pack and the two-pack. They need to allow and aim at defending economic growth and employment, the defence of competitiveness, without the credibility of the commitments being called into question.  In addition, social cohesion, territorial cohesion is another concern that the flexible and intelligent interpretation of these six-pack and two-pack should allow.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that European economic governance must be reformulated in the light of the paradigm shift of recent months, bearing in mind that our continent is characterised by fragile and uncertain growth, dangerous deflation and structural unemployment. The investment plan proposed by Juncker is only the first and insufficient step towards a change of direction, which will have to emerge more clearly in the coming months. The priority given to growth and development in order to emerge from the crisis must now be reflected in the technical instruments of European economic governance. This is an important occasion, perhaps the last appeal for Europe, the Europe that we have built with difficulty and because of myopic economic policies is now in danger of being handed over to populism and nationalism or simply to a fate of irrelevance. As highlighted in the conclusions of the June European Council, intelligent flexibility cannot be a courtesy but must be a strategic choice for Europe. So must the structural reforms that the Member States must carry out in a clear time. But it is not possible to think of basing all the prospects for recovery on the Juncker plan without there being parallel encouragement of smart spending by states. We are not asking for abstract flexibility. We call for virtuous spending to be encouraged to be a multiplier of the Juncker plan itself and to help build a lasting recovery based on a real business economy ... (The President withdrew the floor from the speaker)

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: The two legislative packages were adopted under unprecedented pressure to strengthen economic governance and address the uncertainty that has arisen. The review prepared by the European Commission shows that the new coordination rules and economic and budgetary policies have achieved positive results in reducing levels of budget deficits. While some of the new instruments, such as the automatic sanctions mechanism, have not been implemented in practice, their deterrent effect creates a strong incentive to adhere to a sound budgetary policy. It is essential that we have a reliable and functioning system to ensure that the repetition of old errors with the mitigation of the rules is avoided. Only their consistent implementation will lead Member States to carry out the necessary structural reforms and stability-oriented fiscal policy that improve competitiveness and favour job creation.  There is also a need to improve incentives to implement country-specific recommendations that have so far not been sufficiently taken into account at national level. The new framework allows for sufficient flexibility with regard to exceptional circumstances and any amendment would only undermine confidence in its credibility. Uniform standards must be applied to the establishment of such circumstances to ensure that small countries meet the same criteria as large Member States. I appeal to the European Commission to ensure compliance with these rules, taking objective account of member states' political commitment to reforms and their results.

name: Neena GILL
text: Mr President, I echo the call from my colleagues that we urgently need to review the economic governance rules in the EU. The Commission communication is a small step but we need to go further. As an ultimate proof of failing austerity policies, the economic governance framework needs profound change, and as the European Parliament we have the legislative key. The facts are: 25 million unemployed people, economic stagnation, deflation, excessive debt, high deficits, democratic deficit. These rules are hurting instead of working.  Laudable as it is to keep the deficit under 3%, we need to recognise the cost too. Therefore, I believe the economic governance framework needs to be broader and take into account social elements. The key questions are: what are the Member States doing to tackle poverty, tax fraud and youth unemployment? How do they increase education opportunities? These criteria need to get the same weight in the analysis as the level of public deficit and debt.  Given the interconnection of all our economies, I do recognise the need for effective management of our economies and, yes, smart investments need to be treated in a flexible way. The reform of the six-pack and the two-pack will be an important test to show that the EU takes European citizens seriously, and an opportunity to make a European project people can believe in. I would urge Vice-President Dombrovskis to make sure that the Commission does not just act as accountants but that when they look at the balance sheets ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Romana TOMC
text: I agree with the findings of the European Commission, and also with all those who say that, in recent years, economic governance in the individual Member States of the European Union has been a dead end. And, of course, that both packages of measures offer some way and a way out of this situation.  Whether it was actually a successful project is still very difficult to judge. However, with all the concerns we have, we can say that enhanced and in-depth budgetary control is adequate and, of course, necessary. Too often, governments of individual countries behave irrationally, of course in the context of satisfying their constituents as much as possible.  It is good that, in the macroeconomic balance procedure, the surveillance of economic policies has been extended and that it also takes into account the social aspect.  The Commission reports to us that it has carried out 42 in-depth reviews and identified 5 cases of imbalance, but has not acted.  In this respect, there is, of course, another important question: whether the promises made by individual governments are sufficient, whether the Commission has too much confidence in individual governments, and too little, of course, assesses in substance whether these measures that governments promise are actually realised in the end. At least as far as my country, Slovenia, is concerned, I can find, on the basis of the table annexed, that the Commission believed more promises.  Finally, I would like to point out that, of course, the Commission should, of course, pay greater attention to the substantive assessment of individual measures, and another important matter: the Commission should, in all cases, including in cases ....  (The Chair took the floor of the Member.)

name: Olle LUDVIGSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul It is important that we are very careful in our analysis of the six- and two-pack – how they have worked so far. It is difficult to make an accurate evaluation after such a short time and in a situation where the new regulatory framework has basically only been used in crisis. I believe that it is a good regulatory framework and that it should be kept as it is for the time being. As far as the rules as such are concerned, it is not reasonable at this stage to make any changes. On the other hand, it is very reasonable to look at how the regulatory framework is actually used. There is potential for improvement. The regulatory framework is both flexible and intelligent. The problem is that it has not been used in any flexible or intelligent way. The application has been too much characterised by single-trackness and ideological blinkers. These shortcomings have been negative in several respects for economic development. All the possibilities offered by the rules must now be used seriously. It is possible to create workable plans for the restructuring of deficits and debts. It is possible to create scope for incentives and investment in countries that need it. It is not the regulations that are wrong. That's the application.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Economic and fiscal union is very important for both large and small countries. The euro is one of the key drivers ahead of itself in small, export-oriented countries such as Slovenia.  I support rules that are strict and are respected for both large and small countries. In view of the changed circumstances in which we find ourselves in the midst of the economic and financial crisis, I am very pleased, however, of Mr Juncker's new package, which in some ways makes it possible for us to create fiscal stability, and also a social state, by the most effective measure, that is to say, with jobs.  I therefore firmly believe that these reforms, which are enshied in many country tables, require countries to be scrutined and also insist on these countries that the reforms are implemented and that they are implemented in the long term. They are needed primarily for the countries themselves, not for the European Union.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: Dear Mr Dombrovskis, you seem to have forgotten the first sentence of your own report, which states that the aim of the new mechanisms is to strengthen economic governance in order to achieve sustainable cohesion, economic growth and jobs. Furthermore, the key issue of this review is the extent to which the new rules have contributed to the sustainable convergence of member states' economic development. In your brief introductory words, you did not mention a single fact, not a single number, that the achievement of these real goals of the new economic governance is being achieved. Are you able to answer this question here, today, now?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the debate that has taken place has shown that the huge democratic deficit that applies during the process of famous economic governance is a given. The Commission, without democratic legitimacy, considers that it can determine the economic and social policy of the Member States. It considers that it can control national budgets and force national parliaments to do what to do. Yes, Mr. President. Juncker has completely disintegrated and, acting as a representative of the lenders and The Local, is illegally interfering in internal political developments in Greece, supporting the mnemonic co-government and the memorial parties in the run-up to the upcoming national elections. Mr Moscovici has been doing the same thing in Athens for the last 24 hours. Commissioners, you are breaking the law and violating the Treaty, which imposes political neutrality on you. Get it together! Know that you cannot terrorize the Greek people, who in the upcoming elections will give you a red card and send you the message that suits you.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: There is an ancient Greek proverb which says: "The mountain and the mountain" —the mountain was in pain and gave birth to a mouse. The six-fold and two-fold package of economic measures has not even managed to give birth to a mouse! It has not stopped the plundering of the people in favour of the banks; did not stop unemployment in Greece; has not stopped the closure of small businesses; has not stopped poverty and hunger; It didn't stop the suicides. The debt has increased even further. I don't know. Because it is based on the deification of money, on the perception that money produces everything. Big mistake! Money represents and exchanges values, does not produce goods. Values and goods are produced only by the worker with his work. There is a survey of expert scientists that says that if it were not for the end of workers' goodwill, if it were not for the labour problems ....... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Mr. President, I salute Vice President Dombrovkis and congratulate you on this report. I agree with most of my colleagues who have stressed that rules are important because they provide a systemal, strategic and coordinated approach to good economic governance, and what is still important is that it leaves room for Member States to find the best solutions for smart fiscal consolidation, structural reforms and investments on their own.  There are no copy/paste solutions, but thanks to the European Semester, Member States can exchange experiences and learn from best practices. In addition to implementing reforms in each Member State, persistent work on reforms at European Union level is extremely important, namely strengthening the single market through the establishment of a Banking Union, the Digital Single Market, a new cohesion policy. These reforms are important to us in order to create a competitive, creative, innovative Europe and a Europe of a growing economy.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: Mr President, in the face of a difficulty, it is always easy to designate scapegoats, and this is generally the mark of a certain intellectual laziness. In the face of the situation in the European Union, which is being discussed at the moment, ease is certainly not an option.  We are on the brink of a deflationary spiral that could take us all away, regardless of our nationality. Let us not allow invective between countries to take place as a democratic debate, and let us not allow rules erected in shackles to be used as piloting tools. Rather, the urgency is to build a genuine economic governance that would remind us of what the Union should not cease to be, namely a project of cooperation between states, not a competition, as well as a project at the service of citizens, and not to their detriment. Of course, to do so, we will have to revise the current tools, and that is what we are waiting for the Commission to do.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank everyone for the interesting debate we had today. As I said at the beginning, the Commission sees the follow-up to the review, and the process of strengthening economic governance in general, very much as a dialogue with all stakeholders. The European Parliament is a key partner in this respect. I have carefully taken note of the remarks and points raised. They will help us to see the strong points of the economic governance framework, as well as the areas for improvement. Similarly, I very much look forward to the work being done by Ms Berès and the shadow rapporteurs in preparing their own-initiative report. A number of points have also been raised by colleagues that are probably somewhat outside the scope of the review of the six-pack and two-pack. Nevertheless I will make some brief responses to those, because there were a number of questions as regards the best use of flexibility within the Stability and Growth Pact. As you are aware, the Commission is preparing some more detailed guidelines or a document on the best use of flexibility within the existing Stability and Growth Pact, precisely in order to look into this issue. We will be presenting this document early next year and looking at various issues, including a number of issues raised on taking into account economic cycles, the treatment of investment, and the treatment of structural reforms. But once again, it is worth emphasising that we are making this document within the framework of the existing Stability and Growth Pact. More specifically, on the question of the treatment of investments for the European Fund for Strategic Investments: this is something which the Commission outlined already when presenting the investment plan. The Commission will treat that kind of investment favourably, understanding that, while – just like any other expenditure, it would count towards deficit and debt – it would not trigger specific procedures under the Stability and Growth Pact should the Member States exceed their thresholds of whichever procedures by an amount no larger than their contributions to this fund. We are really ensuring this favourable treatment. Of course, it is clear that the topic of strengthening our economic governance system is far from finished. I am looking forward to engaging with you and other stakeholders in intensive debate during the coming months. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. – In the light of what the Commission and the Council have said in the course of the debate on the revision of the economic governance package, I would like to state: (1) I disagree with the Commission's assessment of the effectiveness of the standards package known as 'Six-Pack' and 'Two-Pack', in so far as the reduction in public deficits has been achieved at the expense of growth and employment. Since the start of the crisis in 2007-2008, the GDP growth differential between the European Union and the eurozone, and the United States, has averaged more than one percentage point per year. Nor has this regulatory package served to ensure financial stability, which has been achieved through economic integration (banking union) and ECB monetary policy. (2) The Commission must therefore propose a revision of these rules, so that they stop focusing on the obsessive pursuit of punitive fiscal adjustments and serve to boost economic growth and social welfare. The European Council should also consider the desirability of reforming the Stability and Growth Pact itself.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. In the wake of the economic and financial crisis, the European Union wanted to "strengthen its economic governance" through the "six-pack" and "two-pack" regulations that are being reviewed here. The "six-pack" allows the Commission to ask for corrections to the budget of Member States whose expenditure is slipping. Worse, after two recalls, it can fine states that are reluctant to comply with Brussels' injunctions, a fine of up to 0.1% of GDP. Added to this is the "two-pack" which strengthens the Commission's powers in budgetary supervision of Member States. Moreover, the "two-pack" requires states to rely on independent growth forecasts and submit their budget to a budget control body. Finally, the fiscal compact (TSCG) will have to become a reality in 2018. This 'golden rule', a genuine austerity plan, will put national budgets under some control and kill the growth of Member States. Having deprived us of our monetary sovereignty, these regulations and treaties sacrifice on the altar of European federalism the freedom of peoples to dispose of themselves. This is the victory of the rating agencies and the financial markets over the states!

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. The Stability Pact must be respected, but new investment is needed to relaunch Europe and work. The real betrayal to the detriment of future generations is to deprive them of the infrastructure necessary for growth and well-being, to leave them with falling infrastructure, mediocre schools, an inadequate health system and compromised potential growth. In order to avoid this situation, we need the inclusion in the Stability Pact of a flexibility clause and the activation of the new European Fund for Strategic Investments. A deeper and fairer monetary and economic union involves a review of the rules of the 'Six Pack' and the 'Two Pack', the texts that introduced the obligation to balance the structural budget and on which policies for the return of excessive debt and deficit imbalances of EU countries were based. There is room for improvement with regard to the transparency and complexity of policy-making and its impact on growth, imbalances and convergence. The Fiscal Compact, which institutionalises on a permanent basis the austerity regime imposed in Europe as a result of the crisis, must be completely revised, and the limited fiscal room for manoeuvre provided for in the Maastricht Treaty and the Stability Pact must also be permanently removed.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing – According to the available information as well as current developments, 2-pack and 6-pack appear to be only marketing names of a non-existent strategy. How else can inconsisventive compliance be perceived, currently in France, for example. If the European Commission wants the citizens of the Member States of the European Union to have confidence in the European Union's economic governance project, then it must first of all demand compliance with the rules it has laid down and, for violating them, to impose harsh sanctions on any state, regardless of its political influence or geographical significance. In addition, the European Commission should also focus on considering the rules for Member States' budgets, which often make pro-growth measures impossible, and thus real growth in economies, or improving the social situation of the population. Last but not least, it is essential to introduce real measures against tax evasion and restrictions on tax havens, whether in the European Union or beyond. Such measures could thus provide the necessary resources for member states' budgets and, at the same time, be a kind of moral satisfaction for the population.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Written. – The eurozone and non-euro area Member States have been torn apart by the crisis in terms of economic performance, a duality which strongly calls into question the effectiveness of any common economic policy. In my opinion, our common future depends or fails on whether this worrying gap can be reduced. Although the process has begun, it is progressing very slowly, and it is feared that by the time the economically 'well' countries, which are suffering from the crisis, especially in southern Europe, will be approaching each other, it will be too late. It has been shown that a disciplined fiscal policy is also needed to overcome the crisis, which requires structural budgetary rules, even at constitutional level.  It has become apparent that the measures launched in the European Union in 2011 have not been able to while, for example, my country, Hungary, has been steadily increasing it since 2010 with small, strent steps, from 60.4% to 63.2%. I believe that this should serve Hungary a good example in this area. The main issue under consideration in the context of the review is now the extent to which the new rules introduced by the six and two packages have been effective in achieving the objectives set and have contributed to the lasting convergence of the economic performance of the Member States. I look forward to the direction in which the Commission will move in order to achieve a possible restructuring.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – In the light of what the Commission and the Council have said in the course of the debate on the revision of the economic governance package, I would like to state: (1) I disagree with the Commission's assessment of the effectiveness of the standards package known as 'Six-Pack' and 'Two-Pack', in so far as the reduction in public deficits has been achieved at the expense of growth and employment. Since the start of the crisis in 2007-2008, the GDP growth differential between the European Union and the eurozone, and the United States, has averaged more than one percentage point per year. Nor has this regulatory package served to ensure financial stability, which has been achieved through economic integration (banking union) and ECB monetary policy. (2) The Commission must therefore propose a revision of these rules, so that they stop focusing on the obsessive pursuit of punitive fiscal adjustments and serve to boost economic growth and social welfare. The European Council should also consider the desirability of reforming the Stability and Growth Pact itself.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. – In the light of what the Commission and the Council have said in the course of the debate on the revision of the economic governance package, I would like to state: (1) I disagree with the Commission's assessment of the effectiveness of the standards package known as 'Six-Pack' and 'Two-Pack', in so far as the reduction in public deficits has been achieved at the expense of growth and employment. Since the start of the crisis in 2007-2008, the GDP growth differential between the European Union and the eurozone, and the United States, has averaged more than one percentage point per year. Nor has this regulatory package served to ensure financial stability, which has been achieved through economic integration (banking union) and ECB monetary policy. (2) The Commission must therefore propose a revision of these rules, so that they stop focusing on the obsessive pursuit of punitive fiscal adjustments and serve to boost economic growth and social welfare. The European Council should also consider the desirability of reforming the Stability and Growth Pact itself.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, it is undoubtedly necessary to agree with the Commission's position that too short a period has passed in order to be able to assess fairly the functioning of the rules on economic governance – suffice it to mention that the two-pack entered into force only a year and a half ago. The Commission boasts of the progress made in reducing deficits in the Member States and the reduction in the number of countries under the excessive deficit procedure. However, looking at the overall economic state of the Union, it is difficult to regard the policy as a comprehensive success. Societies most affected by the sanitation measures introduced at the behest of the Union are increasingly starting to rebel. The political crisis in Greece, the strikes in France and Italy, make us reflect on the social costs of the measures taken to reduce the budget deficit. In fact, in addition to the decrease in debt, it is difficult to identify any other positives. The economies of many Member States are once again approaching recession and unemployment remains high in many of them. From this perspective, it is difficult to talk about the unequivocal success of the current economic governance package. Many economists have pointed out that the mere sanitation of public finances may not be enough to return to the growth path. It is therefore good that the new Commission has recognised the need to complement these regulations with a package that stimulates the European economy. It has received quite widespread criticism, but it is in the interests of all of us that it bring about the expected results.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Union, since the economic crisis, has decided to increase its "economic governance" through the "six-pack" and two-pack regulations. An intrusive instrument by its very nature, the "six-pack" allows the Commission to demand budgetary corrections from Member States whose spending is slipping. After two recalls, states that were reluctant to comply with the Brussels injunctions were fined. The "two-pack" further strengthens the Commission's powers in the area of budgetary supervision. As a result, Member States are forced to rely on independent growth forecasts and submit their budgets to a budgetary regulator. To this arsenal is added the fiscal pact (TSCG), demanded in its time by the duo "Merkel-Sarkozy", which will come into force in 2018. This 'golden rule', or umpteenth austerity plan, will end up putting national budgets under guardianship and annihilate any idea of growth in the Member States. These two regulations run counter to our monetary and budgetary sovereignty and the interests of the French people. With the Union, there is always more submission to the dogma of the single currency, to ultraliberalism, to federalism and to financial markets!

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. – The declaration on governance you have presented to us is a fraud that hides the violence of measures that cause suffering to peoples, which destroy jobs in all sectors – agriculture, fisheries, industry – which generate more and more hunger, misery and poverty. In my country, in Galicia, this past Friday three mobilizations were held simultaneously in different points of our geography for actions related to the destruction of wage employment in Alcoa and Lantero and the non-payment of wages in Cleanet. I heard again today in this debate that no more can be spent than you have, that budgets need to be adjusted. But you know what? My people, Galiza, are not poor: you with your policies have impoverished us. With their policies they have appropriated our wealth and our resources, destroying our productive sectors, our industries, and delivering our markets to multinationals. Of our debt we would have to take stock, to see who owes whom. Economic governance will continue to fail, and as long as they do not put the economy at the service of people, job destruction, misery, hunger, poverty and social exclusion will continue to increase.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing – The rules of the Stability and Growth Pact should be accepted by all EU Member States and the EU should ensure that the same rules apply and are respected by both small and large EU states. I think that 6 - Pack and 2 -Pack do not need revision, as some provisions are not yet in force long enough to be able to assess their operation.

name: Milan ZVER
text: "Dear Sirs, I would like to thank the European Commission and Vice-President, Mr Valdis Dombrovskis, for a brief and concise overview of economic governance. The crisis has exposed our shortcomings and caught Europe off guard.  With the Six-Pack and the Twin, we have strengthened the Stability and Growth Pact and installed a security mechanism that ensures an economically stable Europe through prevention. It is true that we have not yet been able to test the measures in different economic circumstances, but mechanisms such as the annual publication of the reform and stability programme, the European Semester and so on ensure sufficient early detection of problems and timely action.  We have better control and member states need to be more careful and precise in planning their budgets. However, the fact that budget deficits in the Member States have started to decrease shows that the first economic responses to the six-pack and the twin are positive.  It saddens me that my Slovenia is the only Member State that has been alerted to macroeconomic imbalances twice in a row by the European Commission. However, we must face these difficulties, like any other Member State, and by financial consolidation we can correct these imbalances.  Allow me to stress only that we must demand responsibility both from the smaller and the larger Member States to the same extent. The rules should be the same for everyone.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. (The sitting was suspended at 11.50 a.m. and resumed at 12 noon.)

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls Voting Time. (For voting results and other details about them: see minutes)

name: Lara COMI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I refer to Rule 186 of the Rules of Procedure. Europe cannot stand firm in the face of the decision of india's Supreme Court, which rejected the request of the two marò who asked to stay in Italy, one for health problems and the other for visiting the family at Christmas. This is a very serious violation of human rights. Mr Barroso and Mr Ashton had spoken. We are now asking Juncker and Mogherini to give a strong signal. We need to bring them home. Free maròs are European citizens, they are one of us.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: Madam President, I would like to address the House. I am sure you are aware that a terrible tragedy has taken place in Peshawar, Pakistan. Over 500 people are in a state of siege, 124 children have died and 200 are injured. This is a fight against extremists. That brave nation is involved in protecting not only itself but also us all, and we should send a message of sympathy to that nation and we should be partners in the fight against extremists, the Taliban, etc. This is a tragedy of a profound nature and we should all get together and send a message, and help that nation in its fight against these extremists.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would ask Parliament, and on behalf of the Italian members of the GUE Group, to comment on a very serious event which took place on 15 December last, when a well-known Italian journalist, a former Member of this Parliament, Giulietto Chiesa, was arrested in Tallinn, Estonia, shortly before going to a public conference to which he had been invited. He was released and then sent back to Italy as a persona non grata. The conference was entitled 'Is Russia our enemy?' I find this very serious because a European country is prevented from speaking to a public person and a journalist.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Ms Spinelli, thank you, but this is not, strictly speaking, a motion of order. The agenda calls for the election of the European Ombudsman. The election will be held in accordance with section 219 of our regulations. I received the nomination from Mrs. Emily O'Reilly. I would remind you that, in accordance with Article 219, paragraph 5, of the regulation, the vote takes place by secret ballot and that, in order to be elected, the candidate must obtain a majority of the votes cast. In accordance with a constant practice of Parliament, abstentions are not considered votes cast. Since this is a secret ballot, the blue light in your terminal will light up regardless of whether you vote for, against or abstention. Since, in accordance with Article 219, paragraph 6, I have to make sure this time, before the vote opens, that at least half of the members are present - but it seems that you are here - who make up this Parliament. We will conduct a test vote to ensure that at least 376 MPs are present. I therefore ask you to vote in a moment for, against or abstention. The test vote is open.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of Emily O’Reilly for re-election to the role of European Ombudsman. I was pleased to be one of the many MEPs to sign her nomination. It is evident by the fact that Ms O’Reilly was unopposed for this position that, in her relatively short period in the job, she has earned the good will and esteem of those of every political persuasion. As Ireland’s Ombudsman from 2003 and in the office of European Ombudsman since 2013 Emily O’Reilly has won the confidence of ordinary citizens as someone who is ‘on their side’. She has a big challenge ahead of her. The European institutions have lost the confidence of citizens and communities across many Member States. In many cases the manner in which the Council and Commission carry out their roles in secrecy, without transparency and with minimal public consultation, exacerbates this loss of confidence. The European Ombudsman has the responsibility to challenge these cultures within the European institutions. I am extremely hopeful that Emily O’Reilly will be up to that job.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — All citizens, residents, undertakings or associations in a Member State, have been able to complain to the Ombudsman since 1995 about maladministration by their institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. This European institution, built on the Scandinavian model, serves to improve citizens' access to European administrations. It is the role of the European Parliament to elect the Ombudsman or the Ombudsman. In this democratic process, I voted in favour of Emily O'Reilly this week so that she can further improve the quality of the EU administration in the interests of all Europeans.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — This vote was taken by secret ballot.  In the interests of transparency, I believe that my constituents have a right to know how I voted and therefore I wish to clarify that my vote was against.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. — As Socialists, we consider the Ombudsman's office to be one of the most important tools for bringing the EU closer to citizenship. Through this office, citizens can file their complaints and requests; it is also the guarantor of transparency and good practice within the European institutions. We believe that Mrs O'Reilly has shown her ability to carry out this position in the last period, we are confident in her good work and her capacity for dialogue.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — The European Ombudsman investigates complaints of maladministration in the institutions and bodies of the European Union. It can be contacted by EU citizens and residents, businesses, associations and other organisations registered in EU countries. I supported the nomination of Emily O'Reilly as Ombudsman for the 2014-2019 term.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. "We have re-elected Emily O'Reilly as Ombudsman. Its objectives for this new mandate will be to improve the quality of administration and increase transparency within the Union. Its role is important for the transparency of the Union and contact with citizens.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. —It is very easy to vote for a candidate who is already backed by extraordinary performance. Emily O'Reilly has managed, in just one year at the head of the Ombudsman's office, to implement practical and concrete action based on the exemplaryness, transparency and accountability of the European institutions. The Ombudsman's strength depends on the European Parliament. Together with the Committee on Petitions , its reference and to whom it responds – it is the embodiment of the direct participation of citizens in the European institutions. I would like to highlight your thorough work in denouncing administrative ill-practices, as well as so-called 'revolving doors', the demand for greater transparency in the institutions as a whole, particularly prominent in the case of the TTIP negotiations, and its strong, unanimous and strong message in the body of actions that has so far been being developed at the head of the Ombudsman's office.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the continuity of Emily O'Reilly as Ombudsman, elected to office on 3 July 2013 following the retirement of her predecessor, Nikiforos Diamandouros.  O'Reilly is the only candidate for the 2014-2019 term, having become the first Ombudsman in 2013. I believe it is necessary for it to remain at the forefront of an institution, if possible, more necessary than ever, given the economic circumstances facing Europe. Since 1995, the European Ombudsman has investigated complaints about the management of all EU institutions. In 2013 he received 2,420 complaints, with an action that had an impact on 23,245 European citizens. From her position, the Ombudsman can make a unique contribution to overcoming the crisis of citizens' confidence in the European institutions, highlighting the concerns of citizens and helping to bridge the gap between them and the Community institutions.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The role of the European Ombudsman is to investigate cases of maladministration in the EU institutions. It fulfils the task of ensuring that the European institutions are managed effectively and in a politically neutral manner (which is not a given in this institution...). The Ombudsman is elected by Parliament for a five-year term. I voted against the election of outgoing Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly in order not to endorse these technocratic institutions.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of Emily O’Reilly for re-election to the role of European Ombudsman. I was pleased to be one of the many MEPs to sign her nomination. It is evident by the fact that Ms O’Reilly was unopposed for this position that, in her relatively short period in the job, she has earned the good will and esteem of those of every political persuasion. As Ireland’s Ombudsman from 2003 and in the office of European Ombudsman since 2013 Emily O’Reilly has won the confidence of ordinary citizens as someone who is ‘on their side’. She has a big challenge ahead of her. The European institutions have lost the confidence of citizens and communities across many Member States. In many cases the manner in which the Council and Commission carry out their roles in secrecy, without transparency and with minimal public consultation, exacerbates this loss of confidence. I am extremely hopeful that Emily O’Reilly will be up to that job.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for the confirmation of the European Ombudsman because I think that she has done a very good work and shall continue so.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The role of the European Ombudsman is to investigate cases of maladministration in the Union's institutions. It fulfils the task of ensuring that the European institutions are managed effectively and in a politically neutral manner (which is not a given in this institution...). The Ombudsman is elected by Parliament for a five-year term. I voted against the election of outgoing Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly in order not to endorse these technocratic institutions.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The outgoing candidate and mediator has so far carried out her task impartially and has taken steps to improve the transparency of TTIP traits. The Ombudsman is an important position in defending citizens from EU mismanagement. The means that are granted to this figure are not appropriate but the person deserves confidence. I will monitor the follow-up to your work.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — Since 1995 there has been the figure of the Ombudsman in the European institutions. The election of the Ombudsman is governed by Article 228 TFEU; is chosen for a period of 5 years coinciding with the legislature. The former defender, Fr. Nikiforos Diamandouros, resigned without concluding his term of office, being replaced by Emily O'Reilly, Irish Ombudsman since 2013 and former journalist. Although Mrs O'Reilly is the only candidate, we can say that, in the short period of time she has been at the head of the office in question, she has done a good job, highlighting the initiatives she has undertaken ex officio, such as studying the 'revolving doors' or launching the website to bring the institution closer to the citizens. In this line he announces that he will closely follow the problems of citizens. Mrs O'Reilly's hearing took place on 2 December in the Committee on Petitions.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. "I voted for Emily O'Reilly as European Ombudsman. The role of the Ombudsman is very important. Indeed, it is the bridge between citizens and the European institutions. Its mission is to strengthen the rights of European citizens by investigating cases of maladministration in European institutions and bodies. It is therefore an essential element of democratic control within the European Union. Ms. O'Reilly, who had been a Mediator since October 2013, did an admirable job. So I'm very happy to have voted for his re-election.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) One of the greatest challenges facing the European Union is to ensure the effective participation of all citizens in the life of the institutions and to ensure that, by means of a system which cannot be deficient, the greatest possible protection for the subjective positions and the widespread and collective interests of individuals are being apt. A bulwark of the democratic system, which achieves the effectiveness of protection even beyond that guaranteed by national laws, is given by the European Ombudsman. I voted in favour of the election of the European Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly for the next five years, the first woman to hold this post. I stress the crucial nature of the role and agree with his words: 'My aim last year was to start the process of taking the Ombudsman's office to the next level, with the adoption of a more strategic approach that will make it possible to increase the impact of the office, improve its relevance to citizens and improve overall efficiency'.  The task must be continued with determination, considering that the issues before the body concerned the lack of transparency in the European institutions (25% of all cases in 2013) and complaints about the right to participate in EU decision-making.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Emily O’Reilly for re-election to the role of European Ombudsman.  I was pleased to be one of the many MEPs to sign her nomination. It is evident by the fact that Ms O’Reilly was unopposed for this position that, in her relatively short period in the job, she has earned the good will and esteem of those of every political persuasion. As Ireland’s Ombudsman from 2003 and in the office of European Ombudsman since 2013 Emily O’Reilly has won the confidence of ordinary citizens as someone who is ‘on their side’. She has a big challenge ahead of her.  The European institutions have lost the confidence of citizens and communities across many Member States.  In many cases the manner in which the Council and Commission carry out their roles in secrecy, without transparency and with minimal public consultation, exacerbates this loss of confidence.
