The European Ombudsman has the responsibility to challenge these cultures within the European institutions.  As major decisions will be made in the next few years, including a possible conclusion on the TTIP negotiations, the Ombudsman will have serious work to do in demanding accountability.  I am extremely hopeful that Emily O’Reilly will be up to that job.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) I believe that the role of the European Ombudsman is fundamental, a role which unfortunately does not exist in Italy. We regret the presence of only one candidate and that Emily O'reilly's name was the only one to hold the office, given the absence of any candidacy.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) As a member of the Petitions Committee, I have seen in recent months how capable, competent and suitable Mrs O'Reilly has played her role since 2013. I have therefore rightly decided to confirm my confidence in you to continue with this task, in which you have so far shown that you are doing your duty properly. Congratulations!

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. — I voted for Emily O’Reilly as Ombudsman. Ms O’Reilly has consistently represented the rights of the citizens of the European Union. She has done so with true professionalism and with dignity. I would feel it important that she is allowed to continue the good work that she has been doing within her office.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I welcome today's decision appointing the European Ombudsman and thus allowing him to operate and carry out his important tasks in the general interest. I hope that with today's vote, it will be able to act with the utmost independence and transparency, to combat cases of maladministration by European institutions and bodies and, consequently, to strengthen the instruments for protecting the rights of EU citizens and to improve the efficiency of European administration. I also hope that the new Ombudsman will be able to strengthen that dialogue and that fruitful relationship between citizens and the EU, in order to promote the highest standards of conduct in the institutions and to increase citizens' confidence in Europe more generally.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The responsibilities of the European Ombudsman are considerable. It is by means of the European Ombudsman that European citizens are able to gain redress when an instance of maladministration occurs in an institution, body, office or agency of the European Union.  Emily O’Reilly, who has been nominated to stand for re-election, has already presented her priorities in a hearing organised by the Committee on Petitions. I voted in favour of her election as she has presented a very effective strategy to combine three objectives – ensure relevance, increase visibility and achieve a greater impact. This will be attained through the introduction of a modern complaint management system and greater use of the own-initiative power of the Ombudsman.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — On 2 September, the invitation to submit nominations for the election of the new European Ombudsman was published in the Official Journal. The only nomination received was that of the outgoing Mediator Emily O'Reilly, elected in July 2013 following the resignation of her predecessor Diamandouros. The European Ombudsman's responsibility is to follow up complaints from European citizens in the event of maladministration in an EU institution, body, office or agency. I hope that the fundamental objective of the Mediator, confirmed today, will be to make a contribution to improving the quality of democracy in the EU through a strengthening of transparency, ethics and participation in the decision-making process by European citizens.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the election of the candidate for the position of Ombudsman, because her views on critical political issues and their resolution are not considered satisfactory, and her professional experience is not considered appropriate for that position.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. — As first Vice-President of the Committee on Petitions of the European Parliament, the body responsible directly for relations with the European Ombudsman, I welcome the re-election of Emily O'Reilly. I have had the opportunity to meet with her and find many points of common interest, especially with regard to the rights of people with disabilities.  The role of the Office of the European Ombudsman is to investigate complaints for cases of maladministration in the institutions and bodies of the European Union. Complaints may be filed by citizens of the European Union, by residents of EU states, as well as by companies and associations based in Europe.  I hope that in this new legislature we have started to work closely and fruitfully in favour of the interests of European citizenship.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. — The only candidate received for the role of The European Ombudsman was that of the outgoing Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly, a candidacy confirmed during today's vote. The role of the European Ombudsman is of fundamental importance for the collection of reports of maladministration by the European institutions in order to ensure their prompt and effective response and resolution. The Ombudsman's work also aims to improve transparency and democratic participation within the European institutions.  The ombudsman's report for 2013 confirms her commitment to the task assigned to her, and in particular the many ongoing investigations into transparency in the TTIP negotiations, in the Commission's expert groups, in the cases of the so-called 'revolving door' and with regard to the fundamental rights of cohesion policy and the European citizens' initiative are to be welcomed.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. — As Socialists, we consider the Ombudsman's office to be one of the most important tools for bringing the EU closer to citizenship. Through this office, citizens can file their complaints and requests; it is also the guarantor of transparency and good practice within the European institutions. We must strive to make it more and more used by citizens every day and their usefulness is perceived. We believe that Mrs O'Reilly has shown her ability to hold this position in the last period, and we are confident in her good work and her ability to dialogue.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) My abstention stems from the fact that the figure of the European Ombudsman could play a very important role within the European Union. But since so far, of course, by political will, the role played has not been up to scratch, I shall vote because I cannot give my wholehearted support.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — Without having anything against the face of Mrs Emily O'Reilly (Ireland), and the institution, I voted against because I disagree with the way in which I am elected. Espite the fact that the vote was secret, he was the only candidate for the 2014-2019 term. I hope that from his position, the Ombudsman will make a unique contribution to overcoming the public's crisis of public confidence in the European institutions, stressing the concerns of the citizens, and I believe that it will make a positive contribution to bridging the gap between them and the Community institutions.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. — The protection and promotion of human rights and human dignity are the foundation of the construction and system of the European Union. In 2013, 2420 complaints were registered and, in total, 23245 citizens were helped by the Ombudsman. The role of the Ombudsman, who is responsible for the protection of these rights and a direct interlocutor of European citizens, is therefore of fundamental importance.  The promotion of good administration must be a top priority for the new Ombudsman. In a Europe perceived as a heavy administrative apparatus run by cold bureaucrats, good administration imposes more than just an abstention from misconduct. The Ombudsman's task will be to ensure that officials put themselves at the service of citizens in order to ensure that they are properly treated and that their rights are fully respected.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. — I am delighted to vote today on the candidacy of Emily O’Reilly for the role of Ombudsman, as I was equally delighted to sign her nomination papers for this position.  The European Ombudsman plays an important part in ensuring that EU institutions adhere to the principle of good administration and respect EU citizens’ rights under the Treaties and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.  The Ombudsman is independent, she is impartial and it is only right that she is. Her role is to ensure that European institutions abide by the principles of good administration and respect for EU citizens’ rights as guaranteed by the Treaties and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.  Ms O’Reilly has done an outstanding job as Ombudsman after taking over the position in 2013 following the retirement of Nikiforos Diamandouros and I am delighted to see her remain in place.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the candidate Ms Emily O'REILLY for the post of the European Ombudsman. Taking into consideration the fact that the independent European Ombudsman plays an important part in ensuring that EU institutions adhere to the principles of good administration and respect for EU citizens' rights under the Treaties and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, I am sure that Mrs Emily O'REILLY is a suitable candidate for the post of European Ombudsman. She has underlined the dangers of an over-reliance on the law as being detrimental to the requirements of good administration. She has also emphasised that the fundamental values and principles on which the EU is based, including fairness and justice, need to complement the law.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. — As Socialists, we consider the Ombudsman's office to be one of the most important tools for bringing the EU closer to citizenship. Through this office, citizens can file their complaints and requests; it is also the guarantor of transparency and good practice within the European institutions. We believe that Mrs O'Reilly has shown her ability to hold this position in the last period, and we are confident in her good work and her ability to dialogue.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted to re-elect Mrs Emily O'Reilly as European Ombudsman because the candidate's work and CV so far inspire confidence in the successful performance of the new mandate. Ms. O'Reilly has strongly advocated improving the quality of european union administration and has taken concrete action in this direction.  The Ombudsman's role in the overall European system is of particular importance for all EU citizens who encounter administration irregularities, discrimination, abuse of power and others. In my view, Ms O'Reilly will make a further contribution to the role of European Ombudsman in the coming term.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. "I voted to keep Emily O'Reilly as The European Ombudsman. The former Irish journalist had previously acted as a mediator in her country and had already been elected as the European Ombudsman in 2013. During this year, it has extensively modernized the function of Ombudsman and has focused its action on the transparency of institutions and the guarantee of fundamental rights. I welcome his re-election by a very large majority.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — The European Ombudsman plays a key role in securing the rights of EU citizens. Independent and impartial, it examines complaints against EU institutions, bodies and agencies and investigates cases of maladministration. During her previous term, Emily O'Reilly did an encouraging job in promoting the transparency of institutions and the protection of citizens' fundamental rights. I welcome his re-election as European Ombudsman.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of the reconfirmation of Candidate O'Reilly, as she has already demonstrated her commitment to gender equality and respect for fundamental rights. The European Ombudsman plays a strategic role for citizens, businesses and all EU organisations. Candidate O'Reilly has performed her role impeccably and has repeatedly helped to initiate and resolve cases of maladministration and human rights violations.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: In writing. — Referring to this point in the French EPP delegation, I voted in favour of the candidacy of Emily O'Reilly, who was re-elected as the European Ombudsman with 569 votes out of 751. Since her election in the summer of 2013, Ms O'Reilly has begun work to modernise the ombudsman's office, focusing in particular on the transparency of the Union's institutions. His new mandate will, I hope, enable him to continue on this path and to effectively defend the rights of European citizens. It should be remembered that the European Ombudsman is the defender of the rights of European citizens. It ensures transparency of procedures and compliance with the rules throughout the European institution.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — Since 1995 there has been the figure of the Ombudsman in the European institutions. The former defender, Fr. Nikiforos Diamandouros, resigned without concluding his term of office and was replaced by Emily O'Reilly, an Irish ombudsman since 2003 and a former journalist. In order to be elected, it needs to seek the signature of a minimum of forty Members from at least two Member States. Mrs. O'Reilly is the only candidate. I do not appreciate any reason to oppose his continuity and wish him every success in his new term.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — The Ombudsman shall act on the case lodged or on his own initiative in cases where mismanagement of eu authorities or institutions is noticed.  The responsibilities of the European Ombudsman are significant because it is through the European Ombudsman that European citizens can obtain redress in the event of irregularities in the activities of the institutions, bodies, offices or agencies of the European Union.  Ms. O'Reilly proved to be a quality candidate during the hearing with the necessary knowledge and experience to perform her duties, and therefore I support her candidacy for this responsible job.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. — By an absolute majority of 569 votes in case, the European Parliament re-elected Mrs Emily O'Reilly to the post of European Ombudsman and in the new parliamentary term 2014-2019.  I believe that it is difficult to make a better choice of person for this post, called to serve as a guarantor that the European institutions will invariably adhere to the principle of good administration in their work and strictly respect the rights of European citizens. The broad political support and her unequivocal candidacy are evidence of this. In the short time she held this post in the past term, following the resignation of Mr Nikiforus Diamandurus, Emily O'Reilly has been able to show that she firmly intends to make full use of the functions and powers that the European Ubudsman possesses for the sake of the people. Launching a variety of strategic inquiries in the public interest, respecting the principle of good governance in all decisions taken and highlighting the fact that the fundamental values on which the EU is built must complement Community legal norms are just some of the examples of Mrs O'Reilly's good and fruitful work. Work is also to be started on the implementation of the new "Towards 2019" strategy, whose main priorities are ensuring consistency, increasing visibility and achieving greater impact.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the election of Mrs O'Reilly considering her previous successful tenure as The European Ombudsman.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I was delighted to vote for the reappointment of the Ombudsman. I very much welcome the work she has done to bring transparency to the TTIP discussions.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — The European Ombudsman has a fundamental role to play: he helps to strengthen the democratic aspiration of the European Union by giving a voice to Community citizens. Mrs O'Reilly has shown over the past five years that she is able to act as an Ombudsman in an appropriate and balanced manner. She has made an important contribution to the resolution of cases of maladministration and human rights violations perpetrated by the Community institutions. I have great respect for Mrs O'Reilly and I am delighted that a woman is in such a high position. It is for these reasons that I have decided to vote, without hesitation, in favour of his re-election.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — Since I believe that Mrs Emily O'Reilly will carry out the tasks entrusted to her to the fullest satisfaction, I have received my approval of the proposal to appoint her as the new European Ombudsman. The filling of this post and the associated responsibility towards the European Union and its citizens is a challenge which it will do to the best of its knowledge and belief.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The European Ombudsman investigates complaints against EU institutions and bodies in case of maladministration. This occurs when an institution does not act in accordance with the law or respect the principles of good administration, for example in cases of administrative irregularities, abuse of power, lack of response, refusal of information or unnecessary delays. The candidate, Emily O'Reilly, was elected European Ombudsman in July 2013 after the retirement of her predecessor. In particular, it has launched investigations into the transparency of transatlantic negotiations or respect for fundamental rights within the framework of Frontex. I'm voting for.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The Ombudsman plays a very important role in relations between citizens and the European institutions. It is through him that the 500 million European citizens can raise their complaints and concerns in their relationship with the various European institutions. I am sure that the now-elected Ombudsman will fulfil her mandate in an exemplary way, so I wish her all the best. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I am delighted that the European Parliament has confirmed Emily O'Reilly as European Ombudsman with a very large majority. Joining his commitment to increase transparency within the institutions and actively combat the phenomenon of slippers, I wanted to support him. The position of European Ombudsman is a key function for greater efficiency and quality of administration in EU institutions and bodies. Its aim is to investigate complaints submitted by European citizens and residents, companies or associations established in the Union. I have full confidence in Emily O'Reilly's work and thank her for her commitment to implementing her new "Cap on 2019" strategy, which aims to ensure relevance and increase the visibility and integrity of public administration.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing — The Ombudsman's Institute has great weight as it contributes to ensuring high standards and transparency in the functioning of the EU institutions. Thanks to it, for example, it has recently slightly relaxed access to information on the forthcoming EU-US trade and investment agreement, which suffers from many shortcomings and poses some risks to the internal market and EU citizens.  Undoubtedly, the work to consolidate the application of the rule of law and the democratic functioning of the Union must continue to be deepened. I believe that today's choice is to move in this direction.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The European Ombudsman is responsible for investigating cases of maladministration in all EU institutions. In particular, it must ensure that the European institutions respect the principle of political neutrality (which is of course far from being obvious in the way they operate). The Ombudsman is elected by the European Parliament and has a five-year term of office. I voted against the election of the outgoing Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly not to endorse these technocratic institutions without any popular legitimacy.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome the election of Mrs O'Reilly as European Ombudsman for the excellent work she has done over the past few months and for showing her skills during the hearing before the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions. I am therefore sure that you will do an excellent job, succeeding in giving swift and effective answers to all those citizens who will report cases of maladministration by the EU institutions and bodies. I believe that our main objective, and in particular that of the Ombudsman, is to restore public confidence in the European administration, which will therefore have to demonstrate greater transparency, flexibility and efficiency. It is now a priority to provide citizens and legal persons with clearer rights and greater legal certainty with regard to their relations with the Administration of the Union, in order to restore a new confidence: this is no longer just a political necessity but a real cultural need!

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. "I voted for Mrs. O'Reilly because she has so far been very professional in her duties. It has shown that it serves our fellow citizens and plays a decisive role in making the European institutions less arbitrary and more transparent.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the appointment of Emily O'Reilly as European Ombudsman. It is a very responsible position, and its role, for example, is to protect the people of the European Union should they fall between the cogs of an institution. Emily O'Reilly has proven in the last year that she can do the job successfully.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — The role of the European Ombudsman is to investigate cases of maladministration in the Union's institutions. It fulfils the task of ensuring that the European institutions are managed effectively and politically neutrally (which is not self-evident in this institution...). The Ombudsman is elected by Parliament for a five-year term. I voted against the election of outgoing Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly in order not to endorse these technocratic institutions.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the re-election of Mrs Emily O'Reilly as European Ombudsman to which she was first elected on 3 July 2013 in the European Parliament. At the end of her brief first term, Ms O'Reilly presented a report on the European Ombudsman's actions during 2013.  I believe that until now, Mrs O'Reilly has done her duty well and has effectively represented the institution of the Ombudsman - a symbol of democracy and the rule of law. She presented her candidacy excellently to the Committee on Petitions during the hearing when she described her office's strategy for the next five years. It is important to point out that it presented this strategy for the period up to 2019 as a result of months of dialogue with representatives of civil society, the business sector, the European Parliament and the top people of the Institutions and Agencies of the European Union.  I wish Mrs O'Reilly a successful work in her new mandate and call on her to continue working with the European Parliament in achieving her ambition to take the Institution of the European Ombudsman to a higher level of effectiveness.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the election of Dr Emily O'REILLY because, as the outgoing European Ombudsman, she has certainly done a good job and I believe that, thanks to this experience, she can continue to hold the same post in the best possible way.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. — I supported the re-election of the European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly of Ireland. I am convinced that she has managed her five-year term so far and has moved the European Ombudsman's office further towards an effective institution that can help citizens of all Member States in their disputes with the European authorities over their maladministration.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — As the influence of the European Union increases on the daily lives of citizens, the European Ombudsman plays a key role in ensuring the legal compliance of the activities of the institutions. Integrity and a sense of justice are qualities that Emily O'Reilly was able to demonstrate during her previous term. That is why I am voting in favour of him reappointing him.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the re-election of Emily O'Reilly as European Ombudsman because I believe that the candidate has been properly in office since taking office in October 2013.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. — This vote was taken by secret ballot.  I believe that my constituents have a right to know how I voted on this issue, and therefore I wish to confirm for the record that my vote was against the Ombudsman.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. "This is a very good signal than the one sent on Tuesday lunchtime by the European Parliament, which confirmed Emily O'Reilly as European Ombudsman by a very large majority. Joining his commitment to increase transparency within institutions and the active fight against the phenomenon of slippers, I wanted to support him. The position of European Ombudsman is a key function for greater efficiency and quality of administration in EU institutions and bodies. Its aim is to investigate complaints submitted by European citizens and residents, companies or associations established in the Union. The outgoing Ombudsman, re-elected for the duration of the legislature, namely for five years, has resolutely embarked on an ambitious path, through her new strategy "Cap on 2019". The main objectives of this strategy, to increase the visibility and integrity of public administration, must be supported in this turbulent political period where the gap between European institutions and citizens continues to widen dangerously.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. " I voted for the continuity of Emily O'Reilly as Ombudsman. Having become the first Ombudsman in 2013, I believe it is necessary for her to remain at the forefront of an institution if it is more necessary than ever given the economic circumstances that Europe is going through. From her position, the Ombudsman can make a unique contribution to overcoming the crisis of citizens' confidence in the European institutions, highlighting the concerns of citizens and helping to bridge the gap between them and the Community institutions.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the re-election of Emilly O'Reilly as European Ombudsman, following the work she has been doing since October 2013, to whom I want a fruitful and committed mandate at the service of European citizens. Emilly O'Reilly was elected with 569 votes out of 678 votes cast, which demonstrates the confidence of this Parliament, both in the work it has been doing and in the objectives it has set out in its new Towards 2019 strategy, available on the European Ombudsman's website. Over the past year, I have played out its role in accessing the documents of the Agreement with the USA (TTIP) and in the context of the register of transparency of lobbyists with the European institutions and in the composition of the Commission Expert Groups.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. — (DE) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has done so. I am pleased with the re-election of Emily O'Reilly as European Ombudsman. The European Ombudsman is an important institution, because it can be addressed directly by citizens with complaints and have maladministration investigated. Although the Ombudsman can only make complaints and recommendations about what should be different, better and more citizen-friendly, her statement has a high political weight. Therefore, this body is an effective means of countering administrative arbitrariness and poor organisational structures in the EU bureaucracy! Ms O'Reilly has been in this position since last year and has many years of experience as an ombudsman in Ireland. It is good to have continuity with it for the next five years. I therefore wish her every success in the new term of office!

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Today I elected Emily O’Reilly European Ombudsman for the 2014-2019 parliamentary term. The responsibilities of the European Ombudsman are considerable. It is by means of the European Ombudsman that European citizens are able to gain redress when an instance of maladministration occurs in an institution, a body, an office or an agency of the European Union. Each year the Ombudsman submits a report to Parliament on the outcome of her enquiries

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I believe that the work of the current Ombudsperson is aimed at increasing the transparency and accountability of the European institutions and I therefore support her re-election. The Ombudsperson has shown through a series of moves that she wants to improve democratic processes in the European Union, and one example is the greater involvement of all process stakeholders when discussing key topics. In particular, I welcome the Ombudsperson's appeal to the Commission requesting public access to all relevant documents relating to the TRANSATLANTic Trade and Investment Agreement between the US and the EU. Key documents related to this agreement have not been made public, moreover most MEPs do not have access to them. Some areas of negotiation still raise many doubts, such as the issue of GMO products allowed on the US market. I commend the Ombudsperson's work so far, support her re-election and call on her to continue to work even harder to strengthen the democracy of the European Union.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. "I support Mrs. O'Reilly's election. The Ombudsperson's role is to act on the action lodged or on her own initiative in cases where mismanagement of eu authorities or institutions is noticed. Given that during the hearing and her experience, Mrs. O'Reilly has proven to be a quality candidate, I support her choice for the position. The responsibilities of the European Ombudsman are significant because, precisely through the European Ombudsman, European citizens can obtain redress in the event of irregularities in the activities of the institutions, bodies, offices or agencies of the European Union, and the legal protection of every citizen is a fundamental objective of the European Union.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. —I supported candidate Emily O'Reilly in electing a new European Ombudsman.  I think that at a time when politics and the public sector are dominated by men, it is positive to see a woman, at least when we speak in the context of equal gender representation. Emily O'Reilly, in addition to being a woman, is also the author of three books and has a proven career, responsibility and adequate skills to serve as European Ombudsman.  Commitments are numerous, but nevertheless, the key role of the "Ombudsman" is to make fair decisions regarding complaints about the work of administrations in the EU institutions. Also important is the task of ensuring transparency of work as well as making and implementing decisions in a politically neutral manner.  In my view, Ms O'Reilly has the right experience and will contribute to a more efficient and transparent functioning of the institutions as well as to communication with Union citizens.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of emily o'reilly's re-election as European Ombudsman, reci admitting both her personal experience and her work to date and the prominent role of the Ombudsman's institution in the functioning of an effective, transparent and democratic European Union. Although the European Ombudsman's role and powers do not extend to investigating governmental and official anomalies in individual Member States, he has an important guiding and encouraging role in the relationship between the European institutions, bodies and citizens, in particular in the fight against a close, open EU and euro scepticism. Its more successful and visible activities than ever before can be of particular encouragement to citizens of Member States where human and civil rights are still not fully enforced or where the government does not fully ensure the conditions for the functioning of the democratic rule of law in all respects. On the basis of a convincing vote from the EP, in this important mission, the European Ombudsman can rely on enhanced political support and legitimacy in the coming period.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the mediator, the only applicant and already in place. A majority of us have reiterated our confidence in his work.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the appointment of Mrs O'Reilly as European Ombudsman for the 2014-2019 legislature, because I believe that she should have the opportunity to continue her work, having first been chosen last July 2013. In addition, I very much value your previous experience as Ombudsman of Ireland. It is very important to have qualified people like Emily O'Reilly to directly respond to citizen requests in a Europe that must aspire to progressively approach its citizenship.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. — I support O'Reilly Emily's candidacy for European Ombudsman, as I consider that his candidacy meets all the conditions provided for in the rules for the performance of the duties already mentioned. I believe that the candidate has so far successfully served as Ombudsperson and I believe that with her further action she will successfully continue to investigate cases of mismanagement of the Institutions of the European Union, including the lack of transparency and the refusal to provide information or documents to citizens by too bureaucratic administration in the institutions and bodies of the European Union. During her career as a political editor, rapporteur and writer, she received significant domestic and international recognitions and in 2003 became the first woman to serve as Irish Ombudsperson. Her successful performance as European Ombudsman and past career achievements in the past term are my main reasons for supporting this candidate.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. — I supported the re-election of Emily O’Reilly as European Ombudsman for the 2014–2019 parliamentary term. Since October 2013, when she took office, Ms O’Reilly has been an efficient guardian of the rights of Europeans who complained about maladministration by European institutions. I was also satisfied with the results of the hearing on 2 December 2014, where Ms O’Reilly answered questions from Members of the PETI Committee.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — My vote in favour of the only candidate Emily O'Reilly is based on her defence of European citizenship, which perfectly exemplify her complaints of the Beaver case or the EU's foreign subsidies for purposes contrary to the interests of local companies in third countries.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — At the beginning of each parliamentary term, the President, immediately after his election or in the cases provided for at the end of paragraph 8 of this Article, shall call for applications for the appointment of the Ombudsman, setting the time limit for such submission. This appeal will be published in the Official Journal of the European Union. This is a normal procedure. We recognize the candidate's qualities. We have nothing to owe.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — The post of European Ombudsman is one which is characterised above all by many new challenges. Emily O'Reilly, in my opinion, represents this post responsibly and satisfactorily. That is why I voted in favour of her appointment as European Ombudsman.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the candidate for the European Ombudsman Ms Emily O’Reilly. I firmly believe that during her past mandate, Ms O’Reilly has shown a very proactive attitude in terms of the tasks assigned to her office. Moreover, thanks to her prior experience as an Irish National Ombudsman, Ms O’Reilly was able to start working efficiently very early during her term. In my capacity as a rapporteur on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2013, I had the privilege to observe the work of her team closely and I would like to congratulate her on the successful mission to increase transparency within the Institutions and on making the most of the instruments that are at her disposal. I fully support the fact that the role of the European Ombudsman is to highlight citizens’ concerns and help to bridge the gap between them and the EU Institutions. I firmly believe that the just re-elected European Ombudsman will endorse this challenge with great dedication.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing — Ms O'Reilly is a competent candidate and I therefore had no reason not to support her candidacy. However, if we voted on whether or not the European Union needed an Ombudsman, I would be in favour of the abolition of this post. I believe - and the inclusion of the Office of the European Ombudsman in the structure of the European Parliament confirms my view – that, in the context of the division of competences, the control of the European institutions should be exercised by MEPs. After all, in many respects, we also do this when we approve their budgets, their annual reports, we make interpellations, or we organise public hearings and exchanges of views with representatives of the Commission and the European agencies on the premises of the relevant committees. Citizens simply turn to their Members with their suggestions and expect them to deal with them personally, not to forward them to an unknown high official.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the election of Emily O'Reilly as European Ombudsman. I consider her very competent for this post. During the hearing, she answered all the questions referred in kind. First of all, I appreciate its cooperation with the responsible committees of the European Parliament in recent years, and I believe that this cooperation will be strengthened in the future.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — This report on the proposal for a Directive repealing Council Directive 93/5/EEC on assistance to the Commission by Member States and their cooperation in the scientific examination of food-related issues is part of the context of the Commission's current regulatory adequacy and effectiveness programme (REFIT), by which the Commission undertakes to repeal outdated and superfluous legislation. The aim of the Directive was to promote scientific support by Member States and to organise cooperation with national bodies competent in the field of food safety, in order to ensure the effective functioning of the Scientific Committee on Food, which in 2002 was replaced by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). As set out in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, EFSA becomes the competent body for the promotion of scientific cooperation, making Directive 93/5/EEC obsolete. Since it is a purely technical report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — Under the REFIT programme, the Commission is committed to making EU law simpler and reducing costs. The aim is to create a simple, clear, stable and predictable legal framework for businesses, workers and citizens. The REFIT programme recognised that the tasks of the Scientific Committee for Food, which was set up in Directive 93/5/EEC and set up from 1997 onwards, its opinions serve as a basis for EU legislation on, inter alia, consumer health and food safety, food consumption, toxicology and hygiene throughout the course of food production, nutrition or application of agri-food techniques, have been transferred to the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) by Regulation (EC) No 178/2002. I therefore welcome the repeal of Directive 93/5/EEC, as it has become obsolete.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — This motion related to a technical update of a Council Directive from 1993. I am advised that the matter concerned would be better determined individually by the member states.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal to repeal Directive 93/5/EEC on the scientific examination of matters relating to food. At the end of 2012, the Commission launched an EU Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme to enable businesses, workers and citizens to benefit from a simple and stable regulatory framework. In this way, the Commission has undertaken to abolish unnecessary or outdated rules. The purpose of the Council Directive on the scientific examination of food-related matters was to ensure the smooth functioning of the Scientific Committee for Food. Since the tasks conferred on this Committee have subsequently been taken over by the Scientific Committee and the European Food Safety Authority, I agree that the directive has become obsteous and should be repealed.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this text in order to ensure that the scientific committee on human food functions properly. This will encourage Member States to provide scientific support to this committee and organise cooperation with relevant national bodies on scientific issues relating to food safety.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council repeals The Council's Directive 93/5/EEC of 25 February 1993 on Member States' assistance to the Commission and their cooperation in the scientific examination of food issues. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) now carries out these missions. This repeal is the last step before a supranational body confiscates the sovereignty of the Member States where they previously cooperated freely with each other. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the measure transferring to EFSA the tasks of the Scientific Committee for Food referred to in Directive 93/5/EEC.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — In the context of the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT) launched in 2012 to ensure a simple, clear, stable and predictable regulatory framework for businesses, workers and citizens, the Commission is committed to repealing rules that have become superfluous or outdated. Directive 93/5/EEC aimed to ensure the effective functioning of the Scientific Committee on Food by promoting the scientific support of Member States and by organising cooperation with relevant national bodies on scientific issues relating to food safety. However, the scientific tasks entrusted to the Scientific Committee on Food have been assumed by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), which has also become the competent body to promote scientific cooperation with Member States and relevant national bodies operating in the areas comprising the Authority's role. Directive 93/5/EEC has become obsolete and I therefore voted in favour of repealing it for the sake of simplification, improvement and effectiveness of European legislation.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted on this report because it supports the repeal of an already obsolete directive, which was adopted back in 1995. The purpose of this Directive was to ensure the smooth functioning of the Scientific Committee on Foodstuffs by encouraging Member States to provide scientific support to the Commission and to ensure cooperation with national authorities on matters relating to food safety. Since 1995, the functions and objectives of this Directive have been taken over by other, newer legislation, making the 1995 Directive obsolete. The Commission has therefore decided to repeal the legislation adopted almost 20 years ago under the ongoing REFIT programme, which aims to simplify the EU legislative framework so that citizens, workers and businesses can benefit from a simple, clear, stable and predictable regulatory framework.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. — (IT) My support for the proposal is in line with the REFIT Programme launched by the Commission in 2012 to ensure a simpler, clearer regulatory system and a reduction in the Union's costs. The abolition of the Scientific Committee for Food is a step in this direction. With the entry into force of Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council, the tasks and powers of the Committee on Assistance to the European Commission and the cooperation of The Member States in the scientific examination of food issues have been assigned to the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). That is why, as was the case unanimously in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I voted in favour of repealing Directive 93/5/EEC.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for this report because I think that it is absolutely essential to have a good scientific cooperation between the Member States and the Commission in matters concerning food.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The repeal of Council Directive 93/5/EEC of 25 February 1993 is the final step in moving from a system where States cooperated among themselves on food security issues to a system of transfer of sovereignty to a supranational entity without any legitimacy. We have always fought and denounced these policies which take away their rights from the peoples of Europe and entrust them to administrations unknown to the general public and which are not accountable to the citizens. This absolute denial of democracy is unacceptable. Deeply committed to national sovereignty, I obviously voted against such a report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report repealing Council Directive 93/5/EEC of 25 February 1993 on assistance to the Commission and cooperation between Member States in the scientific examination of food-related issues. Following Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999, the Commission has adopted a list of the following The scientific tasks entrusted to the Scientific Committee on Food have been taken over by the Scientific Committee and the groups of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). EFSA has also become the competent body to promote scientific cooperation with Member States and competent national bodies operating in the areas within the Authority's competence. Thus, this report ensures a clear regulatory framework and in line with existing rules, which is intended to further strengthen the European framework for food safety. I believe that food safety in the EU and the world is an essential factor for the development of a healthy population, which automatically also drives economic growth and the harmonious development of society.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. This is the repeal of Directive 93/5/EEC. The tasks of the Scientific Committee for Food referred to in Directive 93/5/EEC have been transferred to EFSA and these tasks are currently governed by Regulation (EC) No 178/2002.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — Simple vote to apply the simplified procedure without amendments to a Directive establishing how Member States will contribute to the scientific examination of foodstuffs.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — The aim of Directive 93/5/EEC was to ensure the regularity of the work of the Scientific Committee for Food by promoting scientific support from the Member States and by organizing cooperation with the national bodies concerned on scientific questions relating to food safety. Today this Directive 93/5/EEC has become obsolete and needs to be repealed. The reason for this repeal is clear: Regulation 2002/178/EC provides for the establishment of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), which also includes the scientific cooperation of Member States and national bodies operating in the areas covered by the Authority. EFSA has therefore replaced the Scientific Committee for Food. Therefore, given that the intentions and reasons given by the Commission are clear, well-founded and exhaustive, but above all tend to streamline the procedural process, I have today decided to vote in favour of this report in order to repeal Directive 93/5/EEC.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion because the proposal repeals Directive 93/5/EEC on assistance to the Commission and cooperation by the Member States in the scientific examination of questions relating to food. The aim of this Directive initially was to ensure the smooth running of the Scientific Committee on Food. In 2002, however, the scientific tasks entrusted to the Scientific Committee on Food were taken over by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and Decision 97/579/EC establishing the Scientific Committee on Food was repealed. Directive 93/5/EEC has thus become obsolete.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. - This is a technical update of a Council directive from 1993, which I oppose.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — The purpose of this Directive is to ensure the regularity of the work of the Scientific Committee for Food by strengthening the cooperation of the Member States on scientific questions relating to food safety. The vote is in favour.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report proposed today by Mr De Clercq, on behalf of the Committee on The Protection of human Health and Industrial Policy. The Way, to which I would like to thank you for the work you have done, is part of the action launched by the European Commission in order to achieve a simple, clear, solid and predictable regulatory framework for companies, workers and citizens, with the aim of repealing obsolete legislation in order to give way to legislation more relevant to regulatory developments and needs.  This is the case with the repeal of Council Directive 93/5/EEC on the Scientific Committee for Food: a directive that has now been passed following the creation in 2002 of EFSA – the European Food Safety Authority – which independently and more structuredly provides the European institutions with scientific advice on the risks associated with the food chain.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour because I think it is appropriate to repeal Directive 93/5/EEC as obsolete.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) My vote in favour of this proposal is not only an act of confidence in President La Via, a colleague whom I respect and whose scientific preparation I appreciate, but it is also an act due to citizens who waste time with bureaucracy. In fact, this measure makes it possible to avoid duplication in the scientific controls of foodstuffs, since efsa is now responsible for everything. In this Europe, we must also peel off useless armchairs.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — Under the REFIT Programme for regulatory adequacy and effectiveness, the European Commission envisages measures to simplify European legislation and reduce regulatory costs, thereby contributing to a clear, stable, predictable and employment-effective regulatory framework. To this end, It seems clear to me to repeal Directive 93/5/EEC, which ensured the effective functioning of the Scientific Committee on Food by promoting scientific support from Member States and organising cooperation with national bodies responsible for food safety, as the European Food Safety Agency is the competent body in these areas by further legislation.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I supported, with my vote in favour, the repeal of this directive, which had become obsolete and which concerned assistance to the Commission and the cooperation of the Member States in the scientific examination of food-related issues, within the framework of the programme to monitor the adequacy and effectiveness of regulation. In particular, the tasks of the Scientific Committee for Food are now being carried out by the European Food Safety Authority and therefore, the directive we repealed no longer made sense to remain in force. So we were right to proceed with its repeal.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Directive 93/5/EEC of 25 February 1993 on assistance to the Commission and cooperation by the Member States in the scientific examination of questions relating to food, as Directive 93/5/EEC has become obsolete and should be replaced. This is being done in the spirit of achieving a simple, clear, stable and predictable regulatory framework for business, workers and citizens and thus supporting growth and jobs.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — In December 2012, the Commission launched the regulatory adequacy and effectiveness monitoring programme in order to ensure a simple, clear, robust and predictable regulatory framework for businesses, workers and citizens. Council Directive 93/5/EEC was intended to ensure the regularity of the work of the Scientific Committee for Food by promoting scientific support from the Member States of that Committee and by organizing cooperation with the national bodies concerned on scientific questions relating to food safety.  Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 lays down the general principles and requirements of food law, establishes the European Food Safety Authority and lays down procedures in the field of food safety, successfully exceeding Directive 93/5/EEC. As this is a technical matter, I can only vote in favour of it.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — This report on the proposal for a Directive repealing Council Directive 93/5/EEC on assistance to the Commission by Member States and their cooperation in the scientific examination of food-related issues is part of the context of the Commission's current regulatory adequacy and effectiveness programme (REFIT), by which the Commission undertakes to repeal outdated and superfluous legislation. The aim of the Directive was to promote scientific support by Member States and to organise cooperation with national bodies competent in the field of food safety, in order to ensure the effective functioning of the Scientific Committee on Food, which in 2002 was replaced by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). As set out in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, EFSA becomes the competent body for the promotion of scientific cooperation, making Directive 93/5/EEC obsolete. Since it is a purely technical report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. - In the context of the on-going Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT) launched in 2012 to ensure a simple, clear and predictable regulatory framework, it is proposed to repeal Directive 93/5/EEC on assistance to the Commission and cooperation by the Member States in the scientific examination of questions relating to food.  The aim of this Directive initially was to ensure the smooth running of the Scientific Committee on Food by promoting scientific support from the Member States and organising cooperation with the relevant national bodies on scientific issues regarding the safety of food. In 2002, however, the scientific tasks entrusted to the Scientific Committee on Food were taken over by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and Decision 97/579/EC establishing the Scientific Committee on Food was repealed. Directive 93/5/EEC has thus become obsolete. Hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. — I welcome the vote on the assistance to be given to the Commission and the cooperation between Member States in the scientific examination of food-related issues, and I agree to a simpler, clear and stable regulatory framework for both businesses and workers and citizens.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. In December 2012, the Commission pledged to promote more appropriate regulation to ensure a simple, clear, stable and predictable regulatory environment. It is in this context that the proposal for a directive repealing the directive on Member States' assistance to the Commission and their cooperation in the scientific examination of food-related issues is taking place. By entrusting the scientific mission previously entrusted to the Scientific Committee on Food to the European Food Safety Authority, the European Union is welcome to streamline its regulatory framework in this area.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. — Mr President, although this vote appears merely technical, it does provide an opportunity to reflect on the EU allergens legislation which came into effect only last week – and which stands to place constraints on food and catering operators across the Member States.  The new provision requires caterers to publicly display whether the food being served contains any of a range of approximately 13 allergens. This goes far beyond communication of commonly accepted allergens, including nuts and gluten – which is vital toward protecting people in our communities.  This regulation will place an added layer of compliance checks for workers, and although exemptions are in place for voluntary, non-formal caterers, there exists a level of uncertainty on the scope and burdens of the new law. I would strongly urge the European Commission to fill this void with effective information.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the report because Council Directive 93/5/EC is becoming obsolete.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - Under the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT), the Commission has undertaken to ensure a simple, clear, stable and predictable regulatory framework for businesses, workers and citizens. The establishment of ESA has made this body competent for the promotion of scientific cooperation with Member States and competent national bodies operating in the areas of the Authority's tasks and empowers it to act in close cooperation with the competent bodies of the Member States, and Member States should cooperate with ESEA in the pursuit of their tasks. Therefore, the repeal of the previous directive makes perfect sense.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — This report on the proposal for a Directive by the European Parliament and the Council repealing Council Directive 93/5/EEC, on Member States' assistance to the Commission and its cooperation in the scientific analysis of food-related issues, is part of the ongoing European Commission regulatory adequacy and effectiveness programme (REFIT), launched in 2012, where the Commission undertakes to repeal obsolete and superfluous legislation. The aim of the Directive in question was to promote scientific support by Member States and to organise cooperation with the competent national bodies on scientific issues relating to food safety in order to ensure the effective functioning of the Scientific Committee on Food which was replaced in its scientific tasks in 2002 by the European Food Safety Authority (ESA). Furthermore, under Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, EESA has also become the body responsible for promoting scientific cooperation with Member States and competent national bodies operating in the areas of competence of the Authority, with Directive 93/5/EEC obsolete. This is an eminently technical report, to which the simplified procedure (Article 50(1) has been applied and which we have voted in favour of.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — In the present case, this is a clear and predictable regulatory framework where the Commission has decided to replace outdated legislation in the field in question. This amendment will result in the repeal of Directive 93/5/EEC on assistance to the Commission and cooperation between Member States in the scientific examination of questions relating to foodstuffs. No objections were raised by Members to this proposal from the European Commission.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of the repeal of Regulation (EEC) No 93/5/EEC. The duties of the Scientific Committee for Food referred to in Directive 93/5/EEC have been transferred to EFSA and are now governed by Reg. (EC) No 178/2002.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — Council Directive 93/5/EC is becoming obsolete and I am therefore voting in favour of repealing it. Furthermore, the nature of the Council Directive does not require the explanatory documents provided for in the Joint Political Declaration of the Member States and the Commission of 28 September 2011.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. — (IT) I should like to vote in favour of the report by Mr La Via, which accepts the European Commission's proposal and repeals directive 93/5/EEC, which is now obsolete. With this vote, we are implementing the prerogatives of the European Food Safety Authority, thus incorporating the previous competences of the Scientific Committee for Food. This new parliamentary term will have to see food safety as one of the priorities of the European environmental agenda, which is why I hope that the committee will have full political and scientific support from the Member States, in particular by facilitating cooperation with the national bodies relevant to these issues.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — I voted against this directive. Although it is presented as the EU repealing an old directive, the EU Commission is actually substituting the Committee on Food with the European Food Safety Authority, giving the European Commission more power, promoting EU regulations further in this field.  This is the job of sovereign nations, not the EU.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which provides for the repeal of the directive on the scientific examination of food issues, which has become obsolete. This directive has not been used since the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) took over the scientific review of food issues. Faced with the bureaucratic burden on businesses and administrations, we must do everything we can to combat normative inflation and better legislate, by not hesitating to remove texts, such as this one, which have become useless.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour for the proposal for a directive on assistance to the Commission and cooperation by the Member States in the scientific examination of questions relating to food. I believe that it is necessary to ensure smooth cooperation with the relevant national bodies on scientific issues regarding the safety of foodstuffs.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. — I supported Mr La Viaʼs report because this is an example of how REFIT is being used to delete obsolete legislation – in this case Directive 93/5/EEC. This helps to ensure a simple, predictable regulatory framework for businesses, workers and EU citizens. Regulation 178/2002 established the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) as the competent body to promote scientific cooperation with Member States and to replace the Scientific Committee on Food referred to in Directive 93/5/EEC. This now means Directive 93/5/EEC is obsolete and should be repealed.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the repeal of this obsolete text.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution on repealing the Council Directive on assistance to the Commission and member states' cooperation in scientific consideration of food-related issues, as this repeals the rules that have become redundant and aged. As a result, I consider that a refreshed and clearer regulatory framework is needed for all businesses, workers and citizens, which is in line with the Regulatory Suitability and Performance Programme (REFIT).  The repeal of the Council directive in question was also given by making the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) a body for promoting scientific cooperation, taking over the activities entrusted to the Scientific Committee on Food.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of my colleague Giovanni La Via's report on the scientific examination of food issues. The text supports the repeal of this directive, the provisions of which had become obsolete. I therefore welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I agree to repeal this regulation. The scientific tasks entrusted to the Scientific Committee on Food were taken over years ago by the European Food Safety Agency making the regulation obsolete.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my report today aims to repeal Council Directive 93/5/EEC. It concerns assistance to the Commission and cooperation between Member States in the scientific examination of food-related matters. Repeal was necessary as part of the regulatory adequacy and effectiveness monitoring programme, in order to ensure a simpler and clearer regulatory framework for businesses, workers and citizens.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — With this debate, the Parliament is positioned on the Commission's proposed implementation of the Directive establishing how Member States will contribute to the scientific examination of foodstuffs, in which there are no reasons for my opposition.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — This report on the proposal for a Directive repealing Council Directive 93/5/EEC on assistance to the Commission by Member States and their cooperation in the scientific examination of food-related issues is part of the context of the Commission's current regulatory adequacy and effectiveness programme (REFIT), by which the Commission undertakes to repeal outdated and superfluous legislation. The aim of the Directive was to promote scientific support by Member States and to organise cooperation with national bodies competent in the field of food safety, in order to ensure the effective functioning of the Scientific Committee on Food, which in 2002 was replaced by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). As set out in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, EFSA becomes the competent body for the promotion of scientific cooperation, making Directive 93/5/EEC obsolete. Since it is a purely technical report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — In the context of the current Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT), which began in 2012 with a view to ensuring a simple and understandable regulatory framework, the Commission has committed to abolishing outdated laws. Accordingly, it is proposed to abolish both the Commission Assistance directive and member states' cooperation for scientific research and food testing purposes. Initially, the objective of this Directive was to ensure the continued work of the scientific committee on food by promoting scientific support from Member States and organising cooperation with competent government authorities on scientific issues relating to food safety. However, in 2002, the tasks entrusted to the Scientific Committee on Food were taken over by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). This outdated the Directive on assistance to the Commission and cooperation between Member States for scientific research and testing of food, and I supported this report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I abstained because the La Via report on the scientific examination of food-related issues does not adequately address the scientific examination of food-related issues.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I voted for this proposal which fits in to the Unionʼs commitment to achieving a simple, clear, stable and predictable regulatory framework for businesses, workers and citizens.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the proposal for a European Parliament directive repealing Council Directive 93/5/EEC on assistance to the Commission and cooperation between Member States in the scientific examination of food-related matters. Having become EFSA's body responsible for promoting scientific cooperation with Member States, this directive is no longer adapted to the regulatory change that has taken place.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) I agree with the need to repeal Council Directive 93/5/EEC on assistance to the Commission and the cooperation of the Member States in the scientific examination of food-related matters, within the framework of the programme to monitor the adequacy and effectiveness of the rules.  European businesses, workers and citizens must be guaranteed a simple, clear, solid and predictable regulatory framework. It is for these reasons that I felt it necessary to express my agreement with the report signed by Mr La Via.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — Since this vote represents a legal remedy in the sense of repealing an already outdated directive, I was able to vote in favour.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — Directive 93/5/EEC deals with the scientific examination of food issues. The aim of this directive was to ensure the proper functioning of the scientific committee on food. This is helped by scientific support from Member States and cooperation with relevant national bodies on food safety issues. But in 2002, the scientific tasks entrusted to the Scientific Committee on Food were taken over by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). Change of framework! Directive 93/5/EEC has therefore become obsolete. This is about repealing it, what a story! But it is to follow the current fitness and performance program of regulation (REFIT) launched in 2012. This proposal does not fundamentally change the scientific review of food issues. All for that... I'm voting for.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — In December 2012, the Commission launched the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT) to ensure a simple, clear, stable and predictable regulatory framework for businesses, workers and citizens. In this context, the Commission has undertaken to repeal the rules which have become superfluous or obsolete. This is the case with Council Directive 93/5/EEC of 25 February 1993, which is now being repealed. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — The aim of Council Directive 93/5/EEC was to ensure the smooth running of the Scientific Committee for Food by means of promoting the scientific support from the EU Member States and by also coordinating cooperation with all the relevant national bodies on scientific issues relating to the safety of foodstuffs.  This Directive has however become obsolete since the tasks entrusted to the Scientific Committee on Food have been taken over by the Scientific Committees and Panels within the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). EFSA has also taken over the tasks related to the promotion of scientific cooperation with the EU Member States and relevant national bodies operating in the fields falling within EFSA’s mission. I have therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. In the interests of legislative simplicity, it was necessary for the European Parliament to give its approval to repeal Directive 93/5/EEC. It had become obsolete after the adoption of Regulation (EC) 178/2002, which aimed to entrust the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) with the scientific review mission on food issues. This decision will have no impact on food security in Europe. It should be remembered that the Commission's guiding principle in this area is to apply an integrated approach to the barn at the table, covering all sectors of the food chain, namely: feed production, primary production, food processing, warehousing, transport and retail.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: In writing — The operation of the Scientific Committee for Food has been ensured by Council Directive 93/5/EEC. As the tasks of this Scientific Committee have already been passed on to the European Food Safety Authority, the so-called EFSA, according to the legislation in force, and this has also become a body for promoting scientific cooperation with the Member States and the competent national authorities, I voted in favour of repealing obstepsive Directive 93/5/EEC.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I support this report, which proposes to repeal Directive 93/5/EEC on assistance to the Commission and cooperation by the Member States in the scientific examination of questions relating to food. The ongoing Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT) was established in 2012 in order to ensure a simple, clear and predictable framework. That is why I have voted in favour, to repeal obsolete legislation.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The repeal of Council Directive 93/5/EEC of 25 February 1993 is the final step in moving from a system where States cooperated among themselves on food security issues to a system of transfer of sovereignty to a supranational entity without any legitimacy. We have always fought and denounced these policies which take away their rights from the peoples of Europe and entrust them to administrations unknown to the general public and which are not accountable to the citizens. This absolute denial of democracy is unacceptable. Deeply committed to national sovereignty, I obviously voted against such a report.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — The Commission has already proposed scrapping Council Directive 93/5/EEC on the running of the Scientific Committee for Food, as it is now obsolete. The duties of the committee have already been taken over by the Scientific Committee and panels of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA); therefore the Directive is redundant and should be repealed.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. The Route because I consider Council Directive 93/5/EEC on assistance to the Commission and cooperation between Member States in the scientific examination of food issues to be obsolete as part of the programme to monitor the adequacy and effectiveness of regulation in order to guarantee businesses, workers and citizens a simple and clear regulatory framework.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — Food safety monitoring is currently carried out by EFSA. The vote included the repeal of an obsolete previous directive, which related to EFSA's predecessor agency. The repeal of this directive is therefore intended to depaint European law and reduce bureaucracy. I therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This is a technical report aimed at repealing an outdated directive, because since the european Parliament and the Council's Regulation 178/2002 came into force, the scientific mission entrusted to the Scientific Committee on Human Food has been carried out by the Scientific Committee and the scientific groups of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). Therefore, I saw no obstacles to vote for.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the draft because it will enable a simple, clear, stable and predictable regulatory framework for businesses and citizens to be achieved.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Considering that EFSA's support and cooperation with member states' scientific bodies on food safety is an essential tool for ensuring greater consumer protection, I would like to vote in favour.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Directive 93/5/EEC of 25 February 1993 on assistance to the Commission and the participation of Member States in the scientific study of food-related issues. In December 2012, the Commission launched the Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT) to provide a simple, clear, stable and predictable regulatory framework for businesses, workers and citizens. In this context, the Commission has committed itself to repealing the rules that have become redundant or obsolete. In accordance with Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council, the scientific tasks entrusted to the Scientific Committee for Food have been taken over by the Scientific Committee and the Councils of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). In accordance with Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, EFSA has also become the competent authority to promote scientific cooperation with Member States and the relevant national authorities active in the fields of mission of the Agency. Council Directive 93/5/EEC has thus become obsolete and should be repealed.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — The repeal of Council Directive 93/5/EEC of 25 February 1993 is the final step in moving from a system where States cooperated with each other on the issue of food security to one where they delegate their sovereignty to a supranational entity without legitimacy. We have long denounced this development, which takes away their power from the peoples of Europe and entrusts all authority to administrations unknown to the public and which are not accountable to any voter. This ever-increasing denial of democracy is not acceptable. I therefore speak out against this report.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — The objective of Council Directive 93/5/EEC was to ensure the seamless work of the Food Science Committee by promoting member states' scientific support and organising cooperation with relevant national authorities on scientific issues in the field of food safety. The tasks of the Scientific Committee on Food under the Directive have been transferred to the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) and are currently required by Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013. 178/2002 of the European Parliament and the Council. The Commission committed to repealing redundant and outdated rules when it launched the Regulation Adequacy and Performance Programme (REFIT) and therefore supported colleague La Vie's report on repealing the directive.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the proposal for a Directive repealing Directive 93/5/EEC on assistance to the Commission and cooperation between Member States in the scientific examination of food-related matters, because the tasks of the Scientific Committee for Food referred to in Directive 93/5/EEC have been transferred to the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and, consequently, these tasks are governed by Regulation (EC) No 178/2002. EFSA has become, thanks to the regulation mentioned above, the competent body to promote scientific cooperation with Member States and it is expressly stated that EFSA must act in close cooperation with the competent bodies of the Member States and that Member States must work with EFSA on its mission. It seems clear to me that it was logical to repeal Directive 93/5/EEC because it was obsolete.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — It is nice to see that the European Commission is fulfilling its obligations towards the citizen for a change.
