In the light of developments in recent years, it is indeed time to withdraw the outdated directive under discussion. This legal clutter may well serve as a model for many other areas of the EU. The Commission and Parliament would be well advised to deal, on the one hand, with the need, or rather with the non-necessity of a whole series of regulations. Furthermore, the EU must learn to withdraw for the benefit of its citizens, rather than extending itself to every area of people's lives to a seemingly limitless extent.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. "We needed to modernize the legislation on safety and food. Therefore, I am in favour of a measure to repeal inoperative legislation.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — Council Directive 93/5/EEC of 25 February 1993 aimed to ensure the effective functioning of the Scientific Committee on Food by promoting scientific support by Member States and by organising cooperation with national competent bodies on scientific issues relating to food safety. It is clear, however, that under Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 of the European Parliament and the Council of 28 January 2002, the tasks of the Scientific Committee on Food were transferred to the European Food Safety Authority and, consequently, Commission Decision 97/579/EC of 23 July 1997, which established that Committee, was repealed. Directive 93/5/EEC has therefore become obsolete and it must therefore be repealed, as proposed by the Commission. I voted in favour.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. — This report streamlines existing Eu-food control procedures. This text is part of the REFIT programme, which aims to abolish unnecessary EU legislation. With this vote, we endorse the abolition of a directive that has become obsolete following the entry into office of the European Food Safety Authority. I encourage these kinds of initiatives, which call on the European Union to focus on the essentials, not to drown in normative details.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — In the context of the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT) launched in 2012 to ensure a simple, clear, stable and predictable regulatory framework for businesses, workers and citizens, the Commission is committed to repealing rules that have become superfluous or outdated. Directive 93/5/EEC aimed to ensure the effective functioning of the Scientific Committee on Food, promoting the scientific support of Member States and organising cooperation with relevant national bodies on scientific issues relating to food safety. However, the scientific tasks entrusted to the Scientific Committee on Food have been assumed by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), which has also become the competent body to promote scientific cooperation with Member States and relevant national bodies operating in the areas comprising the Authority's role. Directive 93/5/EEC has become obsolete and I therefore voted in favour of repealing it for the sake of simplification, improvement and effectiveness of European legislation.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — The Scientific Committee on Food was initially established in 1974 (and subsequently amended by Decision 97/579/EC, which set up scientific committees in the field of consumer health and food safety).  In 1993, with Council Directive 93/5/EEC, it was aimed at greater efficiency in the functioning of the Committee by promoting scientific support from Member States and by organising cooperation with the competent national bodies on scientific issues relating to food safety.  With the adoption of Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, the functions of the Scientific Committee on Food were transferred to the European Food Safety Authority (ESA), and Decision 97/579/EC was subsequently repealed. Directive 93/5/EEC has thus become obsolete, leading to the presentation of the proposal of the European Parliament and the Council which gave rise to the report voted here today. Given that this proposal for a directive was taken up by Parliament in this report and drawn up under the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT) - where the Commission has committed to clear and predictable regulation for businesses, workers and citizens, repealing the rules that have become superfluous and obsolete - I voted for it.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this text because it is part of the efforts to simplify the legislation undertaken by the European Commission since 2012. Indeed, the directive referred to in this text concerns scientific cooperation between Member States and the Commission on food. This cooperation is now managed by the European Food Safety Authority.  As this legislation has become obsolete, the European Parliament has voted to abolish it, in line with clear and coherent European legislation.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - I have chosen to vote in favour because the tasks of the Scientific Committee for Food, as referred to in Directive 93/5/EEC, have been transferred to EFSA and these tasks are currently governed by Regulation (EC) No 178/2002.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - This report on the proposal for a Directive repealing Council Directive 93/5/EEC on assistance to the Commission by Member States and their cooperation in the scientific examination of food-related issues is part of the context of the Commission's current regulatory adequacy and effectiveness programme (REFIT), which undertakes to repeal outdated and superfluous legislation. The aim of the Directive was to promote scientific support by Member States and to organise cooperation with national bodies competent in the field of food safety, in order to ensure the effective functioning of the Scientific Committee on Food, which in 2002 was replaced by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). As set out in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, EFSA becomes the competent body for the promotion of scientific cooperation, making Directive 93/5/EEC obsolete. Since it is a purely technical report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Directive 93/5/EEC of 25 February 1993 on assistance to the Commission and cooperation by the Member States in the scientific examination of questions relating to food.  The tasks of the Scientific Committee on Food referred to in Directive 93/5/EEC have been transferred to the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), and those tasks are currently provided for by Regulation (EC) No 178/2002. EFSA has also become the competent body to promote scientific cooperation with the Member States and relevant national bodies operating in the fields falling within EFSA’s mission. Directive 93/5/EEC had therefore become obsolete and has now been repealed.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I supported this proposal abolishing the Scientific Committee on Food and transferring all its powers in 1993 to the European Food Safety Authority.  I believe that this decision will bring us one step closer to healthier and better controlled food within the European Union single market.  The effective functioning of the European Food Safety Agency is of utmost importance due to the ongoing threats of GM foods and the lowering of standards due to the Transatlantic Trade Agreement (TTIP). The results of recent monitoring of maize crops in Germany, Switzerland and Belgium have shown that we need to be more cautious about controlling the only GM plant whose commercial cultivation is allowed on EU territory. Namely, gm maize pollen can contaminate crops at a distance of more than four kilometres and therefore the European Food Safety Agency needs to further examine the scale and implications of the spread. I expect independence and scientific expertise from this agency to protect European consumers and agriculture.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I have supported this Directive by the European Parliament and the Council on the repeal of Council Directive 93/5/EEC since 25 February 1993 on assistance to the Commission and cooperation between Member States in scientific consideration of food-related issues, as the directive itself has become redundant. In accordance with Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013, the 178/2002 of the European Parliament and the Council, the tasks of the Food Science Committee of Directive 93/5/EEC have been transferred to the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) and these tasks are currently required by Regulation (EC) No 100/2013. 178/2002 Accordingly, EFSA has also become a competent authority to promote scientific cooperation with Member States and relevant national authorities operating in areas under the EFSA mission. Article 22 Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013 178/2002 in particular, it prescribes the close cooperation of EFSA with the competent authorities in the Member States and vice versa, in order to ensure the achievement of its mission.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I supported this legislative proposal, as it primarily provides a clear, stable and predictable regulatory framework for businesses, workers and citizens. It amends directives that do not comply with the market requirements that industries face today. It provides scientific support to Member States and organises cooperation with competent government authorities on scientific issues relating to the safety of food products. To this end, cooperation with the European Food Safety Agency needs to be renewed.  All these changes are essential for improving the legal regulation and the real security of the citizens of the European Union.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The Commission proposal does not have a negative impact on the EU P/O and the nature of the Council Directive in this thematic set does not require the explanatory documents provided for in the Joint Political Declaration of the Member States and the Commission of 28 September 2011.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Directive 93/5/EEC of 25 February 1993 on the support and cooperation of the Member States in the scientific examination of food matters. The Commission has previously launched a programme to provide businesses, workers and citizens with a simple, clear, stable and predictable regulatory framework. In this context, the Commission has committed itself to repealing the rules which have become redundant or obsolete. The purpose of the Directive to be repealed was to ensure the proper functioning of the Scientific Committee for Food by encouraging scientific support from Member States and by organising cooperation with the competent national bodies on scientific issues relating to food safety. Under Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, EFSA has become the competent authority responsible for organising scientific cooperation with the Member States and with the relevant national bodies active in the areas covered by the Authority's mission. In my opinion, simplification steps such as this create the foundations for the effective functioning of the European Union. These are not only technical amendments, but also lead to positive changes in the daily lives of EU citizens.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of my colleague La Via's text. I regret, however, on the one hand, that the text was published so late and, on the other hand, that the debate which was to take place on the Monday before the vote was cancelled. I think it should have taken place.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. — I support the Commission's proposal to repeal Council Directive 93/5/EEC on assistance to the Commission and member states' cooperation in scientific consideration of food-related issues. In my view, the Commission's obligation to repeal outdated and redundant rules and to provide a simple, stable and predictable regulatory framework for businesses, workers and citizens through the new proposal. Guided by data on the work of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), I support the Agency's close cooperation with the competent authorities in the Member States to ensure maximum efficiency when fulfilling its mission. The work of the European Food Safety Authority ensures a mechanism for information sharing and cooperation between competent national authorities on scientific issues in the field of food safety.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — My vote in favour of the review of Directive 93/5/EEC, which has become completely obsolete, as the coordinators of the Committee on the Environment unanimously agreed.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — This report is part of the European Commission's ongoing regulatory adequacy and effectiveness programme (REFIT), launched in 2012, where the Commission undertakes to repeal obsolete and superfluous legislation. The aim of the Directive in question was to promote scientific support by Member States and to organise cooperation with the competent national bodies on scientific issues relating to food safety in order to ensure the effective functioning of the Scientific Committee on Food which was replaced in its scientific tasks in 2002 by the European Food Safety Authority (ESA).  ESA, pursuant to Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, has become the body responsible for promoting scientific cooperation with Member States and competent national bodies operating in the areas of authority competence, with Directive 93/5/EEC obsolete.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. - Food safety and the creation of the best conditions for ensuring public health are a constant concern of the EU. This concern is all the more current, as the public debate generated by the EU negotiations for the conclusion of new free trade agreements has brought many concerns of European citizens to the public's attention. The EU must ensure the highest standards of food safety, and this objective must be achieved on the basis of scientific processes.  That is why I voted for the report on the scientific examination of food issues. This report repeals Council Directive 93/5/EEC, which has become obsolete, thus bringing european legislation up to date.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive by the European Parliament and the Council repealing Council Directive 93/5/EEC, 25 February 1993 on Member States' assistance to the Commission and its cooperation in the scientific analysis of food-related issues, as it fulfils the objective of ensuring the effective functioning of the Scientific Committee on Food, by promoting scientific support by Member States and by organising cooperation with national competent bodies on scientific issues relating to food safety.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — This report is part of the ongoing European Commission regulatory adequacy and effectiveness programme (REFIT), launched in 2012, where the Commission undertakes to repeal obsolete and superfluous legislation. The aim of the Directive in question was to promote scientific support from MS and to organise cooperation with the competent national bodies on scientific issues relating to food safety in order to ensure the effective functioning of the Scientific Committee on Food which was replaced in its scientific tasks in 2002 by the European Food Safety Authority (ESA). Furthermore, under Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, EESA has also become the body responsible for promoting scientific cooperation with Member States and competent national bodies operating in the areas of competence of the Authority, with Directive 93/5/EEC obsolete.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: Madam President, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora is a major international instrument and this motion allows the EU to become part of that. The primary aim of the Convention is to ensure that international trade in specimens of wild animals and plants does not threaten their survival. This trade and associated levels of exploitation of some animal and plant species is capable of heavily depleting their populations and even bringing some species close to extinction.  Because the trade in wild animals and plants crosses borders between countries, the effort to regulate it requires international cooperation to safeguard certain species from over-exploitation. As well as associated cruelty and loss of national heritage, decreased biodiversity, however it occurs, has a knock-on impact on people and industries around the globe and cannot be taken too seriously. The Sinn Féin MEPs supported this resolution.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: The CITES International Convention protects some 35,000 species of flora and fauna from the risk of extinction. The Accession of the European Union to CITES is a very important step, not so much because it becomes a full member of the Convention, thus playing an active role within cites, but rather because the Eu ropean Union will be able to take a leading role at international level on environmental policy, especially in safeguarding biodiversity, where the European Union has the most advanced legislation. The turnover of international trade in exotic species is several billion euros per year and Europe, for some species, such as the buoy, is the world's leading importer and the second largest importer of felines. CITES is the most important instrument for combating smuggling and illegal trade in many species of flora and fauna. The Union's accession to the Convention can only strengthen this fight. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: Madam President, I support the accession of the EU to the CITES Convention. Currently, all 28 Member States are already signed up, so one might wonder what the EU accession adds. What value do we get out of being signed up altogether, rather than separately? I have never attended a CITES meeting, but I understand that the EU Member States do not always speak with one voice; that they sometimes take quite different positions despite the fact that they are all signed up to the same Convention. This will give us the opportunity to negotiate the EU position first, and we would be in the position then to fight very much at the weight we are, that is, representing all the citizens of Europe in this very important issue. The trade in exotic species is estimated to be the third biggest illegal trade, following those in drugs and humans, and it is therefore vitally important that the EU stand together to fight.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President! I think we almost all agree that it is good that the European Union has acceded to the Convention.  One can, of course, ask oneanother, why only now? The truth is, of course, that this has not been possible. So far, only Member States and no associations have been able to join. This has been possible since 29 November 2013. I am also glad that we have seized the opportunity, together as the European Union, to throw our weight behind it. Mrs Girling was right to say that we must, of course, make use of this.  That is why I think it is also a good day for the endangered wildlife. After all, the Convention covers 35 species, and it has rightly been said that there is still a great deal of abuse in the case of illegal imports and exports. Finally, good news: the European Union must, of course, also pay membership fees, but this amount will be reduced by the Member States' membership fees. This is good news for the Member States of the European Union. They now have to pay less, because the contributions are borne by the European Union.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: Madam President, I can join my colleagues in welcoming our accession to this Convention for exactly the same reasons, but I have one additional reason. It is a species in my own country which is endangered. It is called pro-European Conservatives. They have many predators in their own party and I think they should be listed as an endangered species and afforded particular protection from their aggressors within their own political party.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Madam President, trade is not necessarily the enemy of conservation. Providing people with an incentive to treat endangered species as a renewable resource can often be a strong ally of the endangered species. I have mentioned in this Chamber before the contrasting stories of what has happened to elephants in Kenya, which banned the hunting of all elephants and then saw a calamitous decline in numbers, as against Zimbabwe, which declared them to be the property of whoever’s land they were on and has seen an explosion in numbers because people were effectively encouraged to farm the elephants or to treat them as a valuable resource. This is not really about CITES. All 28 Member States are individually signed up to that. This is about the European Union progressively taking on the attributes and trappings of statehood, including what it regards as the necessary right to speak on behalf of its Member States in international forums. Surely this is something that each of the member countries can decide for itself, through its own democratic mechanisms and procedures.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the illegal trade in endangered species of wild animals and plants is a global problem and therefore calls for a global approach. The CITES International Convention is the most important instrument in this fight. It is about the survival of rare species of animals and plants, but also about our safety, about peace. Illegal trade in rare animals and plants and their derivatives is, after all, a multi-billion dollar business. The profits often finance war and terrorism. My party NVA wholeheartedly supports the accession of the European Union to CITES and we voted in favour. Until now, only the individual Member States were members and the EU was only an observer. With accession, there is greater legal transparency about the precise role of the EU and we are increasing our effectiveness without compromising the division of powers between the EU and the Member States.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. — Today UKIP voted against the Ayuso report on the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES). This vote was not about CITES itself. We support the objectives of the CITES convention. This vote was about enhancing the status of the European Commission within the CITES structure which we are not prepared to support. We are also against the related budgetary implications.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is an international agreement aimed at ensuring that international trade in wild fauna and flora does not threaten their survival, mainly those of high commercial interest. CITES's success depends on the effective implementation of the agreed recommendations. The EU maintains observer status in CITES. The aim of this report is to approve EU accession to CITES in order to enable it to participate fully in its work and to link the EU and Member States to the implementation and control of implementation provided for in the Convention itself. That's why I voted for it.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), in force since 1975, is an international agreement aimed at regulating international trade in these species of animals and plants so that their survival is not jeopardised. Until now, the EU had observer status, as the original agreement only included states among its parties. The amendment to the agreement, which entered into force in 2013, now allows the EU to become a full contracting party. This allows it to be adequately represented at CITES meetings and to participate fully in the various work of the Convention. I therefore welcome the Council's decision to allow the accession of the EU, because the EU can now legally apply and enforce this agreement. In addition, this accession will also ensure that the EU can fully pursue its environmental objectives.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — This report called for the spending of taxpayers’ money on the promotion of the European Commission and its policies.   Some of the content of this resolution may well be laudable and my vote should not be taken to construe that I oppose positive steps in terms of protecting endangered species. I believe that nation states should co-operate in these matters.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to confirm the EU's accession to CITES. The CITES Convention is a key international instrument for the protection of endangered species of fauna and flora by controlling international trade in specimens of these species. The Convention entered into force in 1975 and includes 178 countries (including all EU Member States). It covers about 35 000 species. The import, export and import from the sea of these species must be authorised under the licensing system. At the end of 2013, the EU gained the opportunity to become a cites country. I agree that the EU's accession to CITES is a necessary step to ensure that the EU is fully capable of achieving its environmental policy objectives. I believe that accession would enable the Commission to express a coherent EU position on CITES on behalf of the EU and give the EU a stronger role in the negotiations at the CITES conferences.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — The European Union had only observer status at the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). With this vote, the Union will join CITES and will be able to be represented at the meetings and participate fully in the work of the convention. It will have a say in all areas that affect it and directly affect it.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report as the proposal for a Council Decision aims to approve the European Union's accession to CITES and to urge the President of the Council to appoint the person empowered to deposit the instrument of accession provided for in Article XXI(1) , of the Convention and of the declaration of jurisdiction provided for in Article XXI(3) thereo. The accession of the European Union to CITES will enable it to be adequately represented in and play a full role in the work of the Convention, in accordance with the Treaties and established practices on external representation. It will enable the Commission, on behalf of the European Union, to lead the negotiations and serve as a catalyst for balanced compromise solutions between the positions of the 28 Member States. By becoming a CITES Party, the European Union will assume formal obligations and be held accountable to the other Parties with respect to its implementation of the Convention.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The Convention on International Trade of Endangered Species (CITES) is an intergovernmental agreement signed on March 3, 1973 in Washington. CITES must ensure that international trade in the species listed in its annexes, as well as the parts and products that come from them, does not harm biodiversity conservation and is based on sustainable use of wildlife.  This convention, which is imperfect, is very useful in its objective of protecting endangered species. Currently, Member States sit individually within CITES. The accession of the European Union to CITES will lead to a further loss of sovereignty for the States since from now on the Union will have the vote of all The Member States at the conferences. I have therefore spoken out against the UNION's accession to CITES.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against this measure in principle: the signing of treaties and conventions should be the exclusive competence of the Member States which are bound by them.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is a major international instrument aimed at protecting threatened species of fauna and flora through controls on international trade in specimens of wild fauna and flora. In force since 1975, it currently has 178 Parties, including all EU Member States. It comprises some 35,000 protected species and ensures that international trade in specimens of wild animals and plants does not endanger their survival. Any import, export, re-export and introduction of the species included in the Convention must be authorized by means of a licensing system. However, until the entry into force of the decision taken at the Botswana Conference (2013) to allow supranational bodies to accede to the Convention, the EU had not been able to become a Party and had only observer status in the Convention.  I voted in favour of the rapporteur's recommendation to approve EU accession to CITES, which will allow the EU to participate and negotiate with one voice at the summits, strengthening our role and negotiating capacity.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supports the accession of the European Union to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). This international trade in endangered species of wild fauna and flora, adopted back in 1975, is the main international instrument for protecting endangered species of fauna and flora by controlling international trade in specimens of those species. There are 178 countries (including all EU Member States) parties to this Convention and cover around 35 000 species of flora and fauna. These species are broken down according to the level of protection they need and the Convention aims to ensure that international trade in specimens of those species does not jeopardise their survival.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. — This international instrument to protect endangered species of flora and fauna, even if imperfect, may be of some use. I regret that the debates in the Committee on Legal Affairs and in plenary focused on the legal basis of the text. It does not matter whether the basis is Article 192 on the environment or a combination with Article 207 under the Common Trade Policy. Rather, it would be appropriate to question the true usefulness of this text. Indeed, as the rapporteur pointed out, "the decision-making will be the same." Is this necessary, therefore, since different Member States are already parties to the Convention? Essential only for those who continue to strive towards this path of transfer of sovereignty, the outcome of which can only be fatal. Indeed, the European Union will have the right to vote instead of the Member States. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I supported this report because I think it is important that we in the European Union and especially the Member States take strong measures to protect fauna and flora diversity on the planet.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this recommendation on the accession of the European Union to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. The fact that the European Union can join cites as an observer member demonstrates that the EU is fully capable of pursuing its own objectives in line with its environmental policy. The Convention on International Trade in Wild Fauna and Flowers (CITES) to which 178 countries, including all EU Member States, are a party, is an important international instrument aimed at protecting endangered species of fauna and fauna through controls of international trade in specimens of more than 35 000 species. Given that the European Union is an economic and political partnership, its accession to the Convention is nothing more than a normal step, whereby European fauna and flora will be much better protected and preserved.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against EU membership of CITES. Signing treaties and conventions should be the exclusive competence of the Member States, which must have the right to legislate on this matter independently and on the basis of their commercial interests.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — Simple vote on the recommendation in favour of the Council Decision on EU accession to CITES. The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is a major international instrument aimed at protecting endangered species of fauna and flora through controls on international trade in specimens of these species. It entered into force in 1975 and currently has 178 Parties (including all EU Member States). It comprises some 35,000 species, listed in three appendices depending on the degree of protection they need, and ensures that international trade in specimens of wild animals and plants does not jeopardize their survival. Any import, export, re-export and introduction from the species closed in the Convention must be authorized by means of a licensing system. However, until the entry into force of a decision taken at the Botswana Conference (2013), which is to allow supranational bodies to accede to the Convention, the EU had not been able to become a Party and it was the sum of the Member States that determined the European position.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the accession of the European Union to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). In view of the fact that the European Union has undertaken since 1 January 1984 to fully implement the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), although it has not formally joined it, I believe that its accession represents a natural development in a process which will finally enable the European Union to be adequately represented in the work of the Convention and to play its role effectively. By hering to CITIES, the Eu ropean Union will further strengthen its leadership in animal protection and environmental policy, ensuring that international trade in endangered specimens does not reduce its survival at Eu ropean and international level. Furthermore, I believe that accession can increase the coherence and unity of the European Union's action on CITES issues and lead to greater alignment of member states' positions.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. - This promotes the European Commission and its policies, which I oppose. Furthermore, it allows for further funding, which is an extra burden on the British taxpayer.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - EU accession to CITES, which came into force in 1975, is an important step towards strengthening the protection of endangered flora and fauna. The vote is in favour

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour because I believe that the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora is an important international instrument to protect the species under consideration. It is appropriate and reasonable that the import, export and re-export and introduction by sea of the species covered by the Convention should be authorised by means of a licensing system. In this respect, I believe that CITES is a logical and necessary step so that the European Union can be fully able to pursue the objectives it has set itself within the framework of its environmental policy.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — One of the main reasons why the existence of the EU makes sense is related to the role that small and medium-sized states (think of Italy, which with its 60 million inhabitants is on a different order of magnitude than India, China and the United States) could not otherwise have in major world issues. Well, CITES is one of those tables in which it makes sense to participate as the European Union, rather than as individual states. I therefore voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), in force since 1975, is an important international instrument for the protection of endangered species of fauna and flora by monitoring international trade in specimens of these species. The initial text of the Convention limited participation in CITES to States, and the European Union was only observant. The Gaborone Amendment, adopted on 30 April 1983, made it possible to adopt economic and regional integration organisations consisting of sovereign states with the power to negotiate, conclude and implement international agreements on matters covered by the Convention, and the amendment entered into force on 29 November 2013. I support THE EU's membership of CITES, which will make the EU's legal status more transparent vis-à-vis the other parties to the Convention. On the other hand, the EU will be adequately represented at CITES meetings and will participate fully in the work of the Convention in accordance with the Treaties. Membership is therefore a logical and necessary step in ensuring that the European Union is fully able to achieve the objectives of environment policy.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this recommendation approving the accession of the European Union to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). It is of great importance for the European Union to be adequately represented at CITES meetings and to be able to play its full part in the work of the Convention. Furthermore, I believe that cites membership is a logical and necessary step for the EU to be able to pursue the objectives it has set itself within the more general framework of its environmental policy.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — Accession of the European Union (EU) to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) will enable the EU to be adequately represented at CITES meetings and to play a full role in the work of the convention in line with the Treaties and established practices for external representation.  The Commission will be enabled to lead negations on behalf of the EU and thus serve as a catalyst in achieving a compromise between Member States. Rights and obligations of Member States under CITES will not be affected by the accession of the EU. The move will render the legal status of the EU in CITES more transparent. Accession of the EU to CITES is a logical and necessary step to ensure that the EU is fully able to pursue its objectives under its environmental policy. EU accession to CITES will both reflect the current practice and streamline it. I have thus voted in favour of the accession of the EU to CITES.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is an international instrument designed to protect endangered species of wild fauna and flora by controlling international trade in species of wild fauna and flora. The initial text of the Convention provided that only the Member States could take part. So far, therefore, the European Union has been an observer at CITES. I will be voting in favour of this proposal because it aims to allow EU membership of CITES, in order to allow the Union to participate fully in the work of the Convention and to legally bind the EU and all its Member States to implement this Convention and to ensure that it is complying with it. The Union will also be given formal responsibilities, under which it will be required to answer to the other parties to its implementation of the Convention.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is an international agreement aimed at ensuring that international trade in wild fauna and flora does not threaten their survival, mainly those of high commercial interest. CITES's success depends on the effective implementation of the agreed recommendations. The EU maintains observer status in CITES. The aim of this report is to approve EU accession to CITES in order to enable it to participate fully in its work and to link the EU and Member States to the implementation and control of implementation provided for in the Convention itself. That's why I voted for it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. - The report gives its consent  to the accession of the European Union to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). The Convention is a major international instrument aiming at protecting endangered species of fauna and flora through controls on international trade in specimens of those species and ensures that this trade does not threaten their survival. All import, export, re-export and introduction from the sea of species covered by the Convention has to be authorised through a licensing system. Hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. — I welcome the vote on international trade in endangered species of wild life and flora (CITES) and believe that the European Union's accession to CITES will reflect current practices and optimise them in order to protect endangered species of fauna and flora, targeting around 35 000 species.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With this vote, the European Parliament approves the European Union's accession to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). The European Union has jurisdiction to deal with the areas covered by this convention. I therefore support this accession, which will enable the European Union to play its rightful role in protecting the environment, without infringing on national sovereignty. In particular, the Union will be able to participate fully in the work to deal with the threats of extinction of species of flora and fauna.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Accession of the European Union to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora – CITES – as it is an important international instrument aimed at protecting more than 35 thousand species of wild fauna and flora threatened with extinction, thanks to a strengthened regime for monitoring and monitoring international trade in these species. Which came into force in 1975, CITES provided that only individual States could participate. Gaborone's amendment, which came into force at the end of 2013, also allows the European Union to become part of CITES, thus enabling Europe to speak with one voice in this international forum and contribute more effectively to the achievement of its objectives in full coherence with the general principles of our environmental policy. I believe that the EU's accession to CITES can also be an important opportunity to increase the international role of the Convention, which has been contributing to the preservation of biodiversity in the world for years.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — Cites is an important international instrument to protect endangered species of wild fauna and flora by controlling international trade in species of these species. The Convention entered into force in 1975 and currently has 178 countries, including all EU Member States. A later amendment allows the accession to the Convention of Regional Economic Integration Organisations, such as the European Union.  However, this amendment did not enter into force until 29 November 2013, as it has not yet been ratified by a sufficient number of states. I have chosen to vote in favour of accession to this convention because this will enable the European Commission to conduct negotiations on behalf of the European Union and act as a catalyst for the positions of the 28 Member States.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is the world's leading tool to prevent the overexploitation of protected species. THE activities of CITES, of which the 28 EU states are members, are already contributing to the reduction of illegal trade related to protected natural species, but the hunting of certain species, such as sharks or polar bears, should be further monitored. The European Union's accession to the Convention is a step forward, as it will now be able to speak with one voice in the negotiations and participate fully in the projects.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — The majority of Member States have already joined this convention. The accession of the European Union therefore makes no sense, insofar as it would impose different interpretations of the Convention on Member States and would ultimately give the illusion of the legitimacy of the executives of the European Union and its justice. So I voted against this membership.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the recommendation as this is an important step towards ensuring the protection of endangered species of fauna and flora through controls on international trade in specimens of these species.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is an important international instrument for the protection of endangered species of fauna and flora by monitoring international trade in specimens of these species. At this time, it currently has 178 Parts (including all EU Member States), covers around 35 000 species and ensures that international trade in specimens of these species does not endanger their survival. The european union's support becomes important for the work that the Convention has been doing, recommending that current practice be used when someone becomes an effective party: the annual contribution corresponding to 2.5 % of the total amount allocated to the CITES Trust Fund (around EUR 115 000 in 2015) reducing, accordingly, the share of member states in those contributions, which i voted in favour of.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — The Convention on international trade in endangered species of wild fauna and flora (CITES) is an international agreement, the aim of which is to ensure that international trade in species of wild fauna and flora does not threaten their survival, thus constituting an important instrument for the conservation of endangered species, particularly those of commercial interest, which should therefore be defended and valued. The success of CITES depends on the effective implementation of the agreed recommendations. The European Union had an observer status in CITES. At the second extraordinary meeting of CITES COP (1983), Gaborone's amendment to the Convention was agreed, allowing regional economic integration organisations made up of sovereign states to become parties to the CITES Convention. The aim of this recommendation is to adopt the adoption of the European Union to the CITES Convention in order to enable it to participate fully in the work of the Convention and to legally bind the EU and the Member States to the implementation and review of the application provided for in the Convention. It should be noted that member states' rights and obligations under CITES will not be affected by EU membership, which will now pay a quota to the organisation.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — International trade in wild fauna and flora poses a significant threat to the survival and development of animal species and plant specimens worldwide. CITES provides protection for more than 35 000 species according to the degree of protection and thus contributes significantly to the control of illegal international trade in this area. Only States can be members of CITES under the original Convention, but the time has come for a change in the status of the European Union, which currently only acts as an observer, taking into account that accession to CITES will not affect the rights and obligations of the Member States, as the European Union will only vote on those issues that relate to the acquis and individual Member States will continue to vote on all other matters.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — Once again, the EU signs accession to a convention. In this case, I would like to reiterate to CITES that signing treaties and conventions should be the exclusive competence of the Member States.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the EU's accession to the CITES Convention, since it is a firm step towards ensuring that the European Union is fully able to pursue the objectives it has set itself in the context of its environmental policy, since to date it has simply been an observer of the CITES Convention.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — I voted against this as the recommendation is that the EU takes partial powers from Member States, and will increase EU regulation giving overall more power to the Commission. The EU is currently an ‘Observer’ and wishes the Parliament to enable it to become a full member – which is more erosion of nation states’ sovereignty.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. — Until 29 November 2013, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora only admitted States as Parties. After that date, international organizations can also be signatories. It is therefore logical that the European Union, which is a focus on the protection of wild fauna and flora, now adheres to a Convention which has the laudable objective of improving international cooperation in controlling international trade in endangered species. Let us respect biodiversity and prevent the high level of exploitation of some plants and animals from endangering them and destroy their natural habitats.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. "I wished to support this text, which provides for the accession of the European Union to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. The Convention, which came into force in 1975, aims to prevent the risk of extinction of many iconic species such as tigers and elephants by regulating the trade in endangered animals and plants and their by-products. It now provides protection to nearly 35,000 wildlife species that belong to our world heritage. All European states are already parties to this convention, but it was important that the European Union, as an international institution, also lead by example.

name: Eduard-Raul HELLVIG
text: in writing. — I support the accession of the European Union to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), because this adhesion is a global confirmation of the EU's environmental concerns. Initially limited at state level and open since 2013 and to regional integration organisations, accession will not affect the individual rights and obligations of EU Member States, previously signatory to CITES. The European environmental policy already aims to protect species whose survival may be endangered by international trade and stipulates a system of licences for import-export-re-export operations, as well as rules on documents of provenance in the case of species covered by the Convention. Moreover, the EU has adopted a number of legal instruments in this area, which is binding on the Member States. In these circumstances, I believe that, with the accession to CITES and the taking over of part of its trust fund, the EU must be more strongly involved at international level in enhancing cooperation aimed at protecting the nearly 35 000 species classified in the Annexes to the Convention and strictly complying with the rules governing trade in the field.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. — The Washington Convention on International Trade in Wild Fauna and Flora is a major international document aimed at ensuring the protection of endangered species of animals and plants by regulating international trade in specimens of these species.  The text of the Convention originally allowed accession only to States. For this reason, the European Union has so far only participated as observers in the Convention. This is changing, as it has become legally possible for the EU, as a party to the Treaty, to accede to the Convention and to be indirectly represented not only through the Member States. The accession of the European Union to the Convention will enable the EU to be properly represented at the meetings of the organisation established by the Convention and to play a full role in the work of the Convention.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora has been an important international tool for approaching four decades. Both the EU and its individual Member States play a role in implementing CITES, and I accordingly voted in favour of the EU acceding to the Convention in its own right.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision on the Accession of the European Union to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Animals and Plants, as it constitutes an international instrument aimed at protecting animals and plants by controlling their international trade. I support the accession of the European Union to CITES, i.e. the convention, as European interests and needs will be represented on the international stage through the EU, balancing the positions of individual Member States and representing greater bargaining weight. Also, the European Union's environmental policy, through CITES, will gain more power to achieve its objectives, especially in the animal and plant trading sector.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. — Today UKIP voted against the Ayuso report on the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES). This vote was not about CITES itself. We support the objectives of the CITES convention. This vote was about enhancing the status of the European Commission within the CITES structure which we are not prepared to support. We are also against the related budgetary implication.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. —I voted in favour of my colleague Pilar Ayuso's recommendation on the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. This convention has been in force since 1975 and only the Member States have so far been parties, as individuals. The aim of this report is to authorise the Union to become a party to the Convention itself. I welcome the broad adoption of this recommendation.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I welcome the adoption of this proposal on the European Union's accession to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) following the entry into force on 29 November 2013 of the Gaborone Amendment, which authorises the accession to CITES of any organisation of regional economic integration. In view of the sharp increase in wildlife trafficking worldwide in recent years, it is important that the European Union strengthens its role in combating this scourge and that it takes further action, particularly with regard to the online trade in products from endangered species.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I very much welcome accession, as it will elevate the EU from a simple observer to a full member of the Convention. It will also increase the transparency of the EU’s legal status in CITES vis-à-vis third parties and help ensure that the EU is fully able to pursue its objectives under its environmental policy.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate my colleague Pilar Ayuso on her excellent work on this dossier. I supported this report because I consider the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) to be an important instrument for protecting endangered species through stronger control over international trade in endangered species. Furthermore, joining CITES is a necessary step towards enabling the EU to pursue the objectives it has set itself as part of its environmental policy.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. — I voted for two reasons against the EU's accession to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). Firstly, because this accession is a new offensive against the sovereignty of the Member States of the Union which have already joined this Convention: in this matter, the Union will now speak for them. Secondly, because the Union, being the prey of all kinds of lobbies, will defend wildlife worse than states.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is a major international instrument aimed at protecting threatened species of fauna and flora through controls on international trade in specimens of wild fauna and flora. It entered into force in 1975 and currently has 178 Parties (including all EU Member States). However, until the entry into force of a decision taken at the Botswana Conference (2013), which is to allow supranational bodies to accede to the Convention, the EU had not been able to become a Party and it was the sum of the Member States that determined the European position. The recommendation gives the go-ahead to the EU's entry as a CITES Party, which is supported by my support.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is an international agreement aimed at ensuring that international trade in wild fauna and flora does not threaten their survival, mainly those of high commercial interest. CITES's success depends on the effective implementation of the agreed recommendations. The EU maintains observer status in CITES. The aim of this report is to approve EU accession to CITES in order to enable it to participate fully in its work and to link the EU and Member States to the implementation and control of implementation provided for in the Convention itself.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora is an international body whose objective is the protection of threatened species through the control of their trade. All countries of the European Union are part of this Convention, while the European Union has maintained observer status. Due to the recent reform that allows accession to the Convention of International Bodies, I consider it appropriate for the European Union to accede.  The accession of the European Union will be more coherent and transparent and will enable more comprehensive and effective action to achieve its environmental policy objectives, and therefore vote in favour of this accession.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Animals and Plants (CITES) is a major international instrument aimed at protecting endangered species of animals and plants by controlling international trade. The Convention applies to over 35,000 species listed in three annexes according to the degree of protection they need, while ensuring that international trade does not threaten their survival. All trades, including imports and exports, must respect all types of plants and animals covered by the Convention, and imports or exports of protected species must be authorised through a licensing system. The aim of the report is to support the CITES Convention within the framework of the European Union and therefore calls on the President of the Council to designate the person who will be empowered to continue carrying out activities on behalf of the European Union. I support this report and consider that the European Union's acceptance of CITES is a logical and necessary step to ensure that the European Union fully continues to meet environmental policy objectives.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the Ayuso Recommendation on international trade in endangered species (CITES), because the EU's accession to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species will make a significant contribution to further protecting wildlife and will reduce wildlife smuggling.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I voted for this proposal. The accession of the European Union to CITES will enable the EU to be adequately represented at CITES meetings and to play a full role in the work of the Convention, in line with the Treaties and established practices for external representation. It will enable the Commission, on behalf of the European Union, to lead negotiations and to be a catalyst in achieving a balanced compromise between the 28 Member States’ positions. When becoming a party to CITES, the European Union will be granted formal responsibilities and become accountable to other parties for the implementation and enforcement of the Convention.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, or CITES, is an important international instrument with the aim of regulating international trade in endangered wild fauna and flora. It is essential to prevent the commercial exploitation of endangered species and to restrict trade in animals and plants in order to ensure the preservation of biodiversity.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is a key instrument in environmental protection. The accession of the European Union to CITES is, in my view, highly desirable. It will facilitate the pursuit of a number of strategic objectives, which are fully in line with Community environmental policy. It is for all these reasons that I felt it necessary to support Mrs Ayuso's report.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the vote on this agreement. On the one hand, because animal welfare is an extremely important and noble concern and, on the other hand, because the joint representation of all European countries will give this concern even more weight internationally. Nevertheless, individual countries which place animal welfare rules much higher than those provided for in the CITES Agreement must not be restricted in their competences.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is a major international instrument to protect species of flora and fauna threatened by international trade in specimens of these species. It came into force in 1975 and now has 178 members (including all EU Member States). The original text of the convention provided that CITES membership would be limited to states alone. Therefore, the European Union had only observer status. At the second extraordinary meeting of the Conference of the Parties (1983), it was agreed that regional economic integration organizations made up of sovereign states could become members of CITES. The proposal aims to allow the Union to join the Convention 31 years later. I am voting for the Union's accession to this convention.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — I agree with the EU's membership of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). CITES is an important international instrument for the protection of endangered species of fauna and flora by monitoring international trade in specimens of these species. CITES entered into force in 1975 and currently has 178 Parties (including all EU Member States). It covers around 35 000 species, which are listed in the three appendices according to the degree of protection they need, and ensures that international trade in specimens of these species does not endanger their survival.  This convention is very important in the fight against the illegal trade in protected or endangered species, hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — Due to the cross-border nature of the trade in endangered plant and animal species, a truly international effort is required to put an end to this illicit activity. Therefore I voted in favour of this recommendation as it would bind the EU and all its Member States to implement and enforce the CITES convention.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I am pleased that the European Parliament has approved the European Union's accession to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). By signing up, the European Union is strengthening the control of international trade in these 35,000 species and better protecting them, by imposing a system of authorisations for their commercialisation. All Member States have already signed. As the Union is a major international player on the commercial scene, it was essential that it support it, which will enable it to participate in the work of the Convention and to make a legal commitment to implement and enforce the Convention.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: In writing — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora constitutes an important international instrument for the conservation of 35 000 species of endangered species of fauna and flora. Since the entry into force of the Convention, all EU Member States have become Contracting Parties, but until now the European Union has only had observer status. I voted in favour of the EU's accession to the Convention because I consider this to be a logical result of the EU's environmental protection efforts under its remit. Furthermore, accession will make it possible to take a unified position on issues arising from the Convention and to promote a common position in the negotiations during the Conferences of the Parties.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of EU accession to CITES (The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora) with a view to promoting the implementation and enforcement of CITES.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. 178 countries are already part of CITES, including all EU member states. With this recommendation, we are asked here to authorise the accession of the Union. This convention, while not perfect, remains useful, provided that it is limited to its primary role, namely the protection of endangered species of wild fauna and flora. It should also be noted that participating states are legally free to vote in a different direction than that proposed by CITES. It is clear that with the accession of the European Union, we will see a transfer of the vote, and therefore a further transfer of sovereignty of the Member States. Finally, if the Union were to accede to this convention on international trade in endangered species of wild fauna and flora, it is likely that it will not resist the sirens of lobbies for long. Lobbies that will, for example, lobby to restrict or even ban the fishing of certain fish consumed by humans, even though it would be sufficient for the Union to propose regulations. Refusing to give the Union a blank-seing, I voted against this accession.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I believe that this vote is urgently needed and is a long-overdue step that elevates the EU from a simple observer to a full member of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES). The decision will serve to increase the transparency of the EU’s legal status in the CITES vis-à-vis third parties and will help to ensure that the European Union is fully able to pursue its objectives under its environmental policy.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora is an important international instrument for the protection of specimens of these species by monitoring international trade. A convention which entered into force in 1975 and now has 178 countries (including all EU Member States). The initial text of the Convention provided that only states could participate, but accession to the Convention was now also open to regional economic integration organisations made up of sovereign States with competence to negotiate, conclude and apply international agreements in the matters assigned to them. We therefore welcome this Proposal from the Council because, by hering to CITES, the European Union will be able to be properly represented at its meetings and play its role in the work of the Convention. The European Union will thus be fully able to pursue the objectives it has set itself within the framework of its environmental policy.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, having CITES as an international instrument to protect the species of wild fauna and flora threatened with extinction by controlling international trade is, I believe, of fundamental importance to the European Union, so that it can pursue the objectives set in the context of its environmental policy. I voted in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Ayuso so that the EU can express a coherent position on CITES issues and can play an essential role in the negotiations at the conferences of the parties.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — The CITES Agreement is, in principle, a step in the right direction, although I always stress that it can only be a first step towards the preservation of biodiversity and animal welfare. Nevertheless, I consider it important that the Union, as its own legal personality, should now accede to this agreement. I therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I think it is important for the Union to join the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) in order to protect these endangered species, which are still too often illegally traded, and to enable the Union to pursue its environmental objectives. I obviously voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the draft on the accession of the European Union to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, as I consider it important to protect endangered species of animals and plants and to control international trade in specimens of these species. The EU's accession to the Convention will undoubtedly add to the capacity for all action.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the EU's accession to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Wild Species of Flora and Fauna. Any restrictions involving such international conventions run counter to the capitalist economy itself, the liberalisation of capital, the service of the profitability of business groups, competitiveness and the delivery to capital of every physical and social good. As a transnational union of capital, the EU promotes the commercial exploitation of the species concerned by the Convention, substantially undermining their protection, the scope of the convention, for the benefit of monopolies. In addition, participation in the EU Convention is in place of member states' responsibility. The protection of all physical and social goods requires power and economy in the hands of the people. This alone can ensure the satisfaction of popular needs, with respect for the environment, in order to ensure balanced development for the benefit of popular prosperity.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Considering that the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Flora and Fauna is an important instrument for the preservation and protection of the planet's biodiversity and that accession will enable the EU to play its full role in environmental policy, I would like to vote in favour of it.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this report because I believe that membership of CITES is a logical and necessary step, so that the EU can fully pursue the objectives it has set itself within the framework of its environmental policy. Accession will enable the Commission, on behalf of the European Union and therefore all 28 Member States, to express a coherent EU position on issues relating to the protection of endangered species and to play an essential role in conference negotiations with third parties. I believe that this step is a classic example of how the transfer of sovereignty to the EU can benefit the Member States themselves, which are thus strengthened by a common position presented at international level. In particular, in this case, as far as the environment is concerned, it is all the more essential for the EU to speak with one voice so as to make a stronger contribution to the protection of endangered species which, as we know, are the 'thermometer' of our planet's health. I hope that with this vote Europe will be able to continue its battle for environmental protection in all its forms even more strongly and that it will be able to become a world leader in this by setting a good example for other continents.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) aims to ensure that international trade in specimens of wild animals and plants does not threaten their survival.  Although the original text of the Convention stipulated that only States could be members of CITES, on 30 April 1983 an amendment to the Convention was agreed after it was ratified by two thirds of the 80 States party to the Convention at the time the amendment was adopted. The amendment to the Convention allowed the European Union to become a cites party. In 2015, the EU is expected to pay 2.5% of the cites trust fund's total and approximately €115,000,000 annually, as this is in line with the practice of the other parties that have joined.  The European Union's accession to CITES will allow it to monitor the work of the Convention and in accordance with treaties and established practices for external representation. This will allow the Commission to conduct future negotiations on behalf of the European Union and allow for a compromise with all 28 Member States. Once it becomes a cites party, the European Union will approve formal responsibilities and become accountable to other parties for the application and implementation of the Convention.  For these reasons, I supported the adoption of the Recommendation on the Draft Council Decision on EU Accession to the Convention prepared by my colleague Pilar Ayuso.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) I am pleased that Gaborone's amendment has entered into force and that, at last, the European Union can become part of CITES, considering it a fundamental instrument for the protection of endangered species of wild fauna and flora. The control exercised over endangered specimens that are part of international trade is of great value and protects their survival.  By joining CITES, the EU will be able to be represented at meetings and will be able to play its part in the work of the Convention in its own right and no longer just as an observer as in the past.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — The preservation of the natural diversity of our planet is essential for the future of all mankind. Overexploitation of the environment cannot be in our long-term interest. Since the protection of wild animals and plants is a task which requires a certain weight on the international stage, it is to be welcomed that the European Union as a whole is committed to this. Consequently, I will support their accession to the CITES Convention. I am all the more determined to do so because a good practice remains in place. In this way, the Member States do not seek a consensus that the EU must implement and represent. This is precisely the EU, which is truly desirable. I wish the representatives in this area the strength to continue to promote this European ideal of consensus and to reconcile the interests of all states.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — All EU Member States are part of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. The inclusion of the European Union is therefore legitimate in this respect and under the EU's common trade policy and environmental policy.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) entered into force in 1975 with the aim of protecting certain endangered species of wild fauna and flora from overexploitation due to international trade. It currently has 178 Parties, including all EU Member States. As cites's initial text limited states to participation in CITES, to date, the EU has had the status of mere observer. With the entry into force on 29 November 2003 of the Gaborone Amendment, the possibility of cites's entry into regional economic integration organisations consisting of sovereign states with powers to negotiate, conclude and implement international agreements on matters covered by the Convention was envisaged. It is certain that the matters covered by CITES (environmental protection and trade) fall within the eu's remit and that its membership of CITES will enable it to participate fully in the work of the Convention, ensuring the conditions for the achievement of its environmental policy objectives, I voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the EU's membership of CITES.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. — This vote should not be taken to imply in any way that I am in favour of the trade in endangered species.  Nevertheless, I voted against this report because Member States should be able to introduce tougher measures for themselves, and they themselves should be the signatories to CITES not the European Union.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. — The European Parliament said YES to the EU's accession to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (CITES) by an overwhelming majority of 641 votes this lunchtime. It must be said that the current situation is grave with this unprecedented wave of species extinction. Some figures are clear: 20,000, or the number of African elephants killed in 2013, 2,000 horns, or the number of new rhino horns entered the traffic last year, 9,500, or the number of advertisements recorded on the Internet for the trafficking of wild animals, 54% of which are live animals. There are 35,000 protected species in the world, including the largest terrestrial mammals, and Europe, after Japan and the United States, is the third destination region for illegal wildlife activity. That is to say the importance for the Union to speak with one voice in the Conference of the Parties, the decision-making body of CITES. The EU's accession to CITES is simply a welcome and logical transfer of sovereignty to best protect the fragile diversity of our planet.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
