text: In writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora links signatory states to principles of international trade aimed at better protecting endangered wild animal and plant specimens. I voted in favour of this resolution, which gives the green light from the European Parliament to the ratification by the European Union of this international convention. With this gesture, the European Union is sending a strong signal in favour of the protection of biodiversity and asserting itself as a legal entity in its own right on the international stage.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is a major international instrument aimed at protecting threatened species of fauna and flora through controls on international trade in specimens of wild fauna and flora. In force since 1975, it currently has 178 Parties, including all EU Member States. It comprises some 35,000 protected species and ensures that international trade in specimens of wild animals and plants does not endanger their survival. Any import, export, re-export and introduction of the species included in the Convention must be authorized by means of a licensing system. However, until the entry into force of the decision taken at the Botswana Conference (2013) to allow supranational bodies to accede to the Convention, the EU had not been able to become a Party and had only observer status in the Convention.  I voted in favour of the rapporteur's recommendation to approve EU accession to CITES, which will allow the EU to participate and negotiate with one voice at the summits, strengthening our role and negotiating capacity.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is a crucial international instrument for the protection of endangered species of flora and fauna. The Convention came into force in 1975 and now has 178 States Parties (including all EU Member States). CITES covers more than 35,000 species and ensures that international trade in specimens of these species does not threaten their survival (all imports, exports, re-exports and introductions from the sea of species covered by the convention are subject to a system of authorisations). The original text of the convention provided that membership in CITES would be limited to states alone. Until now, therefore, the European Union had only observer status. The Council's proposal for a decision that I voted on today is aimed at approving the European Union's accession to CITES. The EU's accession to CITES will now enable it to be properly represented at meetings and to participate fully in the work of the Convention. I am very happy about that.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is an International Convention covering 178 countries, including all EU Member States and covering around 35 000 species, which are under the aegis of a prior licensing system on their marketing. CITES is therefore an extremely relevant instrument for the protection, control and monitoring of trade in these species. Initially, participation in CITES was limited to states, with the European Union having observer status. However, a recent amendment to Article 21 of the Convention allows the annexation of regional economic integration organisations consisting of sovereign states with the power to negotiate, conclude and implement international agreements on cites matters that their Member States have transferred to them. Given that the areas of action of the Convention concern the protection of the environment and international trade, the first being a shared competence with the Member States and the second an exclusive competence of the Union, I consider the EU's membership of the CITES Convention a logical and very welcome step, and I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — Until 2013, only individual states could be parties to the CITES Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Fauna and Flora. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to authorise the European Union to become a party to the Convention itself.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote against it on a point of principle: the signing of treaties and conventions should be the exclusive competence of the Member States.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is an international agreement aimed at ensuring that international trade in wild fauna and flora does not threaten their survival, mainly those of high commercial interest. CITES's success depends on the effective implementation of the agreed recommendations. The EU maintains observer status in CITES. The aim of this report is to approve EU accession to CITES in order to enable it to participate fully in its work and to link the EU and Member States to the implementation and control of implementation provided for in the Convention itself. That's why I voted for it.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. — Today UKIP voted against the Ayuso report on the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES). This vote was not about CITES itself. We support the objectives of the CITES convention. This vote was about enhancing the status of the European Commission within the CITES structure which we are not prepared to support. We are also against the related budgetary implication.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of the European Union to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). I believe that the accession of the European Union to CITES is a logical and necessary step to ensure that the European Union is fully able to pursue its objectives under its environmental policy. CITES is a major international instrument aimed at protecting endangered species of fauna and flora through controls on international trade in specimens of those species. Accession of the European Union to CITES will enable the EU to be adequately represented at CITES meetings and to play a full role in the work of the Convention, in line with the Treaties and established practices for external representation.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I supported the adoption of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Animals and Plants, as I believe we need to step up our efforts to prevent uncontrolled international trade in endangered species.  International trade threatens more than 35,000 species of wild animals and plants, and further commercialisation will cause them to disappear completely. Worryingly, the market accumulates $10 billion a year. It is therefore necessary to raise awareness among european union citizens, as they are committing an illegal and immoral act by purchasing endangered beings. Many are unaware that purchasing a crocodile leather bag or ivory jewellery requires permission or a pass that guarantees non-endangerment of survival of this species. The reckless exploitation of natural resources in the linear economic system, as well as the illicit trade in products made from endangered plant and animal species, leads to an imbalance that is not sustainable.  From all of the above, I condemn the uncontrolled trade in endangered species of wild animals and plants, and the adoption of a Convention at European Union level is a decisive step towards protecting the biodiversity not only of Europe, but of the world.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I support this Recommendation as it is in line with the Objectives of the European Union on the Conservation of Wild Flora and Fauna. The issue of environmental protection is one of the priorities of the European Parliament. Timely control of endangered wildlife and fauna should be established. It is necessary to establish cooperation between inspection services, police and customs with a view to effectively implementing this Convention, taking into account that the illegal trade in endangered plant and animal species is one of the most profitable means of illegal profit.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I support the adoption of the CITES Convention by the European Union, as it reaffirms its commitment to environmental policy and the fulfilment of its objectives.  We must take into account diversity and development, as well as legal and sustainable international trade. I believe that applying the Convention will reduce the illegal trade in endangered animal and plant species, which with $19 billion after drug trafficking, counterfeit products and human trafficking is the most lucrative form of illegal profits today.  The CITES Convention, more than 40 years old, directly protects over 35,000 endangered animal and plant species. I am therefore satisfied that the Europarlamentaries supported this request, as this problem needs to be addressed seriously and systematically so that many endangered species are not only available in encyclopedias.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The accession of the EU to the CITES Convention will lead it to achieve its environmental policy objectives.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this motion because, by joining the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, we can combat the illegal trade in endangered species with greater emphasis. It should be noted that so far only sovereign states have been allowed to join CITES, a principle that was changed in 2013. From then on, an alliance of states, organisations formed by sovereign states, can join this important international document, thus opening up this possibility to the European Union. I think it is important that, as mentioned in the Recommendation, the accession of the European Union to CITES is a logical and necessary step towards the full achievement of the objectives of EU environmental policy. Accession will enable the Commission, on behalf of the European Union, to speak with one UNION on matters relating to the Convention and to play an important role in the negotiations at the Conferences of the Parties.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. — I supported the recommendation on the proposal for a Council Decision on the accession of the European Union to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). This accession represents a chance for the EU to be fully involved in the implementation of the Convention.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. " I voted in favour of this text, which aims to help defend more than 35,000 species listed in one of the three annexes of the convention and ensure that international trade in specimens of these species does not threaten their survival. All imports, exports, re-exports and sea-tender introductions of species covered by the Convention are subject to a system of authorisations. A text that goes in the right direction.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), as it allows the European Union and the Member States to cooperate with a number of countries with a view to protecting around 35 000 different endangered species of plants and animals, which can be achieved by prohibiting and overseeing the international trade of these species.  I find cites' role particularly useful, as it makes enormous efforts to combat international trade in endangered species by establishing control mechanisms throughout the wildlife supply chain, from country of origin to final destination. I also fully agree with that conclusion that only close cooperation between all bodies involved in the implementation of this Convention at national and international level and by punishing those who violate its provisions can fully ensure the achievement of the objectives.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — As parliamentarians we are committed to serving society in its global complexity. Nonetheless, we must work to ensure that the future generation has the same opportunities as the generation I belong to. Hence, I have voted in favour of the decision on the accession of the European Union to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). I expect that by giving approval for the accession of the EU to CITES we will create a better framework to protect our worldwide common heritage.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report as its purpose is to provide for international cooperation in order to protect species from overexploitation through international trade. This report is part of an on-going legislative procedure aiming at recasting the regulation whereby the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is implemented by the Member States.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is an international instrument to protect endangered species of flora and fauna.  It affects some 35,000 species and ensures that international trade in these species does not threaten their survival. Thus, all imports, exports, re-exports... species covered by the convention are subject to a system of authorisations. This Convention, which came into force in 1975, now has 178 parties, including all the Member States of the Union, but not the Union itself, which until then had no capacity to sign such conventions. It is now done and the European Parliament has therefore approved the EU's accession to CITES. It remains to be hoped that this accession will enable the European institutions and Member States to express a coherent position on these issues.  The desire to achieve concrete results in the negotiations on the fight for biodiversity is very important for the future of the planet, provided that these negotiations are not contradicted by other policies, including trade policies. However, I voted in favour, as a principle.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — We generally agree with this decision to eu membership of this convention. It is at stake, as has been said, the preservation of some 3000 animal species and 40 000 plant species. My concern is the means that the EU will put at the service of this important mission. Without means, without effective intervention on the ground, this adoption of CITES will not make much sense. Within the EU, public veterinary control services have been dismantled in some countries which have played a decisive role in the eradication of various zoonoses, such as tuberculosis and swine fever.  This calls attention to the need to strengthen the means to combat illegal traffic in these species. In particular, border inspection posts need to be strengthened by aleming them with human and technical resources; improve the training of the veterinary body within the Framework of the Food and Veterinary Office, possibly with the European Veterinary Federation; and it is also necessary to give Member States the conditions to be able to monitor their EES, which in Portugal, given austerity, has not been possible, even though we have the largest EES in the EU.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Animal welfare is an important concern in Europe and needs to be strengthened. In doing so, the EU can act as a representative of all Member States in order to make this undertaking heard on an international package. However, it should be noted that individual countries that place animal welfare rules much higher than those provided for in the CITES Agreement are not curtailed, if not restricted, in their competences. However, as animal welfare is also a matter of great concern to me, I voted in favour of this motion.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: in writing. — While I agree that the CITES and the protection of endangered species are a worthwhile cause, I voted against this recommendation since I believe it seeks to promote the European Commission and its policies. Sweden ratified the CITES in 1975 and has been an active member ever since. I see no reason why the EU should be involved as well.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. - I voted on the EP Recommendation on the EU's accession to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). I welcome the fact that, thanks to the amendment of the Convention, the EU, as an organisation of sovereign states, has also been able to adhering to it. International trade must not become an instrument of reckless exploitation of the environment that accelerates the harmful phenomenon of the extinction of new and new species.  This concern is common to many EU citizens and is also reflected in today's EP decision. Having entered into force since 1975, CITES is an important international tool essential for the protection of endangered species of fauna and flora. In accordance with the provisions of CITES, all import, export and re-export operations and introduction of marine species covered by the Convention must be authorised by a system of licences.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Union's annexation of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES).  The EU's membership of CITES has been a coherent and necessary step forward to ensure that the European Union is fully able to achieve the objectives of its environmental policy. Accession will not only allow the Commission to express, on behalf of the European Union, a coherent EU position on CITES affairs, but also to participate effectively in the negotiations of the Conferences of the Parties. This accession will enable the Commission to conduct negotiations on behalf of the European Union and act actively to find a balanced compromise solution between the positions of the 28 Member States. Furthermore, by becoming a Party to CITES, the European Union will have formal responsibilities and must be accountable to the other Parties for the implementation and implementation of the Convention.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is an international agreement aimed at ensuring that international trade in species of wild fauna and flora does not threaten their survival and is therefore an important instrument for the conservation of endangered species, particularly those of commercial interest, which should therefore be defended and valued.  The aim of this recommendation is to approve the adoption of the European Union to the CITES Convention in order to enable it to participate fully in the work of the Convention and to legally bind the EU and the Member States to the implementation and enforcement of the application provided for in the Convention. It should be noted that the rights and obligations of Member States under CITES will not be affected by EU's adoption, so we agree with the recommendation.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted whole much in favour of the European Union's accession to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, because I believe that this is the time for efforts to be made at Community level too. CITES, whose aim is to restrict and control trade in wild specimens in order to protect their survival and spread, entered into force in 1975, and currently includes all EU Member States among the 178 members. Thanks to an amendment to the convention that has been in force since 2013, supranational organisations now also have the opportunity to join. For the EU, this is a logical and almost obligatory step if it is to remain consistent with the frequently reaffirmed desire to protect the environment and the health of the planet. We certainly need a more uniform regulatory framework, one that leaves no window of opportunity for those who want to circumvent the law. Being part of CITES, on the other hand, will enable the Union to confront international players with less advanced legislation in this area with a single voice and to make its point of view more important for the protection of flora and fauna.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. —Certainly the EU has a dependence on the North American GPS system that should be terminated. But it is also true that there is no guarantee that the GNSS system is exclusively for civilian use, but that it also appears to be given military use, as many pacifist organizations have alerted.  In this particular case, a cooperation agreement is proposed with Morocco, the country responsible for the illegal occupation of the territory of Western Sahara, in contravention of the multiple United Nations resolutions on the right of self-determination of the Saharawi people. In this regard, I voted against this report.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. — This cooperation agreement on a Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) between the EU and Morocco should enable both sides to intensify cooperation and exchange scientific knowledge. Morocco wants to develop the use of satellite radio navigation on its territory and in the surrounding region. It is within the framework of the 2006 agreement and through its participation in the European Neighbourhood Policy that Morocco is asking to be associated with the new framework programme for research and innovation (Horizon 2020). It is therefore a purely technical cooperation that I support.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — This report favours a partnership in the Galileo programme, a programme which comes at a cost of EUR 9.8 billion to the European Union.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to sign a cooperation agreement on the civil global navigation satellite system (GNSS) with Morocco. Morocco has extensive practical experience in space technology and would like to make greater use of satellite navigation on its territory and in the surrounding region of the Western Mediterranean and West Africa. The Agreement provides for cooperation on research, industrial production, training, services and market development, trade and issues related to radio spectrum, integrity, standardisation and certification in the areas of satellite navigation and timing. As the agreement will strengthen the joint eu-Morocco presence in these sectors, I believe it will benefit the citizens, industry and scientific communities of both countries. I support the conclusion of the agreement.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Convinced of the need to cooperate with the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, I welcome interstate collaborations such as the interesting Galileo project to which Morocco has been associated for almost ten years, especially since it is a matter of competing with the American GPS.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — This agreement will strengthen cooperation with Morocco in the field of satellite navigation.  Morocco has expertise in the field of space technology and its applications and wishes to develop the use of satellite radio navigation on its territory and in the surrounding region (Western Mediterranean and West Africa), with a focus on applications specific to this region. Moroccan and European companies have maintained industrial cooperation in the space sector for several years and have a solid basis to support and extend cooperation in this area, which is of great importance to both sides.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report as this initiative will enable both sides to improve and intensify their cooperation in scientific and technological areas of common interest, and will enable greater exchange of specific knowledge and the transfer of expertise for the benefit of scientific communities, the industrial sector and citizens. In addition, the Commission services will regularly monitor all activities carried out under the Agreement, including an EU review. The Agreement is based on the principles of mutual benefit, reciprocal access to programmes and activities of the other party related to the purpose of the Agreement, non-discrimination, effective protection of intellectual property, equitable distribution of IPRs and effective exploitation of results. The renewal of the Agreement will increase scientific knowledge, resulting in market access opportunities.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This recommendation for a cooperation agreement on a Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) between the EU and Morocco should enable both sides to intensify cooperation and exchange scientific knowledge. Morocco wants to develop the use of satellite radio navigation on its territory and in the surrounding region. It is within the framework of the 2006 agreement and through its participation in the European Neighbourhood Policy that Morocco is asking to be associated with the new framework programme for research and innovation (Horizon 2020). I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of Morocco's involvement in the GNSS, the system dedicated to the provision of a geospatial positioning service with global coverage, because this action will increase its effectiveness for the benefit of European citizens.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — This Agreement culminates the contacts established between the European Union and Morocco for Morocco's participation in the Galileo programme. The talks began in March 2004 and ended in December 2006, when the Cooperation Agreement on a civil global satellite navigation system (GNSS) was signed between the European Community and its Member States and the Kingdom of Morocco. This Agreement will allow cooperation on navigation and satellite timing. The Agreement covers scientific research, industrial manufacturing, training, applications, service and market development, trade, radio spectrum, integrity issues, standardization and certification.  In this way, joint activities in these sectors may be strengthened for the benefit of citizens, industries and scientific communities on both sides, which is why I have supported it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supports the conclusion of a cooperation agreement between the EU and the Kingdom of Morocco on the Civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS). The aim of the Agreement is to encourage, facilitate and strengthen cooperation between the parties towards Europe and Morocco by contributing to the development of a civil global satellite navigation system (GNSS). This agreement was concluded by the EU and Morocco in the light of the common interest in developing the civil global satellite navigation system (GNSS) and the growing development of GNSS applications in Morocco, Europe and elsewhere in the world, and recognising the importance of the Galileo programme for european and Moroccan navigation and information infrastructure.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal for a cooperation agreement on GNSS between the European Community and the Kingdom of Morocco.  In the space sector, industrial cooperation relations between the European Union and Morocco have intensified and are an important foundation for extending existing cooperation. I am thinking in particular of the implementation of the European Galileo system, which is currently being tested, for geo-radiolocation and land navigation throughout the Mediterranean region. Morocco, a member of the EU Neighbourhood Policy, will be able to cooperate effectively with the European Union in research in the field of GNSS and will bring added value to the efforts being made in the fields of energy and industrial production, bringing benefits to scientific communities, businesses and citizens in both areas.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for the conclusion of the treaty with Morocco because it is essential to include our partner at our borders in European scientific programmes.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — This recommendation for a cooperation agreement on a Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) between the European Union and Morocco aims to improve cooperation between the two sides and enable an exchange of scientific knowledge. Morocco wants to develop the use of satellite radio navigation on its territory and in the surrounding region. It is within the framework of the 2006 agreement and by virtue of its participation in the European Neighbourhood Policy that Morocco wishes to be associated with the new framework programme for research and innovation (Horizon 2020). I voted for it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) for civil use between the European Community, its Member States and the Kingdom of Morocco. The Agreement strengthens the cooperation of Member States with the Kingdom of Morocco in the field of satellite navigation and implements a number of elements of European satellite navigation programmes. The fact that this agreement will develop scientific research and industrial production without having financial implications for the EU budget will strengthen joint activities in these sectors for the benefit of citizens and the European Community.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the agreement on Morocco's involvement in GNSS (The European GPS).

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the cooperation agreement, the aim of which is to encourage, facilitate and improve cooperation between the parties in the context of the contributions of Europe and Morocco to the establishment of a global satellite navigation system (GNSS) for civil use. This agreement and this system will enable users to achieve better performance, in particular in terms of accuracy, availability, integrity and reliability of satellite navigation data. Cooperation activities can bring benefits in various fields related to the field of navigation and satellite synchronization: scientific research, industrial production, training, development of services and the market, trade, etc.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. - I voted against the motion ‘On the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on a Civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) between the European Community and its Member States and the Kingdom of Morocco’. The report states that the Kingdom of Morocco can join the European GNSS Agreement. The GNSS is incredibly expensive, currently securing EUR 6.3 billion under the MFF.  Further, the EU GNSS Agency says on its homepage that Galileo is only to be used for civilian purposes, but it states that law enforcement is a civil use. When you allow law enforcement to use the GNSS system, it is only a small step to ‘law enforcement agencies’ using the system to track civilians under the guise of law enforcement, like the NSA is using the Patriot Act to ‘protect the State’.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. - I voted against this proposal as it favours a partnership on the Galileo programme with a cost to the EU of EUR 9.8 billion.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — The construction of a global navigation network contributes to the safety of civilian vessels in transit between the European area and third countries. Its extension to Moroccan territorial waters is a step forward in stabilising a single mediterranean network.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — The Mediterranean has been " Mare Nostrum " since Roman times. The neighbourhood policy can and must feed on small shares, which are beneficial to both sides, and which do not bind us in other areas. I therefore agree with the cooperation with Morocco on this programme, which will enable us to obtain data to be used not only to guide us when we drive but also to better study the territory with all the implications that may exist for agriculture, for mountain policies, and so on.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — Europe is building its own Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) with the most advanced technology to enable accurate and guaranteed positioning for all types of civil applications, including navigators for cars, mobile phones, maritime, road, rail and air transport. This system offers free satellite radio navigation signals with an accuracy ten times higher than that of the GPS system. This Agreement will promote, facilitate and strengthen cooperation between the parties in the framework of EU and Moroccan contributions to a comprehensive satellite navigation system for civilian use. I therefore support this agreement which brings mutual benefits, reciprocal opportunities for participation in cooperation activities, timely exchange of information, adequate protection of intellectual property rights and free trade of GNSS equipment in the territories of the Parties.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this recommendation approving the cooperation agreement between the EU and Morocco on the civil satellite radionavigation system. This is a significant step forward which will make it possible to strengthen, facilitate and improve industrial cooperation between the parties. This will certainly bring benefits in these areas for citizens, businesses and the scientific community. Furthermore, I believe that this will also have a favourable impact on relations with that country and the dialogue in the scientific field can contribute to improving the delicate situation that the entire Mediterranean area is experiencing.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the cooperation agreement on a civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) between the European Community and its Member States and the Kingdom of Morocco as this respects the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and strengthen the ties of the European Community with Morocco.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — With the conclusion of the agreement, Morocco has good potential to contribute to research in the field of GNSS, in the context of EU research and innovation programmes. Considering that Morocco has know-how in the field of space technologies and applications, given that it intends to develop the use of satellite radionavigation on its territory and in the surrounding region, precisely in the Mediterranean and West Africa, focusing on specific applications for this region. I will vote and vote in favour of all those agreements, such as this one, which represent an opportunity for growth and development.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. —Certainly the EU has a dependence on the North American GPS system that should be terminated. But it is also true that there is no guarantee that the GNSS system is exclusively for civilian use, but that it also appears to be given military use, as many pacifist organizations have alerted.  In this particular case, a cooperation agreement is proposed with Morocco, the country responsible for the illegal occupation of the territory of Western Sahara, in contravention of the multiple United Nations resolutions on the right of self-determination of the Saharawi people. In this regard, I voted against this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. - Morocco has know-how in space technology and applications. It would like to develop the use of satellite radio-navigation on its territory and in the surrounding region (western Mediterranean and West Africa), focusing on applications specific to this region. Morocco, being a country that is part of the European Neighbourhood, is entitled to association to the new Framework Programme for research and innovation (Horizon 2020).  I am in favour of this report giving its consent to conclusion of the Agreement.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I welcome the vote in the European Parliament in favour of the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on a Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) between the European Union and its Member States on the one hand, and Morocco on the other. In this way, Moroccan and European companies will be able to strengthen already successful industrial cooperation in the space field. The adoption of this technology will enable Morocco to develop applications that address the problems specific to the Western Mediterranean and West Africa.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the recommendation because: (a) the GNSS system is funded within the Horizon 2020 framework programme, i.e. through money belonging to European citizens, which should also be used for EU Member States and not for Morocco, and (b) there is no reference to data security issues in the report.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The Galileo Programme is the European radionavigation and satellite positioning programme, which aims to provide the European Union with independent navigation technology in relation to American GPS and Russian GLONASS, in a sector that has become central to economic development. The purpose of this cooperation agreement is therefore to facilitate and promote cooperation between the Union and the Kingdom of Morocco in order to collect contributions from both parties to a Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS). Thus, in view of the leverage role that a European GNSS can play in the European economy and assuming the advantages of greater precision and security that this system offers in relation to the others, I voted in favour of the above-mentioned recommendation.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — A proposal by the Council for a Cooperation Agreement on the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) for civilian use between the European Union and the Kingdom of Morocco is at stake. The GNSS system has an undeniable utility and potential. It is undesirable and limiting the strong dependence that exists today in the face of the American GPS system, in addition to having obvious dangers. We have some reservations, however, that the exclusively civilian use of this system and the possibility of its use for military purposes are not entirely guaranteed – a situation to which several pacifist organisations from various countries have been alerting. On several occasions we have already pointed out this concern. In this case, a Cooperation Agreement with Morocco is proposed, the country responsible for a situation of illegal occupation of the territory of Western Sahara, which oppresses the people of that territory and refuses to accept UN resolutions on their right to self-determination. In this regard, we voted against this report, bearing in view of the view that this agreement could cover occupied territories over which Morocco has no sovereignty in the light of international law.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: written — The Kingdom of Morocco undoubtedly possesses the capability and necessary know-how in the field of space technologies and other applications. It is therefore no surprise that it wants to develop the use of satellite navigation in its territory, as well as in the surrounding regions of the Western Mediterranean and West Africa, with a focus on applications specific to these regions. As part of the European Neighbourhood Policy, the Kingdom of Morocco has the right and the right to cooperate and participate in the new Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Framework Programme. In addition, the Treaty on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and the Kingdom of Morocco has been concluded. This legal basis gives the Kingdom of Morocco good potential to contribute to GNSS research.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of the entry of Morocco's territory into the GNSS.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting against the conclusion of the agreement because the GNSS system is funded through the Horizon 2020 framework programme. This money is of European citizens and better used for EU Member States and not for Morocco. I also believe that the agreement should not go ahead, since the report does not mention data security issues, which should be taken into account.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — Galileo is a massive white elephant, part of the EU’s ambition to create a United States of Europe, costing the hard pressed tax payers of Europe a staggering EUR 9.8 billion.   How will the EU recoup these costs?  By charging each driver in Europe a tax per mile they drive. All sensible people should be against this.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. — The Cooperation Agreement on a civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) between the European Community and Morocco will greatly add to the development of scientific progress and the exchange of knowledge and ideas between the two parties.  Morocco has know-how in space technology and applications which will add to EU know-how in this field and will allow Morocco to develop its use of satellite radio-navigation on its territory and in the surrounding region.  This Agreement also provides Morocco with the means to contribute to GNSS-related research in the context of the EU research and innovation programmes and it is great to see the EU cooperating with other countries to spread R&D innovations across the globe.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Cooperation Agreement on a civilian global navigation satellite system between the European Community and its Member States and the Kingdom of Morocco, as the agreement will strengthen cooperation with Morocco in the field of satellite navigation and implement a number of elements of European satellite navigation programmes. It is also important to continue the industrial cooperation started in the space sector that has existed between European and Moroccan companies for years.  I believe that this agreement will benefit not only industry but also scientific communities and citizens, as areas of cooperation provide for training, scientific research, industrial production activities and more.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of my colleague Jerzy Buzek's recommendation on the conclusion of a cooperation agreement with Morocco on satellite navigation. This agreement will promote the implementation of the European GPS system, with Morocco committing to the mapping of its territory as well as neighbouring areas. The recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I welcome Parliament's approval of the cooperation agreement on a civil-use Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) with Morocco, thus strengthening its already close cooperation with the Union. It should be remembered that Morocco is very active in the European Neighbourhood Policy, is associated with the framework programme for research and innovation (Horizon 2020) and has concluded a scientific and technical cooperation agreement with the Union. It will also have to play an important role in the implementation of the PRIMA (Euro-Mediterranean Partnership for Research and Innovation) programme. With regard to satellite navigation and synchronization, the agreement voted by Parliament will strengthen joint activities in these important sectors for the benefit of citizens, industries and scientific communities in the Union and Morocco. This is an example of successful Euro-Mediterranean industrial cooperation.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — Morocco is already entitled to association to the new framework programme for research and innovation and has concluded an Agreement on Scientific and Technical cooperation with the EU. This provides Morocco with a good potential to contribute to GNSS-related research in the context of the EU research and innovation programmes.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Jerzy Buzek. In short, the aim of this agreement is to encourage, facilitate and improve cooperation between the parties in the context of european and Moroccan contributions to the establishment of a global satellite navigation system (GNSS) for civil use as a contribution to the navigation and information infrastructure in Europe and Morocco.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: Morocco wishes to develop its knowledge of space applications in the use of satellite radionavigation in its territory and in the surrounding region (Western Mediterranean and West Africa). Moroccan and European companies have been maintaining industrial cooperation relations in the space sector for several years. The European Commission negotiated the Agreement with the Moroccan authorities, which was signed on 12 December 2006, in accordance with a Council Decision of 27 November 2006. These are agreements that count on my acceptance.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. —Certainly the EU has a dependence on the North American GPS system that should be terminated. But it is also true that there is no guarantee that the GNSS system is exclusively for civilian use, but that it also appears to be given military use, as many pacifist organizations have alerted.  In this particular case, a cooperation agreement is proposed with Morocco, the country responsible for the illegal occupation of the territory of Western Sahara, in contravention of the multiple United Nations resolutions on the right of self-determination of the Saharawi people. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — I support the Report on Cooperation on the Civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) between the European Union and its Member States and the Kingdom of Morocco. The sectors of cooperation in satellite navigation and timing provided for in the agreement are as follows: scientific research, industrial production, training, application, development of services and markets, trade, spectrum issues, integrity issues, standardisation and certification. The agreement is expected to further consolidate joint activities in these sectors for the benefit of citizens, industries and scientific institutions. It should be noted that the proposal has no impact on the Budget of the European Union. As a European Neighbourhood Country, Morocco has the right to join the Research and Innovation Framework Programme (Horizon 2020). In addition, Morocco and the EU signed an Agreement on Scientific and Technical Co-operation. In this regard, Morocco can contribute to GNSS research in the context of EU research and innovation programmes. With regard to the agreement, the EU and Morocco are in the process of signing a letter of intent on cooperation in the field of GNSS, reaffirming their intention to promote cooperation in this area and the intensive use of services based on European GNSS programmes in the Mediterranean area.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted against the Buzek Recommendation on cooperation with Morocco on a Global Navigation Satellite System for Civilian Purposes (GNSS), as the necessary political, legal and other conditions for the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on a Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) for Civilian Purposes between the European Community and its Member States and the Kingdom of Morocco are not fulfilled.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I welcome the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on a Civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) between the European Community and its Member States and the Kingdom of Morocco.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the cooperation agreement on a global civil satellite navigation system (GNSS) with Morocco. In the space sector, Moroccan and European companies have for several years established industrial cooperation relations, which constitute a solid basis on which to develop and extend cooperation in this field of great importance to both parties. The agreement will allow closer cooperation with Morocco in the field of satellite navigation.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report signed by Mr Buzek, which provides for the approval by the European Parliament of a cooperation agreement on a global civil satellite navigation system with Morocco, as negotiated by the Council, since I believe that it is of great benefit to both its contractors.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal because there is already an existing agreement on a civil global satellite navigation system with the Kingdom of Morocco in 2006, giving both sides advantages.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — I am in favour of the development of the Galileo geolocation system. The EU has signed numerous cooperation agreements on this project with other important countries, including China. The aim here is to conclude a cooperation agreement with Morocco. The aim is to enable the EGNOS system, which improves the accuracy of the Galileo signal, to be effective in the most important area possible. However, I regret the 10 years of delay in the Galileo project. I also regret the choice, imposed by the Commission, of the German company OHB for the construction of satellites at the expense of Astrium (EADS) and Thales Alenia Space, companies that had already proved their worth. Finally, I regret the choice made of interoperability with the United States with the GPS system in 2004. Germany has played a harmful role in this matter, serving the United States and its mercantile interests. I'm voting for.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The purpose of this Agreement is to promote, facilitate and strengthen cooperation between the Parties in the context of contributions by the European Union and Morocco to a global satellite navigation system (GNSS) for civilian use. The sectors open to cooperation activities in the field of satellite navigation and timing covered by the agreement are: scientific research, industrial production, training, application, service and market development, trade, radio spectrum issues, integrity, standardisation and type-approval. This is a very important agreement for the development of industrial relations and research between the two countries, hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this recommendation because of the years of industrial cooperation between Moroccan and European firms in the space sector. It is now time to further this relationship and cooperation in this field.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. For several years, our industrial companies have been cooperating with Morocco in the space field. I therefore welcome this agreement, which consolidates the foundations of this cooperation. It is undeniable that Morocco has real assets in the field of space technology and I am deeply convinced of the need to strengthen this cooperative base which is beneficial for both parties. I support strengthening our joint research activities through European and Moroccan research programmes that will benefit citizens, industries and scientific communities, and facilitate the growth of GNSS applications.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the use of satellite radio-navigation to be developed on Moroccoʼs territory and in the surrounding region: the western Mediterranean and West Africa. Being a country that is a part of the European Neighbourhood, Morocco is entitled to association to the new framework programme for research and innovation, Horizon 2020. Moreover, Morocco has concluded an Agreement on Scientific and Technical cooperation with the EU; this provides Morocco with good potential to contribute to GNSS-related research in the context of the EU research and innovation programmes.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This recommendation for a cooperation agreement on a Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) between the European Union and Morocco aims to improve cooperation between the two sides and allow for an exchange of scientific knowledge. Morocco wants to develop the use of satellite radio navigation on its territory and in the surrounding region. It is within the framework of the 2006 agreement and by virtue of its participation in the European Neighbourhood Policy that Morocco wishes to be associated with the new framework programme for research and innovation (Horizon 2020). I voted for it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — This resolution is as a result of a request for consent submitted by the Council and is necessary to conclude the Agreement on behalf of the European Union to enable the participation of the Kingdom of Morocco in the Galileo Programme.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I voted for this cooperation agreement in the field of research and innovation as it paves the way for new partnerships with countries such as Morocco that share common values with European ones. In this respect, I believe that any future collaboration is a plus in Morocco's democratic journey, and I have also initiated a number of projects aimed at supporting this partnership.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - Cooperation with Morocco in the field of a global civil satellite navigation system is unlikely to pose any financial risks in its actual design. The possibility of abuse is also no higher than with existing satellite navigation systems such as the GPS system. I therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. Negotiations between Morocco and the EU began in 2004. In 2006, the cooperation agreement on a global satellite navigation system between the EU and Morocco was signed. This agreement must now, of course, be approved on behalf of the Union. As I was in favour of cooperation between countries in the field of research, I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the conclusion of the cooperation agreement because Morocco is a well-developed country in this area and the sharing of knowledge with a Company of European countries will increase synergies and develop the sector significantly, in particular as regards the civil global satellite navigation system.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: In writing. — I voted for this text which strengthens cooperation between the Union and Morocco and is part of our desire to integrate Morocco and the Maghreb into a large Euro-Mediterranean region.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Considering that the draft cooperation agreement on the Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) for civil use is an important cooperation initiative between the EU and Morocco, I would like to vote in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — When it comes to experience in space technology, the Kingdom of Morocco is a country that competes with its expertise, so it is not surprising that it wants to expand the use of satellite navigation not only in its own territory, but also to other surrounding regions. As it has also created a good basis for further development with European companies in the industrial and space sectors, the Minister for Infrastructure and Transport has sent a letter with a view to concluding cooperation agreements with the European Community regarding the civilian satellite radio navigation system. The agreement between the European Community and the Kingdom of Morocco was signed on 12 December 2006 on the basis of a Council decision giving Morocco the opportunity to join the Research and Innovation Framework Programme (Horizon 2020). By signing the Agreement on Scientific and Technical Cooperation, Morocco will be able to contribute to GNSS research on EU research and innovation programmes.  I believe that the security of energy delivery, energy systems, ensuring the stability and predictability of energy policies, as well as the management of energy resources is an important precondition for the fundamental achievement of economic growth and development of each country, and I supported the recommendation on the conclusion of the Agreement with Morocco.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. — The objective of this Agreement is to facilitate and extend cooperation between the European Union and Morocco to the functioning of the global satellite navigation system. In addition to satellite navigation, GNSS is also used to determine the time and includes GALILEO, which is fully under civilian control. Cooperation with the Kingdom of Morocco will take place mainly in the fields of scientific research, industrial production, market and service development and security. This agreement does not affect in any way the legal establishment of the European GNSS Supervisory Authority or its institutional structure. I believe that this is an important step in the development towards closer international cooperation in the field of diplomacy and scientific development.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the draft conclusion of the cooperation agreement on a global civil satellite navigation system between the European Community and its Member States and the Kingdom of Morocco because, on the basis of the recommendation of the ITRE Committee, I believe that all the necessary conditions were in place and that it is a step towards a better, increasingly global and comprehensive satellite navigation system.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — Scientific cooperation is, in fact, a very positive thing at first. I also appreciate the good relations that the European Union has with Morocco. However, it would be naive to think that a sector such as satellite navigation could clearly be classified as civil. The concern may be a civil one – but nothing can ensure that the consequences will be purely civil. Navigation always means positioning, which brings us very close to the field of dual use. And then the well-intentioned research cooperation must also ask itself how it believes it can ensure that the work of the democratic opposition to the Moroccan royal family is affected precisely by these dual use items in its work.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — With this recommendation, the European Parliament must decide on the merits of a cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Morocco on a global satellite navigation system. It turns out that the space industries of the European Union and Morocco have good contacts, especially under the Galileo programme. I therefore vote in favour of continuing this collaboration.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — Contacts on Morocco's participation in the GALILEO programme began on 24 March 2004. After a round of bilateral talks on 13 October, morocco's Minister for Equipment and Transport sent a letter to the Director-General for Energy and Transport of the European Commission to confirm morocco's intention to conclude with the EU a cooperation agreement on the satellite navigation system for civilian use. The European Commission, on the basis of a negotiating mandate given by the Council on 21 April 2005, then negotiated negotiations and the agreement was signed on 12 December 2006 in accordance with the Council Decision of 27 November 2006 authorising the signature. It considers that the Cooperation Agreement on a Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) between the European Community and the Kingdom of Morocco will allow for the strengthening of joint activities in important sectors such as scientific research, industrial production and training for the benefit of citizens, industry and scientific communities of both parties. I voted in favour of this resolution, which approves its conclusion.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — This Agreement culminates the contacts established between the European Union and Morocco for Morocco's participation in the Galileo programme. The talks began in March 2004 and ended in December 2006, when the Cooperation Agreement on a civil global satellite navigation system (GNSS) was signed between the European Community and its Member States and the Kingdom of Morocco. This Agreement will allow cooperation on navigation and satellite timing. The areas covered by the Agreement are scientific research, industrial manufacturing, training, applications, service and market development, trade, radio spectrum, integrity issues, standardization and certification. In this way, joint activities in these sectors may be strengthened for the benefit of citizens, industries and scientific communities on both sides, which is why I have supported it.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — Morocco has been participating in the Galileo Programme of the European Union since December 2006. It also has a Scientific and Technical Cooperation Agreement with the EU and is part of the European Neighbourhood Policy, so it can, if you show interest, join the new Framework Programme for Research and Innovation- Horizon 2020. In addition, it has expertise in space technologies and applications and intends to develop the use of satellite radio navigation on its territory, western Mediterranean and West Africa. On the other hand, there are close cooperation relations between various European and Moroccan companies in the space sector, which increases the possibility of enlargement to other sectors of activity. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of concluding this Agreement.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — The establishment of the global satellite navigation system with Morocco will allow for the realization of an accurate mapping of the Moroccan territory as well as its neighbouring areas. The European Union and Morocco will benefit from each other's technology and the data that will come from it.  I supported this report, which reminds us of the importance of the European Union's cooperation with its neighbours.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - Certainly the EU has a dependence on the North American GPS system that should be put to an end. But it is also true that there is no guarantee that the GNSS system is exclusively for civilian use, but that it also appears to be given military use, as many pacifist organizations have alerted. In this particular case, a cooperation agreement is proposed with Morocco, the country responsible for the illegal occupation of the territory of Western Sahara, in contravention of the multiple United Nations resolutions on the right of self-determination of the Saharawi people. In this regard, I voted against this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted in support of the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on a Civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) between the European Community and its Member States and the Kingdom of Morocco. This Agreement allows for closer cooperation with Morocco in the area of satellite navigation. Moroccan and European firms have had industrial cooperation links in the space sector for several years, providing a solid foundation on which to build and extend cooperation in this field which is of great importance to both parties.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — The aim of this agreement is to conclude negotiations on a Cooperation Agreement with the civilian global navigation satellite system between Member States and Morocco. Also, the point of this proposal is to strengthen synergies with Morocco in the field of satellite navigation. Morocco has good experience and results in the field of space technology and applications, and the agreement adopted would be mutually beneficial. Cooperation would be carried out in areas that will be in line with scientific research, industrial production, training, applications, services and market development, trade, radio spectrum issues, integrity issues, standardisation and certification. The realization of this agreement will strengthen joint activities in these areas for the benefit of society and industry, and the benefits of using satellite radio navigation on the territory of the European Union will be a good boost to the growth and development of various industries.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — The proposal for this act is the conclusion of a Cooperation Agreement between the Member States of the Union and Morocco, proposed by the Council, on a civilian global navigation satellite system.  Cooperation with neighbouring countries is important to the European Union, as only through strategic partnership it is possible to ensure prosperity for both the Union and the neighbourhood. The focus of this proposal is to strengthen synergies with Morocco in the field of satellite navigation, and we know well what the importance of such systems is. Morocco is known to have made a major breakthrough in space technology and applications, while the use of satellite radio navigation on EUROPEAN Union territory will benefit everyone.  We can also consider this Agreement in the context of job creation and will directly link scientific research, industrial production, market development, as well as trade. The agreement is useful and will benefit citizens and industries on both sides and that is why I supported it.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — Horizon 2020 funds should be directed to EU member countries and not to third countries. In addition, the data security issues of this system are not defined.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I supported the draft cooperation agreement on a global satellite navigation system (GNSS) for civilian use between Europe and Morocco and therefore voted in favour of Mr Buzek's proposal.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the Civil Global Navigation Satellite Cooperation Agreement (GNSS) between the European Community and its Member States and the Kingdom of Morocco, as I believe it will strengthen cooperation with Morocco in the areas of satellite navigation, industrial production and scientific research. This agreement will facilitate cooperation between the two sides and strengthen european and Moroccan contributions to the global navigation satellite system and further consolidate joint activities for the benefit of citizens, industries and scientific communities.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — Negotiations between Morocco and the EU on an agreement on satellite navigation systems began in 2004.  The aim of the agreement is to strengthen cooperation with Morocco in the field of satellite navigation.  In particular, Morocco wants to "develop the use of satellite radio navigation on its territory and in the surrounding region"; the agreement also builds on "Moroccan and European companies that have maintained industrial cooperation in the space sector for several years". At a time when the human rights situation in Morocco is constantly deteriorating, it would have been appropriate to question whether it would help the Moroccan government develop technologies that could be used to monitor its population. However, not the slightest precaution or reservation has been mentioned in this area. So I voted against this agreement.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — A proposal by the Council for a Cooperation Agreement on a Comprehensive Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) for civilian use between the European Community and the Kingdom of Morocco is at stake. Morocco maintains an illegal occupation in Western Sahara. It oppresses its people and refuses to accept UN resolutions on that people's right to self-determination. In this sense, we voted against this agreement because we did not recognise legitimacy to the Kingdom of Morocco in negotiating treaties that could potentially cover occupied territories belonging to Western Sahara.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — As there is already an existing agreement on a civil global satellite navigation system with the Kingdom of Morocco in 2006 and it gives far-sighted advantages to both the EU and Morocco, I voted in favour of the request.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — A Proposal by the Council for a Cooperation Agreement on a Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS), said for civilian use, between the European Community and the Kingdom of Morocco is at stake. Morocco maintains an illegal occupation in Western Sahara. It oppresses its people and refuses to accept UN resolutions on the right of that people to self-determination, so we voted against this agreement for not recognising legitimacy to the Kingdom of Morocco in negotiating treaties that could potentially cover occupied territories belonging to Western Sahara.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted against this report since I cannot accept as legitimate the current Government of Ukraine, which emerged from a coup d'a coup d'a. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. — This recommendation on the Council's draft decision on the renewal of the EU-Ukraine Science and Technology Cooperation Agreement must be voted on in the same way as the previous one and will cover the next five years.  This decision will enable the European Union and Ukraine to "benefit from the scientific and technical progress made through research cooperation within the framework of their respective specific research programmes and facilitate further cooperation". It is in line with previous votes, particularly on free trade and the possible integration of Ukraine into the Union. This agreement again violates the sovereignty of the nation-states, which are obliged to cooperate because of the will of the Brussels technocrats to speed up the process of Europeanisation of Ukraine and to further distance it from its relations with Russia. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — I note that the European Union has spent EUR 45 million of taxpayers’ money (c. EUR 26.5 million to Ukraine) for the sponsorship of co-operation with research.  At a time when Europe is supposed to be tightening its belt, and at a time where the situation in the Ukraine is unstable, I wonder whether this decision is wise?

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to renew the agreement with Ukraine on scientific and technological cooperation. The content of the renewed agreement will be at the same level as the current agreement, which expired on 7 November 2014. The agreement is based on mutual benefit, reciprocal access to programmes and activities of the other party. The principles of non-discrimination and the protection of intellectual property shall be established. I agree that the renewal of this agreement will allow for more scientific knowledge, which will increase market access.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I am not, on the face of it, hostile to scientific cooperation with Ukraine, but not under the current conditions.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this agreement because it will allow for an exchange of specific knowledge and a transfer of know-how for the benefit of the scientific communities, industry and the citizen. The agreement is based on the principles of mutual benefit, reciprocal access to the other party's programmes and activities in relation to the purpose of the agreement, non-discrimination, effective protection of intellectual property and equitable sharing of intellectual property rights, as well as effective exploitation of results.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This recommendation on the Council's draft decision on the renewal of the EU-Ukraine Science and Technology Cooperation Agreement must be voted on in the same way as the previous one and will cover the next five years.  This decision will enable the European Union and Ukraine to "benefit from the scientific and technical progress made through research cooperation within the framework of their respective specific research programmes and facilitate further cooperation". It is in line with previous votes, particularly on free trade and the possible integration of Ukraine into the Union. This agreement again violates the sovereignty of the nation-states, which are obliged to cooperate because of the will of the Brussels technocrats to speed up the process of Europeanisation of Ukraine and to further distance it from its relations with Russia. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I have voted in favour of the agreement on scientific and technical cooperation with Ukraine, as a consequence of the fact that, on 16/9, I supported the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. In an explanation of vote at the time, however, I highlighted several problems created by the adoption of the Association Agreement with the so-called urgency procedure, which partly undermined the democratic process.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — With the renewal of the Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine, both sides will be able, over the next five years, to continue to develop their collaboration in the field of scientific and technological relations.  It is an Agreement based on the principles of mutual benefit, reciprocal access to programmes and activities of the other party related to the purpose of the Agreement, non-discrimination, effective protection of intellectual property, equitable distribution of industrial property rights and effective exploitation of results. For all this, you have counted on my support.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted on this report because it supports the renewal of the AGREEMENT between the EU and Ukraine on scientific and technological cooperation. The content of the renewed agreement will be at the same point as the current one, which expires on 7 November 2014.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for the renewal of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement with Ukraine because, especially in these times, it is very important to include Ukraine in the European system of scientific cooperation.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — We are being asked here to decide on the renewal (identical to the previous one and for a period of five years) of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and Ukraine. The agreement will enable the European Union and Ukraine to "benefit from the scientific and technical progress made through research cooperation within their respective specific research programmes and facilitate further cooperation." It is, of course, in line with previous votes on free trade and Ukraine's possible accession to the Union. This agreement unquestionably violates the sovereignty of the Member States, which are obliged to cooperate by decision of the Union, of a supranational entity. A Union that continues its geopolitical maneuvers against Russia and its attempts to Europeanize Ukraine. I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision renewing the Agreement on cooperation in science and technology between the European Community and Ukraine. The Agreement on cooperation in science and technology between the European Community and Ukraine was signed in Copenhagen on 4 July 2002. The Agreement provided that it would be concluded for an initial period on 31 December 2002 and would be renewed by agreement of the Parties for additional periods of five years. By Decision 2011/182/EU of 9 March 2011, the Council approved the renewal of the Agreement for an additional five years, until 8 November 2014. The renewal of the five-year Agreement is in the interest of both parties, so as to maintain continuity in scientific and technological relations between Ukraine and the European Union. The European Union must now, more than ever, support Ukraine's efforts to harmonise itself with the European Union and that country's desire to be part of the European Union in the future. The agreement in science and technology will continue to add value to this industry in Europe, and together with Ukraine, Europe will be much stronger on the world market.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — Renewal, without amendment, of the Agreement in force since 1998 and expiring on 7 November 2014. Renewal takes place every five years. Cooperation may cover all research, technological development and demonstration activities, including basic research, carried out in the following fields: − environment and climate, including Earth observation, biomedicine and health, agriculture, forestry and fisheries, industrial and production technologies, materials research, non-nuclear energy, transport, information society technologies, social sciences, scientific and technological policies, training and exchanges between researchers. Similar agreements are in force with other third countries, including Russia (renewed at the beginning of the year). The agreement itself is not problematic. However, the radically changed (and deteriorated) political scenario must be taken into account: such a rapid renewal of the agreement may seem instrumental in relation to the scenario of relations with Ukraine and Russia. I voted against.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of renewing the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation with Ukraine. I believe that it is essential for the European Union to renew the existing agreement with Ukraine, a country that, all the more so at this time, has a very important role to play geopolitically and has the potential to become a leading partner for the EU. The renewal of the agreement will bring Ukraine even closer to the European Union, opening up new channels of political dialogue and establishing basic rules for cooperation, on the principles of mutual benefit and non-discrimination. In addition, the renewal of the agreement will enable both parties to improve and intensify cooperation in areas of common interest and will allow the further exchange of specific scientific knowledge and the transfer of know-how for the benefit of the scientific community, businesses and citizens.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. - I voted against this proposal because the EU has spent EUR 45 million sponsoring co-operation in research with eastern European countries, (including approximately EUR 26.5 million with Ukraine).

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — The renewal of the agreement between the EU and Ukraine on improving scientific and technological cooperation is in favour of the development of relations between the two countries. However, we have doubts about the rapprochement of the two countries, which has been done so quickly, given the instability with Russia.

name: Salvatore CICU
