text: in writing. — The European Economic Area (EEA) brings together EU Member States and three members of the European Free Trade Association (Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway) in a single market. The EEA Agreement provides for the inclusion of EU legislation on the four freedoms (free movement of goods, services, persons and capital) in all EEA countries. The Agreement also covers cooperation in other important areas such as research and development, education, social policy, the environment, consumer protection, tourism and culture, known together as "horizontal and complementary" policies. The Agreement guarantees equal rights and obligations within the internal market for EEA citizens and economic operators. Croatia's participation in the EEA is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU and therefore approval should be given to the conclusion of the Agreement on Croatia's participation in the EEA and its additional protocols.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — This report is purely technical in nature, as Croatia's participation in the European Economic Area is a consequence of Croatia's accession to the EU. But even so, I have not been able to vote in favour, since I believe it is for the Croatian people to decide whether or not to join the EU and, therefore, whether they want to enter into the neoliberal economic logic of the Union. That's why I abstained.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — The Agreement of the European Economic Area provides for a single market between the EU, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway aimed at strengthening economic and trade relations and trade with these countries, including the application of the free movement of goods, persons, capital and services and cooperation in different policies. Having entered the European Union, it is logical that it should also participate in the European Economic Area, and it is mandatory that, after one year after accession, the Commission and the Council take the necessary measures to make their participation possible. For these reasons, I vote in favour of approving Croatia's accession to the European Economic Area.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of Croatia's accession to the European Economic Area because the AfD believes that, below full membership of the EU, any European state can participate in a flexible network of different speeds according to its needs and opportunities. This is a central passage of the AfD election programme, and I personally fully share this view. Croatia's accession to the EU may only be considered after all the accession criteria have been met and after the EU has been consolidated in its present form.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — The Agreement on the European Economic Area (EEA) was signed back in 1992 and entered into force on 1 January 1994. This agreement also joins the European Union's single market with three Signatories to the European Free Trade Agreement: Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway. As a new Member State, the Republic of Croatia should be allowed to participate in the European Economic Area. I supported this report, as it is desirable to expand the free movement space for goods, services, people and capital to strengthen the European economy, and the Agreement further covers cooperation in other important areas such as research and development, education, social policy, consumer protection, tourism and culture. I regret that the treaty amendment and additional protocols are adopted with a late one year.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted against the Lambsdorff recommendation because I believe that the conditions for Croatia's participation in the European Economic Area have not fully matured.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I voted for this proposal as I take the view that the participation of Croatia in the European Economic Area is a natural consequence of its EU accession. The delay is due to the fact that, more than a year after the accession, the necessary legal steps have only just been undertaken by the Commission and the Council to enable this participation.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) I supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the agreement on the participation of the Republic of Croatia in the European Economic Area. It is an agreement that allows Croatia, the twenty-eighth member of the Union, to participate with obligations and benefits in the EEA Agreement which brings together the EU Member States with Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein. The agreement guarantees equal rights and obligations within the framework of the internal market for citizens and economic operators in the EEA.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — The acceptance of Croatia into the European Economic Area is a physiological consequence of its recent entry into the Community family. I voted in favour of this report, in the knowledge that it will help to define the conditions for creating new benefits for the benefit of all Eu ropean States.   I welcome the fact that this document will help to strengthen economic and trade relations between the European Union and the three members of the European Free Trade Association: Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — Since Croatia has fulfilled all the conditions for admission to the European Economic Area, I can only give my assent to this request. With its accession to the EEA, Croatia will be granted the same rights as the other EEA Member States.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The European Economic Area Agreement (EEA) was signed on 2 May 1992 and came into force on 1 January 1994. Croatia's participation in the European Economic Area is a consequence of its accession to the European Union. Also, one year after accession, the Commission and the Council are taking the necessary legal steps to enable Croatia's participation in the EEA and three additional free trade protocols. Out of friendship for the employees of Croatia, I vote against this text which aims to subject them a little more to the neo-liberal yoke.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The EEA Agreement provides for the introduction of EU legislation on the four freedoms – the free movement of goods, services, persons and capital – in all eea countries. In addition, the Agreement includes cooperation in other important areas such as research and development, education, social policy, the environment, consumer protection, tourism and culture, collectively known as horizontal and framework policies. The Agreement guarantees citizens and economic operators who are part of the EEA equal rights and obligations in the internal market.  Croatia's participation in the European Economic Area is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. It is therefore entirely normal that, more than a year after the membership, the Commission and the Council have taken the necessary legal measures to make this participation possible. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — Participation in the European Economic Area (EEA) is one of the major advantages of EU membership and it is time for Croatia and its citizens to enjoy the four freedoms that the EEA agreement provides. Therefore, I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Croatia has been a member of the European Union since 1 July 2013. It is a logical continuation to allow him to participate in the European Economic Area. By voting for the conclusion of this agreement, Croatia is allowed to fully enjoy the attributes of EU membership. This step will enable it to continue its economic integration and to harmonize its domestic legislation with that of the Union, especially with regard to the accompanying policies and horizontal policies that cover the majority of the four freedoms (free movement of goods, services, people and capital).

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of Croatia’s participation in the European Economic Area and the related Protocol, taking into account Croatia’s accession to the European Union. The EEA brings together the EU Member States and three members of EFTA – Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway – in a single market.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The European Economic Area (EEA) brings together the EU Member States and three Member States of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) in a single market, Iceland, Norway and Liechtenstein. This agreement provides for the integration of EU legislation on the four freedoms of the free movement of people, goods, services and capital. With the adoption of this recommendation, Croatia, the new MEMBER state of the Union, will participate in the EEA. Firmly opposed to ultraliberal dogma and to the free and undistorted competition that led to deindustrialization and mass unemployment in France, I voted against this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as I believe that the agreement needs to be updated to include Croatia since its accession to the EU in 2013.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — By virtue of the Act of Accession to the European Union, the Republic of Croatia has undertaken to accede, under the conditions laid down in the Act, to the Agreement on the European Economic Area, in accordance with Article 128. This agreement, which brings together all EU Member States and the three members of the European Free Trade Association – Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway – into a single market, provides for the inclusion of EU legislation on the four freedoms – the free movement of goods, services, persons and capital – in all EEA States. The agreement also calls for cooperation in other important areas such as research and development, education, social policy, the environment, consumer protection, tourism and culture, collectively known as 'accompanying and horizontal' policies. The agreement must also guarantee equal rights and obligations within the framework of the internal market for both citizens and economic operators in the European Economic Area. We therefore believe that Croatia's participation in the European Economic Area is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of Croatia's participation in the European Economic Area, an agreement which allows the new member of the Union to participate with obligations and benefits in the EEA Agreement, which brings together the Member States together with Norway, Liechtenstein and Iceland, or the three members of the European Free Trade Association, in a single market. More than a year after Croatia joined the Eu ropean Union, I believe that the time has come for participation in the EEA as a natural consequence.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - As a member of the European Union, Croatia must be able to participate formally in the European Economic Area. For this logical reason, I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it makes sense to me that Croatia, as a member of the Union, should also participate in the European Economic Area, which brings together the countries of the Union and the three countries of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA).

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal for Croatia to participate in the European Economic Area, because the Treaty provides for four fundamental freedoms on which the whole idea of the European Union is based: the free movement of goods, persons, services and capital. Participation in the European Economic Area is a natural step following accession to the European Union, and Croatia must implement the freedoms as quickly and effectively as possible.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, bearing in mind that the Agreement on the European Economic Area (EEA), in addition to providing for the inclusion of the four freedoms, also provides for the inclusion of cooperation in important areas of development, and considering that croatia's inclusion in the EEA is the natural consequence of its integration into the EU, I would like to vote in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I supported Representative Lambsdorff's recommendation regarding the Decision on the conclusion of an agreement for Croatia's participation in the European Economic Area. I asked High Representatives Ashton about this topic last year.  The purpose of the EEA is to expand the EU internal market to EFTA Member States. In accordance with the EU Accession Treaty, Croatia has also committed to acceding to the Agreement on the European Economic Area, which this proposal ensures. As of April 12, 2014, The agreement on Croatia's participation in the EEA shall be provisionally applied. For the period 2009-2014, EFTA members allocated €9.6 million for Croatia through the Norwegian Financial Mechanism and the EEA Financial Mechanism.  I would point out that this membership will enable Croatia to trade with EEA member states and achieve the free movement of goods, persons, services and capital. The agreement also contains horizontal policies related to the four fundamental freedoms from which Croatia will benefit: social policy, consumer policy, environment, statistics and company law, and a number of policies related to research and technological developments. I therefore supported the Agreement on Croatia's participation in the EEA as well as the three related agreements.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) It seems to me entirely logical that Croatia should participate in the European Economic Area (EEA), given that more than a year has already passed since its accession to the EU. Voting in favour of the agreement is the only possible option and, of course, also the three additional protocols, since the EEA provides for a single market between the EU Member States and the three members of the European Free Trade Association: Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — With Croatia's accession to the EU, the latter has at the same time set out a roadmap for full integration into the European Community. Participation in the European Economic Area is only logical. Furthermore, accession to the Schengen Convention is likely to take place next year. At this point, I would like to point out that I welcome Croatia's progress and, at the same time, I would like to motivate others. In the future, the Croatian border will be partly an EU external border. All Member States are encouraged to support Croatia in preventing the illegal flow of people and capital across this border. This requires an honest analysis of what the EU and Croatia can do to ensure this objective.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The last Member State of the European Union must be able to fully benefit from its status. I therefore vote in favour of a resolution to include Croatia in the European Economic Area.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — In force since 1 January 1994, the Agreement on the European Economic Area brings together the EU Member States, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway in a single market, providing for the extension of EU legislation on the four freedoms (the free movement of goods, services, persons and capital) to those member countries of the European Free Trade Association , as well as cooperation between the parties in areas such as research and development, education, social policy, the environment, consumer protection, tourism and culture. As Croatia has joined the EU with effect from 1 July 2013, it is now necessary, in accordance with its Act of Accession, to ensure its participation in the European Economic Area. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the conclusion of the Agreement on the participation of the Republic of Croatia in the European Economic Area and the three related agreements (Additional Protocols between the Kingdom of Norway and the European Union on a Norwegian Financial Mechanism for the period 2009-2014; between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland; and between the European Economic Community and the Kingdom of Norway).

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. — This matter is a technicality which clarifies the position of Croatia now that, as a full member of the European Union, its relationship with the European Economic Area has changed. As a UKIP MEP, I do not consider it to be for me to tell the European Union how it must act in this regard and therefore I abstained.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — The European Economic Area (EEA), in force since 1994, brings together EU Member States and three members of the European Free Trade Association (Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway) in a single market. The EEA Agreement provides for the inclusion of EU legislation on the four freedoms (free movement of goods, services, persons and capital) in all EEA countries. The Agreement also covers cooperation in other important areas such as research and development, education, social policy, the environment, consumer protection, tourism and culture, known together as "horizontal and complementary" policies. The Agreement also guarantees equal rights and obligations within the internal market for EEA citizens and economic operators. Croatia's participation in the EEA is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU and therefore approval should be given to the conclusion of the Agreement on Croatia's participation in the EEA and its additional protocols. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted in favour as this is a natural consequence of Croatia's entry into the EU. As a result of this entry in July 2013, Croatia undertook to accede, under the conditions laid down in its Act of Accession, to the Agreement signed by the EU on the European Economic Area (EEA) in 1992. The EEA Agreement brings together EU Member States and three members of the European Free Trade Association – Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway – in a single market. The EEA Agreement provides for the inclusion of EU legislation on the four freedoms — the free movement of goods, services, persons and capital — in all EEA States. It covers cooperation in areas such as research and development, education, social policy, the environment, consumer protection, tourism and culture. The Agreement guarantees, in principle, equal rights and obligations in the internal market for citizens and economic operators in the EEA.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. "I voted positively in this draft Council decision. Under the act of accession of the Republic of Croatia (28th member state that joined the European Union on 1 July 2013), Croatia agrees to become a party, according to the conditions set out in that act, to the agreement on the European Economic Area, in accordance with Article 128 of the agreement. By the proposed agreement, the Republic of Croatia is now included in the EEA agreement as a contracting party. I would like to remind you that the agreement on the European Economic Area (EEA) was signed on 2 May 1992 and came into force on 1 January 1994. The EEA agreement ensures the free movement of goods, services, capital and people (the four freedoms) and also includes agreements governing competition policy, consumer protection or education between the 28 EU Member States and Iceland, Norway and Liechtenstein.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — The Agreement on the European Economic Area allowed the single market to accede to the three Non-EFTA countries (Iceland, Norway and Liechtenstein). It entered into force on 1 January 1994 and is part of the 27 Member States (with the exception of Croatia) plus the three countries referred to. The EEA Agreement clearly states in Article 128 that, when a country joins the European Union, it automatically requests entry into the EEA, leading to its enlargement. Croatia thus undertakes to comply with the conditions laid down in the EEA Act of Accession. The Commission and the Council have also taken the necessary legal measures to make this participation possible by Croatia. I therefore believe, like the rapporteur, that this participation is a natural consequence of Croatia's accession to the EU and I am voting in favour of this new Member State being also covered by European rules that regulate the four freedoms of the single market – the free movement of goods, services, people and capital, as well as their integration into so-called horizontal and framework policies , thereby ensuring full equality of rights and obligations in the internal market.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — The European Economic Area (EEA) Agreement was signed in 1992 and came into force on 1 January 1994. Following Croatia's accession to the European Union on 1 July 2013, Croatia pledged to become part of the EEA, following the conditions set out in that act.  I therefore voted in favour of this report, which allows the Republic of Croatia to be included in the EEA agreement as a contracting party.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - Since Croatia has joined the EU, its participation in the European Economic Area must also be sanctioned; Through this vote, the European Parliament gives its consent to the Council to take the necessary measures. Since I do not entirely agree with the application of the principles underlying the single market (movement of goods, services, people and capital), I have chosen to abstain.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as this is a natural consequence of Croatia's entry into the EU. As a result of this entry in July 2013, Croatia undertook to accede, under the conditions laid down in its Act of Accession, to the Agreement signed by the EU on the European Economic Area (EEA) in 1992. The EEA Agreement brings together EU Member States and three members of the European Free Trade Association – Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway – in a single market. The EEA Agreement provides for the inclusion of EU legislation on the four freedoms — the free movement of goods, services, persons and capital — in all EEA States. It covers cooperation in areas such as research and development, education, social policy, the environment, consumer protection, tourism and culture. The Agreement guarantees, in principle, equal rights and obligations in the internal market for citizens and economic operators in the EEA.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - This report is purely technical in nature, as Croatia's participation in the European Economic Area is a consequence of Croatia's accession to the EU. But even so, I have not been able to vote in favour, since I believe it is for the Croatian people to decide whether or not to join the EU and, therefore, whether they want to enter into the neoliberal economic logic of the Union. That's why I abstained.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I consented to the conclusion of an Agreement on the participation of the Republic of Croatia in the European Economic Area, and of three related agreements.  The EEA Agreement brings together the EU Member States and the three members of the European Free Trade Association – Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway – in a single market. The EEA Agreement provides for the inclusion of EU legislation covering the four freedoms — the free movement of goods, services, persons and capital — throughout all the EEA States. I believe that the participation of Croatia in the European Economic Area is a natural consequence of its EU accession.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — The agreement on Croatia's participation in the European Economic Area was signed on 11 April this year and connects the Member States of the European Union and the three signatories of the European Free Trade Zone to the common market. This agreement, which includes Croatia in the European Economic Area, covers cooperation in important areas such as R&D, education, social policy, the environment, consumer protection, tourism and culture. Croatia's membership in the European Economic Area is important for trade with the Member States of the European Economic Area (EU Member States and Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein) as it enables Croatia to become, among other things, a beneficiary of the financial mechanism of the European Economic Area. Also, the aforementioned agreement will provide Croatia with 9.6m euros for the implementation of projects under the current Norwegian financial mechanism. Croatia's accession to the European Economic Area is an obligation stemming from the Treaty on Accession to the European Union and therefore I support the beginning of participation and express my hope that Croatia will take advantage of all the opportunities arising from this Agreement.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I support the proposal for Croatia's entry into the European Economic Area. At the beginning of September 2012, The Commission opened negotiations with Iceland, the Principality of Liechtenstein and the Kingdom of Norway to align the Agreement on the European Economic Area (EEA Agreement) following Croatia's accession to the European Union.  The agreement enables Croatia to become the contracting party to the agreement in the European Economic Area and, after the signed agreements with Norway, Liechtenstein and Iceland, allows it to be included in the Norwegian financial mechanism, which means participation in the single market and free trade, but also equal status with other Member States of the Union. I believe that this agreement will also stimulate the growth of economic exchanges between the aforementioned signatory states.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I supported this proposal by ensuring that Croatia as a new member of the European Union becomes a contracting party to the European Economic Area and, after the signed treaties with Norway, Liechtenstein and Iceland, allows it to also be included in a mechanism that ensures equal action in the single market and free trade, and above all equal status with member states.  Given the high unemployment and difficult economic situation facing Croatia, I expect that the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Economic Area will have positive long-lasting consequences on the economy, exports and new jobs. We know that the Union is based on four fundamental freedoms, and the Agreement is a good step towards ensuring the free movement of goods, services, people and capital.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing — I support the proposal because the removal of barriers between the Republic of Croatia and the European Economic Area will increase prosperity and help the economy for both parties concerned. However, it is a pity that, although Croatia has been a member of the EU since 1 July 2013, the Commission and the Council are only now coming up with this initiative.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — At this particular time, when the economic crisis continues to exist, any attempt to enlarge the EU and the economic agreements with the acceding countries on favourable terms does not contribute to solving the economic problems of the Member States; on the contrary, sharpens them.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the motion on the Agreement of the Republic of Croatia on its participation in the European Economic Area and the signing and provisional application on behalf of the European Union of three related agreements. As a member of switzerland, Norway and the EU-Iceland and EEA Joint Parliamentary Committees, I also consider it important for Croatia to participate in the European Economic Area. The importance of this case is illustrated by the fact that the EEA Agreement brings together EU Member States and three members of the European Free Trade Agreement as a single market: Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway. The EEA Agreement requires all EEA States to take over EU legislation on the four freedoms: the free movement of goods, services, persons and capital. The agreement also covers cooperation in other important areas such as research and development, education, social policy, the environment, consumer protection, tourism and culture ('accompanying and horizontal policies'). It should be noted that the treaty brings obligations and not only benefits, as the agreement provides equal rights and obligations in the internal market for EEA citizens and economic operators.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Croatia's participation in the economy is only the logical consequence of its accession, so there was no reason to vote against it. The EEA agreement provides for the integration of EU legislation on the four freedoms (free movement of goods, services, people and capital) in all EEA countries. In addition, the agreement also governs cooperation in other important areas, such as research and development, education, social policy, the environment, consumer protection, tourism and culture, referred to as "accompanying policies and horizontal policies" The agreement guarantees individuals and economic operators equal rights and obligations in the EEA internal market.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — My vote in favour of this technical dossier is based on considering Croatia's incorporation into the European Economic Area as a step consistent with its accession to the EU.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The EEA Agreement brings together the EU Member States and the three members of the European Free Trade Association – Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway – in a single market.  The Agreement includes cooperation in important areas such as research and development, education, social policy, the environment, consumer protection, tourism and culture. The Agreement guarantees citizens and economic operators who are part of the EEA equal rights and obligations in the internal market. Croatia's participation in the European Economic Area is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. We consider it normal for this issue to be put and we have nothing to stand against as long as the will of the Croatian people is respected.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — (DE) I voted in favour of this request because I believe that Croatia must comply with all the conditions for admission to the European Economic Area and must therefore also fulfil the same rights, but also obligations.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the INTA report (A8-0026/2014) concerning Participation of Croatia in the European Economic Area. The Agreement on the European Economic Area was signed on 2 May 1992 and entered into force on 1 January 1994. According to the Act of Accession of the Republic of Croatia, Croatia undertakes to accede, under the conditions laid down in the Act, to the Agreement on the European Economic Area, in accordance with Article 128 of that Agreement.  On 4 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with the Republic of Iceland, the Principality of Liechtenstein and the Kingdom of Norway to amend the EEA Agreement and the Agreement between the Kingdom of Norway and the European Union on a Norwegian Financial Mechanism for the period 2009-2014. The negotiations with Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway were successfully concluded. The proposed Agreement makes the Republic of Croatia a contracting party to the EEA Agreement. The Protocol includes Croatia in the Norwegian Financial Mechanism.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. - I voted on the recommendation on the Council Decision on the signing, on behalf of the EU, of the Agreement on the participation of the Republic of Croatia in the European Economic Area - SEE. Croatia's participation in the EU is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU. In this respect, today's EP decision completes the enlargement of the EU with the new Member State of Croatia. The Agreement on the SEE, which entered into force on 1 January 1994, brings together the MEMBER States of the EU and three Member States of the European Free Trade Association — Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway — in a single market. The signatories of this agreement undertake to include in national laws EU legislation on the four freedoms - the free movement of goods, services, persons and capital.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — This report recommends the adoption of the conclusion of the Agreement on Croatia's participation in the European Economic Area (EEA).  In view of Croatia's accession to the European Union, it is necessary to conclude different Agreements and Protocols in place to effect Croatia's participation in the EEA. Although we believe that the process of eu join has had negative consequences for the peoples of Europe, we also believe that this is up to us to decide on those same peoples, so we have the same sense of voting here in relation to the decisions or processes that fall within the framework of the normal consequences of that support. That is why we are also abstaining in this report.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. — The granting of sea is a tax on goods that affects both imports of goods in the five ultra-marine French departments and production activities within those territories. This tax allows communities to benefit from a significant financial contribution (1 billion euros) and to stimulate the economic development of local production. This local protectionism works well and remains tolerated by successive governments, which refuse to apply the same methods at the French or European level.  This council proposal presented by the Commission aims to renew for the period 2015-2020 the possibility of applying differentials of taxation, while framing this practice in order to compensate also for the handicaps that affect these distant regions. Together with the Members of the National Front, I voted in favour of this text which protects French citizens living overseas.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — This report proposed special treatment for the French overseas territories.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to create a new legal framework governing dock taxes applicable in the outermost regions of France, payable from 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020, for the approval of products eligible for tax exemptions or reductions there. France is authorised to apply a lower docking tax on certain products produced in the outermost regions of France. The aim is to compensate for the disadvantages faced by this type of region: seclusion, dependence on raw materials and energy resources, and a small local market. As this measure promotes the economy and competitiveness in the outermost regions, but does not affect the co-existence of the internal market and the EU legal framework, I support this proposal.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — This text aims to continue to promote economic activity and competitiveness in the outermost regions, while not harming the cohesion of the internal market or the legal order of the European Union. A new legal framework has been established to change the tax regime known as the "sea grant".

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report as the Commission establishes a new legal framework for 'island discretion' for the period from 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020, determining the products to which tax exemptions and reductions may apply. While the products on the new list are fundamentally similar to those listed in the Annex to Council Decision 2004/162/EC, it should be noted that a number of new products have been introduced and others deleted. This report will serve to further stimulate economic activity and competitiveness in the outermost regions, without understeering the coherence of the internal market and the EU legal order.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The granting of sea, which is a tax on goods, affects both imports of goods in the five French overseas departments and production activities within those territories. This tax allows these communities to benefit from a significant financial contribution (1 billion euros) and to stimulate the economic development of local production. A kind of reasoned protectionism, in short, which seems to work well and does not seem to hinder our political leaders, who refuse to apply the same methods at the French or European level.  This council proposal presented by the Commission aims to renew for the period 2015-2020 the possibility of applying differentials in taxation while framing this practice, in order to also compensate for the handicaps that affect these outermost regions. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the simplified procedure to allow, from 2015 to 2020, a new system of partial or total exceptions to duties on products manufactured in the French outermost regions to support their competitiveness and development.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — Until 1 July 2014, France was authorised to provide exemptions or reductions in the 'island discretion' tax for certain products manufactured in the French outermost regions (except Saint Martin), in order to compensate for the disadvantages affecting them and to support their competitiveness and social and economic development.  The proposal now being submitted aims to establish a new legal framework for 'island discretion' for the period from 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020, determining the products to which tax exemptions and reductions may apply. While the products on the new list are fundamentally similar to those listed in the Annex to Council Decision 2004/162/EC, several new ones have been introduced and others deleted. Sounds like a justified measure. Its aim is to further stimulate economic activity and competitiveness in the outermost regions, without undermining the coherence of the internal market and the EU legal order, so I voted in favour, in accordance with the procedure proposed by the presidency of the REGI Commission, that it be adopted without amendment, in accordance with Article 50 of the Regulation.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supported parliament's decision on the procedure for the application of the docking tax in the outermost regions of France. The purpose of this Decision is to create a new legal framework governing dock taxes in the outermost regions of France payable between 1 January 2015 and 31 December 2020 and to adopt a list of products eligible for tax exemptions or reductions. Since, according to Parliament's assessment, this measure can be regarded as justified and intended to promote the economy and competitiveness in the outermost regions of the EU, without compromising the co-existence of the internal market and the EU legal framework, this agreement was approved by Parliament without amendment.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. "I have spoken in favour of this text. The granting of sea, a tax on goods, affects both imports of goods in the five French DOMs and production in these territories. This tax provides funding for local authorities and their activities and contributes to local economic development, through a differential in taxation. This text proposes to renew this scheme for 2015-2020. We can welcome the consideration of the particular situation of our compatriots overseas.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I supported this resolution because I think that sometimes we need exceptions in our internal market in order to support regions with genuine economic difficulties.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — Funding for France's outermost regions is largely dependent on decisions by Brussels. One issue of particular concern to the RUP today is the future of the sea-granting regime. It was on 1 July 2014 that the Council's decision of 10 February 2004, which authorized the current regime, expired for ten years. This improves the local industry's competitiveness, which suffers from the particular constraints listed in Article 349 of the TFUE: remoteness, dependence on raw materials and energy, the obligation to build larger stocks, the small size of the local market combined with little-developed export activity. It is the recognition by the European Union of a kind of local economic protectionism. However, this exorbitant regime of internal market law is threatened by the European Commission, which now sees it as a so-called situational rent, when in reality it is the guarantor of the survival of the economic fabric of the overseas regions. As such, it demonstrates by its existence that the dogma of free trade poses an unparalleled threat to the most troubled regions. That is why I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution approving the continuation of the 'sea grant' tax regime in the french outermost regions.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report authorising the French Republic to apply exemptions or reductions in taxes to docking fees for certain products manufactured locally in the French outermost regions: Guadeloupe, French Guiana, Martinique, Mayotte and Réunion. The tax on docking taxes is an indirect tax applied to supplies and exports of goods to the French outermost regions. In principle, it applies in the same way to locally manufactured products and to those not manufactured locally. The proposal provides for an extension of the period of application of Decision 2004/162/EC for a further six months, from 31 December 2014 to 30 June 2015, and the measure will give France the time it takes to transpose the provisions of the new Council Decision into its national legislation.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — A vote is taken under the simplified procedure to allow from 2015 to 2020 there to be a new system, agreed with the French Government, of partial or total exceptions on duties on products manufactured in the French outermost regions in order to support their competitiveness and create development. This measure has no consequences for our production system, and I voted in favour of it.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. —It seems like a justified measure. Its objective is to further stimulate economic activity and competitiveness in the outermost regions, without undermining the coherence of the internal market and the EU legal order, so that the presidency of the REGI Commission proposed that it be adopted without amendment, in accordance with Article 50 of the Regulation.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — France has until 31 December 2014 a special regime to abolish or reduce the "sea grant" tax for several products from the French outermost regions. This measure aims to help France's outermost regions cope with the socio-economic problems they face. This report will allow this special regime to last until 2020. I voted for him. I believe that we need to help the outermost regions to support themselves. These regions face particular constraints, particularly in terms of geographical accessibility. In accordance with the treaty, we must adapt our trade rules to this situation in order to establish a level playing field.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — The aim of the report is to establish a new legal framework authorising France to provide, until 31 December 2020, for partial or total exemptions from the tax ("sea duties") for a number of products manufactured in the French outermost regions in order to compensate for the disadvantages of the outermost regions concerned (the great distance, dependence on raw materials and energy, the small size of the local market and the poor development of export activity) and to support their competitiveness and competitiveness. socio-economic development by determining the products to which partial or total tax exemptions may be applied.  I voted in favour of this report today because I believe that the disadvantages suffered by the French outermost regions can still be seen clearly and are therefore in favour of maintaining a differentiated taxation system until 31 December 2020 for certain products.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. - I voted against this proposal which seeks special treatment for French overseas territories  and urges a longer time frame for the French request.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) This measure is an aid to regions which are at a disadvantage because of their geographical position and which does not prejudice the rules of the internal market. We can only support this proposal.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) I am convinced that the rules must be respected, so that there is no chaos. At the same time, as Pope Francis reminded us during the last plenary session, I believe that the rules should be interpreted so as not to be blindly applied. In this case, I am in favour of granting the derogation to the french overseas territories because I realise that they are already at a disadvantage compared to the nearest territories in terms of the competitiveness of their products. Of course, since we have more advantage in exporting, derogations and incentives should be balanced, but as far as the internal market is concerned, I agree with the fact that they are considered as they are: an isolated case, worthy of exception.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this decision on sea duties in the French outermost regions. These are partial or total exemptions from the "sea duties" tax, which will apply to products manufactured in the regions of the French overseas departments.  I think it is right and proper to compensate for the economic disadvantage caused by distance, the small size of the local market and low exports. These measures will support and stimulate the competitiveness and economic activity of these regions. That is why I agree with France's request to be able to extend this type of tax until 31 December 2020 and to extend council Decision 2004/162/EC by a further 6 months, that is, until 30 June 2015, in order to allow France time to transpose the new provisions into its national law.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The ‘dock dues’ tax is an indirect tax applied to deliveries and exports of goods in the French outermost regions. The purpose is to authorise France to apply exemptions or reductions to the ‘dock dues’ tax for certain products produced locally in the French outermost regions of Guadeloupe, French Guiana, Martinique, Mayotte and Réunion, and to establish a new legal framework for the dock dues from 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020, by determining the products to which tax exemptions and reductions may be applied. As this, in particular, might simplify the obligations of small enterprises I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because the purpose of the proposal before us is to establish a new legal framework for sea duties from 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020, determining the products to which partial or total tax exemptions may be applied. Although the products included in the new list are mostly similar to those listed in the Annex to Council Decision 2004/162/EC, some new products have been introduced, while others have been deleted. I voted in favour in order to extend decision 2004/162/EC by a further six months (until 30 June 2015) in order to give France time to transpose into national law the provisions of the new Council decision for the period 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020. I also vote in favour of continuing to stimulate the competitiveness and economic activity of the outermost regions, without prejudicing the coherence of the internal market and the legal order of the European Union.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. - I agree with the objective of this proposal to authorise France to apply exemptions or reductions to the ‘dock dues’ tax for certain products. The purpose of the tax differentials is to offset the handicaps affecting these outermost regions, avoiding the increase of production costs and the prices of products produced locally. Thus I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Under EU rules, it is possible to provide specific measures for the outermost regions of the Union, including the French overseas departments, to deal with the structural economic and social problems specific to these regions. The European Parliament, in favour of exempting certain locally produced products from these regions from the "sea grant", has been listening to their concerns. I have thus supported this text which is beneficial for these French regions.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The outermost regions are hard hit by the economic crisis and the labour market situation is particularly alarming, with a very high unemployment rate: 23.8% in Guadeloupe, 28.7% in the Canary Islands, 28.9% in Reunion, and an even more worrying youth unemployment rate, up to 60%. It is therefore crucial that the Union provides stronger support to local producers.  The renewal for 2015-2020 of the special regime for the granting of seas in the outermost regions goes in this direction. The granting of sea is a tax on goods that affects both imports of goods in the five French overseas departments and production activities within those territories. This tax has the dual objective of ensuring the financing of local authorities (almost EUR 1 billion in revenue per year) and, through tax differentials, to stimulate the economic development of local production. The entry into force of the new decision on 1 January 2015 is of crucial importance, both for the continuity of the system and for the functioning of local businesses.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — According to a Council decision of February 2004, France received discounts for some products up to and including 1 July 2014 in respect of the octroi de mer tax applied in the French outer regions in order to counteract and stimulate their competitiveness, social and economic development through a number of significant difficulties affecting the outer outer regions (e.g. dependence on the small, limited market, geographical distance, low export capacity). France has requested the maintenance of a differentiated tax system such as the one above by 31 December 2020. This measure does not undersk up the unity of the internal market or the Union legal order, it is intended to stimulate the economic activity and competitiveness of the outermost regions and should therefore be supported.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. — I welcome the vote on the tax regime for docking taxes in the French outermost regions; I consider it necessary to stimulate economic activity and competitiveness in the outermost regions.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — I have decided to vote in favour of this text, which in particular promotes the interests of the French maritime area and the activities of the outermost territories, especially ultramarine ones. These territories are power issues for France and for its rank in Europe and the world.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the report because there is a risk that the tax regimes it proposes will lead to the creation and maintenance of 'tax havens'.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The authorisation given to France for exemptions or reductions of the octroi de mer tax on certain products manufactured in the French outermost regions (with the exception of Saint Martin) to compensate for the disadvantages affecting the outermost regions concerned and to support their competitiveness and socio-economic development makes perfect sense. Therefore, the creation of a new legal framework for the octroi de mer tax for the period from 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020, allowing the identification of the products to which exemptions or tax reductions may apply, was necessary. My vote in favour is based on the fact that this measure is justified and aims to further stimulate economic activity and competitiveness in the outermost regions, without undermining the coherence of the internal market and the EU legal order.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. — The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority the vote on the extension of the 'sea grant' and I welcome that. The "sea grant" is a tax that has existed since 1670 under the name "weight granting" created by Louis XIV and brings in more than 1 billion euros to local authorities overseas. A true heir to tariffs, it protects local production. Declared at first incompatible with the Treaty of Rome in the name of the dogma of free movement, this tax was confirmed and then extended at the initiative of many overseas politicians. For our part, we will remain committed to this tax mechanism and will defend it by any means, in the European Parliament, but also, in the long run, by regaining our fiscal sovereignty.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - On 10 February 2004, the Council took a Decision authorising France to apply, by 1 July 2014, exemptions or reductions from the octroi de mer tax on certain products manufactured in the French outermost regions to compensate for the constraints to which they are subject, such as removal, dependence on raw materials and energy, the small size of the market and the poorly developed export activity affecting the outermost regions. France has now requested the maintenance, until 31 December 2020, of a differentiated taxation system, identical to the above. However, the Commission intends to examine the list of products to which the new system will apply, which will make the process time-consuming and incompatible with the expiry date of the Decision. Thus, in order to enable the Commission to finalise the evaluation, the Council Decision extends the duration of the previous Decision for another six months. When the Commission completes the evaluation, the creation of the new legal framework for the octroi de mer tax for the period from 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020 is followed up.  We voted in favour, taking into account our position of principle of defence of specificities and the consequent necessary positive discrimination of the outermost regions.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The main objective is to allow France to apply the tax exemption or reduction to 'dock dues' for certain products produced locally in the outermost regions. The purpose of these tax differences is to compensate for the disadvantages for the outermost regions, which have to cope with the increased production costs and the associated high price of these products. If the measures in question are not adopted, these products will be less competitive than those produced elsewhere. The proposal in question sets out a clear and precise legal framework for maritime taxes from 1 January 2015 to December 2020.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — The report does not present any problems and will ensure that from 2015 to 2020 there is a new system, agreed with the French Government, of partial or total exceptions on duties on products manufactured in the French outermost regions in order to support their competitiveness and create development.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the 'sea levy' tax regime in the French outermost regions, because there is a risk that such tax regimes will lead to the creation and maintenance of 'tax havens'.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — I voted against as this is asking for the French to have longer to sort out their tax arrangements in their overseas territories, in effect asking for special treatment.  If the tax is due, then the FrenchGgovernment should pay.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the extension of the sea grant until the end of 2020. In france's outermost regions, this tax on imported goods is essential to meet the needs of the communities concerned: it amounts to almost one billion euros per year.  But above all, it is essential to promote the development of local businesses, through exemptions. The economy of the DOM - TOM would not survive the disappearance of the grant of sea. The ultra-marine territories are already hard hit by the lack of raw materials, the cost of energy and the small size of their domestic market: it is our duty not to let these territories become even more impoverished and to promote any measure that allows their economic and social development.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour concerning dock dues in the French outermost regions. I am sure that we have to provide a support for the outermost regions in order to make them more competitive and provide a possibility to develop economically and socially. I do believe that the application of exemptions or reductions to the ‘dock dues’ tax will boost the level of the small sized export activity of a small market.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council Decision on the tax 'octroi de mer' in the outermost Regions of France, as this proposal encourages the economic activities and competitiveness of French regions thousands of kilometres away from their homeland, respecting the coherence of the internal market.  I also support the Commission's proposal to extend the current Council decision by an additional six months to allow France to transpose the measures of the new decision into national law for the period from 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020. The new decision will create a new tailor-made legal framework on taxes that will apply to individual products in order to compensate for the lags in the outermost regions and support their social and economic development.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. " I voted in favour of my colleague Iskra Mihaylova's report on the "sea grant" tax regime in the French outermost regions. A 2004 decision authorized France to apply exemptions or reductions on the "sea grant" tax for several products from the French outermost regions, in order to help them deal with the problems of competitiveness and socio-economic development they face. With this agreement coming to an end at the end of 2014, the text proposes to renew it until the end of 2020 while proposing a new legal framework for sea grants. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the proposal, as it will help to support competitiveness, and social and economic development of the producers in the French outermost regions.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Iskra Mihaylova as this decision allows, until 1 July 2014, the partial or total exemption of the "sea duties" tax for many of the products manufactured in the French outermost regions. Furthermore, given that these regions are characterised by their territorial marginality, I believe that this scheme represents an important and sufficient opportunity to buffer the disadvantages that their geographical position causes.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — France was authorised to provide, until 1 July 2014, for exemptions or reductions in the 'island discretion' tax for certain products manufactured in the French outermost regions (except Saint Martin), and requested that it be able to extend that measure until 2020. This measure seems reasonable, given that its objective is to further stimulate economic activity and competitiveness in the outermost regions, which have objective added difficulties with respect to the rest of the continent in this regard, without undermining the coherence of the internal market and the EU legal order.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — France has requested that a differentiated 'island abitrium' tax regime be maintained for the period 2015-2020 for french outermost regions. The products set out in this proposal are similar, with the exception of some inclusions and exclusions, to the products set out in Decision 2004/162/EC. The Commission includes in the proposal the extension of the application of that decision until 1 July 2015 to give France time to incorporate the new provisions into its legal order.  Considering the conditions of these regions — remoteness, insularity, reduced surface area, relief and adverse climate, and dependence on a small number of products adversely affecting their economic development — I think it is appropriate to approve these measures.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — I submit this report because I consider this measure to be justified and defined with a view to stimulating economic activity and competitiveness in the outermost regions and not jeopardising the EU's internal market and legal order. The aim of the exemption or reduction of the 'octroi de mer' tax for a number of products produced in France's outermost regions (including Saint Martin) is to compensate for shortcomings affecting those affected in the outermost regions (distance, raw material and energy dependency, small market and low level of export activity), and to support their competitiveness and social and economic development.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted against the Mihaylova report on the sea levy in the French outermost regions, as I believe that there is no reason to maintain a system of differentiated taxation for a range of products produced in the French outermost regions until 2020.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. " We voted for this decision which will give some French outermost areas the opportunity to get rid of a special tax.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I voted for this proposal which I consider is justifiable as it aims at continuing to stimulate economic activity and competitiveness in the outermost regions, while not undermining the coherence of the internal market and of the EU legal order.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - The outermost regions of the European Union, such as the French regions, need specific aid in the form of targeted legislative actions, capable of adapting their situation in distant regions to the standards and needs of the EU market. The report that has just been adopted refers to the case of sea duties which, in the case of freight transport from the French outermost regions, will not be implemented. France, until 1 July 2014, will have a partial or total exemption from the "sea duties" tax for a number of products from these regions.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Mihaylova report, because I believe that it is necessary to support competitiveness and socio-economic development within the outermost French regions, whose development is undermined by geographical isolation and the small size of the local market. My agreement with the document also stems from the conviction that the existing directives must be extended so that the Commission can properly assess the new legal framework for sea duties.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council Decision allowing France to apply exemptions or reductions to the ‘Dock dues’ tax in the French Outermost Regions in order to tackle the structural handicaps affecting them. I am convinced these regions will benefit from this Decision as it will make it possible to enhance economic and social development, competitiveness and growth. Outermost regions need our full support in order to further explore their potential, as development is key to EU cohesion. These dues are essential to maintain local production, preserve employment in regions where unemployment is the highest in the EU, and prevent stiff competition from low-cost products from third countries.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — (DE) I agree with this request, since the French territories are already in a bad economic position in the extreme border, owing to their remoteness, their limitation to a narrow local market, weak export activity and their dependence on raw materials. However, since they are part of France and are therefore also part of the European Union, it makes sense to support these areas.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — "The granting of sea" is an indirect tax applied to the deliveries and exports of goods in the French outermost regions. The aim of these differences in taxation is to compensate for the handicaps suffered by the outermost regions. The aim of this new proposal is to establish the legal framework for the granting of sea from 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020. France is thus allowed to apply exemptions or reductions in the grant of sea on goods listed in an annex and produced locally in Guadeloupe, French Guiana, Martinique, Mayotte and Reunion. The Council's proposal falls short of what we were advocating, but it is essential to implement it, I vote FOR.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The octroi de mer is an indirect tax applicable to the delivery and import of goods to the French outermost regions. In principle, it applies in the same way to products that are manufactured locally and to those which are not (products from metropolitan France, other Member States or third countries). This proposal aims to establish the legal framework for the octroi de mer tax from 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020. It extends again for six months the validity of Decision 2004/162/EC to allow France time to transpose the provisions of the new Council Decision into national law, and establishes the new legal framework applicable from 1 July 2015 to 31 December 2020. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because of the necessity to ensure that all citizens and regions of the EU are granted the best possible chance to weather the ongoing economic downturn and due to the importance of Parliament’s continued participation and consultation in matters such as this.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. France comprises 5 of the 8 outermost regions of the European Union (Guadeloupe, Guyana, Martinique, Saint-Martin, Réunion). The EU is very concerned about economic and social development in these regions, which suffer from the marginalisation linked to their geographical specificities such as remoteness, insularity, terrain and difficult climate, dependence on some local productions etc. They are part of the priorities of the EU's cohesion policy, the main objective of which is to reduce economic and social disparities across Europe. It is therefore important to allow France to apply a differentiated taxation system (sea grant) for certain products from these regions in order to support their competitiveness and their economic and social development. However, this regime must not go against the cohesion of the internal market and the legal order of the European Union. This is why it is essential to put in place a new regime for sea grants and to determine their legal contours.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this report, which calls to authorise France to apply exemptions or reductions to the ‘dock dues’ tax for certain products produced locally in the French outermost regions. The purpose of these tax differentials is to offset the handicaps affecting the outermost regions, which increase production costs and therefore the cost price of products produced locally. This proposal will establish the legal framework for the dock dues from 1 January 2015 to December 2020

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report concerns the extension of the "sea grant" tax in the French outermost regions until the end of 2020. This tax on imported goods, which amounts to almost one billion euros per year, helps to meet the needs of the communities previously mentioned and to help their economic and social development. Indeed, the DOM-TOM economy would face even greater difficulties if this tax were to disappear. It should also be remembered here that the maintenance and development of local businesses are mainly done through exemptions. Our ultra-marine territories are already being penalized by dependence on raw materials, a limited internal market and high energy costs. For these reasons, I voted for this report in order to avoid a worsening of the impoverishment of these French territories.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I believe that this report will support the Commission proposal regarding the application of exemptions and reductions to ‘dock duties’ tax for a number of products produced in the French outermost regions, in order to offset some disadvantages affecting he concerned regions. In addition, it will help to support their competitiveness and social and economic development.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — Council decisions authorised France to provide, until 1 July 2014, for partial or total exemptions from the "sea duties" tax for a number of products manufactured in the French outermost regions (with the exception of Saint Martin), in order to compensate for the disadvantages of the same areas (long distance, dependence on raw materials and energy, the small size of the local market and the poor development of export activity) and to support their competitiveness and socio-economic development. After careful assessment by the Commission, this new proposal aims to establish a new legal framework for sea duties from 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020, determining the products to which partial or total tax exemptions can be applied. We still consider this measure justifiable because it intends to continue to stimulate the competitiveness and economic activity of the outermost regions, without prejudicing the coherence of the internal market and the legal order of the European Union.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) Mr President, I voted in favour of the report by Mr De Clercq on behalf of the Committee on The Protection of the European People's Rights. Mihaylova on so-called 'sea duties', those indirect duties applicable to the export of certain goods produced in the outermost regions in a similar way to the same locally produced goods. It is useful for France to have at its disposal a system of differentiated taxation which provides for partial or total exemption of tax precisely for goods produced in the french outermost territories, in order both to compensate for the disadvantages of those territories and to support their competitiveness and socio-economic development.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The request was intended to allow the French Republic to exempt certain outermost regions from a special tax. In any case, these areas have always been in a precarious economic situation and often need financial support. The decisive factor for me was therefore the argument to free the regions from excessive burdens in order to maintain their competitiveness. I therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of extending the sea-granting regime until 2020, because it allows the economies of the French outermost regions to remain in a fragile economic and industrial fabric. Although the emergency procedure did not allow the REGI Committee to give an opinion on the merits, the new regime will give the UPRs time to develop a lasting solution to the economic inequalities that exist in these isolated regions.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal on the assumption that it is in line with economic and social strategies and does not exceed the restrictions on the tax cuts that have been imposed and do not have an impact on the Budget of the European Union.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text because the granting of sea is essential: it provides much-needed resources to ultramarine communities and provides strategic support to local productive sectors. With our support, these grants will be extended until 2020. I am the clear to vote for the economic and territorial cohesion of Europe.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Whereas France has requested an extension of the regulatory differentiation with regard to sea duties, which currently provides for a partial tax exemption for a number of products manufactured in the French outermost regions; that this proposal aims to preserve and stimulate the economic activity and competitiveness of the French outermost regions and considering that this decision undermines the coherence of the internal market, I would like to vote in favour.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. — I fully support the Report. Council Decision 2004/162/EC of 10 February 2004 (as extended by Council Decision 378/2014/EU) authorised France, until 31 December 2014, to apply exemptions or reductions to the ‘dock dues’ tax for a number of products produced in the French outermost regions due to handicaps affecting the concerned territories in order to support their competitiveness and socio-economic development. France requested that a similar system be maintained until 31 December 2020. The purpose of the new proposal is to establish a new legal framework for the dock dues from 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020. It also foresees extending Decision 2004/162/EC by six months in order to allow France to transpose the provisions of the new Council Decision into its national law.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — Funding for France's outermost regions is largely dependent on decisions that fall under the jurisdiction of Brussels. One issue of particular concern to the RUP today is the future of the sea-granting regime. It was on 1 July 2014 that the Council's decision of 10 February 2004, which authorized the current regime, expired for ten years. The local industry thus sees an improvement in its competitiveness, which suffers from the particular constraints listed in Article 349 of the TFUE: remoteness, dependence on raw materials and energy, the obligation to build up larger stocks, the small size of the local market combined with a poorly developed export activity. It is the recognition by the European Union of a kind of local economic protectionism. However, this exorbitant regime of internal market law is threatened by the European Commission, which now sees it as a so-called situation rent, when in reality it is the guarantor of the survival of the economic fabric of the overseas regions. As such, it demonstrates by its existence that the dogma of free trade poses an unparalleled threat to the most troubled regions. That is why I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution approving the continuation of the 'sea grant' tax regime in the french outermost regions.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — Guadeloupe, French Guiana, Réunion, Martinique and Mayotte are among the outermost regions of the European Union under the administrative administration of France whose sensitive socio-economic environments need support for development. Production activity in these areas is worse than the rest of the EU due to factors such as geographical distance and isolation, small spatial area, difficult climatic conditions and dependence on a small number of products.  In terms of increasing competitiveness and production development in these regions, in February 2004, Council Decision 2004/162/EC entered into force, giving France the power to apply reduced/zero taxation rates for certain groups of products produced on its own territory. Given that the existing Decision is in force by the end of the year, it is necessary to adopt a new proposed Decision that would support the economic development of these regions by 2020.  I believe that the tax relief of local production is one of the key factors for development and in this sense I supported this proposal. I believe that the part where small businesses are exempted from paying taxes is also a significant measure to foster entrepreneurial spirit. In a report that the French authorities are obliged to present to the Commission by 31 December 2017, I expect a significant impact on the implementation of these measures in creating a sustainable local economy that will not need such incentive measures in the following periods.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — 'Sea duties' are intended to grant partial or total exemptions from the tax for a number of products manufactured in the French outermost regions (with the exception of Saint Martin), with the aim of compensating for all disadvantages linked to the category of outermost regions, such as long distance, lack of raw materials and energy, a small local market and low exports, in order to help competitiveness and socio-economic development. France had requested an extension until 2020 but I agree with the Commission to extend Decision 2004/162/EC by a further six months in order to give France time to transpose into national law the provisions of the new Council Decision for the period 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020 on sea duties (although, on closer examination, most of the products included in the new list are similar to those listed in the Annex).

name: Maurice PONGA
text: In writing. — As rapporteur for the EPP on this issue, I voted in favour of this report which authorises France to provide tax arrangements for products originating in its outermost regions in order to protect employment and contribute to local economic and social development. I regret, however, that the European Parliament had to use the simplified procedure to avoid any legal vacuum (the current regime expiring on 31 December 2014) and that some of the regional demands have not been met.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — For the European Union, the common internal market is a fundamental achievement. It goes without saying that there are certain inequalities in this, which are being countered with the aim of reducing through subsidies. However, it is completely unacceptable that entire areas of the EU should be exempted from the constituent rules of the internal market by the back door. Nothing else is the proposal that is being put forward here. The fact that Parliament's outsized coalition accepts them shows once again that it is more interested in petty regulation than fair competition and economic growth.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The granting of sea is a specificity of the French islands, which, because of their isolation, find it difficult to promote commercial development. Through this tax, local authorities can adjust their needs and stimulate the economic development of local production. I therefore vote in favour of such a measure.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — Council Decision 2004/162/EC of 10 February 2004 (as drafted by Council Decisions 2008/439/EC of 9 June 2008, 448/2011/EU, 19 July 2011 and 2014/378/EU of 12 June) authorises France to apply, by 31 December 2014, exemptions or reductions from the octroi de mer tax on certain products manufactured in the French outermost regions (with the exception of Saint Martin), in order to compensate for the disadvantages affecting them and to support their competitiveness and socio-economic development.
