Following the request made by France to continue to apply such a system of taxation, the Commission has put forward a proposal for the creation of a new legal framework for the octroi de mer tax for the period from 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020, which identifies the products to which exemptions or tax reductions will apply and provides for a 6-month extension of the validity of Decision 2004/162/EC so that France can transpose the new decision into national law. Because I believe that such a proposal is entirely justified in the light of the objectives of supporting and stimulating the outermost regions, I voted in favour.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — Until 1 July 2014, France was authorised to provide exemptions or reductions in the 'island discretion' tax for certain products manufactured in the French outermost regions (except Saint Martin), in order to compensate for the disadvantages affecting them and to support their competitiveness and social and economic development.  The proposal now being submitted aims to establish a new legal framework for 'island discretion' for the period from 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020, determining the products to which tax exemptions and reductions may apply. While the products on the new list are fundamentally similar to those listed in the Annex to Council Decision 2004/162/EC, several new ones have been introduced and others deleted. Sounds like a justified measure. Its aim is to further stimulate economic activity and competitiveness in the outermost regions, without undermining the coherence of the internal market and the EU legal order, so I voted in favour of the procedure proposed by the presidency of the REGI Commission that it be adopted without amendment, in accordance with Article 50 of the Regulation.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal on the Council's 2004/162/EC decision of 10 February 2004 to authorise France, until 31 December 2014, exemptions or reductions on the "sea grant" tax for several products from the French outermost regions, in order to help them deal with the competitiveness and socio-economic development problems they are currently facing. France has asked to be able to maintain a similar system until 31 December 2020. The new proposal aims to establish a new legal framework for sea grants from 1 January 2015 until 31 December 2020. It also plans to extend the 2004/162/EC decision for six months in order to allow France to transpose the provisions of the new Council decision into its national law.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — Stimulating the socio-economic development and competitiveness of the Member States is one of the objectives of the European Union. It is particularly important when it comes to outermost regions, exposed to a greater number of disadvantages at that level.  To that end, I voted in favour of the report of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament, which, on the basis of the current Article 349 TFEU, authorises France to apply exemptions or reductions of the octroi tax on certain products manufactured in the French outermost regions by 1 July 2014 (extendable for another six months).  The desirable stimulus of economic activity and competitiveness of these regions justify the adoption of this measure, aimed at combating isolation and distance, dependence on raw materials and energy, the small size of the market and the stimulus of export activity (poorly developed in these regions). For all these reasons, it seems clear to me that this measure will not call into question either the coherence of the internal market or the EU legal order, which fully justifies the adoption of the Commission's proposal without amendments, as the rapporteur has proposed.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — France's outermost regions are facing major social and economic challenges, coupled with a significant fall in the competitiveness of their economic sectors. I remain mobilized so that our French economic actors can return to the path of growth, and it is in this sense that I voted in favour of this text. As a result, several products from these regions will be exempt or will benefit from a reduction in the "sea grant" tax until 31 December 2020.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - I have chosen to vote in favour to allow from 2015 to 2020 there to be a new system, agreed with the French Government, of partial or total exceptions on duties on products manufactured in the French outermost regions, in order to support their competitiveness and create development.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Today I voted in support of a Council decision concerning the dock dues in the French outermost regions.  Council Decision 2004/162/EC of 10 February 2004 authorised France, until 1 July 2014, to apply exemptions or reductions to the ‘dock dues’ tax for a number of products produced in the French outermost regions, in order to offset the handicaps affecting the concerned outermost regions and to support their competitiveness and social and economic development.  France had requested that a system of differentiated taxation similar to the above-mentioned system be maintained until 31 December 2020. The new proposal submitted is to establish a new legal framework for the dock dues from 1 January 2015 to 31 December 2020, by determining the products to which tax exemptions and reductions may be applied. This measure intends to continue stimulating economic activity and competitiveness in the outermost regions.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I support this report in view of the urgency of accepting these measures with a view to stimulating economic activity and comptitiveness in the outermost French provinces. This report shows that caring for even the outermost parts of the territory of the European Union is as important as taking care of every other part of the European Union.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I support this proposal because of the difficulties affecting the French overseas territory with a view to ensuring its competitiveness and socio-economic development.  Tax cuts and exemptions have been introduced to ensure the competitiveness of local products in relation to imported French products and to prevent a decline in local production, including a decline in economic stability and the economy. As stated in the Commission's report, 'octroi de mar' tax reductions and exemptions will affect all operators with an annual turnover of at least €300,000 to protect small producers that are carriers of economic prosperity not only in France but throughout the European Union.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing — I did not support the proposal because it is about granting unilateral tax exemptions that are detrimental to the market. Instead of these exemptions, a much more effective solution would be to reduce the rate of this tax across the board. All operators on the market should have a level playing field.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — Although each country is a unique case and should be considered separately, such tax interventions involve the risk of creating and maintaining "tax havens", which are a hotbed of tax evasion.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. " I spoke for the colleague's text. Indeed, the proposal tends to continue to promote economic activity and competitiveness in the outermost regions, while not harming the cohesion of the internal market or the legal order of the European Union.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — I supported this report because I agree that this measure is justifiable and intends to continue to stimulate economic activity and competitiveness in the outermost regions of France, especially in the context of economic crisis. The measures taken are not undermining the coherence of the internal market.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — The special nature of the outermost regions in Portugal, Spain and, as in this case, France, justify specific measures to promote local production and consumption. At the same time, I consider it essential to assess the impact of measures such as tax exemption, in order to ensure that the objective of boosting local economies is achieved and that certain business sectors are not fraudulently benefited.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — We agree with the principle authorising France to apply exemptions or reductions in the octroi de mer tax on certain products manufactured in the French outermost regions (with the exception of Saint Martin), to compensate for the disadvantages affecting the outermost regions concerned (remoteness, dependence on raw materials and energy, small market size and poorly developed export activity) and to support their competitiveness and socio-economic development. Given that this measure is justified and aims to further stimulate economic activity and competitiveness in the outermost regions, without undermining the coherence of the eu internal market and legal order, we agree with the proposal and vote in favour.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Since the French territories are already in a bad economic position in the extreme border , whether through seclusion, their limitation to a narrow local market, weak export activity or their dependence on raw materials – I voted in favour of the request.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 608 workers from Whirlpool Europe S.r.l. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Italy, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Italy, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: in writing. — Vote against.  it is not the role of the EU to compensate for redundancies within individual Member States. this should be a matter for national government to decide.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF for Italy's needs in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Whirlpool Europe, which produces electrical equipment. In 2009, the global financial and economic crisis led to a severe economic downturn in the EU-28 and Italy. Italy's market for large household appliances has decreased from EUR 3 174 billion in 2004 to EUR 3 174 billion in 2007. In 2010, up to EUR 2 649 billion was invested in the eu-25. In 2013, 16.5% of the 608 redundancies in the EGF were intended to be allocated a total amount of EUR 1 890 000. The package of services tailored to them will include guidance and counselling, skills assessment, retraining, vocational training and advice on entrepreneurship. I welcome the mobilisation of this fund to workers affected by Whirlpool Europe.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — Italy has been hit hard by the economic crisis and its impact on household consumption. The case of Whirlpool Europe is indicative of this difficult situation faced by many Italian workers. 608 employees were laid off by the company and suppliers, mainly in the province of Trento. The region, which has seen its unemployment rate double since 2007, has not been spared by the crisis. These layoffs therefore weigh heavily on the regional economy. The EGF's EUR 1,890,000 aid to Italy is entirely justified and will enable these laid-off workers to be reintegrated into the labour market in a region and a country where the crisis has proved devastating.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — I supported FEAG's assistance on behalf of Ireland to support the return to the labour market of workers dismissed from Whirlpool Europe S.r.l. In recent years, Whirlpool made investments at the Spini di Gardolo plant. However, this investment has not been profitable due to the contraction in demand for large appliances and the subsequent reduction in production. The Whirlpool Europe group, which in the first half of 2013 accumulated losses of USD 14 000 000 in Europe, developed a business plan to adapt its production structure to market demand. This plan envisaged the closure of the norrkoeping (Sweden) and Spini di Gardolo (Italy) plants. This Fund needs to continue to function.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Italy has submitted a request to mobilise the EGF following the dismissal of 608 workers from Whirlpool Europe LLP, which operated in the economic sector of electrical equipment manufacturing, and 5 suppliers and downstream producers. The economic and financial crisis has led to a sharp decline in household consumption; the Italian market for large appliances contracted from EUR 3.174 billion in 2010 to EUR 2.649 billion in 2013, a decrease of 16.5%. Moreover, these layoffs will only worsen the unemployment situation in the province of Trento, where the unemployment rate has doubled since the beginning of the crisis, from 2.9% in 2007 to 6.1% in 2013 but is still at a correct level. In order to support the workers who are victims of the crisis and the savage globalisation imposed by Brussels, I voted in favour of this point.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in favour of 608 workers and suppliers from the province of Trento working in the manufacture of household appliances. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is one of the most useful and appreciated instruments by citizens, as it allows all those workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the crisis to be given a real hand. In order to make this aid as effective as possible, however, it is absolutely essential for the EU to streamline the European procedure for assessing and mobilising resources for the new unemployed.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I have voted in favour of these reports today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs.  However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped.   Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 890 000 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 608 workers who have lost their jobs at Whirlpool Europe S.r.l., company engaged in the manufacture of household appliances, and in five suppliers and product transformers of that company in Italy, as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalization and the impact of the economic crisis and Financial.  The customized services to be financed from the EGF include training activities, vocational guidance, recycling and incentives for the creation of companies.  While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the home appliance manufacturing sector due to the sharp decline in production in Europe of twenty-eight for six consecutive years (2008-2013), as a result of the economic and financial crisis, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned into work.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supported parliament's decision to grant support to the 608 workers made redundant in 2014 from the Italian firm Whirpool and five supply and downstream companies. According to the Italian authorities, the global financial and economic crisis has had a significant impact on italian household consumption choices, and households have reconsidered their purchasing decisions, in particular decisions on the purchase of durable goods, including household appliances. As a result, the market for large household appliances decreased by 16,5 %. This support also took into account the fact that these redundancies would further worsen the unemployment situation in the province of Trento, where unemployment has doubled since the start of the crisis and the fall in employment has affected both the construction and industrial sectors.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. — (IT) The economic and financial crisis has led many European households to reconsider purchasing decisions, particularly of durable goods. In Italy, the crisis was particularly acute, with a very serious impact on the household appliances market (down 16.5% from 2010 to 2013) and on the employment situation, making timely assistance to affected workers a priority.  I therefore support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the 502 workers made redundant at Whirlpool and a further 106 workers made redundant by suppliers. I welcome the focus on training, retraining and vocational guidance measures to ensure that they can be reintegrated into the labour market.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for the mobilisation of funds from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund because I support European companies which can have difficulties in these times of economic crisis.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — 608 redundancies in the manufacture of household appliances and EUR 1 890 000 (60% of costs). I voted in favour of the measure in support of employment and workers.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — Parliament has decided to accept Italy's request for intervention from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help employees of Whirlpool, which has been hit hard by the employment consequences of globalisation. The financial and economic crisis has, in fact, had very serious consequences in the field of electrical equipment manufacturing in Europe. More than 600 laid-off employees will benefit from training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job. The amount of aid amounts to 1.89 million euros. I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 608 workers made redundant as a result of globalisation by Whirlpool Europe S.r.l., a company located in the province of Trento and operating in the electrical equipment manufacturing sector. The question in question also concerns Whirlpool's suppliers.  In 2009, as a result of the global economic and financial crisis, there was a significant slowdown in the economy, both at EU level and for the Italian economy. This recession had a profound impact on the consumption choices of Italian households that had reconsidered their purchasing decisions, in particular of durable goods: between 2009 and 2013 the Italian market for large household appliances suffered a 16.5% decline. I regret that Italian companies are not able to benefit more from this fund because of the lack of support from local and national institutions. Between 2007 and 2014, Italy submitted only 14 requests to the EGF, three of them in 2007, only one in 2008, none between 2009 and 2010, seven in 2011, two in 2012, none in 2013 and one in 2014.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU contributing 60% of an adjustment fund payout in the sum of nearly EUR 1.9 million to former Whirlpool employees, suppliers and producers in Italy. I believe that this cost should have been met by the Italian Government, and not, in effect, subsidised by the British taxpayer, through their contributions to the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — We are voting in favour of this mobilisation of EUR 1.9 million for the reintegration of 608 redundant workers.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. — The use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is becoming increasingly frequent. In this last session there are already four requests and they are the obvious warning sign, if necessary, of how deep and still long the economic crisis that is affecting many countries, companies and many sectors is. For six consecutive years, from 2008 to 2013, there was a decline in household appliance production in Europe and among the Countries of the Union; Italy recorded the biggest losses with an redundancy of 608 workers.  Italy's request to the European Commission, which was also welcomed by the Council's Budget Committee, to mobilise EUR 1 890 000, will enable companies operating in the sector to temporarily stem the effects of the crisis but, above all, to support the many workers now unemployed. I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour because I believe that the Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be seen as an important instrument for providing additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) Every time I am asked to vote for the allocation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I am in favour of it, and here too I voted accordingly, but I think at length about how many further measures are needed to ensure that these funds do not act as a buffer but allow economic recovery. We all need it.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on mobilising EUR 1 890 000 for Italy with the aim of supporting the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Whirlpool Europe S.r.l

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I supported, with my vote in favour, the decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in relation to the application submitted by Italy. These resources granted provide a financial contribution to Whirlpool Europe S.r.l. in relation to the placement of 608 redundant workers. The household appliances sector has suffered serious losses, in particular as a result of the difficult economic and financial situation of recent years. This recession has had a profound impact on the consumption of Italian households, which have reconsidered their purchasing decision, particularly as regards durable goods. Household appliances are part of this group of goods. I hope that today's vote will allow employees to be reintegrated into the labour market and will be a sign of support for entrepreneurs affected by the crisis.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The redundancies of 608 workers in Whirlpool Europe S.r.l., an enterprise operating in the manufacture of electrical equipment, five providers and downstream producers, are linked to the global and financial economic crisis and the resultant drop in sales of durable goods including domestic appliances. Redundant workers will be given personalised services which will include information sessions, counselling and guidance, general training and accompaniment towards entrepreneurship aiming at the reintegration of redundant workers in the labour market. I have therefore voted in favour of this report since the measure not only addresses loss of jobs but also reintegration into the labour market.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — The European Union has put in place appropriate legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. Union financial support for redundant workers should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible. I am voting in favour of this resolution in order to provide timely assistance to the 502 workers made redundant at Whirlpool. I also vote in favour in order to assess the concrete results of the vocational training, retraining and training measures provided to participants, in order to have a better picture of the effectiveness of the measures implemented and in order to welcome the accompanying measures following reintegration into employment and entrepreneurship.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 608 workers from Whirlpool Europe S.r.l. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Italy, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of all four applications for EUR 35.5 million in total in EU aid to help find and create new jobs for workers made redundant by Air France, Fiat Auto Poland, Whirlpool and a Greek retailer. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aid application in the case of Whirlpool will support 608 workers and their search for jobs with over EUR 1.8 million.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Through the vote of this text, more than 600 Italian employees made redundant by Whirlpool Europe will see their support towards a return to work substantially improved. The budgetary resources allocated under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will enable them to provide counselling and guidance, vocational training and various allocations, including mobility.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up as an additional instrument to support workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade due to globalisation or the global economic and financial crisis. I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in the case of the hundreds of Italian workers made redundant by Whirpool Europe S.r.l. and its related industries. The financial contribution of the EGF, which amounts to EUR 1.89 million, will be available to the Italian authorities to offer workers in the Autonomous Province of Trento assistance in the search for new employment, vocational guidance and support for the creation of new businesses. I believe that the mobilisation of the EGF can provide an immediate response from the EU to workers, but I believe, at the same time, that the situation of serious unemployment that our country and the whole eu is investing will have to find medium and long-term structural responses in the paradigm shift initiated by the Commission with the new investment plan, which has as its main objectives precisely the creation of growth and employment.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — Since 2009, as a result of the global economic and financial crisis, there has been a significant slowdown in the economy, both at EU-28 level and for the Italian economy. The fall in demand has also affected the household appliances market. More than six hundred workers from Whirlpool Europe S.r.l, a company operating in the manufacture of electrical equipment in Spini di Gardolo in the province of Trento, have been made redundant. Redundancies have further exacerbated unemployment in a region where the number of people out of work has doubled since the crisis began, reaching 6.1 % in 2013. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because the EUR 1.89 million allocated will be used for training, reintegration into the labour market and support for redundant workers. I hope that attention will also be paid to other similar crisis situations in Italy.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. In this case, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) is involved in the cost of eur 1,890,000 due to the closure of a Whirlpool production plant in Spini di Gardolo. The closure also affected five suppliers and producers of downstream electrical equipment. The aim is to help 608 laid-off workers in the Italian region of Trento and to enable the co-financing of active labour market measures such as individual job search assistance, training and retraining,... This request has received my support as well as that of the European Parliament and I sincerely hope that this contribution will help, in one way or another, all those dismissed to face the difficulties that might arise in their daily lives as a result of this difficult event.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — On 28 October 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Italy in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Whirlpool Europe, a limited liability company operating in the 27th economic sector under NACE Rev. 2 (production of electrical equipment), as a result of the global financial and economic crisis. This is the 18th request to be examined in the framework of the 2014 budget and a total of EUR 1 890 000 from the EGF for Italy. A total of 608 beneficiaries are affected by the application. The request was submitted to the Commission on 18 June 2014 and further information was added by 13 August 2014. The recession has had a serious impact on the consumption patterns of Italian households, as the latter have reconsidered their purchasing decisions, in particular as far as the purchase of durable goods is concerned: household consumption in Italy decreased in four of the five years 2009-2013 compared to the same period last year. Consequently, the Italian market for household appliances decreased from EUR 3174 billion in 2010 to EUR 2649 billion in 2013, a fall of 16.5%. This explains why production in sector 27 under NACE Rev. 2 has fallen for 6 consecutive years (2008-2013) at the level of the 28 EU Member States. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the report because I am strongly opposed to the economic policy of re-integration, where funds are allocated to training companies instead of to those who are immediately in need.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. — The sharp decline in the production of electrical equipment in 2008-2012 relates to the global economic and financial crisis. In addition to Whirpool's 502 redundancies in Italy, considered to be the main undertaking, in the reference period another 106 dismissed workers from five suppliers and product suppliers are also included in the number of potential beneficiaries, amounting to a total of 608 persons entitled to benefit from the EGF measures. The personalized services to be provided consist of a complete list of actions: information sessions, admission and registration, advice and guidance, assessment of competencies, general training and recycling, vocational training, mentoring, accompaniment after job reintegration and accompaniment to entrepreneurship, job search assignments, allocations for participation and contribution to travel expenses and incentives for recruitment.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The EGF was created to provide additional support for workers made redundant following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Between 2014 and 2020, the fund's annual ceiling is EUR 150 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take action to get their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. On 18 June 2014, the Italian authorities submitted the Application EGF/2014/010 IT/Whirlpool following the dismissal of 608 employees at Whirlpool Europe S.r.l., a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 27 (Manufacture of electrical equipment) of NACE Rev. 2, and in five downstream suppliers and producers, resulting from the significant decrease in household consumption, the Italian market for large appliances increased from 3174 billion euros in 2010 to 2649 billion euros in 2013, representing a decrease of 16.5 %; In this mobilisation of the EGF in favour of the Trento region in Italy, EUR 1.89 million was granted. I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — The application under consideration relates to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 890 000 in favour of Italy. It results from 608 redundancies at Whirlpool and five downstream suppliers and producers. This is the fourth application from Italy's electrical equipment manufacturing sector to be examined since 2010. Application that, in addition to actions to be developed directly with redundant workers, such as information sessions, advice and guidance, assessment of skills, general training and retraining, vocational training, among others, recommends subsidies for hiring, in the framework of fixed-term or fixed-term contracts, and ranging respectively between 3000 and 2000 euros per worker. We believe that this measure should make it conditional on the subsidy to companies to maintain ing rights and to the creation of a permanent job – which is not the case. The justification for the closure of these companies and the consequent dismissal of their workers lies once again in structural changes in world trade patterns and in the global economic and financial crisis. We are approving palliatives, but we must attack evil at the root: we need to break with the policies that are impoverishing the peoples of Europe and destroying millions of jobs.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The Fund in question was set up to provide additional support to workers in the Member States of the European Union most affected by the economic and financial crisis and major structural changes in world trade patterns. The European Commission has adopted a proposal to mobilise the EGF in favour of Italy, namely for whirpool Europe S.r.l. workers, and concerns EUR 1 890 000 and covers a total of 608 beneficiaries. As part of its new business plan, Whirpool closed spini di Gardolo's operations in Italy in order to better cope with the market situation and reduce its financial losses.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of granting the fund for the 608 redundancies in the manufacture of household appliances.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting against the report because I disagree with the economic policy of re-integration, where funds are allocated to retraining companies, rather than to those who are immediately in need.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. — I voted against this application for the Mobilisation of th3 European Adjustment Fund. As I have stated many times before, I support measures that create growth and jobs, but the Globalisation Adjustment Fund is simply a waste of taxpayers’ money. There is no evidence that it offers value for money in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. — (IT) With the vote on Mr Viotti's report, we have expressed a concrete sign of Europe's closeness to the workers and companies affected by the crisis and the impact of global competition. The mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, launched at Italy's request, makes it possible to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by Whirlpool Europe. Whirlpool is a crisis that directly stems from the fall in household consumption: it is a further wake-up call that signals how pervasive the effects of the crisis are and risk jeopardising, for a long time to come, the backbone of europe's productive economy. Today we are able to provide support to 608 beneficiaries, for around EUR 1 900 000. Unfortunately, we know that requests from Member States for action are constantly increasing. That is also why, Mr President, I wonder whether the timeliness of the European response - in this particular case it has taken eight months!) is in step with the urgent need to resolve situations that are so direct to the lives of our citizens. I therefore wonder whether it is not time to review and make more effective the procedures and timing of mobilisation of the Fund.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — I voted against using British taxpayers’ money to subsidise the Italian government.  Redundancies in Whirlpool Europe, and 5 suppliers, have effected 608 people, and the Italian Government wants the EU to pay EUR 1,890,000 towards retraining etc.  This should be the expense of Whirlpool and the Italian Government.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2014/010 IT/Whirlpool. I do believe that the EU should protect and support its citizens from any crisis. We should provide a financial support for people in need and give them a chance to reintegrate themselves into the labour market after they were dismissed due to a significant downturn in the economy. I do believe that the EU has to help the redundant workers to come back into labour market.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for the 608 redundant workers who lost their jobs at Whirlpool Europe in Italy. The application was made on the basis of at least 500 being made redundant over a reference period of four months in a Member State. Of these workers, 502 were involved in the primary enterprise and 106 in downstream producers. The impact of the crisis saw household consumption fall significantly in Italy and household appliances were particularly badly hit. All the workers will attend information sessions while the majority will participate in general training and retraining and avail of counselling and guidance. Employees will be able to avail of a EUR 3 000 bonus if they hire a redundant worker on a permanent contract or EUR 2 000 if this is for a fixed term contract.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. — I do not think that people should be the victims of failing European socio-economic policies. That is why I voted in favour of the mobilisation of funds from the European Fund for Adaptation to Globalisation, but I think this is a wipe for the bleeding. In fact, I believe that companies, and the Member States themselves, should come up with appropriate aid measures themselves, because now we are actually just pumping money from the Member States around. Large companies put their employees on the streets after years of loyal service, because they move their production to places where they can find cheaper labour. I strongly reject these degrading practices, and with the resources from the European Fund, we are at least ensuring that the workers who have been sent away are not left out in the cold.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " I voted against the mobilisation of funds for former employees of the Whirlpool plant in Spini di Gardolo. There is absolutely no reason why citizens of all the Member States of the European Union should make up their own taxes for one group of workers. The difficult economic situation prevails in many workplaces and in many countries. Even if we adopt the logic of full-timeism, but by donating money to some, it would be necessary to transfer money to others, otherwise it is simply unfair. On the other hand, it is clear that subsidising private companies – because, in fact, this subsidy for employees removes their responsibilities from the company employing them – is always a mistake. It is a "reward" for mismanagement and mismanagement. Instead of rewarding economic failure, the Union should reward existing businesses by removing administrative barriers and reducing taxes.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the event of the redundancies of 608 workers of the Italian company Whirlpool, as a result of the need to meet the redundancies, which have certainly been affected by the global financial and economic crisis, as soon as possible and as efficiently as possible. The fact is that we are witnessing a large decline in electrical equipment production and household consumption, which has affected layoffs at Whirlpool. It should be noted that unemployment in trento province, which has doubled since the beginning of the crisis, will be further exacerbated by these layoffs. In fact, I support the measures taken by the Italian authorities to provide services tailored to the needs of the affected workers and the participation of the social partners in the negotiations on measures to be supported. I therefore support the mobilisation of the EGF in as fast and dynamic a way as possible.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Daniele Viotti's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for sacked employees of Whirlpool Europe in Italy. The fund will provide EUR 1.89 million for 608 sacked Whirlpool employees, which will be used to finance training, counselling or business start-up bonuses to help beneficiaries re-enter the labour market. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I supported the resolution on Italy's request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for redundancies at Whirlpool Europe and five of its suppliers and producers. The Fund was created to promote the reintegration into the labour market of workers who are victims of changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization or the financial crisis. I am the the fore, the case for the adoption of this aid, amounting to EUR 1,890,000.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Daniele Viotti. It provides for the reintegration into the labour market of 608 workers made redundant by Whirlpool Europe S.r.l. Through the EGF we seek to ensure a system of reintegration into the labour market for employees affected by the economic crisis, highlighting, once again, the key role that Europe has and must continue to play in this time of crisis. I would also like to stress that today's mobilisation concerns Italian workers who are unfortunately in difficulty and that we will be able to help thanks to the mobilisation of these European funds.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: In writing. — As I had already had the opportunity in the Parliamentary Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I renewed my vote in favour of the Viotti report to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 608 sacked employees of Whirlpool (Italy). The EGF will finance 60% (EUR 1,800,000 at a total cost of EUR 3,100,000) projects consisting mainly of counselling, guidance, coaching, skills assessment, general training, retraining and vocational training measures, as well as business start-up advice. In the face of mass unemployment and the excesses of globalisation, the WEF is once again proving to be an effective and sustainable tool to support the victims of the successive crises that have hit the European Union countries.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. —This report refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 890 000 from feAG in favour of Italy to support the return to the labour market of workers dismissed from Whirlpool Europe S.r.l., which operated in the economic sector classified in division 27 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Manufacturing of electrical equipment and equipment') and five suppliers and transformers of economic products classified in division 27 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Manufacturing of electrical equipment and equipment') and five suppliers and transformers of economic products classified in division 27 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Manufacturing of electrical equipment and equipment') and five suppliers and transformers of economic products , because of the global financial and economic crisis. It affects a total of 608 beneficiaries.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 608 workers from Whirlpool Europe S.r.l. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Italy, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — This fund has been established by the EU to provide additional assistance to workers who have suffered the consequences of major structural changes in global trade patterns or the continuation of the global financial and economic crisis.  Italy submitted a request for mobilization of this fund to support the reintegration of laid-off workers from Whirlpool Europe S.r.l. and five other suppliers and product transformers as a result of the global financial and economic crisis.  The proposal adopted by the Commission consists of a total of EUR 1 890 000 for aid for labour insertion for the benefit of a total of 608 workers. The Commission has concluded that this proposal meets the requirements necessary to receive EGF funding.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — The economic crisis has had a significant impact on spending cuts and thus on the reduced volume of business that has led to the redundancies of the workforce. The aim of creating a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is to further assist redundancy workers and the self-employed who have had to cease their activities as a result of globalisation.  That is why I supported the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help workers dismissed from Whirpool Europe S.r.l and its suppliers. This report aims to provide a contribution of €1.9 million to assist redundan's workers in finding work and obtaining additional education.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the Viotti report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, because the mobilisation of the fund in this case contributes to the significant relief of the redundant workers of Whirlpool in the province of Trento in Italy and thus strengthens the region of the European South.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I voted for this support under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, noting that the Italian authorities argue that the global financial and economic crisis has had a profound effect on the consumption choices of Italian households which have reconsidered their buying decisions, in particular those related to buying durable goods, including domestic appliances.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a fundamental instrument by which the European Union can actually intervene in support of workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the economic and financial crisis. The aim of the proposal is to support the reintegration into the labour market of employees made redundant by Whirlpool, a company operating in the electrical equipment manufacturing sector. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — In the province of Trento, the industrial and service sectors, both engines of the city's economy, have been severely affected by the consequences of the current recession. My vote in favour of mr Viotti's report stems from the conviction that the 608 workers made redundant at Whirlpool Europe S.r.l, a leader in the field of household appliances, have the right to be adequately supported by the European Union.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I have agreed to assist the Italian company Whirlpool because all the criteria of eligibility are met. Furthermore, the company was particularly hard hit by the financial crisis, which is mainly reflected in the fact that the entire large household appliance sector recorded a decline of more than 16% between 2010 and 2013.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The globalization aid fund plays its destructive role. Instead of helping workers, it encourages shareholders and states to adhere to the social irresponsibility of capitalism. The "Offshoring Assistance Fund" is helping north American appliance giant Whirlpool. In early 2014, when the Swedish site closed and the Italian site was to be strengthened, the executives announced that a "small part" would be relocated to the United States because "the current production structure is no longer competitive". This has turned into a vast redundancy plan and the Italian state is calling for the rescue of those who remain on the tile, after having itself killed domestic consumption by its austerity policies. The company's lies are therefore rewarded since Whirlpool can lay off without worrying about the conditions of reclassification of its workers. Under these conditions, I vote against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. More and more companies are relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices that are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, it is now appropriate to give that aid to Italy which submitted the EGF/2014/010 IT/Whirlpool application on 18 June 2014, following the dismissal of 608 workers at Whirlpool Europe S.r.l., a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 27 (Manufacture of electrical equipment) of NACE Rev. 2, and in five downstream suppliers and producers.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — This report notes that 608 workers in Italy have been made redundant because of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. The financial and economic crisis caused a significant decline in household consumption in Italy. This has further aggravated the unemployment situation in the province of Trento, where the unemployment rate has more than doubled since the beginning of the crisis. I have therefore voted in favour of this report, which will aid affected workers.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Italy in order to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant at Whirlpool Europe S.r.l operating in the economic sector classified under NACE Rev. 2 division 27 (Manufacturing of electrical equipment), and at five providers and downstream producers, due to the global financial and economic crisis

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Italian authorities are requesting a financial contribution under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 1,890,000 to help retrain the 608 employees laid off by Whirlpool Europe LLP and 5 suppliers and producers downstream (economic sector classified in Division 27 "Electrical Equipment Manufacturing"). Since 2009, in the European Union and particularly in the euro area, the economy has been slowing down considerably, with the ultra-liberal economic system set up by Brussels and imposed on The Member States being the main cause of the collapse of our industries and the social breakdown in Europe. The Italian economy is suffocated: for example, while Italy's GDP growth rate was still positive in 2011 with 0.4%, it has since turned negative (-2.4% in 2012 and 1.9% in 2013). Household consumption has declined considerably, as the recession has had a clear impact on the choices and priorities of Italian consumers (decisions to purchase durable goods - household appliances - postponed). Between 2008-2012, the top 5 manufacturers of household appliances in Italy (Electrolux, Indesit, Whirlpool Europe, Frank and Antonio Merloni) recorded a significant drop in production. It should also be noted that ... (Shortened voting explanation under section 170 of the regulation)

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — The economic crisis has had a profound effect on the consumption choices of Italian households, particularly those related to buying durable goods. I voted in favour of the application as I believe that it will help to address the decline in durable goods.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: in writing. — Today's vote by the EP gave the green light to the possibility of using a significant amount of money from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be allocated to the redundancy of 608 workers by Whirlpool Europe s.r.l. This money should be used in particular to promote a range of activities such as reintegration courses into the world of work and refresher courses for workers who have remained at home, as well as a series of aids intended for their livelihood. While we can only welcome this measure, which shows that the European Union is ready to play its part in situations of need, we cannot fail to emphasise that the closure of Whirpool is a defeat for all; The economic and financial crisis that is gripped a large part of the Union, and in particular our country, must, in fact, draw attention to the need to rethink and revise current industrial policies. The solution to the crisis cannot, in fact, be entrusted solely to emergency instruments such as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, but also, and above all, to a series of long-term actions aimed at strengthening growth and development.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) We welcome the Commission's proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Italy in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by Whirlpool Europe S.r.l., as demand fulfils all the conditions for a financial contribution from the Fund. In fact, as a result of the global economic and financial crisis, there has been a significant slowdown in the Italian economy, a situation of recession that has had a profound impact on the choices of household consumption. In recent years, even though Whirlpool had made investments at the Spini plant in Gardolo, the investment has not proved profitable due to declining demand for large household appliances and the consequent decline in production.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of the report by Mr De Clercq on behalf of the Committee on The Protection of human Rights, Research and Energy. Viotti for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the 608 workers made redundant by Whirlpool Europe and five suppliers and producers downstream in Italy, companies affected by the increasingly incisive financial and economic crisis.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Whirlpool should be supported, as the company concerned meets all the criteria for support. It is also very commendable that the Italian Government has already started to provide assistance to the workers concerned before the EU has applied for assistance. This willingness to act will allow us to be sure that the funds provided by the Union will be used in a meaningful way and will only benefit the workers. I therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I support the programmes implementing the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, particularly in the countries heavily affected by the financial crisis, in this case here in Italy. It is inconceivable for Europe not to guarantee security to workers who have found themselves unemployed as a result of relocations or increased competition from newly emerging countries. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal to allocate EUR 1 890 000 from the EGF to Italy, because it will help the labour market to help the 502 people who became unemployed in Whirpool, Italy. Unemployment is one of the most painful problems in the European Union. With the EGF, we can mobilise these people again in the labour market.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Whereas the Italian authorities have submitted a specific application for financial assistance from the EGF as a result of the redundancies made by Whirpool Europe s.r.l. and five suppliers and producers downstream in Italy; that negative economic convergence caused by the crisis has led to a significant slowdown in the household appliances sector; that the Commission has checked that the application fully meets with the criteria for the application of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I would like to vote in favour of.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. — The protection of workers and their dignity is one of the fundamental principles on which European policies must be based. The intention of the establishment of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is precisely this: to give further support, together with that of the Member State involved, to workers who are seriously affected by the consequences of the economic crisis.  I voted for this resolution because the 608 whirlpool workers and all the related workers in the province of Trento are the victims of a global crisis that has affected, in this particular case, the household appliances sector, with a frightening drop in purchases by families. In fact, the unemployment rate in this area has doubled since the beginning of the crisis. The financial contributions (EUR 1 890 000) obtained through the mobilisation of the Fund, in addition to the Structural Funds provided to Italy, should be used for the relocation of redundant workers, for their training, for incentives for recruitment and entrepreneurship, for accompanying them for reintegration into employment. Their use will then be constantly monitored with the involvement of the social partners. This is a strategic contribution to resurrecting not only the fate of individual Whirlpool workers, but the economy of an entire production district.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. —I supported colleague Daniela Viotti's report. Globalisation has brought an acceleration of the economic development of the world, but it also has negative consequences. The major economic and financial crisis has affected the restructuring of many companies with the purpose of eliminating unprofitableness, and many companies have found themselves affected by structural reforms resulting in the redundancies of a large number of workers. Trent's unemployment rate has doubled since the crisis began, rising from 2.9% in 2007 to 6.1% in 2013. The closure of Whirlpool Europe Srl will leave a negative impact on the economy in the region and the local economy of the Trento Region. I support the proposal of the European Commission and the Council to grant financial assistance to 608 redundanheless Whirlpool Europe workers of €1.8 million out of a total estimated €3.1 million in costs for support activities, training for other jobs and as support for self-employment, as I consider these to be quality measures to assist workers.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) As we know, the Purpose of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to support workers in companies suffering from the negative economic situation and major structural changes in world trade, especially at this time of serious general crisis. In this case it is Whirlpool Italia and, as we have seen from the data, all the main Italian manufacturers of household appliances suffered a sharp decline in production in the period 2008-2012 due to the negative economic situation. The reintegration into the labour market of the 608 workers made redundant will be helped by personalised services such as: general training and retraining, vocational training, coaching, follow-up to reintegration and entrepreneurship, job-seeking allowances, participation allowances and contributions to travel expenses, as well as recruitment incentives.  I hope that the services put in place will best help them to re-enter the labour market and that all the principles of equal treatment will be respected.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The crisis led Whirlpool to lay off more than 600 employees in Italy. It is therefore up to the use of a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help sacked employees in their search for retraining and business creation.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — Italy has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 608 redundancies at Whirlpool Europe S.r.l, a company operating in division 27 of NACE Rev. 2 (Manufacture of electrical equipment), and in five downstream suppliers and producers, during the period from 10 December 2013 to 31 March 2014. According to the Commission, that application complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, and it is noted, on the one hand, that the redundancies in question are related to the economic and financial crisis and the consequent significant decrease in household consumption, which had an impact on the Italian market for large appliances, which fell by 16.5 %, from 3174 billion in 2010 to 2649 billion in 2013; and, on the other hand, that such redundancies will further aggravate the employment situation in the province of Trento, where the unemployment rate has doubled since the beginning of the crisis, from 2.9 % in 2007 to 6.1 % in 2013. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Italy.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. — The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Italy, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 890 000 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 608 workers who have lost their jobs at Whirlpool Europe S.r.l., company engaged in the manufacture of household appliances, and in five suppliers and product transformers of that company in Italy, as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalization and the impact of the economic crisis and Financial. The customized services to be financed from the EGF include training activities, vocational guidance, recycling and incentives for the creation of companies. While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the home appliance manufacturing sector due to the sharp decline in production in Europe of twenty-eight for six consecutive years (2008-2013), as a result of the economic and financial crisis, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned into work.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the italian authorities' request for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the redundancies at Whirlpool Europe LLP, as well as five suppliers and downstream producers. As a result of the economic downturn of recent years, many households in Italy have had to review their purchasing decisions, particularly those concerning durable goods (particularly household appliances). The Italian authorities have also told us that the five main manufacturers of household appliances in Italy suffered a sharp decline in production between 2008 and 2012 due to the economic and financial crisis. I therefore think it is important to be able to help the 608 workers affected by these redundancies.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — In the face of structural changes in international trade patterns, legislative and budgetary instruments have been put in place to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of these changes, empowering them to reintegrate into the labour market. Whereas Italy has submitted an application to the EGF following the dismissal of 608 employees of Whirlpool Europe S.r.l and whereas it meets the eligibility criteria, I am in favour of allocating this financial contribution from the EGF, amounting to EUR 1 890 000, as a means of minimising the adverse effects that this has on former workers, especially in this electrical equipment production sector, , which has suffered a sharp decline over the period 2008 to 2012 and, above all, for the lives of the more than 600 workers affected by this dismissal, who see this instrument as a window of opportunity to relaunch their working lives.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 608 workers from Whirlpool Europe S.r.l. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU. These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Italy, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Thanks to todayʼs vote Italy was granted aid from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant at Whirlpool Europe S.r.l. Whirlpool Europe S.r.l operates in the economic sector classified under NACE Rev. 2 division 27 (Manufacturing of electrical equipment).  The Italian authorities argue that in 2009, as a consequence of the global financial and economic crisis, there was a significant downturn in the economy at EU-28 level, as well as in the Italian economy. This recession situation has had a profound effect on the consumption choices of Italian households which had reconsidered their buying decisions, in particular those related to buying durable goods. The EUR 1 890 000 in aid will pay for personalised services consisting of advice and guidance, training and a job search allowance for the 608 redundant workers, provided by a team of expert consultants.  The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — The Italian authorities have submitted an EGF/ 2014/010/ IT Whirlpool application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The fund is intended for workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade. Applications can only be accepted if more than 500 workers have become redundant within the company (including suppliers and other manufacturers), which in this case has been complied with. After reviewing the application, the Commission found that the conditions for this case had been met. The European Commission has also proposed allocating €1.8 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to Italy to help 608 former Whirlpool Europe Srl workers find new jobs. These are measures to combat unemployment and deal with the financial crisis, and therefore I support this report.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour in order to avoid 608 redundancies in the manufacture of household appliances.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund supports people who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade. The wave of economic problems that have befallen most Of the Union's Member States has left Whirlpool employees from Italy where more than 608 workers have lost their jobs, in dire need of financial assistance to find a new job. Unemployment, as we know, is a big problem throughout the European Union, especially in Italy, but I must also point out in Croatia, especially when we talk about young people. The Commission has approved the application, and I believe it is our duty to support any initiative that favours the worker as it ensures a fresh start for them.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing — I do not agree with the proposal tabled because I believe that this is an extremely inefficient solution to the problems presented. Among the reasons presented for granting this aid, for example, is a significant decrease in the consumption of Italian households during the crisis. However, the funds provided by the European Union to stimulate the consumption of Italian households are also a means by which household consumption in other countries of the European Union will be reduced.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. — The ECR Group fully supports measures that put in place policies that create growth and jobs. However, we do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for putting in place such policies, nor do we believe it is an efficient tool that offers value for money for EU taxpayers, therefore I voted against.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The money from the adjustment fund should basically be given to the dismissed persons and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, or more often known as the WEF, was set up to provide support to workers who are becoming victims of restructuring and global trade. The aim is therefore to train, or help to rebound, those working citizens who have committed no fault except that of living in a time when human character often seems less important than the search for profits for certain investors or speculators. The fund we are voting on is therefore intended to be a second chance.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The proposal to mobilise more than EUR 1.2 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in favour of the Fiat Auto Poland factory in The United Kingdom is worth strong support. Last year, about 1,500 employees of Fiat Auto Poland lost their jobs. Thanks to intensive and effective national action by the Labour Fund, today only 80 of them remain unemployed. The EGF will allow for a partial reimbursement of support costs incurred by the Labour Fund, m.in. for programmes to help find a job or create new employment opportunities m.in. through business start-up grants and entrepreneurship training.  As required by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, exemptions in an establishment are linked to significant structural changes in world trade due to globalisation. The European Commission has confirmed the existence of these circumstances with regard to the Tychy plant. As a result, today the European Parliament approved by a large majority a report approving the Commission's proposal to use the Fund, while reaffirming the need for and effectiveness of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — In this context of economic crisis the EU must be ready to give a second chance to workers that have lost their jobs, in this case of Whirlpool Europe SRL company, in Italy. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established to provide support for workers made redundant and self-employed persons whose activity has ceased as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis, to assist them with their reintegration into the labour market. That is why I give my support to this report.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — My vote in favour of this report is in support of an essential fund for mitigating the impact of globalisation on the functioning of local economies and employment.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - I supported the decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) with a financial contribution of EUR 1 890 000 for more than 600 redundancies at the Italian company Whirlpool, which will be supported in a process of reintegration into the labour market. The company, operating in the household appliances sector in the province of Trento, has in fact suffered severely from the fall in household consumption caused by the economic and financial crisis.   Whirlpool is certainly not the only company to have had to make massive job cuts in Italy, where companies, even more than in other countries, have been suffering for years from the pressures of globalization and the impact of the financial and economic crisis. However, it is the only case in Italy to benefit from the fund in 2014, given that the Italian Government, inexplicably, has not submitted similar requests for the other thousands of workers made redundant.
