Although the fund is by no means a long-term solution, given the serious emergency situation in Italy, I hope that the government will also begin to devote some attention to the many companies in difficulty and to the thousands of workers who continue to lose their jobs.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — The European Parliament has overwhelmingly adopted Daniele Viotti's report calling for the mobilisation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 1.890 million for 502 employees licensed at Whirlpool and 106 at five of its downstream suppliers and producers. Austerity policies have led to a contraction in household consumption, particularly in the durable goods sector. The Whirlpool Europe Group would have accumulated the losses and, we are told, "developed a business plan to adapt its production structure to the market." Today, two sites of the group close, and this "despite" investments whose content we do not know. However, this group, the world's number one appliance manufacturer, bought Indesit this year, renouncing its relocation. Indesit threatened to reduce its workforce by a third and the US giant's 60% takeover of its capital had been touted as a life-saving asset for these employees. These recent layoffs reveal the sad reality of the capital strategies of these global giants. I do not want European public funds to be used to finance such practices because, de facto, it leads to encouraging them instead of trying to stop them. So I voted against it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The application under consideration relates to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1,890,000 from the EGF in favour of Italy to compensate for the loss of 608 redundancies at Whirlpool and five downstream suppliers and producers. This is the fourth application from Italy's electrical equipment manufacturing sector to be examined since 2010. Part of the amount mobilised is earthed to allowances for the contract, under fixed-term and fixed-term contracts, which vary respectively between EUR 3,000 and EUR 2,000 per worker. This would only make sense if the workers to hire maintained the rights guaranteed by Whirlpool, including a permanent employment contract.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — (DE) I gave decisive support to the request for assistance to the Italian company Whirlpool, not only because the company was particularly hard hit by the financial crisis, which in turn is reflected in its sales of household appliances, but also because I consider it important that the EU must provide European companies and workers with appropriate assistance, especially in times of crisis.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The application under consideration relates to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1,890,000 from the EGF in favour of Italy. It results from 608 redundancies at Whirlpool and five downstream suppliers and producers. This is the fourth application by Italy's electrical equipment manufacturing sector to be examined since 2010. Application that, in addition to actions to be developed directly with redundant workers such as information sessions, advice and guidance, assessment of skills, general training and retraining, vocational training, among others, recommends subsidies for hiring, in the framework of fixed or fixed contracts, and ranging respectively between 3 000 and 2000 euros per worker.  This would only make sense if the workers to hire maintained the rights guaranteed by Whirlpool, in particular a permanent employment contract, which is not guaranteed.  We are approving palliatives, but we must attack evil from the ground up: we need to break with the policies that are impoverishing the peoples of Europe and destroying millions of jobs.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - (IT) The mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been appropriate to help workers who have been made redundant, or who have lost their jobs, from four separate companies. In particular, with regard to the Situation in Italy, a contribution of EUR 1.9 million was made to facilitate the reintegration of 608 Whirlpool workers in Trentino, who were made redundant as a result of the closure of their production plant. I voted in favour because even though the EGF is not the best solution, it is currently helping the workers. In addition, particular attention will have to be paid to ensuring that these funds are used correctly by each Member State.  Finally, it is clear that this instrument cannot be constantly relied upon to solve the structural problems of the economy.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 1079 workers, 829 Fiat Auto Poland and 250 from 21 suppliers and product transformers; 777 people are expected to participate in the EAGF measures, related to the decline in production at the production plant of Fiat Auto Poland S.A. de Tychy, located in Slaskie Province, Poland, during the reference period from 21 January 2013 to 21 May 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Poland, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Poland, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to grant a total amount of EUR 1 259 610 from the EGF to Poland in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by Fiat Auto Poland. Since 2007 The European car industry has lost part of its market. In that year, European passenger car production accounted for 32.2% of global production, up from 23.2% in 2012. The impact of globalisation has been exacerbated by the financial crisis, which has led to the fall in sales of new passenger cars in the Union to unseen lows. The package of services for 777 redundant workers will include entrepreneurship training, learning grants, apprenticeships and grants for self-employed workers. I welcome the allocation of this fund to employees affected by Fiat Auto Poland.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — The request for assistance concerns 1,079 redundancies, including 829 workers dismissed by Fiat Auto Poland and 250 workers laid off by suppliers following the fall in European car production. These layoffs account for 1/10 of the total number of unemployed living in the region according to the Polish authorities, which exerts a strongly negative influence on the Tychy region of Silesia. It is therefore imperative to allow these former workers to return to work, which is why the EGF's assistance of EUR 1,259,610 is therefore welcome.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — On 10 November 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a Decision on the mobilisation of feAG in favour of Poland to support the reintegration into the labour market of laid-off workers at the Tychy production plant of Fiat Auto Poland S.A., located in the Slaskie region of Poland, following significant structural changes in global trade patterns as a result of globalisation. I supported this decision; this is the nineteenth application under review under the 2014 budget and refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 259 610 from the EGF for Poland. It affects 829 layoffs from Fiat's production plant in Tychy and 250 redundancies from the 21 suppliers and product transformers made during the reference period from 21 January to 21 May 2013.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Poland submitted the EGF E's request for financial contribution following the dismissal of 1,079 workers, 829 at Fiat Auto Poland and 250 from 21 downstream suppliers and producers, 777 of whom are expected to participate in the EGF measures, due to the decline in production at Fiat Auto Poland S.A.'s Tychy plant in Silesia. The WEF will mobilise EUR 1,259,610. This sad finding is only the result of austerity and the total opening of borders by the EU, which have caused production to fall but also the volume of new car sales in the Union to its lowest level. In addition, this will have a negative impact on the region as licensees account for 10% of the unemployed in the Silesia region. I therefore voted for this text in order to help these workers.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in favour of 829 Polish Fiat workers and suppliers. The EGF is an important but at the same time still too slow to achieve the levels of efficiency necessary to ensure the right support for citizens and businesses affected by the crisis.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I have voted in favour of these reports today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs.  However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped.   Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 259 610 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 777 workers who have lost their jobs at Fiat Auto Poland S.A. in Poland, engaged in the manufacture of automobiles, as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.  The customized services to be financed from the EGF include training activities, vocational guidance, recycling and incentives for the creation of companies.  While these aids are not in themselves able to alleviate rising unemployment in the automotive industry sector accentuated by the impact of globalisation that has worsened the effects of the financial crisis, reducing sales of new passenger cars in the EU to the lowest level since data are collected, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of workers affected.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supported parliament's decision to grant support to 1079 workers made redundant in 2013 from Fiat Auto Poland and its suppliers and downstream companies. The decision to grant support underlines that the European car industry has lost part of its market since the start of the crisis and that the situation is even worse at national level. Parliament therefore agrees that the redundancies at Fiat's plant in Tychos and its suppliers and downstream companies are linked to major structural changes in the world trade system caused by globalisation and that the impact of globalisation has been exacerbated by the financial crisis, which has led to an unprecedented reduction in sales of new passenger cars in the Union. In this case, redundancies at Fiat's Tychose plant in Tychose will have a negative impact on the region as a whole, as former employees of Fiat Auto Poland, its suppliers and downstream companies account for 10% of the total unemployed in those areas.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for the Mobilisation of Funds of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund because I support the European companies which can have difficulties in these times of economic crisis.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — 829 FIAT redundancies plus 250 redundancies and EUR 1 259 610 (50% of costs). I voted in favour of worker support and employment.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — The European Parliament voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the sacked employees of Fiat Auto Poland. The amount of aid amounts to 1.26 million euros. More than 1,000 laid-off employees will benefit from training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job. The European automotive industry is experiencing serious hours. European car production is down from rising global production. The mobilization of the EGF was therefore totally justified and necessary. I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 777 workers made redundant as a result of globalisation at the Fiat plant in Tychy in the Silesia region of Poland.  According to the data, the European car industry has lost market share since 2007. In that year, European car production accounted for 32.2% of world production, compared with 23.2% in 2012. The situation was even worse nationally, where the volume of production fell by about a third in 2012 compared to 2011 levels. The impact of globalisation has been exacerbated by the effects of the crisis, which has led to a reduction in sales of new cars in the EU to its lowest level since the surveys began. Eurostat data on the employment situation in the automotive sector show a continuous decline. This is already poland's twenty-second request for assistance only in the automotive sector. I regret that Italian companies are not able to benefit more from this Fund because of the lack of support from local and national institutions, which have so far submitted only 14 requests in total.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU contributing 50% of an adjustment fund payout in the sum of nearly EUR 1.26 million to former Fiat employees, suppliers and producers in Poland. I believe that this cost should have been met by the Polish Government, and not, in effect, subsidised by the British taxpayer, through their contributions to the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — We are voting in favour of mobilising EUR 1.25 million for the reintegration of 777 workers into fiat plants in Poland.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) As a Piedmontese, I have a very special point of view on FIAT, and above all it gives me a strange effect to feel that Polish FIAT wants access to European aid. Polish workers also deserve these facilities, but a much broader speech should be made on FIAT in the industrial policy of my region, as well as in the whole of Italy.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 1 259 610 in favour of Poland with the aim of supporting the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in Fiat Auto Poland and in the 21 companies its suppliers and producers downstream.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in response to Poland's request. This choice will involve the payment of a financial contribution to Fiat Auto Poland, in particular the Tychy plant, which has declared 829 redundancies. It is well known that the car manufacturing sector has suffered serious economic consequences, especially a sharp decline in the EU's market share since 2007. Due to the difficult economic situation of the CAR manufacturing sector in the EU and the growing popularity of Asian cars, as well as the substantial decline in car sales, Fiat Auto Poland was forced to close its Tychy plant and relocate production of panda classic to Campania, Italy, resulting in a large number of job losses in the automotive production sector in recent years. Today's vote is a sign of EU support and the hope is that it will allow employees to be reintegrated into the labour market.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments in order to provide additional support to workers who have been affected by the consequences of major structural shifts in world trade patterns and to support the reintegration of the same workers back into the labour market. The report confirms that 777 of 1 079 workers previously operating in the automotive industry in Poland will be targeted by the EGF co-funded measures. Personalised services for workers will include entrepreneurial training, internships and training scholarships. I therefore voted in favour of this report as it will provide additional opportunities and support to the workers (and their families) affected by these redundancies.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — Poland submitted its application EGF/2013/006 PL/Fiat Auto Poland for a financial contribution from the EGF following 1,079 redundancies, of which 829 at Fiat Auto Poland and 250 at 21 suppliers and producers downstream, with 777 workers expected to participate in the EGF measures, linked to the decrease in production at the Tychy plant of Fiat Auto Poland S.A. ("Fiat plant in Tychy") located in the Silesia region of Poland, during the reference period from 21 January 2013 to 21 May 2013. I voted in favour of this resolution in order to promote the reintegration into working life of the 777 workers made redundant, including through training and related costs, entrepreneurial training, training grants, traineeship grants, traineeship costs, targeted interventions, aid for self-employment and recruitment incentives.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources following the dismissal of 1 079 workers, 829 Fiat Auto Poland and 250 from 21 suppliers and product transformers; 777 people are expected to participate in the EAGF measures, related to the decline in production at the production plant of Fiat Auto Poland S.A. de Tychy, located in Slaskie Province, Poland, during the reference period from 21 January 2013 to 21 May 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Poland, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of all four applications for EUR 35.5 million in EU aid to help find and create new jobs for workers made redundant by Air France, Fiat Auto Poland, Whirlpool and a Greek retailer. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aid application in the case of Fiat, its 21 suppliers and downstream producers will provide support for 777 workers with over EUR 1.2 million.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The automotive sector is an economic sector particularly hit by the economic crisis, as this text proposes to help the 777 sacked employees who previously worked in the automotive industry in Poland. With the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, these employees will be able to benefit from targeted support and training, increasing their chances of finding a job quickly.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — Almost a thousand workers have been laid off at the Fiat plant in Tychy, southern Poland, because of the loss of market share in Europe in car production. Production in Tychy fell by at least a third between 2011 and 2012, affecting both the plant and its suppliers and producers downstream, in a region where unemployment has been rising steadily since 2011. I strongly supported this proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because it will allow redundant workers to be reintegrated into the labour market.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. In this case, the Contribution of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (WEF) is EUR 1,610,259 and is planned for the reintegration into the labour market of 777 laid-off workers in the Polish region of Silesia. These layoffs are linked to the closure of a Fiat car production plant in Tychy. Twenty-one downstream suppliers and producers in the automotive sector were also affected by the closure. The measures put in place and co-financed by the Fund are mainly geared towards training. Of course, I have spoken in favour of this aid and I hope that it will be able to help these people in part to combat this anxiety, this sense of uncertainty about their future, which invades us when we lose our jobs in such circumstances.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — On 10 November 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the EGF for Poland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from fiat auto poland S.A. in Tychy, a Silesia region of Poland, as a result of major structural changes in world trade in the event of globalisation. This is the 19th request to be examined in the framework of the 2014 budget and a total of EUR 1 259 610 from the EGF for Poland. The application relates to 829 people made redundant from fiat in Tychy during the reference period from 21 January 2013 to 21 May 2013 and 250 from 21 suppliers and down processors. The request was sent to the Commission on 29 July 2013. The Commission has established that the application fulfils the requirements for the use of the EGF laid down in Article 2(a) of Regulation (EC) No 1927/2006. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-financed includes the following measures to reintegrate 777 redundant workers: reimbursement of training and training costs, entrepreneurial training, training scholarships, traineeships, traineeships, intervention costs, self-employment support and recruitment incentives. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the report because I disagree with the economic policy of re-integration, where funds are allocated to retraining companies, rather than to those who are immediately in need.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. — Poland submitted application EGF/2013/006 PL/Fiat concerning a financial contribution from the EAGF following the dismissal of 1 079 workers, 829 Fiat Auto Poland and 250 from 21 suppliers and product processors. It is expected that 777 people will participate in the EGF measures. The European car industry has lost market share since 2007, when European passenger car production accounted for 32.2% of world production, falling to 23.2% in 2012. It should be noted that, among other measures, intervention focuses specifically on the group of workers over the age of 50, which represents a high percentage of beneficiaries; this is important as this age group is more exposed to long-term unemployment and the risk of exclusion from the labour market.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The EGF was created to provide additional support for workers made redundant following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Between 2014 and 2020, the fund's annual ceiling is EUR 150 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take steps to obtain their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. Poland submitted the EGF/2013/006 PL/Fiat application to a financial contribution, following 1079 redundancies, i.e. 829 at Fiat Auto Poland and 250 in its 21 downstream suppliers and producers, with participation in the EGF measures expected to be 777 people, given a decrease in production at Fiat Auto Poland S.A.'s Tychy plant in Slaskie province. In this mobilisation of the EGF, EUR 1.26 million was granted. I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — This application is submitted by Poland, following 829 redundancies at FIAT Auto Poland and 250 in 21 its suppliers and downstream producers. In addition to actions to be developed directly with redundant workers, such as training costs, entrepreneurship training, training grants, traineeships, self-employment grants, among others, the report calls for encouraging hiring: employers who hire a former employee of this company for a period of 24 months will receive a subsidy of up to EUR 4 845. We believe that this measure should make it conditional on the subsidy to companies to maintain ing rights and to the creation of a permanent job – which is not the case. In the name of the millions of unemployed, the millions of people living on the poverty line, these policies must be fractured, and the promotion of socio-economic development, the defence and promotion of national productive sectors and employment with rights is required. We need to face this avalanche of collective redundancies head-on and give it the real reason: it is the fastest and easiest profit that is speaking louder. And it is always the workers who pay for the crises that capitalism generates and that will never be able to solve.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The Fund in question was set up to provide additional support to workers in the Member States of the European Union most affected by the economic and financial crisis and major structural changes in world trade patterns. The European Commission has adopted a proposal to mobilise the EGF in favour of Poland, namely for workers made redundant from the Fiat Auto Poland S.A. production plant in Tychy. In the present case, the applicant points to a clear link between the decrease in car production and the employment rate at Fiat Auto Poland. Between 2009 and 2013, production decreased by an astronomical 56%.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of granting the fund for the 829 workers made redundant at the FIAT plant in Poland plus the 250 redundancies as suppliers.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting against the report because I disagree with the economic policy of re-integration, where funds are allocated to retraining companies, rather than to those who are immediately in need.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — Explanation of vote: deadline of 17.12.2012 on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, Council and Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation on budgetary matters and sound financial management (proposal EGF/2013/006 PL/Fiat Auto Poland S.A. z Polish) (COM (2014) 0699 – C8-0243/2014 – 2014/2181(BUD)) Ladies and gentlemen! I am very pleased to welcome the proposal, of which I was shadow rapporteur, with an overwhelming majority, and I congratulate Mr Olbrycht on the consequences in pursuing the objective and the well-drafted report. Its verification took an exceptionally long time, which is why it welcomes the positive result of the vote.  The dismissal of more than 1,000 people at the Fiat factory in Tychy was a huge blow not only for the Upper Silesia region. This particular factory of the Italian car manufacturer was the largest in Europe and the second largest in the world five years ago. However, the wave of the European crisis has not spared the factory. The decline in production by almost a third between 2011 and 2012 hit both the company and its suppliers in a region where unemployment is steadily rising.  The €1.26 million European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will allow for a partial reimbursement of the support costs of the 777 redundant persons who have taken part in m.in training to facilitate finding a new job.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — I voted against using British taxpayers’ money to subsidise the Polish Government.  Redundancies in Fiat have affected 777 people, and the Polish Government wants the EU to pay EUR 1 259 610 towards retraining etc. This should be the expense of Fiat and the Polish Government.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour for the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2013/006 PL/Fiat Auto Poland S.A. I do believe that the EU should protect and support its citizens from any crisis. We should provide a financial support for people in need and give them a chance to reintegrate themselves into the labour market after they were dismissed due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. Moreover, there are 6 workers with longstanding health problems or disabilities who definitely need support to overcome the crisis.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. — I supported the mobilisation of EUR 1.259 million of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for 777 redundant workers at Fiat Auto in Poland where 829 workers were made redundant as production levels plummeted at the factory, while 250 workers were made redundant by suppliers. The EGF monies to be spent include training of different types and also grants for self-employment. There is a significant amount of money available for hiring incentives when companies hire former Fiat Auto Poland workers for 24 months.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. — I do not think that people should be the victims of failing European socio-economic policies. That is why I voted in favour of the mobilisation of funds from the European Fund for Adaptation to Globalisation, but I think this is a wipe for the bleeding. In fact, I believe that companies, and the Member States themselves, should come up with appropriate aid measures themselves, because now we are actually just pumping money from the Member States around. Big car manufacturers like Fiat put their employees on the streets after years of loyal service, because they move their production to places where they can find cheaper labour. I strongly reject these degrading practices, and with the resources from the European Fund, we are at least ensuring that the workers who have been sent away are not left out in the cold.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — It is always a bad idea to support private companies with state-owned or public funds, regardless of which European country this practice takes place in. Polish workers do not need funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Polish workers need favourable economic conditions, based on reduced tax ation, a lower threshold for legislative and administrative interference in the freedom of establishment. For Fiat Auto Poland too, a public subsidy is a bad solution, as it raises the belief that errors in the management and planning of production can also be repaired in the future by the State, and therefore all taxpayers. In this sense, state money hinders the balanced and economic development of companies and worsens the economic security of their employees.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of Fiat Auto Poland S.A. as it is necessary to assist redundant workers in a concrete way, through EGF funds. The European automotive industry has seen a big drop, which will have a significant impact on unemployment in Shleska. In addition, these redundancies relate to workers who have lower qualifications and who are of older age. Therefore, it is necessary to effectively assist these workers in such a way as to avoid long-term unemployment and to encourage re-inclusion in the labour market.  In doing so, it is important to note that another twenty applications have been recorded for the allocation of EGF funds by the automotive industry. It is obvious that the negative effects of the financial crisis and the phenomenon of globalisation have had a profound impact on the automotive industry in Europe.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — Despite some shortcomings, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a good instrument to support member states' assistance efforts. It is particularly useful in the automotive sector, which has been experiencing huge problems for several years. The example of fiat's Polish factory in Tychy shows very clearly that changes in the global economy, combined with the economic crisis in Europe and the politicization of the economic decisions of private companies, can bring problems even to modern and extremely efficient plants. The dismissal of more than 1 000 people has led to the collapse of factory co-operators and an increase in unemployment in a region that is still experiencing huge structural economic problems. It is therefore to be pleased that the assistance measures taken by Polish government and local authorities have helped to find the work of most of the workers made redundant. That is why I supported the mobilisation of funds from the fund to reimburse the expenditure incurred. They will undoubtedly be needed to carry out projects supporting the remaining 100 people, especially as they are mainly elderly or low-skilled people.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Jan Olbrycht's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of employees made redundant by Fiat in Poland. The fund will provide an envelope of 1.26 million euros for 1,079 employees laid off by Fiat, which will be used to finance training, consulting services or business start-up bonuses to help beneficiaries reintegrate into the labour market. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I supported the resolution on Poland's request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for redundancies at Fiat Auto Poland S.A. and 21 of its suppliers and producers. The Fund was created to promote the reintegration into the labour market of workers who are victims of changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization or the financial crisis. I am the the the firm, the city, which is worth EUR 1,259,610, to adopt.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - I very much welcome the approval of the application for mobilisation of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for redundant workers from fiat auto poland s.a. plant in Tychy. It is clear that the reasons for the collective lay-off at the plant were due to the effects of globalisation, in particular the ever-decreasing market shares of the European automotive industry and the sharp fall in demand for passenger cars caused by the financial crisis. This decision means that more than €1.2 million from the European Union budget will be used to reimburse the costs incurred last year by the Silesian district labour offices to help the laid-off employees of the Tychy plant. These activities were multi-level and covered vocational and entrepreneurial training, training and traineeship grants, intervention work, start-up measures and incentives for re-entry into the labour market. The granting of these funds to Poland is an example of the effective use of EU funds, as, as it turns out, thanks to the resolute initiative of our government, only 80 people out of more than 1000 affected by redundancies are still out of work.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Jan Olbrycht because I consider the decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Poland to be an undisputed opportunity for the reintegration into the labour market of the 829 redundancies at the FIAT plant in Tychy and of 250 redundancies at 21 suppliers and producers during the reference period from 21 January 2013 to 21 May 2013. In a context of economic crisis such as the one we are experiencing, we have repeatedly stressed the importance and effectiveness of an instrument such as the EGF.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: In writing. — As I had already had the opportunity in the Parliamentary Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I renewed my vote in favour of the Olbrycht report to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 777 sacked employees of FIAT (Poland). The EGF will finance 50% (EUR 1,259,610 at a total cost of EUR 2,506,220) projects consisting mainly of: general training measures, entrepreneurship training, internship grants, grants for self-employment and incentives for hiring.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I supported the proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The relocation of Fiat Panda production from Polish to Italy was a political decision that negatively affected the situation of Polish workers. The resources available through the EGF will facilitate their reintegration into employment or self-employment.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — This is a proposal for a Decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Poland to support the reintegration into the labour market of dismissed workers at the Fiat Auto Poland S.A. production plant in Tychy, in the Slaskie region of Poland. It refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 259 610 and concerns 829 redundancies from that Fiat production plant in Tychy, and 250 redundancies from the 21 suppliers and product transformers, made during the reference period from 21 January to 21 May 2013, and I am in favour of its approval.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources following the dismissal of 1 079 workers, 829 Fiat Auto Poland and 250 from 21 suppliers and product transformers; 777 people are expected to participate in the EAGF measures, related to the decline in production at the production plant of Fiat Auto Poland S.A. de Tychy, located in Slaskie Province, Poland, during the reference period from 21 January 2013 to 21 May 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Poland, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — On 10 November 2014, the Commission approved a proposal for the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Poland. The reason for the application was the dismissal of workers from the production plant of Fiat Auto Poland S.A. de Tychy. Europe's automotive sector has been severely affected by structural changes due to globalisation, which have led to a dramatic drop in demand and production in Europe in recent years.  The proposal approved by the Commission consists of a total of EUR 1 259 610 for the co-financing of measures to support the reintegration of 777 laid-off workers. Whereas the measures will promote access to the labour market for dismissed workers, I vote in favour of the mobilisation of the EGF.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — Significant structural changes have led to a decrease in the market share of the European automotive industry on the global market and the financial crisis has led to a decline in citizens' purchasing power resulting in redundancies.  That is why I supported the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help workers laid off from Fiat Auto Poland S.A.'s manufacturing facility.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been created to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of structural changes due to globalisation.  The report aims to provide 1.25m euros to help redundate workers, which would allow workers to be reintegrated more faster through education and incentives for self-employment.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Olbrycht report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, because the mobilisation of the fund in this case contributes to the considerable relief of the redundant workers of Fiat Auto Poland in Tychy, Poland.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I voted for this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) application. The applicant shows the correlation between the declining car production and employment levels in Fiat Auto Poland. The plant in Tychy hired 6 422 workers in 2009 in order to produce 606 000 cars, while in 2012 production amounted to 361 000 units with 4 882 workers. Over the 2009-2013 period, while production decreased by 56 %, employment dropped by only 46 %. In Fiat Auto Poland the decrease in employment has therefore been less acute than the decrease in production. This was achieved by the factory operating on a two-shift basis instead of the regular practice of three shifts. The Polish authorities also provide Eurostat data on the employment situation in the automotive sector, where a continuous fall isdemonstrated. Employment in the automotive industry in EU-27 at the end of 2009.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund concerning Poland's application for an amount of EUR 1 259 610. The application concerns 829 workers at the Tychy plant of Fiat Auto Poland, a company operating in the automotive sector, and at its 21 suppliers in the Silesia region, made redundant, during the reference period from 21 January 2013 to 21 May 2013. We must ensure that the Fund supports the stable reintegration into the labour market of redundant individual employees affected by structural changes in world trade flows.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — The profound transformation of the international trading system, attributable to the advance of globalisation and the economic and financial crisis, has led Poland towards total economic asphyxiation. The European Union must intervene in support of the country, and its inhabitants, so that the burden of the economic depression is made bearable.     That is why I thought I was in favour of the Olbrycht report, which calls for the EGF to be mobilised in favour of 1079 workers made redundant at Fiat Auto Poland S.A.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I have given my assent to the request to support Auto Poland S.A. from the EGF. With the active help of the Polish Government, the more than 1000 redundancies will be able to re-enter the labour market in the short and medium term.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The globalization aid fund works in the service of job destruction.  It encourages shareholders and states in the social irresponsibility of capitalism. The request concerns Polish workers who have suffered 829 redundancies from Fiat's Tychy production site and 250 redundancies at 21 suppliers and downstream producers. The Fiat Panda was originally mounted in Italy. The second generation was relocated to Poland, leaving the Campania region in misery. Now that Fiat has taken advantage of Polish low wages, it has returned to Italy by lowering Italian labour law and creating many layoffs in Poland. Fiat has thus blackmailed Italian trade unions, asking them to join a "special" collective agreement, including requiring more night rotations, a reduction in break times and an increase in mandatory overtime. I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. More and more companies are relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices that are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to Poland to give this aid to the EGF/2013/006 PL/Fiat application, following 1 079 redundancies, that is, 829 in Fiat Auto Poland and 250 in the 21 companies its suppliers and producers downstream, and participation in the EGF measures of 777 people is expected, redundancies related to a decrease in production at the Tychy plant of Fiat Auto Poland S.A., located in the province of Slaskie, during the period from January 21, 2013 to May 21, 2013.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — This report outlines the European automotive industry losses in market share since 2007, with a drop of almost a third over the same period at the national level in Poland. With this funding, the reintegration of redundant workers into employment will be helped. I have therefore voted in favour of this report, which will promote entrepreneurship and help the reintegration of workers back into the workforce.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this Report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Poland in order to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in Fiat Auto Poland S.A.’s production plant at Tychy, located in the region of Slaskie, Poland, due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Poland seeks co-financing (50%) EUR 1,259,610 under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to help retrain 829 employees laid off by Fiat Auto Poland and 250 other sacked employees at 21 downstream suppliers and producers. Ultraliberalism, imposed by Brussels, has led to deindustrialization and mass unemployment throughout the European Union and particularly in the euro area. Without the re-establishment of national borders and the application of reasoned protectionism, low-cost countries will therefore continue to maintain totally unfair competition in the automotive industry as in other sectors. French car manufacturers are the first victims of this. It should be recalled that while world car production increased by 5.3% between 2001/2012, it fell by 7% in the EU over the same period. I voted for this request, although I consider that on the merits, the European Union is the main culprit in this economic and social collapse.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the application as it will address the 829 redundancies in the production plant of Fiat Tychy, and 250 from 21 suppliers and downstream producers, which have been impacted by the European automotive industry’s falling share of the global market.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Olbrycht for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the 829 redundancies of Fiat Auto Polonia and a further 250 redundancies at the 21 suppliers and producers downstream. The relevant and negative fact to consider is that these redundancies represent only 1/10 of all the unemployed in the Tychy area alone where fiat's plant is present.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Fiat Auto Poland is, in my view, worthy of support, as the company concerned meets all the formal criteria for granting the aids. The idea of maintaining know-how in the field of the production of small-car vehicles in the affected region is of particular importance to me. I therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I support in principle the programmes implementing the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund but considering, in this case, that the redundancies in question allow Fiat to return to Italy after having relocated to Poland for the first time, while imposing considerably reduced working conditions, I abstained on this vote.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the european Parliament's motion for a resolution to allocate EUR 1 259 610 from the EGF to Poland, which will allow the reintegration into the labour market of 777 people who became unemployed as a result of redundancy. With the EGF, we can mobilise these people again in the labour market.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Whereas the Polish authorities have submitted a specific application for financial assistance from the EGF following redundancies at Fiat Auto Poland and its 21 suppliers in Poland; that the economic and financial crisis has had a major impact on the car sector, with a significant decline; that the Commission, following its examination of the application, considered that the criteria for applying the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund were met, I would like to vote in favour of it.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I supported Jan Olbrycht's report. The global and financial crisis has affected sales of new passenger cars, which are at their lowest level since measurements began, which also reflected a sharp decline in EU market share, but also the loss of jobs for Fiat Auto Poland workers. Demand for new cars in 2012 in the EU-27 fell by 8.7% while globally there was a 5.1% increase in car sales, so it is no surprise that the EU's downward market share in the production and sales of passenger cars was confirmed by the final report of the Competitive Regulatory System of the Automotive Industry, published on 6 June 2012. The redundancies of Fiat Auto Poland's factory workers in particular have left a negative impact on the Tychy area, where former Fiat Auto Poland workers and its suppliers, represent one-tenth of all unemployed people living in the area. I supported a proposal by the European Commission and the Council to grant financial assistance to the 777 redundanced workers of the Fiat Auto Poland factory in the form of €1.2 million in self-employment support.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — This time, the mobilisation of the EGF is in favour of Poland in order to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at fiat Auto Poland S.A.'s Tychy plant because of the crisis in the car industry, particularly affected by a significant decline in sales across the EU. There are 777 workers made redundant, benefiting from the measures provided for in the EGF, and I believe that the services put in place, such as training grants, traineeship grants, traineeship costs, targeted interventions and aid for self-employment, can definitely help them to re-enter the labour market.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The level of car sales in the European Union continues to fall. There have been many layoffs in recent years. I therefore vote in favour of mobilizing the Globalization Adjustment Fund for the conversion and creation of companies for the sacked employees of the Fiat company in Poland.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — Poland submitted an application to obtain a financial contribution from the EGF following 1079 redundancies at Fiat Auto Poland's Tychy plant (829) and 21 companies, its suppliers and downstream producers,(250) during the reference period between 21 January 2013 and 21 May 2013. According to the Commission, this application complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, and it is, on the one hand, that the redundancies in question are related to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, as the European automotive industry has lost market share since 2007 (in 2007, European car production accounted for 32.2 % of global production , while in 2012 it was only 23.2 %, with a decrease of 7 % between 2011 and 2012, during which world production increased by 5.3 %) whereas, at national level, production volume fell by almost a third between 2011 and 2012; and, on the other hand, that such redundancies will have a negative impact on the province of Slaskie. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Poland.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. — The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Poland, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 259 610 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 777 workers who have lost their jobs at Fiat Auto Poland S.A. in Poland, engaged in the manufacture of automobiles, as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis. The customized services to be financed from the EGF include training activities, vocational guidance, recycling and incentives for the creation of companies. While these aids are not in themselves able to alleviate rising unemployment in the automotive industry sector accentuated by the impact of globalisation that has worsened the effects of the financial crisis, reducing sales of new passenger cars in the EU to the lowest level since data are collected, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of workers affected.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help the 829 Fiat Auto Poland workers and the 250 people working for 21 subcontractors, all of whom were dismissed. And for good reason: the European automotive industry is going through a major crisis, as evidenced by its loss of market share since 2007. In that year, European production of passenger cars accounted for 32.2% of world production, up from 23.2% in 2012. Between 2011 and 2012, world production increased by 5.3%, while at the same time, the EU-27 production fell by 7%. It therefore seems to me perfectly legitimate to help these many workers who are victims of the crisis in the automotive sector in order to help them find a job quickly.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — As in mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Greek and Italian cases, I voted in favour of the proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Poland, amounting to EUR 1 259 610, in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 777 workers made redundant at Fiat Auto Poland's Tychy plant , which suffered a 56 % decrease in production in the period 2009 to 2013. With this financial contribution, it will be possible to finance the training of workers, to allocate training grants, internship grants, integration work, self-employment grants, incentives to hire and foster entrepreneurship.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour in order to avoid some 1 000 redundancies in the automotive sector.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 1 079 workers, 829 Fiat Auto Poland and 250 from 21 suppliers and product transformers; 777 people are expected to participate in the EAGF measures, related to the decline in production at the production plant of Fiat Auto Poland S.A. de Tychy, located in Slaskie Province, Poland, during the reference period from 21 January 2013 to 21 May 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU. These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Poland, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Today I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for application EGF/2013/006. Fiat Auto Poland has been granted EGF aid to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in the production plant at Tychy of Fiat Auto Poland S.A. located in the region of Slaskie, Poland, due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. The Polish authorities argue that the impact of globalisation has been worsened by the effect of the financial crisis which has reduced the sales of new passenger cars in the EU to the lowest level since records began.  The application concerns 829 redundancies in the production plant of Fiat Tychy and 250 from 21 suppliers and downstream producers during the reference period from 21 January 2013 to 21 May 2013. The EUR 1 259 610 of EGF aid will pay for the package of personalised services to support the reintegration of 777 redundant workers into employment.  The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing — It is important that the financial contribution under mobilisation for that undertaking is used efficiently. Financial resources from the European Globalisation Fund should not only be seen as aid, but mainly as an investment in human capital in a given region.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I supported the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to assist workers from Fiat Auto Poland S.A. production facility due to the redundancies of workers as a result of major structural changes in global trade flows occurring as a result of the major economic crisis. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of structural changes due to globalisation. This report aims to free up the amount of 1,259,610 euros to help laid-off workers, which would allow workers to be reintegrated more faster through education and incentives for self-employment.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I agree with the decision to assist Poland, which like most Member States is in an unenviable economic position and encounters a high unemployment rate. As we know, the automotive sector in the European Union has reduced its production, lost market share, all of which has led to a rise in unemployment. This scenario has also affected some of the more developed members of the Union, and Poland has not remained immune either. I therefore consider that assistance is necessary as it will lead to an improvement in the economic and social situation, not only in Poland but also throughout the Union. Solidarity is one of the fundamental principles of the Union and assistance to a Member State means assistance to the Union. This Fund was also set up to assist in the event of such situations, and states seeking Union assistance do so because they are compelled to respond to the situation in which they have found themselves.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing — I do not agree with the proposal because, like all other contributions from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, it amplifies precisely the problem to be addressed. In fact, the funds provided to redundant Polish workers are financed by taxes on other EU firms and employees, which accordingly reduces their competitiveness.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. — The ECR Group fully supports measures that put in place policies that create growth and jobs. However, we do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for putting in place such policies nor do we believe it is an efficient tool that offers value for money for EU taxpayers, therefore I voted against.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The money from the adjustment fund should basically be given to the dismissed persons and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, or more often known as the WEF, was set up to provide support to workers who are becoming victims of restructuring and global trade. The aim is therefore to train, or help to rebound, those working citizens who have committed no fault except that of living in a time when human character often seems less important than the search for profits for certain investors or speculators. So the fund we're voting on is meant to be a second chance.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — The EU must be ready to give a second chance to workers that have lost their job because of the economic crisis, in this case of PL/Fiat Auto Poland S.A. company, from Poland. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established to provide support for workers made redundant and self-employed persons whose activity has ceased as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis, to assist them with their reintegration into the labour market. That is why I give my support to this report.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as I consider it appropriate to mobilize the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to ensure the continuity in the future of regions affected by deind industrialisation processes.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - (IT) As with the other three requests for the activation of the EGF, I voted in favour of the decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in connection with Poland's request for financial assistance, following the massive job cut at Fiat Auto Poland's Tychy plant. Here, too, the fund is a useful and concrete measure to limit the impact of globalisation and the financial crisis on the European car industry. While I therefore support the allocation of around EUR 1.2 million to support the reintegration into work of almost 800 redundancies, I would nevertheless like to stress that the response to the crisis cannot be entirely entrusted to emergency management instruments, but requires an urgent rethink of the whole architecture of European economic governance.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — This report enables the mobilization of the Globalization Adjustment Fund for 777 of the 829 workers laid off at Fiat's Tychy, Poland, site, as well as 250 others laid off by subcontractors. It follows the Fiat Group's decision to relocate its production to Italy at the Pomigliano d'Arco plant. Italian workers, who were placed out of work due to the shutdown of half of the Alfa Romeo range, had to accept significant feedback on their working conditions in order for Fiat to relocate its operations to Italy. In defiance of branch agreements, a specific collective agreement ratified willy-nilly by the majority of trade unions allows for more night rotations, a reduction in break times, penalties for absenteeism and an increase in mandatory overtime. Since this fund was mobilised when Fiat had relocated these activities to Poland, it is clear that it is a question of financing the consequences of social dumping within the Union and that this encourages offshoring operations, by transferring a large part of their cost to European finances. It's up to these multinationals to pay for their social damage. They can afford it. I therefore systematically vote against these anti-social measures.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — This application is submitted by Poland following 829 redundancies at Fiat Auto Poland and 250 in 21 its downstream suppliers and producers. The European car industry has been losing market share since 2007, when European passenger car production accounted for 32.2% of world production, down 23.2% in 2012. The group also decided to transfer production of the Panda Classic model to the Campania region of Italy from January 2013 in order to generate jobs in their country of origin.  In addition to actions to be developed directly with redundant workers such as training costs, entrepreneurship training, training grants, internship grants, self-employment grant, among others, it encourages hiring: employers who hire a former employee of this company for a period of 24 months will receive a subsidy that can go up to 4,845 euros. That measure would only make sense if the allocation of this subsidy to undertakings was conditional on the maintenance of the rights which the workers made redundant had in Fiat Auto Poland and corresponded to a permanent job.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — To provide aid to Auto Poland S.A. from the European Globalisation Fund is, in my view, a necessity which must be made at a time of crisis. Since, thanks to the active help of the Polish Government, more than 1000 redundancies can regain their footing in the labour market in the short and medium term, I have, among other things, approved this motion.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — This application is submitted by Poland following 829 redundancies at FIAT Auto Poland and 250 in 21 companies supplying its downstream producers. In the justification presented, Poland stresses that the European automotive industry has lost market share since 2007, a percentage which fell to 23.2 % in 2012; stresses, furthermore, that production in the EU-27 decreased by 7 % between 2011 and 2012, while world production increased by 5.3 % in the same period; on the other hand, the group decided to transfer the production of the Panda Classic model to the Campania region, Italy, which demonstrates how capitalism uses labor in the taste of profit. In addition to actions to be developed directly with redundant workers such as training costs, entrepreneurship training, training grants, traineeships, self-employment grant, among others, it advocates encouraging hiring: employers who hire a former employee of this company for a period of 24 months will receive a subsidy of up to EUR 4 845. This measure would only make sense if the allocation of this subsidy to undertakings was conditional on the maintenance of the rights which the workers made redundant had in FIAT AUTO POLAND and corresponded to a permanent job.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 551 workers from Odyssefs Fokas S.A., a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 47 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Retail trade, except motor vehicles and motorcycles'). This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Greece, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Greece, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF for Greece's needs in order to support the return to the labour market of workers made redundant from Odyssefs Fokas S.A. in retail. Since 2008 Greece's GDP fell by 25.7%, government consumption by 21%, private consumption by 32.3% and unemployment increased by 20.6%. The EGF is intended to provide an amount of EUR 6 444 000 to a total of 600 beneficiaries. The individual needs package for redundant workers will include vocational guidance, training, retraining, business support and mobility allowance. I welcome the allocation of funds from this fund to employees affected by Odyssefs Fokas.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — For six consecutive years, Greece has been experiencing severe economic difficulties. During the period 2008-2013, the unemployment rate quadrupled and the highest among EU Member States.  The layoffs at Odyssefs Fokas aggravate the economic situation.  The regions of Central Macedonia, Attica and Thessaly, where these layoffs take place, suffer from very high unemployment and a severe shortage of job opportunities. In addition, Attica accounts for 43% of Greece's GDP. This is why the closure of businesses in this region has a negative impact on the country as a whole. EGF assistance of 1,259,610 is more than necessary to stimulate local growth and provide essential support to former Workers of Odyssefs Fokas.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — On 11 November 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision mobilizing the EGF in favour of Greece to support the return to the labour market of dismissed workers from Odyssefs Fokas S.A. I supported this decision as the Greek authorities argue that the Greek economy is plunged, for the sixth consecutive year (2008-2013), into a deep depression. According to ELSTAT, the Greek statistical authority, since 2008 Greek GDP has fallen by 25.7%, public consumption by 21%, and private consumption by 32.3%, while unemployment has increased by 20.6%. Consumption in Greek households has declined since the onset of the economic and financial crisis and numbers have worsened every year.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Greece submitted the application following the dismissal of 551 workers from Odyssefs Fokas S.A., which operated in the retail economic sector, particularly in the Attica and Central Macedonia regions, where the unemployment rate is already above the national average (27%). This situation is mainly due to the increasing austerity imposed in the EU and particularly in Greece by the troika and the financial markets. The EGF's contribution is expected to be EUR 6.444 million and nearly 500 unemployed young people will also receive training in this context. In view of the difficult economic and social situation in Greece, I voted in favour of this Fund.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in favour of 600 redundancies in the retail sector. The EGF is both a concrete and indispensable instrument for supporting companies and workers affected by the crisis and the malfunctioning of the internal market, but it needs a leaner and more flexible activation bureaucracy in order to have a positive impact on the lives of European citizens.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I have voted in favour of these reports today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs.  However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped.   Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 6 444 000 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 600 workers who have lost their jobs in Odyssefs Fokás S.A., company engaged in retail trade in department stores in Greece, as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalization and the fall in purchasing power of Greek households following the decline in the country's economy since the beginning of the economic and financial crisis. The customized services to be financed from the EGF include training activities, vocational guidance, recycling and incentives for the creation of companies. In addition, the Greek authorities will provide personalized services co-financed by the EAGF to 500 young people who neither work nor follow studies or training, under the age of thirty, as redundancies affect an eligible region under the Youth Employment Initiative. While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama faced by millions of Greek households, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supported parliament's decision to grant support to 551 workers who were dismissed in 2014 from Odyssefs Fokas S.A. It is argued that the events that led to the early redundancies were two: a reduction in disposable household income due to the higher tax burden, lower wages (in the private and public sectors) and rising unemployment, and a sharp reduction in purchasing power.
