At the same time, the lack of cash in Greek banks has led to a significant reduction in the provision of loans to businesses and individuals.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for the mobilisation of funds of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund because I support European companies which may have difficulties in these times of economic crisis.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — 600 redundancies in the retail trade (excluding motor vehicles and motorcycles) and EUR 6 444 000 (60% of costs). I voted in favour of worker support and employment.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — Parliament has decided to accept the request for intervention from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund from Greece to help employees of Odyssefs Fokas, which is heavily affected by the employment consequences of globalisation. The amount of aid amounts to 6.4 million euros. More than 600 laid-off employees will benefit from training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job. I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 600 workers made redundant as a result of globalisation at Odyssefs Fokas, a company operating in the retail sector. Due to the decline in the purchasing power of Greek households due to the contraction of the Greek economy since the beginning of the economic and financial crisis, demand for non-basic necessities has plummeted and Odyssefs Fokas' turnover has started to decline accordingly. The reduction in turnover due to the fall in consumption, combined with the unachieability of credit, has frustrated Odyssefs Fokas' attempts to find a solution. The aim of the EGF is to facilitate the rapid reintegration of these redundant workers through personalised accompanying actions, such as information sessions, reception and registration, counselling and guidance, skills assessment, general training and retraining, vocational training, coaching, job-seeking allowances, as well as recruitment incentives. I regret that Italian companies are not able to benefit more from the EGF because of the lack of support from local and national institutions that submitted only 14 requests in total between 2007 and 2014.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU contributing 60% of an adjustment fund payout in the sum of EUR 6.44 million to former Odyssefs Fokas employees, suppliers and producers in Greece. This cost should have been met by the Greek government, and not, in effect, subsidised by the British taxpayer, through their contributions the EU. This is, effectively, a further bailout payment.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — The mobilisation of the EGF in question to the value of EUR 6.5 million helps not only the 600 workers affected by the closure of a Greek company, but also 500 young people in the area who have suffered a severe economic depression.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — Greece is a country hard hit by globalisation. I hope that these funds, which were also allocated with my vote in favour, will have the effect of moderating the extremist positions that appear to be majority positions in Greece and will give us an election result that bodes well for the future. Our economies are so interconnected that greek affairs also have serious repercussions on other countries and we are not in a position to suffer shoulder to shoulder.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use every means at its service to react, in particular as regards the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on mobilising EUR 6 44 000 for Greece with the aim of supporting the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Odyssefs Fokas S.A.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - In the Attica and Central Macedonia region, 90% of the redundancies of Odyssefs Fokas, a retail company, are concentrated. The fall in household disposable income, the fall in wages and the rise in unemployment have led to a collapse in purchasing power in Greece, which has had devastating economic and financial consequences. We are all concerned about the situation in this country, which has the highest unemployment rate among the Member States, having already been in recession for the sixth consecutive year (2008-2013). The reduction in turnover due to the fall in consumption, combined with the unachieability of credit, has frustrated Odyssefs Fokas' attempts to find a solution to the 551 workers made redundant. That is why I welcome today's decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in response to Greece's request, and I hope that today's vote will allow employees to be reintegrated into the labour market and will be a small lever for the economic recovery of the sector.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The redundancies of 551 workers in Odyssefs Fokas S.A., an enterprise operating in the retail trade, five providers and downstream producers, are linked to the decrease of available household income, rising unemployment and the drastic reduction of loans to enterprises and individuals due to lack of cash in the Greek banks. Redundant workers will be given personalised services which will include occupational guidance, training, retraining, contributions to business start-ups, job search allowances and training allowances. I have therefore voted in favour of this report since the measure not only addresses loss of jobs but also reintegration into the labour market.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — (IT) According to the Greek authorities, there are two main reasons for the redundancies: the fall in disposable income of households, due to the increase in the tax burden and the fall in wages (both in the public and private sectors), and the increase in unemployment, which has led to a collapse in purchasing power. These redundancies will further exacerbate the employment situation in a country where, over the period 2008-2013, the number of unemployed has quadrupled and with the highest unemployment rate among Member States and the fifth highest in the world. I am voting in favour of this resolution in order to facilitate the reintegration of the 551 workers into sustainable and forward-looking economic sectors. I am also voting in favour in order to take account of the future prospects of the labour market and the skills required and to be compatible with the transition to a resource-efficient economy.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 551 workers from Odyssefs Fokas S.A., a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 47 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Retail trade, except motor vehicles and motorcycles'). This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Greece, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of all four applications for EUR 35.5 million in EU aid to help find and create new jobs for workers made redundant by Air France, Fiat Auto Poland, Whirlpool and a Greek retailer. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aid application in the case of Odyssefs Fokas will support 600 workers and their search for jobs with over EUR 6.4 million.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Since 2008 and the beginning of the banking and financial crisis, Greece has been experiencing a very difficult economic and social situation. High unemployment leads to a decline in purchasing power, which has a strong impact on the retail sector. That is why the vote in favour of unlocking funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) is important. It will give the 600 laid-off Greek employees of odyssefs Fokas the tools necessary for a rapid reintegration into the labour market.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — As a result of the fall in the purchasing power of Greek households due to the contraction of the economy, demand in Greece for non-basic necessities has plummeted since the beginning of the economic and financial crisis. Odyssefs Fokas' revenue also began to decline with the onset of the crisis. The reduction in turnover due to the decrease in consumption, combined with the unachieability of credit, frustrated the company's attempts to find a solution to the corporate crisis, in November 2013 the company therefore filed for bankruptcy that caused numerous redundancies. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the workers of Odyssefs Fokas who, as a result of the economic crisis, have seen their jobs lost.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. In this case, the contribution of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) is EUR 6,444,000. It is thus intended to enable the reintegration into the labour market of 600 workers dismissed from Odysseys Fokas SA, a Greek retail company that had to file for bankruptcy in November 2013. The Greek authorities have also taken this opportunity to provide 500 NEETs (Not in Education, Employment or Training) with their personalised service package. This aid is essential for Greece, whose economy is in deep recession for the sixth consecutive year (2008-2013). I can only be in favour of such a demand, while hoping that Greece will finally emerge from the acute crisis in which it finds itself and that its national economy will finally progress.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — This is the 21st request to be examined under the 2014 budget and a total of EUR 6 444 000 from the EGF for Greece. The application concerns a total of 600 beneficiaries and 500 NEETs. The request was submitted to the Commission on 29 July 2014 and further information was added by 23 September 2014. On the basis of the relevant provisions of the EGF Regulation, the Commission concluded that the conditions for the financial contribution from the EGF were fulfilled for the application. A coordinated package of personalised services for redundant workers and NEETs includes the following actions: career guidance advice, training, retraining and vocational training, contribution to setting up a business, financial support for job search and training, mobility support. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the report because, although I am opposed to the economic policy of re-integration, where funds are allocated to retraining companies instead of those who are immediately dismissed, it concerns a Greek company.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. — Due to the fall in purchasing power of Greek households following the decline of the Greek economy since the beginning of the economic and financial crisis, demand for products other than commodities plummeted and the turnover of Odyssefs Fokas, a company engaged in the sale of clothing, began to decline accordingly. In this case, it is the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 6 444 000 from the EGF for Greece. It affects a total of 600 beneficiaries and 500 ninis. It should be positively assessed that most of the funds requested will go towards contributing to the creation of enterprises (EUR 3 000 000) and training measures (EUR 2 960 000).

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The EGF was created to provide additional support for workers made redundant following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Between 2014 and 2020, the fund's annual ceiling is EUR 150 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take action to get their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. the Greek authorities submitted the application EGF/2014/013 EL/Odyssefs Fokas on 29 July 2014, following the dismissal of 551 employees of Odyssefs Fokas S.A., a company with activities in the economic sector classified in division 47 (Retail trade, excluding motor vehicles and motorcycles) of NACE Rev. 2 In this mobilization of the EGF for Greece EUR 6.44 million was granted. I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — Greece's application under consideration concerns ODYSSEFS FOKAS S.A., a company with activities in the retail sector, which declared bankruptcy, placing 600 workers unemployed, of whom 87% are women. The justification for this dismissal has already seen it before: a reduction in household disposable income – due to increased tax burdens, falling wages (both in the private sector and in the civil service) and increased unemployment – which has resulted in a huge drop in purchasing power. The drastic reduction in loans to companies and individuals due to the lack of liquidity of Greek banks has also been invoked. It should be noted that 90% of redundancies are concentrated in the regions of Attica (unemployment 28.2 %) and Central Macedonia (unemployment 30.3 %), and that Greece is the fifth country in the world with the highest unemployment rate. On the other hand, the Attica region contributes to 43 % of Greek GDP and, for this reason, the impact of the closure of this company affects the entire Greek economy. The report proposes to support the 600 redundant workers and up to 600 young people who do not work, study or train. We voted in favour, while the well-known reservations we have regarding this instrument.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The Fund in question was set up to provide additional support to workers in the Member States of the European Union most affected by the economic and financial crisis and major structural changes in world trade patterns. The European Commission has adopted a proposal to mobilise the EGF in favour of Greece, namely for oddysefs fokas S.A. The Greek economy has been in a deep recession for the 7th year and unemployment has risen by 20% across the country. As a result of the poor purchasing power of Greek households, interest in the products of the company in question decreased significantly, which, due to a number of factors, was forced to declare bankruptcy and lay off employees.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of granting the fund for the 600 workers made redundant in the retail sector in Greece.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — Although I disagree with the economic policy of re-integration, where funds are allocated to retraining companies instead of to those who are immediately in need, I am voting in favour of report A8-0063/2014 because it concerns a Greek company.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — I voted against using British taxpayers’ money to subsidise the Greek government.  Redundancies in Odyssefs Fokas have affected 600 people, and the Greek Government wants the EU to pay EUR 6,444,000 towards retraining etc.  This should be the expense of Odyssefs Fokas and the Greek Government.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour for Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2014/013 EL/Odyssefs Fokas.  I am in favour of the mobilisation of the fund concerning this request, because the application relates to 500 young persons not in employment, education or training. Considering the fact that youth unemployment rate is dramatically high in the EU, thus I strongly support all financial measures that promote entrepreneurship and business initiative that might lead to create more workplaces.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the EGF application from Odyssefs Fokas in Greece where 600 workers lost their jobs. I am pleased to see the Greek authorities using the possibility to include 500 NEETs in this application also. The high level of youth unemployment in Greece means that it can use this option within the EGF. The overall fund is EUR 10.7 million with a EUR 6.44 million contribution from the EGF. 70% of this money is going to training, retraining, vocational training, business start-up and occupational guidance, with 30% earmarked for allowances such as job search allowance, training allowance and mobility allowance.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. — I do not think that people should be the victims of failing European socio-economic policies. That is why I voted in favour of the mobilisation of funds from the European Fund for Adaptation to Globalisation, but I think this is a wipe for the bleeding. In fact, I believe that companies, and the Member States themselves, should come up with appropriate aid measures themselves, because now we are actually just pumping money from the Member States around. Large companies put their employees on the streets after years of loyal service, because they move their production to places where they can find cheaper labour. I strongly reject these degrading practices, and with the resources from the European Fund, we are at least ensuring that the workers who have been sent away are not left out in the cold.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for this motion for a resolution on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to assist 551 redundancy workers of the Greek company Odyssefs Fokas S.A. It is clear that the situation of unemployment in Greece has been critical since 2008 and that these redundancies will deteriorate further. For this reason, I strongly support the financial assistance of the EGF in this case, and any coordinated one that would contribute positively to the state of the economy of European countries such as Greece. I also support the fact that the Greek authorities have decided to provide services tailored to the needs of the affected workers in order to mitigate the consequences of this case, especially in young people. It is also necessary to ensure the competitiveness and efficiency of European economies so that they can strongly counter crisis situations such as large redundancies.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Monika Vana's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the sacked employees of Odyssefs Fokas in Greece. The fund will provide a 6.4 million euro package for 600 laid-off employees of Odyssefs, which will be used to finance training, counselling or business start-up bonuses to help beneficiaries reintegrate into the labour market. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I supported the resolution on the european Globalisation Adjustment Fund's request for the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund introduced by Greece concerning redundancies at Odyssefs Fokas. The Fund was created to promote the reintegration into the labour market of workers who are victims of changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization, or the financial crisis. I the example of this aid, which amounts to more than EUR 6,400,000, is welcomed.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Monika Vana which provides support for some Greek companies. Specifically, the report provides for the allocation of resources necessary for the reintegration into the labour market of 600 redundancies at Odyssefs Fokas S.A., a company operating in the economic sector of the retail trade. Europe is once again demonstrating its mission of solidarity and its concreteness in helping the people most affected by a devastating economic crisis.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: In writing. — As I had already had the opportunity in the Parliamentary Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I renewed my vote in favour of the Vana report to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 600 employees, including 500 young people, who were dismissed from the company Odyssefs Fokas (Greece). The EGF will fund 60% (EUR 6,444,000 at a total cost of EUR 10,740,000) projects consisting mainly of training, orientation, job search and training allowances and mobility aids.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — This is a proposal for a decision mobilizing the EGF for Greece to support the return to the labour market of dismissed workers of Odyssefs Fokas S.A., which operated in the economic sector classified in division 47 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Retail trade, except motor vehicles and motorcycles').  It refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 6 444 000 from the EGF for Greece. It affects a total of 600 beneficiaries and 500 young people who are out of work and do not take any formal training or education at this time. I agree with your concession.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 551 workers from Odyssefs Fokas S.A., a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 47 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Retail trade, except motor vehicles and motorcycles'). This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Greece, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — On 11 November 2014, the Commission approved a request from Greece for the mobilisation of the EGF for 600 dismissed workers from Odyssefs Fokas S.A. and 500 ninis. The mobilisation amounts to a total of EUR 6 444 000 for the financing of measures to support labour insertion. This dismissal was due to the global economic crisis, which has had a particular impact on Greece. The reduction in the purchasing level of consumers has caused a major drop in demand for Odyssefs Fokas S.A. This, coupled with harsh credit conditions, made an escape from bankruptcy impossible. In view of this situation, I consider it appropriate to approve the mobilization of the EGF.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — The crisis, which has been shaking the Greek economy for the sixth year in a row, has caused a significant decline in citizens' purchasing power, significantly affecting the retail sector.  That is why I supported the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to assist redundantic workers from Odyssefs Fokas S.A at the request of Greece. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been created to provide additional support to workers made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis to help re-enter the labour market.  This report aims to mobilise €6.5 million for career guidance, training, retraining and incentives for self-employment, all with a purpose of bringing redundant workers back into the labour market.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Vana report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, because the mobilisation of the fund in this case contributes to the considerable relief of the redundant workers of Fokas in Greece.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I welcome this support under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) given that these redundancies will further aggravate the unemployment situation in a country where, during the period 2008-2013, the number of unemployed people increased four-fold and which presents the highest unemployment rate among Member States and the fifth highest worldwide. There is especially concern about the regions of Attica and Central Macedonia, where 90 % of the redundancies are concentrated and which already have unemployment rates above the national average of 27.5 %.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund concerning greece's application for a total of EUR 6 444 000. The application concerns 551 workers made redundant at the Odyssefs Fokas S.A. plant, a company operating in the "retail trade, excluding motor vehicles and motorcycles". The EGF must provide timely assistance to facilitate the rapid reintegration into working life of workers made redundant as a result of the economic and financial crisis.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) The Greek economy continues to be the victim of a deep recession. The unemployment rate has reached unprecedented levels within the country. It is against this backdrop that we must put into context the 600 redundancies at Odyssefs Fokas S.A.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I have approved the application for EGF funding for Odyssefs Fokas. The situation in Greece is particularly tragic for the retail trade, where Odyssefs Fokas is also active. It is particularly laudable that the Greek Government will set up a care system co-financed by the EGF for the approximately 500 young people affected without education, vocational training or permanent employment.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The globalization aid fund plays its destructive role. Here the demand concerns 1,100 Greek workers, 551 of whom are made redundant by the retail company Odyssef Fokas and 500 young people without work and training. The Greek government has clearly analysed that this is due to lower household disposable incomes, due to higher taxes, lower wages (both in the public and private sectors) and rising unemployment, resulting in a sharp fall in purchasing power.  But of course it does not propose an alternative policy to austerity. I abstain so as not to deprive Greek workers of this fund.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. More and more companies are relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices that are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, Greece, which submitted the EGF/2014/013 EL/Odyssefs Fokas application on 29 July 2014, is now responsible for giving that aid to Greece, following the dismissal of 551 employees of Odyssefs Fokas S.A., a company with activities in the economic sector classified in division 47 (Retail trade, excluding motor vehicles and motorcycles) of NACE Rev. 2.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — This report notes that 600 workers and 500 young people not in employment, education or training in Greece have been adversely affected by the global economic and financial crisis. It is encouraging that the majority of the requested funds are to support business start-ups and fund training programmes. Therefore, I have voted in favour of this report, which will aid affected workers.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The automotive industry is going through difficult years in Europe, especially in Poland. More than 1,000 workers have been laid off by Fiat in southern Poland, due to a loss of market share in the automotive sector and the growing popularity of Asian cars. These layoffs are directly related to major changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization. It is therefore essential to help our workers and ensure them stable and sustainable jobs in the long term. I fully support the 1.26 million euro aid from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which will be crucial in giving 777 workers the assets needed to re-enter the labour market.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Greece in order to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in Odyssefs Fokas S.A. operating in the economic sector classified under NACE Rev. 2 division 47 (‘Retail trade, except of motor vehicles and motorcycles’) due to the global financial and economic crisis

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report concerns the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help Greece, which is facing massive layoffs in the retail sector (excluding cars and motorcycles). For example, 6,444,000 euros will be allocated under the EGF, for the conversion of 600 employees laid off by the company Odyssefs Fokas S.A. The economic, financial and social situation in Greece has been tense for years and the austerity measures demanded by Brussels have only made the situation worse. Some 23% of Greeks lived below the poverty line in 2012. Since 2008, unemployment in Greece has soared to 20.6 percentage points and household consumption has fallen by 32.3 percentage points. Greece's GDP per capita is at its lowest and the gap has widened with that of the European Union. Moreover, for the 6th consecutive year (2008-2013), the Greek economy is in a recessionary phase. In view of this situation, Greek consumers have profoundly changed their habits and have consequently reduced their spending, including the budget for clothing (clothes and shoes). For all these reasons, I voted for this aid.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the application as I believe that it will tackle concerns related to beneficiaries and NEETs effected by the economic crisis in Greece.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of the report by Mr De Clercq on behalf of the Committee on The Protection of human Rights, Research and Energy. Vain for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the 600 workers made redundant by the Odyssefs Fokas company in Greece, a country hard hit for the sixth year in a row by a deep recession from which it is still struggling to recover.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The company covered in the application had already had to lay off 600 workers in an already structurally weak region, which can be attributed primarily to declining consumption in Greece. The financial support is intended to help former Odyssefs-Fokas employees to become self-employed or retrain. Moreover, since the formal criteria for mobilising the Fund were met, I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I support the programmes implementing the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, particularly in the countries heavily affected by the financial crisis, in this case here in Greece. It is inconceivable for Europe not to guarantee security to workers who have found themselves unemployed as a result of relocations or increased competition from newly emerging countries. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal to allocate EUR 6 444 000 from the EGF to Greece, as it will help the labour market to help the 551 names who became unemployed in the Greek retail sector.  With the EGF, we can mobilise these people again in the labour market.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Whereas the Greek authorities have applied for financial assistance from the EGF as a result of the redundancies made by Odyssefs Fokas S.A. in Greece; That the Greek economy is in deep recession for the sixth year in a row and that the unemployment rate has risen considerably as a result of thousands of businesses leaving business, I would like to vote in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I supported rapporteur Monica Vana's report. Due to the consequences of globalisation, many industrial sectors in Europe are undergoing major structural changes, and due to the decline in purchasing power of Greek households, odyssefs Fokas felt the biggest impact on its business in 2008. Most of the layoffs are concentrated on Attika and Central Macedonia, while 10% relate to Thessalia. In the last quarter of 2013, the unemployment rate in Athens was 28.2% and in Central Macedonia it was 30.3%. Both recorded unemployment rates higher than the national average (27.5%). Furthermore, there is also a lack of jobs in all three regions compared to the large number of job seekers. Between 2008 and 2013, the number of unemployed people quadrupled, representing the highest unemployment rate among Member States and the fifth highest in the world. I support a proposal by the European Commission and the Council to grant financial assistance to 600 redundanheless the workers of the Fokas factory, amounting to €6.4 million in support.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — As in other cases, the mobilisation of the EGF is due to the global crisis affecting several sectors of EU production. Odyssefs Fokas S.A., a Greek retail company, has suffered a significant drop in sales, also due to the recession that has hit the Greek economy for more than five years, with a significant drop in consumption due to a reduction in household income and a drastic reduction in business credit. In this case – the company has declared bankruptcy – there are 600 beneficiaries and in addition there are 500 NEETs. The measures envisaged are similar to the others and of undoubted usefulness: they will certainly benefit workers in order to retrain on the market.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The crisis has severely affected the purchasing power of households, having a direct impact on certain products, including retail sales. Like the layoffs of the company Odyssefs Fokas, unemployment must be curbed in particular by retraining and entrepreneurship measures, for which the Globalization Adjustment Fund will be a valuable aid. So I'm voting for it.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — Greece has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 600 redundancies at Odyssefs Fokas S.A., a company operating in division 47 of NACE Rev. 2 (Retail, except for motor vehicles and motorcycles). Under that application, Greece also proposes to provide custom services co-financed by the EGF to a maximum of 500 young people under the age of 30 who do not work, study or attend any training. According to the Commission, this application complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, and the redundancies in question are linked to the economic and financial crisis, which, as is well known, has led to a significant increase in the unemployment rate and a sharp decrease in Greek GDP, as well as a huge drop in purchasing power and consumption and a drastic reduction in loans to businesses and individuals due to a lack of liquidity from banks , eventually determining the bankruptcy of Odyssefs Fokas. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Greece.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. — The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Greece, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 6 444 000 of the Europoreo Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 600 workers who have lost their jobs in Odyssefs Fokás S.A., company engaged in retail trade in department stores in Greece, as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalization and the fall in purchasing power of Greek households following the decline in the country's economy since the beginning of the economic and financial crisis. The customized services to be financed from the EGF include training activities, vocational guidance, recycling and incentives for the creation of companies. In addition, the Greek authorities will provide personalized services co-financed by the EAGF to 500 young people who neither work nor follow studies or training, under the age of thirty, as redundancies affect an eligible region under the Youth Employment Initiative. While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama faced by millions of Greek households, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the greek authorities' request for a contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) following the redundancies at Odyssefs Fokas S.A. in Greece. It is no secret that the Greek people are going through a painful period from an economic and social point of view. Faced with the economic recession between 2008 and 2013, Greece has seen its unemployment rate skyrocket. This increase in unemployment led to a drop in incomes, which then led to a decrease in consumption. As a result, many Greeks have reduced their spending, notably by reducing their budget for items such as clothing and footwear, hence the 551 layoffs at Odyssefs Fokas. The aid that Europe must provide to these workers therefore seemed to me to be quite legitimate.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — Based on the premise that the financial assistance provided to workers affected by redundancy proceedings as a result of globalisation should be done individually and aim at their reintegration into the labour market, I voted in favour of this proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Greece, amounting to EUR 6 444 000 , as a way of assisting the 551 workers directly affected by the closure of odyssefs Fokas S.A., dedicated to retail trade. I would also stress the relevance of the Greek authorities' decision to channel this fund into the provision of personalised services to a maximum of 500 young people who, unfortunately and after this closure, have not been able to work again, have not returned to study or entered a training course, stressing that they should be carried out in close compliance with social criteria and in full respect of the principles of non-discrimination and equal opportunities.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour in order to avoid six hundred redundancies in the retail sector.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 551 workers from Odyssefs Fokas S.A., a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 47 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Retail trade, except motor vehicles and motorcycles'). This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU. These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Greece, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I welcomed today’s vote on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Greece to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in Odyssefs Fokas S.A. operating in the economic sector classified under NACE Rev. 2 division 47 (‘Retail trade, except of motor vehicles and motorcycles’). The Greek authorities argue that the Greek economy is for the sixth consecutive year (2008-2013) in deep recession. The events giving rise to the redundancies were mainly the decrease of available household income – due to the increase in the tax burden, decreasing salaries and rising unemployment – resulting in a huge drop of purchasing power and the drastic reduction of loans to enterprises and individuals due to the lack of cash in the Greek banks. A total amount of EUR 6 444 000 from the EGF will support the package of personalised services to 600 workers made redundant and 500 NEETs. The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I support the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which, at the request of the Greek authorities, would financially assist 551 workers who have been fired from Odyssefs Fokas S.A. Odyssefs Fokas S.A. is a company that has operated in the economic sector. The European Commission has concluded that the conditions for receiving monetary support and contributions from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund have been met and the proposed cash contribution is €6 444 000, representing a significant amount for the already shaken Greek economy. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund supports people who have lost their jobs as a result of structural changes in the flows of world trade and globalisation. Closing large companies or moving production outside the EU, which may be the result of the global economic and financial crisis, puts EU nationals who are out of work at a disadvantage, and I therefore support this report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I supported the European Commission's proposal to grant monetary support and contributions from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as the mobilisation criteria for it are met. I believe that €6,444,000 net will not save greece's faltering economy, but there will certainly be an injection that will ensure livelihoods for 550 families. I also welcome the efforts of the Greek authorities, who have made efforts to apply for financial assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for dismissal at Odyssefs Fokas S.A. That is why more responsibility is needed in the labour market and we must do everything to achieve economic growth and that while funds have been provided, Member States are not reaching for this kind of assistance.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing — I do not support the proposal as I believe that the european Globalisation Adjustment Fund system is not correct. Paradoxically, the nonsense of granting these funds can also be found in the report itself on the proposal, which sees an increase in the tax burden as one of the main causes of this problem. However, since this contribution is financed by the taxes of other EU countries, compensation for the high tax burden in Greece is to be made at the expense of increasing the tax burden in the rest of the European Union.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. — The ECR Group fully supports measures that put in place policies that create growth and jobs. However, we do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for putting in place such policies nor do we believe it is an efficient tool that offers value for money for EU taxpayers, therefore I voted against.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — I support, because it concerns Greek unemployed people, the argument that the funds should be given to employment programmes for the unemployed and/or the laid-off and not to some companies that will be rewarded for training them. In Greece we have an unemployment problem and not a lack of knowledge, skills and degrees for the unemployed.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, or more often known as the WEF, was set up to provide support to workers who are becoming victims of restructuring and global trade. The aim is therefore to train, or help to rebound, those working citizens who have committed no fault except that of living in a time when human character often seems less important than the search for profits for certain investors or speculators. The fund we are voting on is therefore intended to be a second chance.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established to provide support for workers made redundant and self-employed persons whose activity has ceased as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalization and economic crisis and to assist them with their reintegration into the labour market. That is why I give my support to this report in order to help people fired from Odyssefs Fokas S.A. in Greece company. They deserve a second chance in life.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — This European fund is essential to ensure the continuity of industry in peripheral countries and the employability of workers in this sector. That's why I voted for it.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the activation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) requested by Greece to stem the now unstoppable rise in unemployment. The financial contribution of approximately 6.5 million euros will be used to support over 500 employees of the company Odyssefs Fokas, which have been made redundant as a result of the difficulties of the company affected by the crisis and the paralysis of consumption. I can only support a measure that directly supports those who have lost their jobs as a result of a crisis for which they are not at all responsible. I wonder, however, what the usefulness and effectiveness of measures for professional reintegration in a country with a destroyed economy can be in practice, if nothing else is done to enable Greece to emerge from the recession.  Rather, Europe should radically change the economic and monetary policies which have had a great responsibility to lead Greece into the deepest recession in European history.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — Greece's application under consideration concerns ODYSSEFS FOKAS S, which declared bankruptcy, putting 600 workers unemployed, of whom 87.17 % are women. The justification for this dismissal lies in the reduction in household disposable income and increased unemployment – which has resulted in a huge drop in purchasing power, and the drastic reduction in loans to businesses and individuals due to the lack of liquidity of Greek banks, factors that are associated with the global financial and economic crisis. The report proposes mobilising EUR 10 740 000 for actions targeting the 600 workers made redundant from ODYSSEFS FOKAS and for a maximum of 600 young people who do not work, study or train (NEETs). We have voted for another situation in which it is the workers and their families who pay for the crisis that others have caused. We have not voted on the solution so that these situations do not happen again.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — I wholeheartedly agreed to the application for funding from the European Globalisation Fund for Odyssefs Fokas, because the situation in the Greek retail trade is particularly dramatic and the Greek Government has also been particularly positive in this regard, as it will create a co-financed care system for the 500 or so young people concerned without education, training or permanent employment.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The application under consideration concerns odyssefs fokas s.a. with activities in the retail sector, which declared bankruptcy, firing 600 workers, of whom 87.17 % are women. The justification for this dismissal, according to the Greek authorities, lies in the reduction in household disposable income – due to increased tax burdens, falling wages (both in the private sector and in the civil service) and increased unemployment – which has resulted in a huge drop in purchasing power, and a drastic reduction in loans to businesses and individuals due to the lack of liquidity of Greek banks. It should be noted that Greece is the fifth country in the world with the highest unemployment rate. The report proposes mobilising EUR 10,740,000 for actions targeting the 600 workers made redundant from ODYSSEFS FOKAS and for a maximum of 600 young people who do not work, study or train. It is the workers and their families who pay for the crisis that others have caused.  We have not tried the solution so that these situations do not happen again. This lies in the peoples of Europe, who have to take into their hands the construction of an alternative to the policies that have sunk us.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources after the 5 213 redundancies — with 3 886 people expected to take advantage of the measures — which occurred during the reference period from 1 July to 31 October 2013 due to a decline in the Union's market share in the air transport sector. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in France, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of France, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project. In this case, I note additionally the high amount requested for the project and that various concerns have been raised on this matter within the BUDG Committee.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: in writing. — Vote against.  Whilst I sympathise with the plight of the workers who are losing their jobs, it is not the role of the EU to compensate.  This is the role of national government.  My voters in the UK sent me here to vote against this kind of thing, particularly as the money is destined to pay for redundancy only, not for training to get people back to work.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise a total amount of EUR 25 937 813 from the EGF for France. International air transport has experienced severe economic shocks and, in particular, the EU market share has decreased. The exemptions from Air France relate to the substantial structural changes in the world trade system resulting from globalisation and to the decline in the Union's air transport market share. The 3 886 personalised service package for redundant workers includes staff counselling and guidance services, training, business support, change of qualifications and mobility allowances. I welcome the allocation of this fund to the workers affected by the air france venture.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — On 11 November 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a Decision on the mobilisation of EGF in favour of France to support the return to the labour market of dismissed workers as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns caused by globalisation. I voted in favour of this decision; this is the twentieth application under review under the 2014 budget and refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 25 937 813 from the EGF for France. This application concerns 3 886 redundancies during the reference period from 1 July to 31 October 2013 and during the subsequent period, but relating to the same collective redundancy procedure. The application is based on the intervention criterion in Article 2(a) of the EAGF Regulation, which requires at least five hundred redundancies to occur over a period of four months in an undertaking of a Member State.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. France has submitted a request to mobilise the EGF in order to obtain a financial contribution from the EGF following 5,213 redundancies (of which 3,886 people are expected to participate in the measures) at Air France. The contribution will amount to EUR 25,937,813, which is the largest demand in terms of amounts requested since the establishment of the EGF. These layoffs are directly linked to globalisation and the EU's market share in air transport is declining, particularly in the face of the dramatic rise of three major companies in the Persian Gulf, a trend further exacerbated by the global financial and economic crisis. After the closure of PSA in Aulnay, it is Air France that lays off and this increases unemployment in the Ile-de-France, which is why I voted for this request in order to protect and help our workers to train to retrain.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in favour of 3 886 workers. The EGF is a very important instrument, but European intervention in favour of workers and businesses must take place not only through this form of support, but also and above all by eliminating the malfunctionings of the single market.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I have voted in favour of these reports today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs.  However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped.   Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 25 937 813 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 5 213 workers who have lost their jobs at Air France, as a result of structural changes in world trade caused by globalisation. The Union's market share in air transport is in decline, especially in the face of the dramatic increase in the three major airlines in the Persian Gulf region, a trend that has been exacerbated by the global financial and economic crisis.  The customized services to be financed from the EGF include training activities, vocational guidance, recycling and incentives for the creation of companies.  While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama faced by thousands of European airline workers, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supported the granting of support to 5 213 workers made redundant from Air France in 2013. It is noted that the redundancies at Air France are linked to the substantial structural changes in the world trade system resulting from globalisation and to the decline in the Union's air transport market share, particularly following an impressive increase in the three main Gulf companies, which has been exacerbated by the global financial and economic crisis. The support was also decided because the redundancies in Air France would have a negative impact on the Ile de France region, where there will be another collective redundancies, as the Peugeot Citroën Automobile (PSA) car plant, located in One, is completely closed earlier this year.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. — The deregulation of the air sector, encouraged and financed by the European Union, is now resulting in the destruction of jobs in France, particularly in the Midi-Pyrénées region. Air France has laid off 3,886 workers for whom it is seeking the benefit of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The latter would contribute 25.9 million euros, or a 50% co-financing. I am in favour of this text, whose beneficiaries are compatriots, victims of the madness of Brussels.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this EGF report so as to make sure the workers concerned are given the best possible chance of reintegration into the labour market. However, I do note serious issues concerning the amount requested and the use of the funds. The funds are intended to help with the reintegration of beneficiaries into the labour market instead of providing them with salary replacement after being dismissed and I believe this is not the case with this particular mobilisation. I would like to have seen a much greater percentage of the find going to training, in order to assure a future in the labour market by those affected in this case. It is also the biggest mobilisation of the fund to date, which may have an impact on other mobilisations.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for the Mobilisation of Funds of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund because I support the European companies which can have difficulties in these times of economic crisis.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — 5,213 dismissed, of which 3,886 were admitted to the EGF and 25 937 813 (50% of costs). I voted in favour of supporting employment and workers.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — The European Parliament voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked Air France employees. The amount of aid amounts to more than 25 million euros. More than 5,000 laid-off employees will benefit from training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job. Air France has been forced to lay off several of its employees due to increased competition in global air traffic. I voted in favour of this mobilization of the WEF. It is important, in these times of crisis, to help citizens who are victims of certain negative consequences of globalization on employment. This is a great proof of solidarity between European countries.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 3886 workers made redundant by Air France as a result of globalisation. The dismissal of these workers is linked to major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, with a reduction in the Union's market share in the air transport sector, particularly in the face of the extraordinary rise of three large airlines in the Persian Gulf, a trend aggravated by the global financial and economic crisis and rising fuel costs. The impact of these redundancies has also been aggravated by the closure of a Peugeot company in Ile-de-France, the same region where Air France is located. The EUR 25,937.813 million in EGF aid, many of which will go to reimburse the French authorities for plans already funded to reintegrate redundant workers into the workplace, represents the highest amount of money ever paid by the fund. I regret that Italian companies are not able to benefit more from the EGF because of the lack of support from local and national institutions, which submitted only 14 requests in total between 2007 and 2014.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this EGF report so as to make sure the workers concerned are given the best possible chance of reintegration into the labour market. However, I do note serious issues concerning the amount requested and the use of the funds. The funds are intended to help with the reintegration of beneficiaries into the labour market instead of providing them with salary replacement after being dismissed and I believe this is not the case with this particular mobilisation. I would like to have seen a much greater percentage of the find going to training, in order to assure a future in the labour market by those affected in this case. It is also the biggest mobilisation of the fund to date, which may have an impact on other mobilisations.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU contributing 50% of an adjustment fund payout in the sum of nearly EUR 25.94 million to former state-owned Air France employees in France. I believe that this cost should have been met by the French Government, and not, in effect, subsidised by the British taxpayer, through their contributions to the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — This mobilization is the largest, from an economic point of view, since the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has existed and commits EUR 26 million to assist almost 4000 Air France workers.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution, but regret the inertia of the system, due to the cumbersome procedures for investigation and decision-making. I think it would be wise for us to be able to implement this assistance as a preventive measure to avoid dealing with the irreparable.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Written. — (EES) We generally support the support for redundant employees provided by the EGF. However, we believe that support from the EGF should be given much more to active labour market measures aimed at getting laid-off workers back into work. We do not believe that EU funds should be spent on passive support, but should instead be targeted at employment-enhancing initiatives and projects such as continuing training of redundant employees. That is why we cannot vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this proposal, but I do not deny that I raised my eyebrow while reading its content: in view of the recent events relating to relations between Alitalia and Air France, it is not pleasing to see that what appeared to be a strong subject appeals to the EU to support its redundancies. Yet, in this world, this can also happen.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use every means at its service to react, in particular as regards the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 25 937 813 in favour of France with the aim of supporting the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by Air France.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in relation to France's application for the 3 886 workers made redundant at Air France, as the international air transport sector has suffered serious economic damage. These would be linked to major changes in the structure of world trade, due to globalisation, with a decline in the European Union's market share, in particular due to the rise of three large airlines in the Persian Gulf. This concession is the highest in terms of the amount requested since the EGF came into force and in fact we are talking about large sums (EUR 25,937,813). But I think it is right to provide these resources for the reintegration of redundant workers and, above all, to support this sector, which is of strategic importance to the European market.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments in order to provide additional support to workers who have been affected by the consequences of major structural shifts in world trade patterns and to support the reintegration of the same workers back into the labour market. The report confirms that 3 886 of 5 213 workers previously operating in the aviation industry in France will be targeted by the EGF co-funded measures. Personalised services for the redundant workers will include advisory services and vocational guidance for workers, training, contributions for business creation, redeployment and a mobility allowance. I therefore voted in favour of this report as it will provide additional opportunities and support to the workers (and their families) affected by these redundancies.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — The redundancies at Air France are linked to major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, with a reduction in the Union's market share in the air transport sector, in particular in the face of the extraordinary rise of three major airlines in the Persian Gulf, a trend aggravated by the global financial and economic crisis. These redundancies at Air France will have a negative impact on the Île-de-France region, which is already facing further mass redundancies due to the final closure, in 2014, of the Peugeot Citroën Automobile (PSA) car plant in Aulney. I can only vote in favour of this resolution, in order to help the reintegration of beneficiaries into the labour market and to improve the employability of all workers through appropriate training and recognition of the skills and competences acquired during the worker's professional career.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources after 5 213 redundancies, with 3 886 people expected to take advantage of the measures, which occurred during the reference period from 1 July to 31 October 2013 due to a decline in the Union's market share in the air transport sector. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in France, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of all four applications for EUR 35.5 million in EU aid to help create new jobs for workers who were made redundant by Air France, Fiat Auto Poland, Whirlpool and a Greek retailer. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aid application in the case of Air France will support 3 886 workers with over EUR 25 million.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The Ile-de-France region is facing a particularly difficult situation on the employment front. It is subject to massive social plans affecting large companies. After voting in favour of European aid for psa's sacked employees, I strongly supported the text on personalised services financed to the tune of just over 25 million euros by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (WEF). This funding will benefit nearly 3,886 laid-off employees of Air France, a company headquartered in Roissy, Ile-de-France. Intelligently developed with the social partners, which I welcome, this offer of services will allow the employee beneficiaries to be more mobile, better trained or to try the adventure of starting a business.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — The national airline French Air France has applied for support after lay off 3886 employees because of the major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation. The international air transport sector has experienced serious economic disruption in recent years, in particular a contraction in the EU's market share. The effects of these changes in the structure of world trade are due to the fall in demand resulting from the economic crisis and the rise in oil prices. I strongly supported the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because it will support the re-employment of the 3886 workers made redundant by Air France.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. In this case, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) is involved in the euro of EUR 25,937,813. This application, submitted by France, is for redundancies in the aviation sector. Indeed, traditional EU airlines have lost market share to emerging competitors in the Middle East and Asia. The aim is to help 3,886 employees and to enable the co-financing of active labour market measures such as individual job search assistance, training and retraining,... This aid is certainly not up to the tragedy experienced by the laid-off workers, but it is a sign that Europe, if not prevented it, is sensitive to their plight.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — On 11 November 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for France to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade in the event of globalisation. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-financed includes the following measures to reintegrate 3 886 redundant workers: advice and guidance, training, contribution to the creation of enterprises, regular information and communication activities, retraining aid and mobility support. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the report because I am opposed to the economic policy of re-integration, where funds are allocated to education companies instead of those who are made redundant in urgent need.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. — The Union has established legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade, as well as to help them rejoin the labour market. The European Union's financial support for laid-off workers should be dynamic and made available as quickly and effectively as possible. France submitted the EGF's request for financial contribution after 5,213 redundancies, with 3,886 people expected to take action. The layoffs in Air France are due to major structural changes in global trade patterns due to globalisation and declining Union market share in the air transport sector. However, in accordance with Article 6 of the EAGF Regulation, it is necessary to ensure that the EGF supports the reintegration of laid-off workers into stable jobs, since EGF aid can only co-finance active labour market measures resulting in long-term durable jobs.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. - (IT) The European air transport sector is facing a decline in its market share, in particular as a result of the rise of three major Persian Gulf airlines and the worsening global financial and economic crisis.  Air France sees a particularly high number of redundant workers who, thanks to the adoption of today's resolution, will benefit from the reintegration measures, counselling and training services included in the proposed package.  Although the EGF is not a decisive instrument for the productive and entrepreneurial environment, it still makes it possible to provide funding for the reintegration of redundant workers into the labour market and therefore the vote on this resolution is favourable.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The EGF was created to provide additional support for workers made redundant following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Between 2014 and 2020, the fund's annual ceiling is EUR 150 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take steps to obtain their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. France submitted the EGF/2013/014 FR/Air France application for a financial contribution from the EGF, following 5213 redundancies, with participation in the measures of 3 886 persons expected during and after the reference period from 1 July 2013 to 31 October 2013, such redundancies related to a decrease in the Union's market share in air transport. In this mobilisation of the EGF in favour of France, EUR 25 million was granted. I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — France submitted an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) following 5213 redundancies, with the participation in the measures expected to be 3886 people during and after the reference period from 1 July 2013 to 31 October 2013. These redundancies are allegedly related to a decrease in the European Union's market share in air transport. According to information that came to us from the trade union movement and the organizations representing these workers – information that is decisive in our assessment of this report – the participation of workers' representatives in this process has not been properly taken care of. We note that the majority of redundant workers are between the ages of 55 and 64. We reaffirm that the EGF cannot be used as a means of financing redundancies. We voted against this report in view of the position of the French trade unions, assuming that the risk of misuse of the EGF in this case is not excluded.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
