text: in writing — The Fund in question was set up to provide additional support to workers in the Member States of the European Union most affected by the economic and financial crisis and major structural changes in world trade patterns. The European Commission has adopted a proposal to mobilise the EGF in favour of France. In particular, there are 3 886 employees who were made redundant in the course of 2013. The redundancies in question were necessary as a result of the significant economic shock that international air transport had to overcome and which, according to all available estimates, is not yet over.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of granting the fund for Air France for the 5,213 dismissed, of whom 3,886 were admitted to feg.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting against the report because I disagree with the economic policy of re-integration, where funds are allocated to retraining companies, rather than to those who are immediately in need.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — I voted against using British taxpayers’ money to subsidise the French government.  Redundancies in Air France have affected 3 886 people, and the French Government wants the EU to pay EUR 25 937 813 towards REDUNDANCIES.  We are here to vote against this kind of outrage. This should be the expense of Air France and the French Government.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. I gave my full support to the activation of 25.9 million euros in aid to the 3,886 sacked employees of Air France, the regions of Ile-de-France, Midi-Pyrénées and Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur, under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This sum is intended to accompany the financing of measures aimed at mitigating the human and social consequences of job loss and to enable the support of these people in their second professional life through vocational training and counselling services, redeployment allowances or mobility allowances. This decision illustrates the principle of solidarity on which the European project is based: this aid supports a European airline - Air France - which, like others, is hit by aggressive extra-EU competition in the passenger air market, accentuated by rising fuel prices.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2013/014 FR/Air France, from France. I do believe that this application fulfils the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation. To my mind the EU has to support the companies suffering the consequence of the economic crisis. The EU has to take all possible measures to ensure that the dismissed workers have the ability to reintegrate themselves into the labour market, to get appropriate advisory services and vocational guidance, training etc.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. — I am happy to support the mobilisation of the EGF for the 5 213 workers who were made redundant by Air France in 2013. 60% of workers targeted were men and 69% were aged between 55 and 64. I was extremely disappointed that only 6.28% of the EUR 51.8 million support (EUR 26 million being the EU contribution) was spent on training and 42% on allowances foreseen under personalised services. In this context I am happy to say that the new Regulation has capped those allowances at 35%. However it is positive that up to 955 workers can access grants up to EUR 24 000 for setting up their own business. These grants can be paid in instalments once certain milestones have been reached.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. — I do not think that people should be the victims of failing European socio-economic policies. That is why I have voted, reluctantly, for the provision of funds from the European Fund for Adaptation to Globalisation, but I think this is a wipe for the bleeding. In fact, I believe that companies, and the Member States themselves, should come up with appropriate aid measures themselves, because now we are actually just pumping money from the Member States around. Big companies like Air France put their employees on the streets after years of loyal service, because they move their production to places where they can find cheaper labour. I strongly reject these degrading practices, and with the resources from the European Fund, we are at least ensuring that the workers who have been sent away are not left out in the cold. However, I would like to stress that the globalisation fund is not intended for the remuneration of workers, this is the responsibility of Air France itself. Nor should the EU take over the role of social security provision of the Member States, for this the globalisation fund is not intended at all.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. — In the face of the wave of restructuring, Europe responded by providing financial support to the 3,886 Air France employees who have been laid off due to the structural difficulties the airline has faced in recent years. I am pleased that we can offer a more lenient future to all those people who find themselves deprived of employment overnight. With the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, these former employees will be able to benefit from reclassification leave, mobility allowances but also training and career guidance. We cannot talk about a Christmas present, but I hope that these aids can at least, for a time, bring some relief and hope.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I voted against the grant to Air France. I believe that every business grant, every grant, undermines the competitiveness of the market. It laxs people. When LOT Polish airlines failed, the European Commission negatively assessed their request for assistance. Why should we subsidise Air France employees today? In addition, the largest grant of all so far awarded during this term of office. An astronomical amount of around €26 million will be allocated to support Air France. Do the problems of French airlines come from the relocation of production? Well, no. They come from a lack of change. A company cemented by trade unions is unable to compete with other carriers. Too high salaries, lavish politics and a lack of savings in top positions are the reasons for the collapse of this giant. Then there is the disastrous policy of the European Union, which is doing everything it can to beat European companies and industry. EU green rules effectively deter investment in the aviation sector by promoting non-EU airlines. Instead of giving money, let us change the foundations of our industrial and environmental policy.  How are we going to grow when we keep looking back, pulling the socialist zombies of state-owned companies behind us?

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the event of the redundancies of Air France workers, as it will, in large part, be caused by global structural changes affecting air transport, which will have a strong impact on the Ile-de-France region. It is important that, with the help of the EGF, redundance workers are re-entered into the labour market, and that training programmes are launched for this purpose. Reintegration of redundancy workers and services tailored to the needs of affected workers are extremely important in order to avoid a persistent state of unemployment. I believe that active measures and dynamic support are essential to ensure that EGF financial assistance is concretely implemented.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Marco Zanni's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked Air France employees. The Fund will provide a 26 million euro package for 3,886 sacked employees of Air France, which will be used to finance training, consulting services or business start-up bonuses to help beneficiaries reintegrate into the labour market.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I supported the resolution on the european Globalisation Adjustment Fund's request for the mobilization of France's 2013 layoffs at Air France due to strong competition from airlines in the Persian Gulf. The Fund was created to promote the reintegration into the labour market of workers who are victims of changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization or the financial crisis. I the for example, I welcome the adoption of this aid, amounting to more than EUR 25,900,000 and aimed at 3,886 laid-off workers.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Written. — (EES) We generally support the support for redundant employees provided by the EGF. However, we believe that support from the EGF should be given much more to active labour market measures aimed at getting laid-off workers back into work. We do not believe that EU funds should be spent on passive support, but should instead be targeted at employment-enhancing initiatives and projects such as continuing training of redundant employees. That is why we cannot vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we have voted on three other requests for the mobilisation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Mr President, I would like to make it very important that we get the commission to Marco Zanni, in particular, concerns the reintegration into the labour market of 3,886 redundant workers. The application shall be based on the intervention criterion referred to in Article 2(a) of the EGF Regulation, which provides for the redundancy of at least 500 employees of an undertaking over a period of four months in a Member State. These are concrete signals that the European Parliament is sending to workers and companies in difficulty as a result of the economic crisis.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: In writing. — As I had already had the opportunity in the Parliamentary Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I renewed my vote in favour of the Zanni report to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 3,886 former employees of Air France (mainly Roissy site). The EGF will finance 50% (EUR 25,937,813 for a total cost of EUR 51,875,626) projects consisting mainly of the distribution of reclassification leave allowances and the introduction of support in finding a new job, starting a business or starting training. As a reference to the French EPP delegation on this issue, which I have been able to get involved in, I welcome the adoption of this European aid.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of helping those who have been made redundant from Air France. As a result, some 25 million euros will be paid to France under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) aims to support laid-off workers, mainly in disadvantaged regions and sectors by opening up to the globalised economy. It consists of an annual endowment for the retraining and reintegration of workers into work and is a concrete example of the financial solidarity of the European Union. Today, France and former employees of a French company will benefit from this European Fund. A total of 3,889 laid-off Air France employees who, through Training, Retraining and Business Development Assistance Programmes Funded by Europe, will have more assets to quickly re-enter the labour market or create a new business. I would add that some of the people involved in this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund are inhabitants of my Euro-constituency, since three French regions are concerned, including the Ile-de-France.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. — The European Union has a Globalisation Adjustment Fund, EGF, which aims to mitigate the effects of relocations and the crisis. The Fund's request for mobilization concerns former Air France employees who lost their jobs as a result of the "Transform 2015" restructuring plan. For 3,886 former employees, 25 million euros, the largest mobilization of this Fund, are used to finance training, business start-up aid and reclassification leave allowances that go beyond legal obligations. As a member of the Social Affairs Committee, I have to decide on every request from the WEF, including the latter. In this review, I contacted Air France trade unionists to ensure that these funds advanced by Air France were indeed affected by the employees and that they did not allow Air France to evade its social responsibilities. Before I made a statement, I also asked company officials for specific information on the scope of the programmes implemented, the number of people involved and their quality. As this analysis presented the necessary guarantees, I voted in favour of this additional aid.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — The motion for a Resolution refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 25 937 813 from the EGF for France. This application concerns 3 886 redundancies during the reference period, from 1 July to 31 October 2013, and during the subsequent period, but relating to the same collective redundancy procedure. And I agree with your approval.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources after the 5 213 redundancies — with 3 886 people expected to take advantage of the measures — which occurred during the reference period from 1 July to 31 October 2013 due to a decline in the Union's market share in the air transport sector. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in France, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — France's application for mobilisation of the EAGF in favour of Air France's 3 886 dismissed workers was approved by the Commission on 11 November 2014. The decline in market share in the European Union, combined with declining demand and rising oil prices, has economically disrupted the air sector.  Measures aimed at the reintegration of workers amount to a total of EUR 25 937 813 and include, inter alia, occupational advice and guidance, training and contributions for the creation of enterprises. I think it is necessary to vote in favour of mobilizing this fund.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — As a result of the structural changes taking place as a result of the growing trend of globalisation, I supported a report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help workers who have lost their jobs at Air France from France.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis and globalisation. The purpose of this Fund is to assist in the reinsuement of the labour market.  This report aims to mobilise €26 million to advise, educate and encourage employment to help workers return to the labour market.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Zanni report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, because the mobilisation of the fund in this case contributes to the considerable relief of the redundant workers of Air France.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. "I voted for this mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This vote allocates EUR 25,937,813 to Air France, a decision in favour of the interests of workers.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I supported this proposal and welcome the fact that the resolution ʽOpposes the use of the EGF as a way to funding redundancies; advocates that this fund should be used to assist the reintegration of workers into the labour marketʼ.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) I think it is essential and of the utmost importance that measures be taken to assist redundant workers in terms of placement, training and job protection. That is why I supported France's request for financial assistance under the EGF following the redundancy of 5213 workers at Air France, which was made redundant as a result of the contraction of the Union's market share in the air transport sector.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — The expansion of airlines such as Emirates, Qatar and Etihad shows that the centre of gravity of global air traffic has shifted from Europe and North America to the Middle East. Although European airlines continue to play a leading role in the international air transport sector, they are gradually losing market share. My agreement with the report signed by Mr Zanni reflects the conviction that the EGF must be mobilised promptly in favour of the 5213 people made redundant at the airline French, victims of an unstoppable global economic crisis.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I have received my agreement with the use of the EGF by the French Air France. The declining market share of the EU-27 in international air traffic resulted in more than 3800 redundancies in this operation alone. The reintegration of these workers into the labour market is only eligible and should therefore also be co-financed by the EGF.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The Globalization Fund encourages shareholders and states to be irresponsuable into the social irresponsibility of capitalism. The request here concerns the 3,886 licensees of the Air France Roissy site in the Ile-de-France region for a total amount of 25.9 million euros, the largest Fund for Globalization Assistance requested. The report makes no justification for such a redundancy plan, except for a few vague considerations: "According to the French authorities, the growth of the long-haul fleet of three major airlines in the Persian Gulf region was unexpected and spectacular". The solution recommended by the French state is to encourage licensees, mostly over the age of 55, to start their own businesses. What cynicism! I'm voting against this request for a redundancy bonus.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. More and more companies are relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices that are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, It is now appropriate to give this aid to France which submitted the EGF/2013/014 FR/Air France application to a financial contribution from the EGF, following 5213 redundancies, with the participation in the measures of 3886 persons expected during and after the reference period from 1 July 2013 to 31 October 2013, which are expected to be reduced by a decrease in the Union's market share in air transport.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — This report notes that 3 886 workers in France have been made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. The EU market share in air transport has declined. Therefore, I have voted in favour of this report, which will aid affected workers.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. European airlines are severely affected by globalisation. Air France had to lay off 3,886 workers due to intense competition with low-cost carriers, accentuated by higher fuel prices. The Financial Difficulties of the French carrier are directly related to a major change in the structure of world trade. That is why I believe it is necessary to assist the French authorities through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in order to reimburse the schemes already put in place for the reintegration of laid-off workers into the labour market. The European Union is thus keeping its promise to combine economic growth and solidarity by allocating 25 million euros to get the airline out of its uncertain economic environment.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Greece in order to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. France is requesting financial assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to the tune of EUR 25,937,813 to enable the reintegration of 3,886 workers made redundant by Air France. It should be noted that this aid is the largest in terms of amount since the creation of the WEF. The air transport sector in France is going badly and is permanently impacted by the free and undistorted competition and deregulation imposed by Brussels. The European Union's market share in air transport has steadily declined in recent years, due in particular to the growth of three major airlines in the Persian Gulf. These redundancies also affect a region (the Ile-de-France) already affected by the recent closure of PSA's production site in Aulnay in 2014. It is clear that here the European Union is showing total cynicism, since its ultra-liberal and monetary policy has a direct impact on the disastrous economic and social situation we are experiencing. However, I voted in favour of this report so as not to penalise those who have been made redundant further.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as I believe that the application will help to address the below average growth rate in the European air transport sector as well as aid the rapid growth of the Middle East’s air transport sector.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the events that Air France has had to face. Indeed, in 2013, Air France laid off 5,213 employees due to the disruption of the global air market due to the rapid and unexpected growth of long-haul flights to and from the Countries of the Persian Gulf. I fully support the measures taken in this report, following the request of the French authorities to provide rapid assistance to workers, namely: counselling and career guidance, training aids, business start-up aids and reclassification support. Unfortunately, the negative impacts of this dismissal are evident on the one hand within the company, but also at the regional level, in the Ile-de-France, but also in the PACA region, Languedoc-Roussillon, Corsica and the DOM. I fully agree with the proposals made to support this great French company, now and in the long term, as well as to help our European citizens to bounce back in the face of this redundancy.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am voting in favour of The honourable Member's report. Zanni for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the 3,886 workers made redundant by the company French Air France. The economic crisis also affects the air transport sector, despite the fact that there is a good share of the global market still dominated by our European airlines.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this EGF report so as to make sure the workers concerned are given the best possible chance of reintegration into the labour market. However, I do note serious issues concerning the amount requested and the use of the funds. The funds are intended to help with the reintegration of beneficiaries into the labour market instead of providing them with salary replacement after being dismissed and I believe this is not the case with this particular mobilisation. I would like to have seen a much greater percentage of the find going to training, in order to assure a future in the labour market by those affected in this case. It is also the biggest mobilisation of the fund to date, which may have an impact on other mobilisations.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The application concerned the granting of financial aid to Air France, which is headquartered in the Ile-de-France region. This is a region that is currently suffering particularly from global competitive pressure. The mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Air France should be supported as the company concerned meets all the criteria for support.  Of particular note are the French Government's far-reaching plans for the reintegration of the workers concerned, which suggest that the funds approved will be used efficiently. I therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. The case of Air France's application is certainly the largest sum envisaged for the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. However, the 3,886 Air France workers who found themselves unemployed because of increased competition from emerging countries and low-cost airlines with low-cost working conditions deserve Europe's help in finding an alternative.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the european Parliament's motion for a resolution to allocate EUR 25 937 813 from the EGF to France, which will allow the reintegration into the labour market of 3886 people who became unemployed as a result of redundancy in the aviation sector. With the EGF, we can mobilise these people again in the labour market.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: In writing. — I voted for this text: 25 million euros will be released to help the 5,213 licensees of Air France. Non-EU competition directly affects the major European groups and, therefore, their employees. Here I give my full support to this type of issue focused on solidarity and employment among Europeans.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, since the French authorities have applied for the EGF contribution to deal with the redundancies recorded by Air France; that the allocation of these funds is intended to assist workers made redundant as a result of structural changes in world trade; That, as a result of globalisation, the world air traffic sector between Europe and the rest of the world has slowed down growth, I would like to vote in favour of it.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I supported rapporteur Marc Zanni's report. Air traffic recorded a growth of only 2.4% in 2008-2012, leading to negative consequences for Air France. As it faced high levels of debt and under-capitalisation of shares (less than the value of its fleet), it was unable to respond effectively to the loss of market share in international air transport, which eventually led to the elimination of several thousand jobs. France has sought help from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 5,213 of its workers. In 2008-2013 unemployment rose by 38.7% in Ille-de-France, 37.8% in PACA, 47.0% in Midi-Pyrenees and 44.1% in mainland France. I support a proposal by the European Commission and the Council to grant financial assistance to 3,866 redundanheless dismissed Air France employees, amounting to €25.9 million in support. I believe that France needs reforms, which will make it easier to lay off workers in difficult times, but also increase the protection of fixed-term workers, as this is a key element to kickstart the economy and reduce unemployment.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) In the case of the application submitted for air france redundancies, it is also right to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help workers made redundant as a result of the crisis affecting the civil aviation sector. The French authorities claim – and I agree with their analysis – that, although the international air transport market is still dominated globally by European airlines, the sector has suffered a serious economic disruption, with a significant decrease in the EU's market share. The demand relates to a very large number of 5 213 redundancies, of which 3 886 are eligible for assistance. With my vote in favour, I considered it worth helping workers made redundant by Air France who will benefit from measures co-financed by the EGF for reintegration into the labour market through a package of tailor-made services.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — I am in favour of using the Globalization Adjustment Fund to provide financial assistance to 3,886 laid-off workers of Air France to help them retrain or start a business. Solidarity is a fundamental value of our Union, and the Fund is there to demonstrate that.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — France has submitted an application to obtain a financial contribution from the EGF following the dismissal of 5213 workers, of whom 3886 will be beneficiaries, which occurred at Air France during the reference period between 1 July 2013 and 31 October 2013. According to the Commission, this application complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, and it is apparent, on the one hand, that the redundancies in question are related to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, which have resulted in a decrease in the EU's market share in air transport, in particular in the face of the unexpected and spectacular expansion of the long-haul fleet of three major air carriers in the Persian Gulf region; and, on the other hand, that such redundancies will have a negative impact on the Île de France region, already in the face of another collective redundancy as a result of the closure of the Peugeot Citröen Automobiles plant in Aulnay. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of France.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. — The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of France, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project. In addition, the amounts concerned on this occasion were much higher than usual and would not indeed be permitted under the rules pertaining to closures after 31 December 2013.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. — I welcome the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) for Air France. Of course, progress needs to be made in the management of this fund, particularly in terms of its visibility to the public or the monitoring of workers affected by the measures funded. Nevertheless, in these difficult times, I think the WEF is a valuable tool. The amount allocated to Air France, of nearly 26 million euros, will only be used to reimburse "positive" measures of reclassification in the labour market, such as vocational training or project assembly assistance (not home transfers or early retirements). Moreover, it is an example that shows that Europe cares about social issues. Unfortunately, its intervention in this area boils down to giving money, with the Member States remaining the only ones able to enact binding standards. This now leads to many differences within the Union, of which the citizens are tired. The fight for more social convergence must continue.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 25 937 813 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 5 213 workers who have lost their jobs at Air France as a result of structural changes in world trade caused by globalisation. The Union's market share in air transport is in decline, especially in the face of the dramatic increase in the three major airlines in the Persian Gulf region, a trend that has been exacerbated by the global financial and economic crisis. The customized services to be financed from the EGF include training activities, vocational guidance, recycling and incentives for the creation of companies.  While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama faced by thousands of European airline workers, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — Despite the growth in global air traffic between 2008 and 2012, European airlines are experiencing severe economic disruptions with a loss of market share in the face of global competition. In addition, air traffic between Europe and the rest of the world grew slowly (2.4% compared to 4.6% of global air traffic). As a result, Air France-KLM, which is in a difficult financial situation due to high debt and insufficient market capitalization, has made numerous layoffs. To cope with these job losses, France has requested the intervention of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to help the 5,213 workers concerned. Aware of the importance of this EGF intervention for these thousands of workers, I voted in favour of this request from the French authorities.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — As in the cases described in reports Numbers A8-0062, 0063 and 0064 and taking into account that France has submitted a request for financial assistance to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following 5213 redundancies by Air France, relating to a decrease in its market share in the Union, for the reasons explained in the report and which meets the eligibility criteria, I voted in favour of the allocation of this fund, in the amount of 21 580 020, which provides for the reintegration of 3886 workers into the labour market, in accordance with the provisions laid down in Regulation No 1309/2013 in force.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report to provide financial and professional assistance to the 3,886 Air France airline workers who were laid off between 1 July 2013 and 31 October 2013 (the majority of them were based in Roissy). The amount of aid provided by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will be more than 25 million euros and will come through the "Transform 2015" project. The various actions financed will enable support for the reintegration of former employees into the labour market. These actions will take the form of counselling and career guidance, training, business start-up bonuses and reclassification leave allowances. Having always supported the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I voted in favour of this text because Europe must be close to its citizens.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - The delegation of Podemos in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. — (EES) We generally support the support for redundant employees provided by the EGF. However, we believe that support from the EGF should be given much more to active labour market measures aimed at getting laid-off workers back into work. We do not believe that EU funds should be spent on passive support, but should instead be targeted at employment-enhancing initiatives and projects such as continuing training of redundant employees. That is why we cannot vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of resources after the 5 213 redundancies — with 3 886 people expected to take advantage of the measures — which occurred during the reference period from 1 July to 31 October 2013 due to a decline in the Union's market share in the air transport sector. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU. These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in France, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Today I welcomed the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of France to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant. According to data referred to by the French authorities, international air transport has undergone serious economic disruption, in particular a decline of the EU’s market share. Over the period 2008-2012, global traffic increased by 4.6% per year, as part of a trend of long-term growth observed since 1970. However the air traffic between Europe and the rest of the world is growing at a slower pace (2.4%) which has led to a decrease of the EU-27’s market share in air transport. The coordinated package of personalised services, to be co-funded with the EUR 25 937 813 in EGF aid, includes training and guidance measures for the reintegration of 3 886 redundant workers into employment.  The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is tasked with helping and supporting people who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade. The annual budget is €150 million for 2014-2020. The growth of global air traffic between Europe and the rest of the world has its limits, and lately it has been stagnating. Air traffic declines between the EU and four other continents (North America, South America, Africa and Asia) ranged from 0.3% to 2.8%, while air traffic between the EU and the Middle East fell by 11.4%. This data has shaken national economies, and especially in this case the French airline Air France. Following the assessment of the application, the European Commission concluded that the conditions for granting financial support from the EGF had been met, and proposed €25,900,000 assistance to France for Air France workers. This is a measure to combat unemployment, deepen the crisis and protect workers, and therefore I support this report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I welcome the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as it aims to provide support, i.e. to help people who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade, which is what has happened in this case. Given the market turbulentness, a budget of €150 million for 2014-2020 may not be enough, but it instills some certainty for workers across the EU.  I also think that the drop in air travel between the EU and the four continents (North America, South America, Africa and Asia) from 0.3 per cent to 2.8 per cent, as well as the 11.4 per cent drop in air travel between the EU and the Middle East is certainly not the workers' fault, but the responsibility lies with management. Because of all this, I voted for a Proposal from the European Commission to provide assistance to France with €25,900,000 for Air France workers that will make it easier for jobless workers to find a new job.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing — I did not support the proposal because I believe it to be counterproductive. The proposal foresees a contribution of up to EUR 25.94 million for 3 886 dismisses. This represents a heavy burden on the EU budget, which is financed by taxes on employees and firms of all the countries of the European Union, which will reduce the competitiveness of the rest of the EU.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. — The ECR Group fully supports measures that put in place policies that create growth and jobs. However, we do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for putting in place such policies nor do we believe it is an efficient tool that offers value for money for EU taxpayers, therefore I voted against.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The money from the adjustment fund should basically be given to the dismissed persons and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, or more often known as the WEF, was set up to provide support to workers who are becoming victims of restructuring and global trade. The aim is therefore to train, or help to rebound, those working citizens who have committed no fault except that of living in a time when human character often seems less important than the search for profits for certain investors or speculators. The fund we are voting on is therefore intended to be a second chance.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for all four requests for financial assistance submitted by France, Italy, Poland and Greece in order to support workers in companies affected by the negative impact of global competition and the crisis. In particular, the Zanni report concerns the mobilisation of more than EUR 25 million to support the reintegration into working life of almost 4000 Air France redundancies. In recent years, the company French has suffered the repercussions of the drastic contraction in the air transport sector within the EU, due to the rapid advance of Persian Gulf companies in an unfavourable context of financial crisis and economic recession. This is the largest financial contribution to date through the EGF to support the implementation of counselling and guidance services, retraining courses, business contributions and mobility allowances. I therefore felt it was important to support this decision, which alleviates the serious employment emergency in which the Ile-de-France region in particular is located, where Air France's redundancies are concentrated, aggravated by the closure of the Peugeot Citroën car plant.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — The European Parliament has overwhelmingly adopted Marco Zanni's report calling for the mobilisation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of 25.9 million euros (a record since the launch of this Fund!) concerning 3,886 employees who have been made redundant at Air France. A majority of these employees are between the age of 55 and 64 and will therefore have great difficulty finding a job. These layoffs are part of a massive social plan (more than 8,000 job cuts by 2015, or 10% of the airline's workforce), even as both European and global air traffic is on the rise (3.8% in Europe in 2013) and 38% of global air traffic is in Europe. I have always considered that large companies can (should) find ways to finance their redundancy plans other than by using public funds and even more so european funds which, in this case, only "accompany" social plans without any added value and therefore endorse these social plans and their job-destroying logic, especially since it is above all, in this case, in this case , to encourage the creation of businesses and thus finally to leave the sacked employees to fend for themselves. So I once again refused this logic by voting against it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — France submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 5,213 redundancies, with the participation in measures of 3,886 persons expected during and after the reference period from 1 July 2013 to 31 October 2013, such redundancies related to a decrease in the Union's market share in air transport. According to information that came to us from the trade union movement, the participation of workers' representatives in this process was not properly taken care of. We note that the majority of redundant workers are between the ages of 55 and 64. We reaffirm that the EGF cannot be used as a means of financing redundancies. We are voting against it as a matter of principle in relation to this fund which represents only a mere palliative in the face of the effects of neoliberal drift, but also because we believe that there is a risk of misuse of the EGF here.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — (DE) I voted in favour of the request for the European Globalisation Fund to be mobilised by the French airline Air France, because there have been simply tragic events in the same company in recent times. The re-employment and integration of the 3800 employees referred to in the report must be promoted by all the means available to the EU. The mobilisation of the Globalisation Fund is intended to ensure this.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — France submitted on 20 December 2013 the application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 5213 redundancies in AIR FRANCE, of which it will benefit only 3 886 people. Of these workers, 68.94% are aged between 55 and 64 years and 31.03% are aged between 25 and 54 years.  The justification for this dismissal lies in important structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. The consequences of this dismissal had a negative impact on the Île de France region, which has already faced the closure and collective redundancy of another major company - Peugeot Citroen Automobiles. The mobilised amount of EUR 25 937 813 corresponds to 70 % of the worker's last gross salary. The measures recommended for the reintegration of 3886 redundant workers undergo training, advice services for workers, contribution to the creation of businesses, retraining allowance, mobility allowance.  According to information that came to us from the trade union movement, the participation of workers' representatives in this process was not properly taken care of. We reaffirm that the EGF cannot be used as a way of financing redundancies and we voted against it because we cannot support that possibility.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted against the appointment of the members of the Single Resolution Board since among the proposed ones is Antojo Carrascosa, who was Director General of the FROB in the Spanish State appointed by the Minister of the People's Party, Mr. De Guindos, and who measured in the Bankia crisis. There is no way I will endorse Mr Carrascosa's appointment after seeing the disastrous management in the Bankia case.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — This vote was taken by secret ballot. In the interests of transparency, I believe that my constituents have a right to know how I voted and therefore I wish to clarify that my vote was against.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to appoint the Chairperson, Vice-Chair and Members of the Single Resolution Board responsible for the functioning of the Single Bank Resolution Mechanism. This mechanism will complement the Single Supervisory Mechanism, which, at the end of 2014, will be directly supervised by the European Central Bank in the euro area and in other Member States that decide to join the Banking Union. The Single Resolution Mechanism would ensure that if, despite the tighter supervision, the bank covered by the SSM faced significant difficulties, it could be effectively restructured at the lowest cost to taxpayers and the real economy. The members of the Board shall be appointed on the basis of merit, skills, knowledge of banking and financial affairs and experience in financial supervision, regulation and bank resolution. I support the proposal to appoint candidates proposed by the Commission.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the candidates presented to the Office of the Single Resolution Mechanism (MRU). The MRU was initiated following the banking and liberal crisis that began in 2008. In cases where a bank is expected to fail despite the enhanced supervision put in place through the single supervisory mechanism, the MRU will enable more effective management through a single Resolution Board and a single resolution fund funded by the banking sector. The aim is to ensure an orderly resolution of failing banks by minimizing the burden that could fall on taxpayers and the real economy.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The SRB is the cornerstone of the single resolution mechanism, which will soon be tasked with implementing the dismantling of banks in distress. This institution will be able to rely on a series of instruments, including a resolution fund being set up and new rules on the hierarchy of creditors in the event of bankruptcy. The Single Resolution Council (SRB) is the cornerstone of the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM) which will soon be tasked with setting up the dismantling of "banks in distress" using various instruments, including the Single Resolution Fund powered by banks. The MRU will apply to banks covered by the MSU, which makes the European Central Bank (ECB) the central prudential supervisor of euro area banking institutions (approximately 6,000 banks). The MRU will respond in cases where a bank is expected to fail despite its enhanced oversight. It will be based on a six-member Council, which we must approve here.  Aware of the need to prevent the failure of banks, we remain opposed to the loss of sovereignty of The Member States through these mechanisms, which is why I voted against this report and these appointments.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the list of six candidates proposed by the European Commission to lead the new European Resolution Mechanism, a body responsible for bailing out banks that go bankrupt or need money to get afloat. It will now be up to the Council to ratify appointments by qualified majority, so that board members can take office on 1 January 2015. Taking into account the importance of the Single Resolution Board within the process of building the banking union and as an authority that must ensure the orderly liquidation of the banks in difficulty, I would like to express my reservations to the incorporation of Antonio Carrascosa to this Board of Spain for his previous management in relation to the Bankia crisis.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted on this report because it supported the appointment of the members of the Single Resolution Board. The Single Resolution Board is part of the European Banking Union. The European Banking Union is a unified banking supervision mechanism to improve the credibility and security of the financial sector. It was designed to improve the regulation, supervision and governance of the financial sector so that taxpayers do not have to pay for bank mistakes in the future. Most of the rules of the Banking Union have already entered into force or are being finalising.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for these members for the resolution board because I think they have the competence and the qualifications to do the best work in this new Single Resolution Board.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The SRB is the cornerstone of the Single Resolution Mechanism, which will soon be tasked with implementing the dismantling of banks in distress. This institution will be able to rely on a series of instruments, including a Resolution Fund being set up and new rules on the hierarchy of creditors in the event of bankruptcy. The SRB is the cornerstone of the Single Resolution Mechanism, which will soon be tasked with implementing the dismantling of banks in distress. This institution will be able to rely on a series of instruments, including a Resolution Fund being set up and new rules on the hierarchy of creditors in the event of bankruptcy. The Single Resolution Council (SRB) is the cornerstone of the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM) which will soon be tasked with setting up the dismantling of "banks in distress" using various instruments, including the Single Resolution Fund powered by banks. The MRU will apply to banks covered by the MSU, which makes the European Central Bank (ECB) the central prudential supervisor of euro area banking institutions (approximately 6,000 banks). The MRU will react in cases where a bank should fail despite ... (Shortened voting explanation under section 170 of the regulation)

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — The consultation procedure asks Parliament to give an opinion on the appointments proposed by the European Commission on the Management Board of the Single Resolution Committee. Although it does not go into the merits of the candidates' competences, it is noted that the President is German and the Deputy Finnish. The Committee is defined by Regulation (EU) No 806/2014 laying down uniform rules and procedures for the resolution of credit institutions and certain investment firms. It acts to regulate the so-called "single resolution mechanism" introduced by Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 establishing the European Supervisory Authority (European Banking Authority). I voted against.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — Following the hearings held at the ECON Commission, on Monday 15 December, the adoption of a report prepared by the Italian socialist Roberto Gualtieri, in favour of the appointment of various members* of the Single Resolution Board, the body of the Single Resolution Mechanism, is voted on in that committee. No group objected to Gualtieri's report, so it is expected to be adopted smoothly in both committee and plenary. * (a) Elke Konig, as Chairman of The Board (b) Timo Luyttyniemi, as Vice-Chairman of the Board (c) Mauro Grande, as a member of the Board d) Antonio Carrascosa, as a member of the Board e) Joanne Kellermann, as a member of the Board f) Dominique Laboureix, as a member of the Board.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: in writing. — I did not vote in favour of the appointment of the members of the European banking supervision body because of mr Carrascosa's presence there. This gentleman, in my view, has focused his professional career in the world of bank bailouts in Spain with strategies which have not taken into account at all the recovery by citizens (taxpayers) of the large sums supplied to bank consolidation, so he may not be the right person to protect European taxpayers.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the candidates who are members of the Single Crisis Resolution Committee. It is an independent body, responsible for initiating and then managing bank crisis resolution procedures, including through the use of single resolution fund resources capable of financing the bank's operations in the medium term during the resolution phase. The innovative profile of this body is that the composition of its executive body does not directly reflect mechanisms of intergovernmental compromise, drawing instead on the more purely managerial logics that had never been applied, or at least stated, at European Union level with the same vigour: the President and the other four members, in fact, are appointed on the basis of the , skills, knowledge of banking and financial matters, as well as experience in financial supervision and regulation and banking resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) The setting up of a crisis resolution committee is an act due to those who have sacrificed so much because of austerity policies. The Troika's resolution of banking crises has not been transparent, so we support the appointment of the Single Committee because it centralises decision-making power and makes it possible to identify those responsible if the solutions adopted do more harm than good.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) My colleagues in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs have examined the candidates and considered them fit for the tasks assigned to them. I too have seen the documents and shared their conclusions: I have given them confidence at the moment by voting in favour; But I am ready to flea their work, so that they act in the interests of Europe and, above all, of European businesses and citizens who need to emerge from this crisis.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal on the appointment of six members of the Single Resolution Board, the independent authority responsible for managing the resolution of failing banks. This Committee, which together with the national authorities, has the centralised resolution power for the Member States, plays a very important role in the correct, effective and coherent functioning of the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM).  As provided for in Regulation (EU) No 806/2014, and especially in relation to the high tasks to be carried out, members are appointed on the basis of merit, expertise, knowledge in banking and finance, as well as experience in financial supervision/regulation and resolution of institutions. Having therefore checked parliament for these requirements, I welcome the appointment of these members, which will make the Committee operational and ready to work without delay in the interests of the European market.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The Single Resolution Board is the European Resolution Authority for banking, which is very important as being the second pillar of Banking Union. The proposed candidates were chosen through an open selection procedure on the basis of skills and knowledge of banking and financial matters and other relevant experiences. The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs proceeded to evaluate the credentials of the proposed candidates and held a hearing where the candidates responded to questions from the members. I decided to give my approval of the Commission's proposal for each of them, so I voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted against the appointment of the members of the Single Resolution Board since among those proposed is Antonio Carrascosa, who was director general of the FROB in the Spanish State, appointed by the Minister of the People's Party, Mr. de Guindos, and who measured in the Bankia crisis. There is no way I will endorse Mr Carrascosa's appointment after seeing the disastrous management in the Bankia case.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — The Single Resolution Board has the important role of restructuring the failing banks. The candidates for the board’s members have been shortlisted by the Commission at the beginning of this month, following several in-camera hearings, and finally last week the European Parliament also held public hearings with the candidates nominated. I think that the persons nominated are fit for the job at hand. Therefore, I supported them with my vote in the Plenary today.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — The Single Resolution Board (SRB) will be responsible for preparing plans for the "orderly bankruptcy" of banks in difficulty, after the ECB, which is responsible for supervision, signals the danger of default. After the successful hearings of the candidates in recent weeks in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON), I have decided to approve the appointments of the six members of the single bank resolution authority.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. Refusing the Single Resolution Mechanism and its banking union, which are a matter of financial socialism and do not seem to be able to respond to the shortcomings of the banking system in Europe, I objected to the appointment of the candidates appointed to the Single Resolution Council in the interests of coherence and with the firm conviction that this Council has neither the means nor the legitimacy to hold office.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the candidates for the Single Resolution Council, as I do not consider their experience satisfactory for the proposed positions.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament held a hearing of the candidates proposed to serve as members of the Single Resolution Board. All five candidates made opening statements and then answered questions from committee members. We have nothing to say about the people themselves as well as about their curriculum vitae. The question here is in principle and has to do with our rejection of the entire banking union building and the purposes it serves. An undemocratic process that strengthens the immense power of the European Central Bank, an entity that is not democratically scrutinised and entirely dependent on and subordinated to the interests of large financial capital and major powers; which removes sovereignty from Member States in an area of capital importance, impoverishing and disfiguring democracy. For these reasons, we abstained in this vote.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — Parliament is asked to give an opinion on the appointments proposed by the European Commission on the Management Board of the Single Resolution Committee. My vote will be against because I believe that this financial and banking system must be completely reformed. The Committee will act to regulate the so-called "single resolution mechanism" introduced by Regulation 1093 of 2010 establishing the European Supervisory Authority (Banking).

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am against the appointment of the new members of the Single Resolution Board, because I believe it will force the Member States participating in the Banking Union to carry out the resolution plan with more measures to the detriment of the citizens.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution on the Commission's proposal for the appointment of presidents, vice-presidents and members of the Steering Board of the SRB on the grounds that they were appointed on the basis of their own capabilities, merits and skills. I believe that the qualifications of candidates are positively satisfactory and have proven their experience in financial supervision, and that the principles of qualification and experience were respected in their choice.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Roberto Gualteri as I agree with the appointment of the following candidates as members of the same Committee. Elke Konig for the role of Chairman of the Committee, Timo Loyttyniemi for the role of Vice President, Mauro Grande, Antonio Carrascosa, Joanne Kellermann and Dominique Laboureix for the functions of members of the Committee. The Single Resolution Committee is responsible for overseeing banks in the eurozone and in all Member States that decide to join the Banking Union.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — Following the hearings held in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, the committee recently voted on the adoption of a report in favour of the appointment of the following citizens to various posts of the Single Resolution Board, body of the Single Resolution Mechanism: a) Elke Konig as Chairman of Board (b) Timo Luyttyniemi as Vice-Chairman of the Board (c) Mauro Grande as a member of the Board d) Antonio Carrascosa as a member of the Board e) Joanne Kellermann, as a member of Board f) Dominique Laboureix, as a member of the Board. My political group and myself agree with these appointments.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted against the appointment of the members of the Single Resolution Board since among those proposed is Antonio Carrascosa, who was director General of the FROB in the Spanish State, appointed by the Minister of the People's Party, Mr. De Guindos, and who measured in the Bankia crisis. There is no way I will endorse Mr Carrascosa's appointment after seeing the disastrous management in the Bankia case.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. — The proposed members of the Board are, without exception, regarded by me as experienced, well-qualified professionals. However, I voted against the appointment as I fundamentally reject the SRM as part of the Banking Union.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — I support the appointment of Elka König, Tim Löyttyniemi, Mauro Grande, Antonio Carrascose, Joanna Kellermann and Dominique Laboureix as members of the SRB, as they have proven to be good candidates through quality answers to the questions asked and good introductory presentations at the committee hearings.  The SRB will oversee the liquidation or restructuring of failing banks, which should spare EU countries' budgets the cost of their resolution and restore confidence in the eurozone. Its headquarters will be in Brussels, starting on 1 January 2015 and not fully a year later. The Committee will work with the European Single Supervisor for Banks at the European Central Bank (ECB).

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting against the Gualtieri report on the appointment of a member of the Single Resolution Board, as I do not agree with key points in this report.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I supported this resolution believing that all the candidates are suitably qualified for the postion they are to fill.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) After the vote in the ECON Committee on Monday and the hearings last week, we voted today on the appointment of the Chairman and Vice-Presidents of the new Single Resolution Mechanism. As announced, the Resolution Mechanism completes all the reforms of the new single European supervisory system after the entry into force last month of the Single Supervisory Mechanism. With the entry into force of the Resolution Mechanism, since 2015 a bank that is in serious difficulty would be helped in managing its crisis so as not to harm savers and the real economy, sequentially to the use of the Resolution Fund for banks in difficulty.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. — The members of the Single Resolution Council will have the overwhelming responsibility to decide, during a banking crisis, whether or not to trigger the resolution mechanism provided for in the second pillar of the Banking Union. They will be able to decide on the bankruptcy of a bank, its break-up into several entities, and decide to put in place the mechanism that can go so far as to dispossess savers of their savings to pay for the faults of the banks. The personalities presented to sit are from the world of banking supervision, which has so far failed to prevent and predict risks. Although the French candidate was precise and rather convincing in his answers, the single list vote forces a negative opinion on this subject.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — The Single Crisis Resolution Committee for the Banking Union is responsible for monitoring banks in the euro area and in other Member States that decide to join the Banking Union. I voted in favour of the Gualtieri report, agreeing with the appointment of the following candidates as members of the report: Elke König, for the functions of chairman of the committee; Timo Löyttyniemi, for the duties of Vice-Chairman of the Committee; Mauro Grande, for the functions of member of the Committee; Antonio Carrascosa, for the duties of member of the Committee; Joanne Kellermann, for the duties of a member of the Committee and Dominique Laboureix, for the duties of a member of the Committee.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — (DE) The commission's proposal on the composition of the Single Resolution Committee did not receive my approval and was not rejected. Mrs Elke König, as chair of this committee, will act to the best of her ability and will incorporate all her experience so far into the work of the committee, but unfortunately I can only reject the body itself.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM), which will come into force on 1 January 2015, is expected to allow for the recovery or reorganization of banks that are likely to fail. In this context, the Single Resolution Council (CRU) is responsible for putting in place a plan for the recovery of the institution either by internal recapitalisation or by external capital inflow from the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) or from the States or the ECB. Thus the troika was established as the supreme saviour of the European banking sector. Candidates to enter the CRU have the profile of the job: for example, the German Elke Konig, who is aiming for the presidency, is currently director of the German Financial Markets Authority, the Finn Timo Layttyniemi is director of pension funds, the Dutch Joanne Kellermann is president of the Central Bank of the Netherlands... This mechanism will not change the speculative practices that feed crises: it prepares to treat the effects of the next with those who usually produce them. I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The Commission presented at the beginning of December this year a proposal for the appointment of the President, vice-president and members of the Single Resolution Board. The various nominees submitted their CVs and were heard at a hearing, receiving the Commission's assent in relation to their benefits. I therefore wish the nominees all due to the nominees in the performance of their duties.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The nominees are well-qualified people, but I am very sceptical about the body: I too think it is appropriate to monitor the financial market, which is the focus of the panel, among other things. However, this cannot in principle be at the expense of the competences of the Member States and national autonomy. Because of this contradiction, I abstained.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal to appoint the Chairman, Vice-Chair and Members of the Single Resolution Board. Elke König, a candidate for Chairman of the Board of Parliament, has answered questions in depth in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament and has been given approval. I believe that these are suitable candidates.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — In line with the group's position, I intend to vote in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — The task of the SRB (JSO) is essential for the successful operation of the Single Resolution Mechanism. It is the responsibility of future JSO leaders, together with the European Central Bank, which plays the role of single supervisor, to provide security to the European banking system. Since the summer of this year, intensive work has been done to find a candidate to lead the JSO and I believe that the selection criteria for the president, vice-presidents and members of the JSO Board of Directors have been carefully selected in the process, and that the candidates selected in the process fully satisfy them. I have confidence in the assessment of the Parliamentary Committee on Economic and Monetary Policy, which, taking into account Article 56 of the 4. Regulations (EU) No 100/2013 806/2014, positively evaluated the candidates proposed, and I hereby give them my support.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) On the basis of the assessments made by the committee responsible (and the final vote, with a very large majority in favour), thanks in part to the introductory statement made by the candidates and the hearings held, I voted in favour of the resolution, certain that the choices made are the most valid for the proper functioning of the Single Resolution Committee.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The successive crises that the European Union has gone through have demonstrated the need for a bank supervision system adapted to the specifics of the euro. I therefore vote in favour of the appointment of this Single Resolution Council in order to enable it to understand as soon as possible the important mission entrusted to it.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution approving the appointment of the President, vice-president and members of the Single Resolution Board, the proposed candidates, therefore regard, following the assessment carried out by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, that, from the point of view of merit, competence, knowledge and experience, the proposed candidates meet the conditions for the performance of those tasks in accordance with Article 56(4) of Regulation (EU) No 806/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council of 15 July 2014.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. — This vote was taken by secret ballot.  I believe that my constituents have a right to know how I voted on this issue, and therefore I wish to confirm for the record that my vote was against.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the list of six candidates proposed by the European Commission to lead the new Single Resolution Mechanism, a body responsible for bailing out banks that go bankrupt or need money to get afloat. It will now be up to the European Council to ratify appointments by qualified majority, so that they can take office on 1 January 2015. Taking into account the importance of the Single Resolution Board within the process of building the banking union and as an authority that must ensure the orderly liquidation of the banks in difficulty, I do not want to fail to express my reservations to the incorporation into this Board of Spain Antonio Carrascosa for his previous management in relation to the Bankia crisis.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion but would like to condition it with the following observations.  A banking union should serve to create transparency of operations across banks in the Union while shielding national governments from the burden of bailouts should their big banks collapse. Theoretically, all banks would need to be treated equally, subject to the particular conditions of their national economic environment. However, the Resolution Authority will inevitably be coloured by political considerations of a multilateral nature, as is happening now in the European Central Bank.  Quite likely, the political dynamics of the Resolution Authority will hardly be different from those of the Eurogroup when, say, the latter was dealing with Southern European countries. Not all banks will be equal. Least able to counter such considerations will be the banking systems of medium to small Member States, especially in economies where financial services have become a significant sector. We need to ensure that smaller banks within the smaller economies do not become more risk-averse by inhibiting their exposure to financial services in their national economy, and more importantly when lending to SMEs, while becoming less competitive.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Today I voted to approve the Commission’s proposal for the appointment of the Chair, Vice-Chair and Members of the Board of the Single Resolution Board.  Parliament’s Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs evaluated the credentials of the proposed candidates for the functions of Chair, Vice-Chair and Members of the Board. All six proposed candidates made an opening statement at a hearing organised by Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and then responded to questions from the members of the Committee

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted against the appointment of the members of the Single Resolution Board since among those proposed is Antonio Carrascosa, who was director general of the FROB in the Spanish State, appointed by the Minister of the People's Party, Mr. de Guindos, and who measured in the Bankia crisis. There is no way I will endorse Mr Carrascosa's appointment after seeing the disastrous management in the Bankia case.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I support the appointment of these members because they have shown themselves to be quality candidates at the hearings before the Committee not only with their experience but also with quality answers to the questions asked and good introductory presentations, and I believe that they will carry out their work with quality and responsibility.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I supported this Commission proposal on the appointment of presidents, vice-presidents and members of the Board of Directors of the SRB, as the SRB oversees the European Central Bank as well as all banks wishing to join the Banking Union.  I believe that such a body is necessary in the financial market, because unfortunately in recent years it has proved that supervision of financial institutions is necessary so that the financial sector of the Union does not get into trouble again. If financial difficulties occur, the resolution board will react, with minimal costs for taxpayers, with the aim of solving the problem.
