The chairwoman of the committee is Elke Konig, who in recent years has been president of federal financial supervision, which instills hope that all other candidates who presented themselves at the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee can adequately respond with new and demanding roles, which is confirmed by the positive opinion of the board members.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the appointment of the President, Vice-President and members of the Single Resolution Board and the fact that the new body could soon start its work. This body and the single resolution mechanism and the associated financing mechanism are an important building block for the establishment of the Banking Union. The purpose of establishing a single bank resolution mechanism is to minimise the cost to taxpayers and budgets of a possible bank bankruptcy or the recovery or liquidation of a financial institution. This goal must be supported. This key expert and independent body will facilitate the functioning of this mechanism.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the proposal. The purpose here was to determine the appointment of the Chair, Vice-President and Members of the Single Resolution Council.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — I support the appointment of the new members to the SRB as, generally, I consider that they are very capable to act with the European interest at heart and will enforce the new bail-in rules in a way that favours European citizens in a context where just bailing out banks with taxpayers’ money is no longer acceptable.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - The process of appointing the members of the Single Resolution Committee has been opaque from the outset. The European Parliament has been kept in the dark about the names proposed by the Commission. In addition, MEPs would have to submit written requests for access to information about the proposed persons. The hearings were mostly held behind closed doors. The proposed personalities also came from the rigorist countries of Northern Europe and had in the past had links with the banking sector. This raised serious doubts about the committee's independence and its specific competences. During the hearings, the proposed members gave vague and insensitid answers, showing a superficial knowledge of the banking crisis resolution system. That is why I expressed my disappointment by voting against the report on the appointment of the Single Committee for the Resolution of Banking Crises.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The Commission held a hearing of the candidates proposed to serve as members of the SRB, and all five candidates made opening statements and then answered questions from the Members of the Commission. We have nothing to say about the people themselves. We abstain because we want to make a point of being on the sidelines of this whole undemocratic process which strengthens the immense power of the Central Bank and impoverishes EU democracy.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — (DE) I supported the composition of the Committee on Uniform Resolution on the part of the Commission and I believe that Mrs Elke König is the right person for the Presidency, as she also has the appropriate experience.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The European Commission has listened to the candidates proposed for the functions of members of the SRB.  We have nothing to say about the people themselves as well as about their resume. We abstain because we are keen to stand on the sidelines of this whole undemocratic process which strengthens the immense power of the ECB, impoverishes EU democracy and does not contribute to an effective recovery of the economy.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We have received shocking news from Pakistan this morning. At one school, more than 120 people, including more than 100 children, were killed in cold blood by the Taliban. There are more people in the violence of these terrorists. This heinous and cowardly crime makes us stunned and speechless and shows once again the inhumanity with which the Taliban are acting, their inhumane ideology, their relentless fanaticism. What is certainly particularly shocking to us is that they do not stop at the murder of children. Our sympathies are with the victims, their families and their friends at this time. We express our solidarity with the Pakistani nation. On behalf of the European Parliament, I express our full sympathy to all the families of the victims. We wish the injured a speedy and complete recovery. I believe I am speaking on behalf of all of you when I express our deep disgust not only with the crime itself, but also with the spirit of the criminals here.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the Commission Work Programme for 2015 (2014/2829(RSP)).

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: President der Kommission. - Herr President! Nach den von Ihnen zu Recht verurteilten Vorgungen heute Morgen in Pakistan fellt es schwer, yesterday in ruhigem Ton 'ber das Arbeitsprogramm der Europ-ischen Kommission zu reden.  Es follt mir aber nicht schwer, Ihnen im Namen der Kommission sehr herzlich zur Verleihung des Aachener Karlspreises zu gratulieren. Ich bin ja selbst Karlspreistr-ger - und zwar ein doppelter. Einmal hat das luxemburgische Volk 1986 den Karlspreis als Volk erhalten, zu dem Volk geh-re ich nach wie, vor und ich hatte die Ehre, ihn selbst im Jahre 2006 in Empfang zu nehmen. Die Reihe der Karlspreistr-ger wird durch Ihre Bestellung noch beeindruckender, Herr President. (Beifall) With regard to the work programme of the new Commission, let me say, Mr President, that I had the impression during the election campaign, in which you were my rival but nevertheless a friend, like Guy Verhofstadt and others, that European citizens wanted to see a new beginning in Europe. At least that's the impression I got after visiting some 20 countries and thirty-three European cities. I have fallen in love with Europe again, because there are few times when, in such a short period of time, you can discover so many sensibilities, see so many colors, meet so many men and women. We agreed, during the process of setting up the new Commission, that it should focus on the essentials, on the major subjects, defined by the guidelines that I had the honour of developing before you on 15 July and at the end of October. I think we agreed that any problem that exists in Europe is not necessarily a problem for the European Union or the Commission. Indeed, many of us thought that the principle of subsidiarity should be rehabilitated and the task of solving this problem should be given to the levels of power - namely Member States, regions or local authorities - which are best able to respond to the problems in Europe. On the basis of these principles, in accordance with the Commission's guidelines, we have examined 452 legislative initiatives that are currently under consideration and which are being debated. We have done so with the main priorities that must be those of the European Union in mind. The top priority, the one that is not in doubt, is based on the elements of growth and employment. That is why, some three weeks after its installation, the Commission has proposed an ambitious investment plan that will occupy not only the minds, but also our meetings over the next six months, and I would be grateful to the European Parliament for working closely, courageously and with a concern for the work well done, in the consideration of these texts. Mr President, we wanted to limit the number of new initiatives we are going to undertake and launch. There was a time when the Commission announced 130 new initiatives a year. We are announcing twenty-three new initiatives for 2015; we are presenting the work programme for 2015 and not the work programme that will cover the duration of the legislature. We limit the number of new initiatives by applying the often disputed principle of discontinuity: we will withdraw, amend or amend eighty-three texts that are on the legislative table. New initiatives, in addition to the important investment program, include all those related to taxation. I repeat in this regard that the Commission will present in the first six months a directive on the automatic exchange of advance decisions, namely tax rulings - as they say in bad French. In addition, the Commission will present an action programme for the fight against tax evasion and evasion by establishing in principle the fact that the country where the profit is made must become the place of taxation. (Applause) This will happen and I would like to say very amicably that I am sensitive to the fact that, day after day, I am invited to do what I said. I said it and it will be done in 2015. Frans Timmermans, whom I congratulate on the zeal with which he coordinated the Commission's work on its work programme, met with each of the Commissioners separately. He prepared this programme with the Council of Ministers and the European Parliament. He has - I must say this - merit and since he is the one who deserves the work done, I will leave it with your agreement, Mr President, to the first Vice-President to set out the Commission's work programme and priorities. (Applause)

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission - Mr President, let me briefly add my congratulations to those of President Juncker. The Charlemagne Prize is something that is very close to you and me because we are from the region. Aachen is the pivotal city in the region we are from, and the origins of the Charlemagne Prize are so intimately linked with the idea of healing the wounds after the Second World War that to be honoured with the Charlemagne Prize is one of the highest distinctions any European can receive. I want to congratulate you on that.  Through you, Mr President, I want to thank this House for the elaborate cooperation in preparing the Commission work programme for 2015. As President Juncker has just said, we want it to be focused on priorities for 2015, and we want it to be about 2015 – not about 2016 or 2017, etc. Of course, the Commission will also have priorities in the years after 2015, but these will be in the work programmes for the years to come.  This Commission wants to deliver change in terms of the way we work, but we can only do that in close cooperation with your Parliament and with Council. Therefore, when today we present the Commission work programme it is also an invitation to the European Parliament to use it as a platform for discussion between our two institutions, and then also to bring the third institution in legislation into the fold when they also have to play their role, namely the Council. As President Juncker said, we have 23 new measures on our list. We are breaking with the practice of listing everything for fear of being incomplete, and we are only putting forward the things we will actually do in 2015. No more, no less. This does not mean that preparatory work will not start for future initiatives to implement the political guidelines to be presented in 2016 and 2017, like the multiannual financial framework mid-term review. Of course it will, and Parliament will be kept closely informed.  Our first priority, as the President has already said, is to deliver on the investment plan for Europe. We showed we can act quickly by presenting our strategy within the first month of the mandate. Now we need to implement and deliver to unlock public and private investments in the real economy of at least EUR 315 billion over the next three years.  We will table an ambitious digital single market package to create the conditions for a vibrant digital economy and society. This will be done by complementing the telecommunications regulatory environment, modernising copyright rules, simplifying rules for consumers making online and digital purchases, enhancing cyber-security, and mainstreaming digitalisation.  We will take steps towards a European Energy Union. It has never been so vital to ensure energy supply security, integrate national energy markets, reduce energy demand in Europe, and promote green technology.  Deepening economic and monetary union is important for the stability of the Eurozone, and, together with our plans to create a capital union, will attract investors to Europe. In parallel, we will invest in reinvigorating the social dialogue at all levels. We want to promote fairness and opportunity in our societies. We will look at new ways to support Member States in getting people, especially the younger and long-term unemployed, into the workplace and making sure they have the skills they need to stay there. We will present a package of measures to promote labour mobility while supporting Member States’ efforts to ensure that benefits are not abused.  A fairer approach to taxation is something citizens rightly feel very strongly about. Our aim should be that companies’ profits are taxed in the place they are made, including in the digital economy. We will bring forward an action plan to that end alongside proposals on transparency of tax rulings and relaunching work on the common consolidated corporate tax base. We will develop a holistic and balanced European agenda on migration. Citizens expect us to improve the management of migration into Europe while keeping it an attractive destination for talent. We will strengthen our better regulation agenda and follow up our commitment for democratic change. We have already started with important improvements in the transparency of our meetings with interested representatives, and I am looking forward to a debate with Parliament on how we move this agenda forward. We have looked at what we are planning with a critical eye. Will this initiative contribute to jobs and growth? Will it add value beyond what Member States are able to do? Will it be effective in changing things on the ground without adding unnecessary burdens? All the initiatives we are taking are well within the ten priorities President Juncker agreed with your Parliament upon his election. We have also asked the same question: ‘is it is necessary and useful?’ of the 400 or so pending proposals that are already on the table, applying the principle of political discontinuity that is set out in the framework agreement between our two institutions. It is very often set out as a principle but, in practical terms, it is very often difficult to actually apply it, as I have discovered in the last couple of weeks. At the start of the new legislative cycle, it is time to clear the decks so that time and energy can be invested in those proposals that will have the biggest impact on jobs and growth and which have a good prospect of being adopted in the near future. So we have looked through every pending proposal across all sectors and decided whether we want to maintain, amend or withdraw them. We want results on the ground so, where it is clear existing proposals would be not be agreed in a way that meets our objectives, we will propose alternative, more effective, approaches. That is the case with the Energy Tax Directive, which we propose to withdraw because the Council has watered it down so that it no longer meets our environmental objectives of taxing fuel in a way that reflects real energy content and CO2 emissions. We are also proposing to withdraw the existing proposal on the circular economy to make way for a broader and more ambitious approach that can be more effective… (Interjection from the floor: ‘Shame!’) Let me finish and then you can still cry ‘shame’, but perhaps it will not be necessary. What we want to do is actually to make sure that the circular economy is indeed approached in a circular way, and not just half the circle. This means that we will withdraw the present waste proposal and come back with a more ambitious proposal that will cover the whole of the circular economy, and we will do this in 2015.  We will not drag our feet with this. We will do this very quickly, because we want the circular economy to be in pole position when the Juncker plan is being put into effect so that the economy that can profit from investment is indeed smack in the middle of the circular economy. This is what we want to do. So, if we withdraw the waste package, it is because we want to put something on the table that is more ambitious and that really can make a huge contribution to a part of the European economy that really needs a boost, which is the circular economy. We can also do this in line with the Juncker plan. I am deeply convinced of this. No ‘shame!’? Good. As I said, we will present this new, more ambitious proposal to promote the economy next year. In parallel, we will promote investment in this sector through the new European Fund for Strategic Investment as well as European structural and investment funds. In the political guidelines, we said we would assess the air package and our conclusions are clear. There are good prospects that the medium-sized combustion plants proposal will be adopted soon, closing the unacceptable loophole in our source legislation. The proposal on national emission ceilings has proved more controversial, and there is a gap emerging between what Parliament and Council might view as an acceptable outcome. We will bring forward, in the course of the ongoing negotiations, a modified proposal which we hope can help bridge this gap by better reflecting synergies with the energy and climate package, and by reducing the administrative burden. We are optimistic that negotiations will be a success and that agreement can be reached. I stress that we are not compromising on the goals we want to attain, but we are looking critically at the methods we can use to bring parties together so that we have a conclusion that can actually be implemented soon, so that we can achieve cleaner air in the EU. We have discussed the Maternity Leave Directive a lot. Let me be clear. The Commission deplores the persisting barriers to women’s access to and progression in the workplace just as much as you do. Over the past years, perhaps partly because of our proposal, many Member States have improved their maternity leave arrangements. However, there are a range of other issues that also need to be addressed to enable more women to participate in the labour market. We are ready to work with you and the Council to make one last effort to unblock the directive. But if there is no breakthrough in six months, we will take it off the table and come instead with a new initiative tackling those issues in the round. So yes, we will remain ambitious – yes we want this directive to succeed – but if it still continues to go nowhere, we will take new initiatives to break through the glass ceiling to create better positions for women in the labour market. We believe that it would be more useful for everyone to invest their time and effort in such a discussion than in an ongoing institutional stalemate. The onus is now on the three institutions in the next six months to create momentum around this proposal. If you really mean business, we can do it; if not, we will have to come up with something else. This is all part of our better regulation ethos. Our work programme also has a strong implementation simplification dimension. It again includes a set of regulatory Refit initiatives through which the Commission assesses the existing stock of legislation on a rolling basis to ensure that laws remain fit for purpose and deliver on their objectives in the most efficient and effective way. So what comes next? We will now discuss the withdrawal proposals with you, and we will only enact them after hearing your views. It is clear to me that we can only get things really done if there is an agreement between three institutions.  On the priority initiatives, we look forward to following up with the Parliament and the Council. We would like to work with you to identify a list of files on which the institutions can make a common commitment to progress swiftly to bring the benefit to the citizens as soon as possible. We look forward to a good and deep structural dialogue with your committees in the course of next spring and summer. On the basis of this experience, I hope we can move to a deeper understanding of interinstitutional programming in the future.  The Commission’s work programme is not the end of the affair or the dialogue. It is the beginning of a dialogue, and I am very much looking forward to this dialogue and coming back to your Parliament early next year if you allow me, Mr President, to continue that. Today is the start; we need your support. Europe needs us to deliver concrete measures for citizens who are looking for growth and jobs.

name: József SZÁJER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, may I join with my colleagues in congratulating you on this great prize. It is Christmas time and we are decorating trees, and at Christmas time for many years now we have done the exercise of the Commission work programme where everyone wants to put many decorations on this Christmas tree! However, the exercise of the Commission work programme is completely different and I would like to welcome and congratulate the Commission on this work programme, on behalf of the EPP, in achieving – at least so far – this impossible exercise by not making the Commission work programme into a Christmas tree where everyone finds their own point. We welcome the change; we welcome the simplicity and sticking to the basic principles, the ten priorities of the Juncker programme and investment plans in this work programme. I understand, and the same problem exists for Parliament: we all want our decorations on the Christmas tree and in this exercise we have seen in this election that we are losing the basic priorities. The word priority comes from the Latin word for ‘one’. Priority means one. Ten priorities are already more than one. Twenty-three priorities are more than ten. However, twenty-three priorities are more than 452 which is an extremely important and efficient exercise. The EPP would like to see efforts concentrated on the key items and refrain from taking initiatives which are not essential. Also we have to pay very strong attention to the implementation. Very often parliaments and our colleagues demand other elements and legislation just because the implementation is not done, so I would also welcome concentration and orientation on the implementation issues. We would like to see a growth-oriented Commission work programme creating all the conditions needed for more jobs, more mobility on the labour market and therefore better educational skills, notably in the IT sector, and the establishment of a real energy single market ensuring energy security and supply and going further towards a real and secular digital single market.  We also support your endeavours to have less bureaucracy at all stages at the national and Union level, using taxpayers’ money in a more efficient way in the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion, as well as simplifying the life of the economic actors, farmers, SMEs, because entrepreneurship needs a friendly environment without unnecessary administrative burdens and obstacles, and facilities in capital and financing access. We are therefore welcoming change. However we have been through this exercise so the implementation of this Commission work programme is the key. We are therefore in favour of a new deal allowing the Commission, Council and Parliament to define together the EU priorities. Whether this Commission work programme is the starting shot for that we will only know later on, but I wish us all the best of luck and strength to the Commission for the implementation.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, on behalf of myself and my group, I also congratulate you on the award of the Charlemagne Prize, which dignifies your long and fruitful political career in the service of the Union. Mr President, Mr Vice-President, 'this time it is different'. With this motto we attended last May's election. But how was it different? I quote: "This Parliament is different from its predecessors. He is the first to really elect the President of the Commission, in every sense of the word. And he chooses it in a new spirit." They're not my words. These are your words, Mr Juncker, of your July speech. Words that I fully share. The way we chose him changed his relationship with Parliament politically. We increased their legitimacy and, in return, demanded a different relationship of trust than the previous one: more dialogue, more joint action, more accountability. "I want to work with Parliament in a transparent manner, in a spirit of loyalty, mutual trust and cooperation, taking into account and respecting the co-legislators of the Union equally. I propose to update the methods of cooperation and work between the Commission and Parliament through constructive dialogue'. They're not my words. These are your words, Mr Timmermans, and they are words that I fully share. Believe me, I am very sorry to have to convey to you, on behalf of our group, our disappointment and some anger. What we have experienced in recent days and hours in relation to the Commission's work programme does not correspond to those words which I share. It's too much like the past to accept that this time it's different. Opacity at work, media versions, confusion, lack of information relevant to Parliament. Confidence between Parliament and the Commission has been damaged. The distance has increased. But we will have to reflect on that and I welcome the words that have just spoken today, pointing out that not only do different things, but do things differently. We will try to do it in the next resolution and that should be the work program. My group has priorities. They know them perfectly. Reducing unemployment, especially among young people. We demand, I said, a profound, visible, rapid and effective turn on taxation. I have to acknowledge with satisfaction that, on this particular point, certainly partly because of our pressure, the Commission has made a significant proposal. We want more and are ready to work together with the Commission to advance taxation in 2015. The social model has to be defended. We also want measures to combat growing social and territorial inequalities, to combat poverty in the Union with solidarity. On these issues, positive subsidiarity is needed, but also a strong European Union, which is able to respond to these challenges. Just a few seconds to point out that, on the matters for which they are proposing withdrawal, my group has some reservations and fully agrees that the objectives must be maintained, even if the procedure has to be changed: on maternity leave or on the circular economy. In any case, we are ready to work together with the Commission. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Guerrero, I ask you, after hearing your speech, if you still think it was right on the part of your group to vote for this Commission.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Iglesias, I must point out that there are two types of coalitions in the European Union: the positive coalition, which seeks to respond to the needs of citizens and solve their problems, and the negative coalition, which tries to confront without offering solutions. My "possible" coalition is with those who want to solve the problems; yours is at the ends of the House, in those who protest because they have no solutions for citizens. (Applause)

name: Vicky FORD
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, thank you for opening this session with a statement on the truly shocking news from Pakistan. As parents we take our children to school to learn and trust them to be safe, and our hearts go out to those families who have lost children today.  We do face unprecedented challenges. Our economies are under pressure, our resources are under pressure, security is under pressure and Europe needs to change. The Commissioners have talked about change, we need to see them deliver. We must build our economic strength. Yes, we share wider objectives – higher living standards, the environment, opportunity, equality – but we need strong economies to deliver this. So the economy must come first. And every EU initiative should face that simple test: will it make it easier or harder for businesses to thrive? Too often in the past we have seen the EU churn out new laws without thinking through the impact on growth, on small businesses, on innovation. This must stop and our decisions should be based on evidence.  Mr Juncker promised our Group he would keep a chief scientific adviser. Please keep that promise, Mr Juncker. Instead of focusing on yet more new laws, we should also make sure the existing ones work, and if they do not, then let us change them. And the last Commission promised to reduce burdens. Will you keep that promise, will you set a target for cutting red tape and then stick to it? We need to focus on growth, the single market in energy and services, and new public procurement rules should reduce costs and help growth. Let us deliver those changes. In 2015 we want to look forward to 2050 and not back to the 1950s. We need vibrant digital markets, conditions that let industries succeed and increase external trade too. And if we do not conclude that deep trade agreement with the US, then yes, we will be left behind. We need to unlock investment, especially for small companies and for infrastructure, investment built on private funds, on equity and not just public debt, because the crisis in public debt is not over.  Budgetary stability is still key as are structural reforms, but this does not mean centralising social and employment policies, because overruling national governments would risk even deeper resentments. And, Commissioners, we cannot have one set of rules for public spending at home and another set here in Strasbourg and Brussels. You must cut costs and waste from the EU budget and put the EU’s own finances in order. It is because public services are so stretched that the people of Europe have concerns over immigration. These must be addressed. Yes, we must cooperate with third countries and help tackle the causes of migration. But serious actions must also be taken to stop abuses of the migration system, both within and outside the EU. Our single market is meant to help businesses and consumers trade easily across 28 countries, not a bureaucratic one-size-fits-all monolith stifling creativity and reducing competition, not red tape, not regulation. That is our vision and we will work with those who share it. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jörg LEICHTFRIED
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, Mrs Ford, I would like to thank Mrs Ford for her work on this I have now listened very carefully and I wanted to ask, because I am very interested in one point of your speech. You said that the economy always takes precedence, the corporations always take action, and they should not be hindered. Does that mean, in return, no more social regulations, no more labour law, low salaries for employees, low taxes for large corporations? No, that is something, we do not want to work with you if you mean so. We mean it differently.  We believe that everyone should benefit from the economic recovery, not a few.

name: Vicky FORD
text: blue-card answer. – Sharing the benefits of growth is key, but one needs to have growth in order to share it. The economy must come first in order to deliver equality, opportunity and higher living standards. That is why we support calls for a leaner and more focused approach that respects subsidiarity at the same time.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, let me also congratulate President Juncker on behalf of the ALDE Group. First of all, we are talking better lawmaking today and in my view that would also mean transparency and indeed involving Parliament, but to my knowledge we are having a debate today on the basis of a document that was leaked to the press. I find that an unusual procedure. ALDE naturally supports efforts to slim down and simplify EU legislation, but we believe in smart trimming, not in taking a blunt axe to the trunk of the tree.  The Commission should not throw the baby out with the bathwater by arbitrarily scrapping laws. The Commission should respect the democratic policymaking process and not pick and choose. No one can be opposed to eliminating unnecessary regulation, but what one person considers unnecessary may be considered essential by someone else. The Commission wants to concentrate on the big themes and ALDE, of course, fully supports that. Now ALDE considers equal treatment a big theme, but in the Commission’s logic the blocked anti-discrimination directive is unnecessary red tape. ALDE considers transparency a big theme, but in the Commission’s own logic the access to documents law, blocked by the Commission and the Council, should be scrapped. ALDE considers sustainability a big theme, but the Commission’s red-tape slayer wants to withdraw the proposals for waste and air quality. ALDE also considers upholding democratic values and the rule of law a big theme, and unfortunately in many Member States it is a very topical issue these days, but the Commission proposes no instrument. Democracy and the rule of law are also necessary. Conversely Parliament rejected the proposal for an EU PNR scheme but the Commission keeps pushing for it without any proper justification or evidence for its necessity.  In our view the Commission should focus on improving the process rather than ignoring the outcome of democratic decision. ALDE strongly objects to the withdrawal of files only and exclusively because the Member States failed to take responsibility and the Council is paralysed. If that were the rule, many good laws making the lives of EU citizens better would not have existed today. There would be no banking union, no European patents, no standards for the health and safety of workers in the internal market, no common asylum rules.  Scrapping or simplifying certain laws may be useful, but how will the Commission tackle goldplating by Member States, a major cause of excessive red tape? How will the Commission ensure better implementation of EU laws by Member States, and will the Commission finally introduce a sunset clause in all legislative proposals. Last but not least, will the Commission drastically raise the standards of transparency and access to documents so as to allow for full accountability and public scrutiny, which in my view is key to better lawmaking? At his confirmation hearing Vice-President Timmermans said that this Commission is born in the European Parliament, so we expect the new Commission to work in tandem with this House to reduce the regulatory burden but also to ensure a democratic and transparent legislative process.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: gue/NGL Group. Mr President! You in the Commission want a new course. A course in which we should not have more of the same, but instead must listen to the citizens and bring about real change. Never before have I been as in agreement with the Commission as I have on this issue. Unfortunately, the agreement also ends there. Instead of focusing on creating a better framework for our workers, the work programme talks about making it easier for companies at the expense of workers' rights and working conditions. But let me be very clear: it is certainly not for the benefit of workers if their rights are to be rolled back to make it easier for companies, as you in the Commission are proposing. So let us get a really fresh start by putting citizens and our welfare communities first, and let us start by burying the whole REFIT programme. This is not for the benefit of workers.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, you are right: this Parliament is indeed the last-chance legislature here in Europe. If we want to reconcile our citizens with the very idea of European integration, we must - as you have often said - bring Europe closer to the citizen. But what does it mean to bring Europe closer to the citizen, other than to ensure that our Europe works for the majority of our citizens, not just for a minority? If we want to achieve this, I think we have to go through three directions. The first is social justice. You have told us that you want Europe to deserve a social triple A and, in this, we can only approve of you. Some will say: 'Social policy is not a competence of the European Union'. Quite the opposite! Let us first talk about tax justice: you have already announced a few initiatives on this subject which, without going to the point they should reach, represent at least a step in the right direction. There is still a lot of work to be done in terms of tax transparency and these are relatively easy, from a political point of view, to implement. We encourage you to do so. We also believe - and I did not hear this in your speech, nor in Mr Timmermans's speech - that, contrary to what we heard in plenary this morning, we need to review the economic governance package, in order to make the social objectives of reducing poverty and inequality and the environmental objectives as restrictive as the budgetary targets. The budgetary choices that governments make will thus be choices in the direction of reducing inequalities and our ecological footprint, rather than in the direction of their worsening. We must also review - and I have not heard it either - the directive on the secondment of workers and stop using the semester to actually put the workers of this continent, especially the most insecure of them, in competition with each other. Finally, you need to put in place the social impact assessment of all measures, including the budget measures you want to take. The second axis is long-term environmental sustainability. I continue to hear from the Council, here in Parliament and in the Commission that the ecological transition of the economy is a burden. "We'll do that when things get better," they say. Yet for Europeans, it is both a requirement - we continue to depend on the outside for our energy - and an opportunity! This is how we will set Europe at the forefront of the next industrial revolution. The third and final axis is the need to address the democratic deficit. I have heard ideas about transparency in lobbying. What I have not heard is that the European semester, the instrument par excellence of policy convergence in Europe, must be subject to much more democratic scrutiny, at the levels of both the European Parliament and national parliaments. We really need to give legitimacy to the discussions that are taking place at the moment when the country-specific recommendations are being developed - recommendations that, more often than not, result from behind-the-scenes agreements between government officials, often at the official level, and Commission representatives, without either being accountable for democratic representation. In fact, measures are taken or imposed without anyone paying the political cost. At this point, we are no longer in a democracy. I will end with the question of better regulation. Mr. Timmermans, you told us that better regulation does not mean no regulation, nor deregulation. You have said some interesting things about the "waste" package, and I take note of that. I would like you to confirm to me that it is no longer a question of removing air quality measures. Finally, with regard to REFIT, it is a device used, including by a majority of this House - I am a democrat, therefore I recognise this - to continually weaken the social and environmental protection measures we need if we are to lead, especially the most fragile among us, a decent existence. REFIT cannot be the pretext for a large-scale deregulation operation. In conclusion, I would like to encourage you to show a better sense of customer service. I was very surprised to see that it took five days - five days! Commissioner Hill to respond to the letter sent to him by the banking federations, calling for the withdrawal of the directive on structural reforms of the banking sector. It took her five days to take her back to her Account! Real customer service reacts instantly to this kind of demand from the big banks; the commissioner really should make him a much more enthusiastic lawyer than he is now. It is, of course, out of the question for us that this directive should be withdrawn. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: blue-card question. – Mr Lamberts, you suggested at the beginning of your speech that Mr Timmermans is facing the last-chance saloon for Europe to promote support for the many rather than the few. Is it your contention, therefore, that the European Union is only looking after the few now?

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: "blue card" answer. "Mr. Woolfe, I am a simple mind. I have an engineering background, so I tend to look at the numbers. I'm a little silly about that. Therefore, since the beginning of the crisis, I have been watching the evolution of Europe, which is doing better at the same time - financially - and less well. What do we see? In short, according to the statistical institutes, between 1 and 2% of the population is richer today and lives more comfortably, while the rest of the population lives in the same situation, or even less comfortably or more precariously. Therefore, I must note that the policies that are being carried out in Europe today, at the instigation of national governments and the Union, are policies that benefit a minority. That's a fact!

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would like to make the following remarks to Mr Juncker. You are here with your Commission presenting your new work plan but I can see that you have been busy with the PR consultants. You have been busy spending a pretty penny or two. You have been trying to rebrand the European Commission and you have come up with a slogan: ‘A New Start for Europe’. You could not invent it, could you? We do it every five years. We should get our money back. I even noticed on the Berlaymont Building last week a great big banner with your face on it and the rest of the Commission team – a new start for Europe under team Juncker. Well I do not know about ‘new’. This Commission has got four former Prime Ministers in it, it has got 19 former government ministers in it, it has got seven former Commissioners in it. I do not know about some bright new fresh start for Europe. It looks a bit more like the knacker’s yard for failed domestic politicians.  And at the top of it, as President, we have got you. Now I do not want anybody here to think that I am questioning Mr Juncker’s competence. I am not. You are certainly competent. You are a good operator and there are 240 multinationals who all managed to avoid hundreds of millions of euro of corporation tax by paying 1% to 2% tax in Luxembourg during your term there as Prime Minister that would testify that you are certainly a more competent operator than the man that went before you. But please do not give us ‘new’. You were Prime Minister of Luxembourg for 19 years and you headed up the Eurogroup. ʽNewʼ you are not. You and this Commission, frankly, are as stale and musty as a corked bottle of wine.  We are being encouraged by your sidekick, Mr Timmermans, who, by the way, today talked about the ʽcircular economyʼ. Sir, I have not got a clue what you are talking about but it sounds absolutely lovely. You told us today that you are going to adopt a minimalist approach to legislation. Again, rather like Mr Juncker, you are rather brighter, cleverer and sharper than those who have gone before you. We are not going to get from you any more proposed bans on olive oil being poured into dishes that we dip our bread into in restaurants and I suspect that you will not be updating the curvature of cucumber regulations that came in a few years ago. Minimalism is one thing, but what it fails to address is the fact that the very last time we attempted to address within the European Union how big the body of law that had already been imposed on our businesses was – that was in 2005 – it was 170 000 pages of active legislation. It is probably now a quarter of a million or perhaps even more than that. I would suggest to Mr Timmermans that what we do not need is minimalism. If Europe is to become competitive and to trade globally and competitively, what it needs is the axe. You have actually got to start getting rid of excessive regulation, particularly on the small and medium-sized enterprises, which in any free market economy could not be expected to maintain the same standards for everybody and everything as the giant multinationals. But there are two areas where minimalism will not work. One is in negotiating with the United Kingdom about immigration. Mr Juncker, you have made it clear that it is non-negotiable. The free movement of peoples is non-negotiable; the British want wholesale change. Secondly, there is Greece’s membership of the euro when it is clear for all to see that she, and everybody else, would be better off without it. I suggest that, whatever your work programme is, the next five years will actually be dominated by Greece and the euro and Britain’s membership of the European Union. I suspect that you will spent most of your time dealing with those issues. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Blue card question. I wanted to ask Mr Beazley whether he is going to be able to do that. Farage, if he has not forgotten to ask, in addition to the regulations concerning Luxembourg, whether he has not also taken advantage of these regulations in his own country. Secondly, I am pleased to see that this whole group no longer has the English flag in front of it. Does that mean that you recognise that this is a European Parliament and not a Parliament of the United Kingdom?

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: blue-card answer. – I was not really sure what the question was but it is awfully good of the President to give me more speaking time. As far as Luxembourg norms are concerned, I made it clear that I am not especially critical of Mr Juncker. I actually think tax competition and different countries doing things their own way in a diverse Europe is a good and healthy thing. By the way, a correction if I may: you are quite right – my flag is not on my desk but it has never hitherto been an English flag, it has been the Union Jack which is the British flag.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I believe that the flag keeper has fallen victim to the Belgian strike. He always comes and hands out the flag and collects it again on Thursdays. Next time you have the Union Jack again.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: Mr President, at the last Strasbourg session, you ruled in favour of a group which was displaying flags, displaying signs which claimed opponents were racist, homophobic and all kinds of things, and in the same breath, you criticised the flags, the national flags, that were on our desks. Now, I have had a look at the rules since then, and Annex 15 to the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament states that visual displays will be tolerated provided they are not offensive or defamatory. Now I think that ‘racist’ and ‘homophobe’ are allegations which are defamatory. Although I expect it sometimes of the hard-left Green group, perhaps others in this group do not.  Mr President, could you tell us please: is the British flag in your opinion offensive or defamatory? What was the reason for your attacking it?  (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: No, the British flag is not offensive. I just noticed that you obviously didn't bring any with you today. Otherwise, we have been used to carrying your flag here for many years. As far as I know, neither one of my predecessors nor I have complained about this. By the way, I would like to say something to you: you have complained about other people holding up posters here. At the meeting in Brussels that you mentioned, your own group held up at least half of the posters – the Italian part of your group. I would have liked you to have protested.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Mr President, I, as a Belgian, can at least comfort Mr Farage and his group, because he is not the only victim of the Socialist strike in Belgium, but also all the Flemings who would have liked to have gone to work that day. Anyway, too much is too much.  As an ardent lover of Europe and an advocate of European cooperation between our Member States, but at the same time as a critical and sceptical member of parliament on your concept of the European Union, I was in fact pleased with the Commission's intention to limit its legislative priorities and initiatives. For example, I myself am an active waste recycler and I have always supported Flemish initiatives in this direction as much as possible as an active citizen and also as a politician. But what is the advantage of European patronising in this area seems to me to be completely unclear and undesirable and in any case unnecessary. More can be achieved through voluntary agreements, possibly stimulated by trade agreements.  The energy you put into a coercive system in relation to countries that do not want or can follow will lead to incomprehension and cost more money than anything else. Moreover, the advantage of the riot around the evaluation you are now making is that it once again becomes clear what a large and extensive competence the European Commission does have. I do not think it makes sense for legislation to be drafted in that bureaucratic Commission, nor should it be that legislation should be legislated on top of and separate from the Member States on as many issues as what is currently on the table.  It has all gone too far and gone way too far and the only reason I could recommend you not to hoe in your powers and in your stacks of legislation would be – ironically speaking – because those who want to do everything can do nothing in the end. After all, that would probably be best.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Arnott, you raised a point of order.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: Mr President, as you well know, my colleagues in the Italian Five Star Movement put up signs which were not offensive or defamatory. My point to you is that the Rules of Procedure must be applied equally to all, impartially, and that all groups should be afforded the same respect and impartiality by the Chair. That is simply what I am asking for. Do you believe that these proceedings should be chaired in an impartial and neutral way? If offensive slogans over that side are not allowed but then, when we raise it, you complain about non-offensive slogans on our side of the House, it comes across to us as being anything other than impartial.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you for your comment.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I am very pleased with the Declaration by the President of the Commission that the programme and its presentation are only the beginning of the debate, not the end. Contrary to what has been announced, I do not believe that this Commission is dusty and nothing has changed in it. I very much welcome the fact that the Commission's objective is better legislation. I agree that a review of Community law is needed. The question must be asked whether the acquis communautaire is not duplicated, where there are loopholes in the same law that make it difficult for us to operate, which need to be replenished, and where there are reserves that strengthen, above all, economic growth or social cohesion. Secondly, the review of the passage of part of the programme from the previous Commission requires a swift decision to ensure that Parliament is not uncertain about the fate of the projects we have already started work on – m.in. on the clean air package or the waste package.  Thirdly, I would like to support the european Commission's priorities, and in particular the Energy Union. It must be acknowledged that the question of security of energy supply, the decommissioning of energy islands, the development of transmission infrastructure or diversification of supply are extremely important, in particular in the context of the crisis in eastern Europe. Furthermore, the functioning of the internal market is important, including, I stress with all emphasis, the free movement of persons or the implementation of the Services Directive, as m.in well as the Digital Agenda as the basis for rapid and smart growth or the development of entrepreneurship, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, together with the entire investment package presented. I also consider it very important to tax profits where they are made. We know examples of transfers, especially at the beginning of the transformation of countries such as mine, from the countries where the profit was made, to the countries of origin of companies that operated in the area. Lastly, the issue of the circular economy and its relationship with other priorities, e.g. bioecon economics, which has already been enshrined in the Europe 2020 Strategy.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: Mr President, the first work programme is certainly very important because it is important to set a new direction for Europe and to set a new level of ambition. If we want to focus on a strong idea for this new direction for Europe, then it is certainly to restart the job creation machine in Europe. This machine is not working and we need to restart job creation in order to overcome the stagnation trend we are in, in order to overcome economic and social divergences between Member States, and in order to pave the way for new activities: a green transition, a smart and innovative economy.  But for that we really need to change direction and we are waiting for a Commission that pushes for a new policy mix; where we have fiscal consolidation but where the top priority is certainly growth; where we have reforms but reforms to enhance growth potential and not just to cut public spending; where, most of all, investment is a top priority, and this means having an investment plan which is able to support strategic projects, which are missing in Europe. This also means having a fiscal rule with more room for investments and this, we know very well, means having a credible agenda to tackle tax avoidance and to exclude harmful tax competition.  This is the level and ambition we are waiting for. Let me just underline that you also hold a historic task in your hands which is to complete the economic and monetary union. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question under Rule 162(8))

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for taking this blue card question, Ms Rodrigues, and thank you, Mr President, for seeing it on this occasion. Ms Rodrigues, you mentioned in your remarks the importance of job creation. Do you consider that the existence of the euro, the one-size-fits-all currency, and the eurozone, help job creation or hinder job creation?

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: blue-card answer. – I do not think the problem is with the euro, the euro can become a strength for European Union Member States; the problem is that our economic and monetary union is deeply imbalanced. We need to complete the banking union, we need to have proper coordination to support demand with supply in deficit countries and most of all we need to build up a real fiscal capacity. With these conditions I think we can again deliver high job creation and better standards in the euro area.

name: Andrzej DUDA
text: Ladies and gentlemen, Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent There have already been many very important statements in this House today – first from the mouth of President Timmermans, now from the mouth of the Honourable Member – namely that today it is our great duty in the European Union to fight unemployment decisively. This is a very negative phenomenon, which affects young people in particular today and to create development prospects for them that will enable them to live in a dignified life in our countries, in the countries of the European Union, and not to go beyond it in search of jobs – because this is not a way to combat unemployment – it is a great prospect today. In January 2014, less than a year ago, the previous European Commission issued a communication on the need for a revival of European industry. Even then, the candidates for European Commissioners, m.in Elżbieta Bieńkowska, now Commissioner, spoke of the need for reindustrialisation. In this regard, a few questions need to be asked, Mr President, namely, the rebirth of industry and reindustrialisation, and I understand that this is the same in Europe. What has been done about this since January 2014? Until now, this remains in the sphere of demand. How do climate-related constraints come to this? The Union is taking decisive steps on these issues, but no action has been taken so far on reindustrialisation, the construction of new sites ... (The President has taken the vote.) (The speaker agreed to answer the question raised by raising the "blue card" (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Do you agree with me – I am following on from what Ms Rodrigues was saying – that governments do not create jobs? Business creates jobs, not governments. This may be a novel idea for this pan-European socialist assembly, but that is why people are queuing up to get into England, Scotland and Ireland, and they are not queuing up at the borders to get into Europe.

name: Andrzej DUDA
text: the answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. I have a short question: when will we finally see any legislative solutions on reindustrialisation? When will we see, Mr President, any European Commission action plan that will be proposed to us? This is the thing that interests me the most today, because this is a way to fight unemployment, a way to further develop Europe, a way out of the economic crisis. If we are to generate money somewhere, they should go in this direction. And the last question: what will be the money? Thank you very much.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, the debate has returned from a sitcom to a real debate, and if you allow me, I will continue along those lines. You have introduced to us the programme, a version of which was leaked a few days ago. This was fine, it was advance notice so we could be prepared. But on the other hand, I hope that the information that this programme has been driven by the services and the Secretariat General is not a leak, but just gossip, because what we expect from a political Commission is very thorough political work. Now on the programme: it is a good paper. It is still general, of course, and we will have to get down to the nitty-gritty, but I think that it addresses a number of issues. On the other hand, what I notice in the plan is that we also somehow slightly neglect other issues which are of daily concern to citizens. The economic and social agenda is definitely among these, but there are other issues which may be less prominent. Now on the investment plan: I really regret that the Commission, at least at this stage, missed an opportunity to link the benefits which the investment plan is to bring with the structural changes which need to occur in the Member States. I would be looking for conditionality, in other words. Now in terms of better regulation, I think that this is a good first step that we have seen today. I am a little bit concerned as to whether we will see a real system soon enough; this is what I am looking for and what I am missing in the plan. There is no system; there are no targets; there are no benchmarks. We need to look at its complexity. A final remark: we are currently in the process of withdrawing legislation. Hopefully this is the right thing to do, but I would expect that this process would be based on impact assessments. Legislative initiatives have to be based on impact assessments, and so should their withdrawal. I am not sure I understood it; I would appreciate a clarification on that. It is a good start, but as a cornerstone we would be really looking for a solid system that would bring better regulation.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: Mr President, you are talking about restoring trust, you are asking us to believe in your Commission as if it were a matter of faith, you say that this time it is different. I have listened carefully to your words and read the Communication, and the truth is that I seek and find no reason to convey to the public a message of trust towards you. Falling in love with Europe and its people is easy, but falling in love with this European Union has nothing to do with it. The principle of subsidiarity must be invigorated, correct, but I am afraid that, in some fundamental respects , for example the environment , the Commission is draining the lump — or so it seems – no long as they announce much more ambitious programmes to us. Because again it seems like a matter of faith, because we don't know those ambitious proposals. One last point on democratic change that he claims to push. He says he's betting on transparency: okay, I take note. See. But that's not enough to restore the trust of the public. Citizens need another model, another Europe, and be art and part of that change, and I don't see any of that in their program.

name: Jill EVANS
text: Mr President, like many colleagues I was shocked last week to hear that the Commission was proposing to scrap two new environmental laws on clean air and recycling targets which sent out a very negative message to those who expect the EU to take the lead in environmental action. I know from my own experience in Wales that these are crucial public health issues and create thousands of green jobs, so we will take as a promise that you will bring forward more ambitious proposals and we will wait for those with interest. I was encouraged, however, to see that the Swansea Tidal Lagoon was included in the indicative project list for investment. It will not only be a source of renewable power for generations to come, but also a catalyst for investment in jobs: world leading technology being developed with the real involvement and the support of the local community. That is the kind of sustainable job-creating investment we really need to see in the future.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Like Mr De Clercq, i.e. the Committee on The Other Hand, i.e. the Committee on The Lambert, I have a scientific background and a certain tendency to look at the figures: I give some. Air pollution is the cause of over 400 000 000 premature deaths every year, and what does the Juncker Commission do? Withdraw from its "Clean Air" package investment plan. According to the Commission's own estimates, efficient use of resources can create 580 000 new jobs, making Europe more competitive and reducing the demand for resources, which are increasingly scarce and expensive. But what does the Juncker Commission do? Withdraw the circular economy package from its investment plan. We lose around 600 million tonnes of waste materials every year, which could be recycled or reused. These materials could bring net savings of 600 billion euros each year, while reducing total greenhouse gas emissions from 2% to 4% per year. But what does the Juncker Commission do? It withdraws the Waste Directive from its investment plan. Do our health systems focus on a myriad of waste and scams that weigh heavily on citizens' pockets? The Juncker Commission deletes the dossier on the transparency of the price of medicines. Are we living in a period of extreme economic crisis with citizens begging and entrepreneurs committing suicide? The Juncker Commission throws away years and years of work by hundreds of employees who have prepared those proposals and wastes a sea of public resources used to finance various studies, feasibility assessments, effectiveness assessments. Ladies and gentlemen, we are not going to deal with this Commission because they are our enemies and they are the enemies of the citizens and we knew that they would do all this. We take issue with you, with those Members of this Parliament who voted for them who continue to support them and who are not outraged by all this crap you are seeing.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the Commission's Programme for 2015 is a means of escalating the attack on the peoples of Europe and a tool for recovering the profitability of business groups with permanent, even stricter surveillance. You are giving monopolies even more capital for investment, with the basic condition of vulnerable workers with flexible industrial relations. The energy union, the digital single market, free trade with the United States and other restructurings open up new areas of profitability for businesses and bring new suffering to the people. The so-called 'markets', i.e. capital, are neither 'convinced' nor 'humiliated', only this and its power are overturned. Immediate popular intervention is now needed to recover the losses, for life without 'markets', the European Union and monopolies, with the people a real boss at home.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Mr President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab, for Commissioners! We are talking about a programme for the European Union for the next year. This is very important, because this programme must be realistic, and I thank you for this approach. What we are committed to must be done – that is the most important thing, but we also understand that if something is not included in the programme for the next year, it will be implemented in the years to come. We would like to hear the Commission's commitment that these things are not lost, as we have set out in the 10-point programme. Let me move on to certain specifics. Many people raised the issue of unemployment. The most important thing is to give people a job – it's true. The committee I chair is developing several points that can prevent or reduce unemployment. First, energy – it's obvious, it was mentioned. We also need cheaper energy, openness to the US market, security of supply, the use of indigenous energy sources, and new technologies. The second point – thank you for highlighting this – is the digital market: trilogues should start as soon as possible; we must press the Council. The third point – in my opinion very important – is the road map of our industrial policy. Thanks to the reindustrialisation that was so important at the end of the previous Commission, we can also strengthen small and medium-sized enterprises and give people jobs. So we are waiting for the road map.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his work on You have announced that you will make this Commission more political. You cannot be blamed for this, quite the contrary. What we are talking about today is whether it works, how we can achieve this together.  We cannot say what exactly your ideas on the work programme are, because you are not presenting them to us today. But the document that was leaked last week does not yet adequately show this – far from it in many respects. I do not know exactly why, but we should talk about it. Let me try to explain this to you by way of a single example. This House prevailed in the last parliamentary term – in banking regulation with Mr Karas's report – that from 2015, from next year, all financial institutions will have to prove country by country where they make what profits and where they pay what taxes. That is a good principle. That is where Mr Karas, who has listened carefully, who has been able to welcome him, who has achieved this for the European People's Party. There is Mr Lamberts, who has spoken. He has pushed this through for the Green Group. I was the shadow rapporteur for the Social Democrats, and we have achieved this for the Social Democrats. Is it so unfair that my group expects you today, in view of the discussion we have on tax avoidance practices, to finally extend this to all multinationals? Why is this proposal not in your work programme? It would ensure overnight that many avoidance practices cease to exist and that we can finally achieve fair taxation and justice for tax citizens in Europe. You say that I assume that this is a newer development, that there is an action programme by June of next year. I very much hope that this will be included in this action programme. It is a good example of how we could work better if we listened, approached each other and when we are in dialogue. You want partners, you have partners. But this is not a one-way street. We have expectations of this Commission.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his Their programme was presented earlier by the EPP representative as a Christmas tree and the Vice-President placed ten candles there. These are your ten priorities. I have to tell you that I have a problem with your fifth priority, which is to deepen monetary union. In fact, it is clear to everyone that the world economy has been growing faster than Europe for some time now, and that Europe is growing faster than the eurozone. So we have a problem, particularly in the eurozone. I cannot help myself, I must remind you that the euro is far too strong for the south of Europe – including France – and far too weak for Germany. This can be seen in youth unemployment in southern Europe or in the export surplus in Germany. I wonder: when do we stop subjecting the different fiscal and economic cultures in Europe to the needs of a single currency, and when are we starting to create a currency that corresponds to these cultures?

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Mr President, you have decided to make politics, which is good news, and I am grateful for that! Yes, Europe needs to refocus on the essentials and it is time. The main thing, of course, is the economic and the social. Your investment plan is moving in the right direction. But we must go further, put on the table a timetable for tax harmonisation, create a truly stable environment for businesses and finally make progress towards the economic governance of the euro area. The other major priority is for Europe to regain its capacity to respond to the world's major climate questions, the common immigration policy, real foreign and defence policies. We see today the state of the world and the danger there, especially with what happened in Pakistan, which we are all thinking about right now. So let's focus on these two main areas and two major priorities, and make concrete progress for five years. We can make a difference and show our citizens that Europe brings them real added value, as long as Europe decides to really exist.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr President, Mr Juncker, is the Commission's programme responsible for the blunt interference in the internal political affairs of the Member States? A few days ago, speaking of Greece, you indicated to the Greeks to vote for your own familiar faces and not to make a mistake. Excuse me, this is none of your business! Would you dare make such a statement on the eve of an election about Germany or the United Kingdom? You could not stand as President of the Commission for 24 hours! When did the Commission decide to do so? On the basis of what articles of the Treaties? Listen, my party, SYRIZA, is fighting for solutions within the euro area, with growth, with justice, with sustainable debt, with the rule of law, with a strong social state. This policy is not extreme, but the Troika policy, which you support, which brings unemployment, recession, inequality, an explosion of cohesion and deflation. You promised us changes starting. But increasingly you look like Mr Barroso's twin brother. (Applause)

name: Pascal DURAND
text: Mr President, Mr Timmermans, it is sometimes good to go back to basics and find out why we are here. If we are here, it is first and foremost to carry together the European project, that of a civilization that has always sought this balance between the quality of life and the ability, for the greatest number of us and the citizens, to be able to win it. The power of initiative, which belongs to the Commission alone, gives you a special responsibility, that of favouring the general European interest, namely to constantly seek a balance between the social, the environment and the economy. By directly undermining, through the issues of air quality, the circular economy and, for example, the work of pregnant women, you would undermine this balance and the European social contract. There is still time to revisit this situation and take that general interest back on your own account.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul I would like to start by perhaps proclaiming Congratulations or why not Bingo for Herman Van Rompuy: EUR 730 000 in pension money over the next 3 years; direct mockery of every taxpayer in the Member States. In this age of unemployment that is only escalating to ever worse levels, Herman Van Rompuy is pulling the jackpot, again with taxpayers' money. Now Mr Juncker wants to focus on rebuilding the confidence and trust of the people of Europe, and I would like to ask. How are we going to do that? By allowing them to pay even more tax to allow eu politicians to have horribly retired retirements in order to continue their luxury lives at taxpayers' expense? Another priority from Jean-Claude Juncker's work programme for 2015, it is a new policy on migration. Surely it is a matter for the individual Member States to take a position on, and not the EU, or have you thought today that immigration cannot be dealt with?  There are currently not enough jobs for the inhabitants of the EU Member States. Despite this, therefore, we now want an EU policy on immigration. There is neither housing nor work for those who already exist in eu countries, and as usual, it will be the ordinary worker who will have to pay for the never-ending tide of failed proposals coming from this House. I do not even believe that it is possible to restore confidence and trust. Less than 43% of all persons entitled to vote took part in the last European elections, so I would say that the people have already lost all confidence in this establishment. Mr. Applause.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in his speech, Mr Juncker set out, as a flagship, the point concerning the fight against tax evasion, fairness and the promotion of tax fairness. Strange, however, that nothing specific is read in the whole program. Perhaps a small directive that illustrates how we can equally fight and prevent trafficking, anomalies, laws or laws, such as those that have delighted us in recent years and which have encouraged the massive tax evasion of multinationals to the detriment of honest taxpayers. Now, there is one fact, Mr Juncker. There is a country, a Member Of the European Union, in which not only are there no measures to this effect but, indeed, honest citizens are being chased, and this country is yours, Mr Juncker, if it is true that an investigation has even been opened in Luxembourg against Antoine Daltour, that is to say honest citizens, the honest official, who has uncovered this shameful scandal that should have prevented her from becoming President of the European Commission. Congratulations! I believe that the way forward is quite different, namely to free our countries from the prison of the euro in order to restore our peoples' monetary sovereignty and free ourselves from the visitors to Bilderberg, the Trilateral, like you.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: Mr President, Mr Juncker, First Vice-President Timmermans, we have of course made your desire to concentrate on a few main objectives and priorities, to refocus the work of the European Commission on the essentials. On behalf of the French delegation of the EPP Group, I wanted to highlight what two key key priorities for us French MEPs in the EPP Group would be: a common European asylum and immigration policy and a common European energy strategy. We attach particular importance to the progress of these two priority areas in 2015. As EPP coordinator in the Committee on Women's Rights, I would like to quickly raise two important issues. The first is one of the EPP Group's priorities, the draft Women on Boards directive. We would like to urge the European Commission to weigh, as far as possible, on the ongoing negotiations in the Council to carry out the draft directive on greater representation of women on the boards of large listed companies, known as Women on Boards. We in the European Parliament voted for a reasonable and balanced compromise, and the EPP Group had contributed a great deal to that. We really hope that this file can be completed in 2015. With regard to the draft directive on maternity leave, we have also heard you. You are moving forward, in my opinion, in a lucid, realistic and reasonable way. We have taken note of the idea of considering a withdrawal, if there is no substantial movement or initiative within six months. Nevertheless, we will be careful that there will be no setback in the cause of women, in general, in the coming months, in view of the future lines of work of the European Commission.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: Mr President, I would like to start by thanking Mr Juncker for coming to present his work programme to this Parliament – although it would have been nice, to be honest, if it had been presented here first rather than having been leaked to the press. After listening intently to your proposals, I do have a couple of observations.  My first observation is on the issue of tax havens. I welcome the fact that you recognise the problems we face in your work programme, though I have got to be truthful, the cynic in me does wonder if this would have been included if it were not for the recent LuxLeaks scandals.  Mr Juncker, this Parliament made it clear last year that we wanted immediate action to tackle tax evasion, outlining priority areas such as country-by-country reporting and blacklisting for tax avoiders. That was last year, and so far we have seen little action. In that time, citizens across the EU have continued to see their wages cut, health services cut, public services cut. Day by day, week by week, people from all over Europe, who continue to pay their taxes, have seen their living standards squeezed.
