Yet in this time we have continued to allow large corporations to avoid paying their dues, avoid paying what they owe and avoid living up to their responsibilities. We need legislation now. No longer can we turn a blind eye to tax injustice.  My second observation is in regard to the scrapping of the air quality package. Mr Juncker, I warn you now. Kicking this legislation on air quality into the long grass will have serious implications for public health across the EU. Air pollution kills 400 000 people every year. To scrap legislation that could save so many lives is not just appalling, it is actually totally irresponsible. This will send a message to everyone that the EU is no longer interested in promoting progressive environmental health policy. I urge you, Mr Juncker, to reconsider this issue now. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: the blue card. – I wanted to ask my colleague: indeed, in elections and now the people of the European Union, who are on lower incomes, are very hopeful and expect that both the new Commission and the new Parliament will make many decisions that will give a greater perspective. Whether you think there should be a desire in the new programme to ensure a minimum wage, a minimum wage within the European Union.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: blue-card answer. – I am not sure that is anything to do with what I said, but I would say in response that I do not believe in a Europe that is just for business. Europe has got to serve all its citizens, and that includes making sure that everybody has a decent standing of living too.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, President Juncker has a very ambitious plan for Europe which is good because only ambition and the desire for genuine progress can push us in the right direction. I hope this ambition is based on facts, not fairytale projections that will one day deflate like a soap bubble in the near future.  It would not be the first time the Commission has lived in a world of its own where everything is in the best order and there is no need for real reforms.  But now we have a new composition of the Commission and a new president, so it would be good and fair to give these people a chance to show how much they can.  I want to believe that the Commission will indeed behave according to Mr Timmermans, who talks about a Europe that improves the lives of citizens and does not interfere with it. And about a Europe that increases businesses' competitiveness rather than burdens them with red tape. However, if the Commission's answer to all the problems is - we need more Europe, I fear we will have a new political and economic crisis from which we will find it very, very difficult to get out.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul Thank you to the Commission's leadership for being here to share your visions for the Commission's work in 2015. That's good, but it could have been even better. In particular, I welcome the priorities for regular migration aimed at making europe more attractive to workers, to students, to researchers and to investors. We need all this to see economic growth, jobs and success at a globalised time.  But the programme should have included legal and safe routes for people who have to escape war and persecution. Just so – by allowing people to safely get here – can we stop the grotesque advances of people smugglers. We must ensure that the Mediterranean does not become the mass cemetery that we are now seeing, with almost 4000 people this year alone who have lost their lives there.  I am also very pleased to see that we now have a digital single market in place, and I would argue that we need to see that the Commission – I would like to congratulate the Commission – is courageous and does not swerve to those conservative forces that do not dare to innovate.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Looking at this programme we see what the juncker commission's proposed new cycle means. An investment plan consisting of giving public guarantees to a gigantic public-private partnership programme. Public interest infrastructures that start operating in a logic of private monetization. Condemn young people to precariousness and forced emigration. Social security attacks. More liberalisation, trade deregulation, selective immigration. It is symbolic that dossiers that could still represent some kind of social advancement, even if tenuous, such as the maternity directive, should be dropped. And it is clear the retreat, it is blatant the retreat in environmental issues. The Commission reveals its true face here – the business committee of large transnational capital. This programme is nothing more than the specifications of the great confederations of the great European employers. Regardless of who sits in this chair, they're the ones pulling the strings.  None of this is a future. Everything is in the past. A dark past that will sooner or later be unavariably defeated.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr. President! President Juncker, you spoke of securing the future of Europe in a work programme with 23 investments. I have 60 seconds to ask. First of all, I would like to ask you: where do you intend to invest in tackling the causes of migration, instead of increasing the pressure on the European labour market with 24 million unemployed through integration and legalisation of immigration? You talked about fighting tax evasion and tax fraud. Taxes, you said, must be paid where they are generated. How credible is this according to your Luxembourg model? Should tax fairness then also apply to employees or only to entrepreneurs? Where is the investment in social justice? Do you believe that you can continue to combat national differences in Europe effectively with the single currency, the euro?

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, I am speaking here in my capacity as coordinator of the Group of the European People's Party for Foreign Affairs and I am very pleased, Mr President of the Commission, to discover in your work programme for 2015, one of the priorities, the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy, which is also a priority for us. We are already working on that. It is my colleague, Éduard Kukan, who is managing the subject - and we have received a very positive signal from Commissioner Hahn in this regard. I am convinced that we will work very well together, especially since in recent years we have also been a little surprised by the changes in the South and the East. We were ill-prepared and we sometimes felt here in the European Parliament that we were not very well positioned to make certain decisions. We are therefore aware that today, the reform of the European neighbourhood policy cannot be a mere cosmetic reform. We must try to respond to the great challenges of our time and, indeed, find a balance between East and South. I would also like to say a word about the agreement with the United States, because of course these negotiations are important for economic growth and jobs, but also in terms of policy. This partnership is crucial for us and Europe will be a very strong global player if it succeeds in concluding these negotiations with its American partners.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Junker, Commissioners, we welcome the starting point, which is that of discontinuity with regard to the past. But we tell you that this point must be taken to the end. Especially in the substantive political relationship with Parliament, if you want a Europe that is more open to the citizens, if you want us to move in the same direction. From this point of view, we are not there, as our colleague Mr Guerrero said. So, in addition to the selection effort, which is all well and good, there is also a more organic division of the individual measures around the priorities; next to better regulation, we want better implementation. There is too much bureaucratic elephantine, too many procedures in the last, too much outsourcing of work. We also need more transparency. But what I want to say basically about the content is that, if the implementation of the investment plan, named after you, Mr Juncker, is central and immediate, we must also tackle the issues of economic policy. There will be no investment and growth unless some things are corrected. This morning we had a very interesting debate on flexibility, the revision of the rules or implementation, with a different approach to the rules in force. We want to reassure you and I would like what was said in this morning's debate to be reflected in the Commission's first acts. With regard to the document on flexibility that we are all waiting for as a kind of post-Christmas cadeau, we want – I am speaking on behalf of my country, 40% of Italian voters have chosen my party, which has made a stronger proposal for a stronger Europe but a different Europe – a flexibility that is intelligent, that is, useful to the common objective of growth; we want good investment, good spending, therefore flexibility that helps GDP growth and not that it spoils public finances. Stop thinking about flexibility that goes into unnecessary public spending! There is talk of flexibility on investments, on the cofinancing of projects within the 2020 Agenda, on the cofinancing of the Projects of the Juncker Plan, on those of the Structural Funds. This debate must therefore already be contained in the commission's first acts. Then we want more social initiatives. We loved that triple A. We want to work for that. We want initiatives for culture, for the social economy, for the withdrawal of foundations and finally, in relation to the specific points, I would like to link up with those environmental objectives that my fellow Members have already mentioned.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Mr President, I put my trust in Mr Juncker in the election of this House and I put my trust in the Commission. But that trust was breached when I heard that the air quality package, the waste package and the circular economy would be withdrawn. However I got a new sense of hope when Mr Timmermans told us that it will be rewritten and reintroduced in some way. But patience is running thin and before we have a timetable on these issues we will start digging a hole of distrust between this House and the Commission. So these are really urgent issues. I put my trust in you because I think that you have the ability to actually change Europe towards more prosperity and a greener Europe. But I do hope that the aim of the Commission is not to strive for a black belt in abolishing environmental policies. (Applause)

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: Mr President, Mr Juncker, you said that you are in love with Europe. I invite you to come and visit with me an CIE, a social dining room or the melilla fence, and you will see how quickly you spend your infatuation. And now let's translate the work plan into a language that we can all understand. Let's see what's behind that work plan. Its work plan is the Free Trade Agreement with the United States, so that multinationals camp at their own devices. It's more cuts, more poverty and more unemployment. His work plan is the fracking and oil exploration of Commissioner Cañete. Its roadmap is the privatization of public services to turn our rights into market. His plan is more tax evasion, Juncker-style in Luxembourg. In short, new Commissioners, a new work plan for an old policy: the Titanic policy, which drowns the people while saving those travelling in first class. Mr Juncker, your work plan is the policies we're going to fight.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Mr. President! I would like to begin by thanking President Juncker and Vice-President Timmermans for discussing this work programme with us today. I very much welcome the fact that this programme includes concrete initiatives to contribute to the implementation of the Ten Commission priorities. It is important to stress that Europe needs to focus again on the big things, the big problems, and less on the small-scale ones. I would like to encourage you, as the Commission, today to fundamentally review the existing legislation and, in the end, also to have the courage to withdraw unnecessary legislative texts. Our citizens expect better regulation initiatives from us, and our businesses rightly expect us to be less bureaucracy, more proportionality and, above all, better access to finance and funding. That is why these Commission priorities are certainly a promising approach. I would like to highlight two priorities in the short ness. Firstly, as a new impetus to promote jobs, growth and investment, the investment package is certainly a very important and important stimulus here in order to restore confidence in the European economy as well. And then, of course, the deepening of economic and monetary union. In this regard, it will be crucial to press ahead with economic policy reforms in the Member States and to continue to focus on stability and the future in the evaluation of economic governance.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr Vice-President, the LuxLeaks case has gone through this and, fortunately, you are now committed to establishing taxation in the country where the profit is made. That is the announcement effect of your presentation today, your work program, but we need to shed more light on how you are going to move forward on this path, which is absolutely essential to us — that is why we applauded you. In the same spirit, we also expect initiatives to make country-by-country reporting a reality. It's an ancient claim to this house. It seems to us that it is even more topical today, but in that respect we have not heard anything. Then, with regard to this famous better regulation, we were afraid, because we understood that it could be used not to remove the hassle procedures, but to remove from the Commission's agenda the texts which displease the industry - this was clearly the case with regard to air pollution or the circular economy - or to the Member States - and this is clearly the case with the text on maternity leave. You have announced new prospects today, including a resumption of work on the circular economy. We would like to understand a little more what you have in mind, to ensure that this is a commitment to work together on this absolutely important mechanism, especially if we want to succeed in the Paris conference next year. Finally, you mentioned, by the way, the revision of the Copyright Directive and, again, we would like to be sure that this will bring this European creative industry to life, not just satisfy the appetites of a few multinationals across the Atlantic.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, mr. Juncker and his Commission's statements so far have instilled in me, I must say, instill confidence. I believe this is a fresh start, but I have to consider that the question is whether there will be any new chance.  I see three words, Mr Juncker, as crucial to your mandate: investment, development and growth. This is what your Commission will succeed or fail to do.  I believe in the need for an Energy Union. I believe in the need for a Digital Single Market that can even become Europe's fifth freedom. I believe in the circular economy and from the many ideas I have heard I want to believe that this Commission with that programme it has come forward with today, in synergy with member states, but also with regions, but also with cities, can take Europe forward. I wish you success along the way.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Junker, I too would like to ask you what you said on Friday about the vote in Greece. Alluding to Siriza, he denounced what he calls "extremists" by expressing his desideratum: "I would like to review the known faces" ("vertraute Gesichter"). When I read your programme, I said to myself that it must have been these well-known faces that drafted it. It is the faces that have led Europe to become impoverished and disintegrating. These are the faces that have conceived one of the most empty chapters of the programme: the one on immigration that I deal with in the Committee on Civil Liberties. The migrations are seen with yesterday's glasses, as if you had not noticed their metamorphosis. Today, mainly fugitives from wars or climate disasters migrate. Today we have a Mediterranean turned into an indecent mass grave. There is an urgent need for a review of our asylum rules, starting with the increasingly ineffective Dublin 3. There are many people who think of the new, including the new sins that Europe is tarnishing.  Are you convinced that new faces will help us face this reality?

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: I must first have something of the heart, Mr President of the Committee and Vice-President. Since the commission was installed some time ago, when it comes to environmental legislation, it has been as if that is that annoying legislation that gets in the way of activity, of people, as if that legislation is red tape. Well, I would like to convince you, if that is still necessary, that nothing less is true. Good legislation that we have on water, on air, on chemicals, has led to healthier living environments in Europe, more jobs and also much more innovation in our economy. Let us continue on that path.  Last week we were with some colleagues in Lima and the leaked document really came as a cold shower. We tried there in Lima – and you know the outcome – to take steps forward at world level in the fight against global warming.  And then it is as if in Brussels, thousands of kilometres further away, there is actually a reverse switch at that moment! Now, I have listened carefully, I want to be optimistic and I want us to support that from our group and possibly from Parliament. I have heard that new proposals on the circular economy and air quality are being worked on or amendments are being made to the existing proposals. So they are not off the table: in 2015 there will be a new proposal on the circular economy and there will be a proposal, whether or not amiced after some negotiations, on air quality. It is important that we give that support, but I am doing so under that condition. The ambitious targets on the circular economy and air quality must not be met and the proposals must be put forward in 2015 so that this Parliament and the Council can get to work to ensure that our economy really becomes more sustainable.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Dear Mr Juncker, I have read the whole programme of the Commission's work and, indeed, I have been very surprised. I'm really surprised at the magnitude of the mockery. The new Commission presents us with a programme based on the motto that everything will change, that new things will become new and new policies, but in reality everything is the same. I wonder if you have read the Commission's previous programme, to see what I am telling you – things based on thousands of failed policies, policies that have led Europe and our countries to crisis and peoples to impoverishment. What's new when your announcements about the European Fund for Strategic Investments of EUR 315 billion are not enough? is it based simply on so-called leverage? Isn't that in the same logic of neoliberal politics? Heavy-weight announcements for the EUR 315 billion that have been made in the last five years. of which 16 from the Community budget, 5 from the European Bank and the rest will rely on so-called leverage ratios to help whom? Ensure a safe environment for investment groups and monopolies. And, most importantly, will there be a process to go – if this money goes – to small and medium-sized enterprises? One last sentence, Mr President, if I may say so: I am very surprised that your Socialists were opposed during the election period to support you during your Presidency. If that wasn't funny... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Millions of Europeans today cannot find work or lose their savings during the crisis. We have dynamic, young people with a lot of potential, but their perspective is worse than ever, even at the expense of multinationals and tax fraudsters who are free to exploit differences in our tax systems. If we were to really fight tax havens and tax avoidance in Europe, we could invest around EUR 1,000 billion a year in the black hole, invest in youth employment, in investment for economic recovery, into empty national coffers. I believe that a huge majority of us here and in the general public see tax evasion as unfair and immoral evasiveness. The Commission and European governments are now among the first to promise to fight tax avoidance, but it is their ministers in Brussels who have blocked a series of tax-related legislation in the past. We in the European Parliament already proposed last year that mandatory reporting of operations be introduced for all multinationals in the countries where they are present. This would prevent them from paying only a few per cent of tax at the end of the year.  Even today, we need evidence of a bold, dynamic but reliable European Commission, so my New Year's wish is that people not only in my country, Slovenia, but across Europe, should follow and co-create European policies with the same enthusiasm as we did a decade ago and more. If we fail, it means that we have not learned any lessons from the past: whether it be tax fraud, the rise of extremism, nationalism in Europe or the dying of desperate people in the Mediterranean Sea, because, despite the tragedies, we do not have a comprehensive solidarity and asylum policy. And i just don't want that as a sure European. (The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card (Article 162(8)).

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – I wonder if you would agree with my football analogy on something. I believe that football is best played when the referee has a very light touch. He looks after the rules, he makes sure that there is no cheating and no foul play but he is not blowing his whistle every five minutes over the slightest thing. That way you can have a beautiful game; you can see things go well. With an economy, you can have a beautiful dynamic flowing economy and it can be a wonderful thing to see just like watching my home club Wolverhampton Wanderers is a beautiful thing to see in football. Would you agree?

name: Olli REHN
text: Ms Fajon, it sounds like the Commission press room in the good old days.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – I do not know, honourable colleague, if I have fully understood your question. I love football, I don't play it, but I know there's a lot of beautiful things in the sport that connects us, so I would like to see a lot of these sporting, healthy moments in Europe. And if I can take your comparison to what we can do better in the economy, for jobs and for growth, we can pull that parallel.

name: Paul TANG
text: President, for a good football game of course you need a level playing field. The Commission would like to be political and ambitious, and I would like to see that, because it is desperately needed to seize that last opportunity for Europe. The question is whether the work programme for 2015 shows that ambition. That is why I am asking the Commission for three points of attention. First, 'better regulation' should not get bogged down in a discussion about rules. Better regulation means for me and for us a better Europe, a Europe that is understandable to all. Environmental legislation is needed to move towards a sustainable economy, and that is in the interests of all. I am also pleased to hear that we can expect new proposals for air quality and circular economy this year. Secondly, LuxLeaks has shown that it is seriously wrong with the income tax in Europe. We are now calling for a Commission plan of attack with more public access through country-by-country reporting, a blacklist for companies and more regulation to eliminate unilateral tax arrangements. Thirdly, Jean-Claude Juncker has promised us a Europe that will become Triple A in the social field. This cannot be done without the complete revision of the Posting of Workers Directive and this essential point is still missing from the 2015 work programme ... (The speaker is interrupted by the President.)

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, you said that the Commission should focus on the essentials. Social protection is for me an essential right in Europe. In your work programme, you suggest that the issue of social dumping must be addressed within the framework of worker mobility and that the solution would be to combat abuse. But, Commissioners and Commissioners, social dumping is more than that: it is downright an attack on our European social system. It is the competition between workers, to which none of these workers wins. The best-protected workers are unemployed, while the least protected workers are exploited. SMEs are also not winners. Those in Europe who try to respect workers' rights are SMEs that are now bankrupt. Mr Juncker, neither you nor I were elected to destroy workers' rights or the fabric of SMEs in Europe. Therefore, the priority must, of course, be the revision not only of the Directive on the Detachment of Workers, but also of all the tools at our disposal to ensure that social protection in Europe is indeed a priority. The second point concerns maternity leave. We've talked about it before. I am delighted to see that the Commission will finally put this issue on the agenda and the Council intends to take its responsibilities. I would like to add that six months is not much: a pregnancy usually lasts nine months. I hope you will give us time to come up with a solution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Mr. President, Mr. Vice President, I would like to thank you for your support. I voted with high hopes for your Commission a few weeks ago because I believed that the programme would serve to kick-start the economy, to strengthen European competitiveness and to eradicate unemployment.  Do you know which sector is the third largest in Europe? The one that employs 20 million people? The one that gives most SMEs a job, an opportunity, a margin? It's tourism. And tourism didn't make it into the program plan, as it's not mentioned. I know that we have little to do with it from a legislative point of view. But if we are talking about a united Europe, a competitive Europe, we cannot forget it. If we are to solve the problem of youth unemployment, we must turn to this sector. We need to see that 50% of the world's tourism revenue is generated here in Europe. Why don't you take care of him? I offer my intention to assist as Vice-Chairman of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, former Hungarian Tourism Secretary and Chairman of the Tourism Committee at home. More than 100 of our fellow Members have signed up to the tourism integroup that is now being established. We will help, but let us be cooperative partners, put tourism back in its deserved place.  And I have another comment as a Hungarian: I wrote a letter to you last week, Mr Juncker, asking one of your Commissioners about his political involvement at home in an election campaign in breach of the Code of Ethics. In comparison, I have not received a reply from you, but I have received from your spokesperson a rather outrageous, simple communication to the Hungarian Telegraph Office. I ask that we take each other seriously, both on professional issues and on the issue of political institutional cooperation. Thank you very much, Mr. President.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Junker, Vice-President Timmerman, as chairman of parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy and on behalf of the coordinators of all the political groups, I would like to express to you my deep dissatisfaction, both personally and with my fellow Members, at the withdrawal of the legislative package on the circular economy and with the similar initiative on the air quality package. We have listened to your new proposal and what has just come out of the agencies on the improvement proposals that you will make. We wait to see them but if someone then also has the opportunity to come and explain to us what they will improve on, of course we will appreciate it. Mr Vice-President, we have invited you to the Committee on the Environment several times and we are still a waiting for your visit. It is clear that justifying the withdrawal of the package simply by the fact that no agreement was possible between the institutions, even before we had had the opportunity to examine it, certainly seemed ridiculous to us to say the least.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, it is only after two hours of debate that we come to talk about agriculture - 38% of the European budget. Better legislation is what the Commission has already begun to do, notably by simplifying a dossier on the distribution of fresh fruit and vegetables and milk in schools, so that it is more accessible and also includes educational measures around food. It's fundamental. As Parliament's rapporteur, I can tell you that the report has been tabled and is already being translated; it would have been a pity to remove it. The Commission's intention is apparently to maintain it and I would have liked clarification on that. The same applies to the regulation on organic agriculture: organic producers are asking for more protection against "false organic" and the import of 30% of organic consumption into Europe. The sector needs protection. I imagine that the Commission will not withdraw its draft rules. What about seeds? That is one of our expectations, in a case that we have pushed back. What is the Commission's intention in this regard? It would be essential to be able to give a clear signal to the agricultural sector, which is in great need of it today.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr Juncker, I am surprised to see you here! I thought you had gone to Athens to support your memorial political friends on the ground, since Mr. Moscovici, who you sent to Greece, has screwed up. With your recent statements you have expressed a political preference for certain politicians who are familiar to you, as you said, in view of the forthcoming general elections in Greece. Who do you think you are, Mr Juncker? The new man of Athens? Who gave you the right to intervene bluntly in the internal political situation of Greece? After all, are you President of the Commission or representative of the Troika and the lenders? So get it together, Mr Juncker! Observe the political neutrality imposed on you by the Treaty. Make the decision: You will drink the bitter glass, and you and your memorial political friends in Greece, because the Greek people will send you a message at the next general election. (Applause)

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: Mr President of the Commission, Mr Vice-President, we are talking here about the Commission's work programme for 2015. However, you wish to liquidate, once and for all, some environmental laws, such as air quality, recycling of waste in cities and the circular economy. Mr Juncker, I would like you to reassure us and tell us that the alleged attempt to repeal the directives to reduce air pollution caused by vehicles circulating in our cities and that you set a recycling target of 70%, as well as that you set a recycling target of 70% of waste in the European Union by 2030, is not serious and that you did not realize that your Vice-President had nailed this brave departure to you , you and all of us. Mr Juncker, You certainly know that there are already several Member States, including Germany and France, that have called on the Commission to maintain these two directives. What do you have to say about this and by the way, how will you manage the conflict that seems to have broken out between Mr Timmermans and the Environment Commissioner, who said last week that he would not allow the end of these two environmental directives?

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Mr President, Mr Juncker, one in three women in the European Union suffers from sexist violence. I have seen nothing, in your work priorities for 2015, to fight this scourge. Agriculture, fishing, the two legs of food sovereignty and still maintain many jobs in Europe; I haven't seen anything either. Small and medium-sized enterprises, zero. Poverty, hunger, social exclusion; nor have I seen anything in their priorities to fight this. Access to housing, or rather, prevent thousands of people from losing their home every day; nothing appears in their priorities either. Just as nothing appears about job precariousness, about the loss of social rights, which is increasing every day. Nor about the privatization of basic public services such as health and education. Is this out of your priorities, or have you forgotten to tell us what you're going to do?

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, years ago, a great man, Paolo Borsellino, said that politics and the Mafia are two powers that live on the control of the same territory: either they wage war or they come to an agreement. That the agreement often wins, the honest citizens of my city, Rome, are well aware of this, upset by an investigation that is becoming more serious from now on: 37 arrests, more than 80 suspects including politicians, cooperatives, journalists, the military and entrepreneurs. This is Mafia Capitale. This is organised crime, which is increasingly shrewd and ruthless. When you presented your programme, Mr President, you said that combating it is a European responsibility. It is time to move on from words to deeds. The anti-recycling proposal is useful, but it is not enough. If we do not introduce the crime of association with mafia-style crimes and incisive forms of confiscation throughout the Union, if we do not abolish banking secrecy and tax havens, if we do not punish trade votes and environmental crimes, then silence will eventually win and we will all lose. The mobster can no longer be a person who says he doesn't exist to people who say they don't know him. The silence of the institutions, Mr President, kills. Silence is mafia.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I will say my praise and thanks. Vice-President Timmermans said that if something is not mentioned, it does not mean that it is not important. I understand that this is about priorities, or the 2015 work programme – that is the right thing to say – but clearing the desk of these problems, not addressing these issues, does not mean that they are missing, much less solving them. We are here in Europe today at the turn of 2014/2015. We have difficult problems that affect the whole Union, which are facing the entire European Commission, the Council and Parliament. I am thinking here of the Russian embargo, the growing problems on the milk market due to the elimination of milk quotas, the threat to food security from the effects of African swine fever. It is reportedly envisaged to exclude from the work programme socially important proposals for organic production and school programmes. They are difficult, cumbersome, but, as I said, socially sensitive.  In conclusion, firstly, these problems should be addressed and should be included in the work programme and priorities for 2015. Secondly, I agree that it is time to simplify and reduce the number of pieces of legislation.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: Mr President of the European Commission, Commissioner, I would once again ask the European Commission to act pre-emptively on the milk sector. Faced with the end of milk quotas in 2015, the sector may face severe difficulties and high price volatility, often in areas where there is no other economic alternative.  I come from the Azores - which contributes 30% to milk production in Portugal - which are self-sufficient and exporters in this sector thanks to a strong individual investment in better technology and a rule-of-supply management that allowed us to get the return on this investment.  I call on the European Commission to have the political will to find viable solutions for regulating this market, so that any structural changes can be taken into account and that there is a need to anticipate the mishaps. At the level of marine management, I warn of the need to ensure that the delegated acts of the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund are actually used for the purposes mentioned therein and not for short-range expedients.

name: Olli REHN
text: I give the floor to First Vice-President Frans Timmermans who is responsible for better regulation. Our regulation is a maximum of five minutes. You have a great chance to practise what you preach and I trust no injury time. (End of catch-the-eye procedure)

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, it is still new for me to listen to your voice and not think you are passing judgement on the economy of a Member State. But I see you now in your new role, and I will certainly get used to it very quickly. I have little experience in the European Parliament, and I am learning very quickly. I was a member of a national parliament for many years. I was elected six times. You get used to the way of working in a national parliament, and now I have to get used to the way of working in the European Parliament, which is different. For instance, I would have loved to answer Mr Farage, but he apparently did not have the time to wait for our answer. This is something I am not really used to in a parliamentary debate, but apparently that is the way we do things here. Secondly, a document was leaked last week. President Juncker and I were very upset about that because it really does not help us to work very well. What happens is that it creates a huge row in the media and you all react to that. Even today, many of you went into that leaked document. I decided, with my parliamentary experience, not to react. I could have gone out immediately and said: ‘This is bogus. This is not what we are doing. We have a different line and we are going to take a political decision on how we work’. But, out of respect for Parliament, I did not do that because I thought that I need to present the Commission Work Programme in Parliament and not in the media. So you are always fighting with at least one arm behind your back if somebody leaks a document and you do not defend your position when everybody here reacts to a leaked document. I would ask you, if I show the respect which I think I need to show to Parliament to present our plans here, then please also listen to what I say and react to what I say – not to what you have read about a leaked document in the press. It would make our work a lot easier if we listened to each other. I try to listen to you. This is what we have decided as a Commission, and this is what we are going to do. Indeed, on the environment, we are going to – as I have said, very clearly – maintain some existing programmes. We are also going to have an overhaul of the waste package, but to make it complete in terms of the circular economy and to make sure that it can benefit from the opportunities that the Juncker plan will offer in terms of investment for the circular economy. We will not lower our ambitions. We will not do that. We will not lower our ambitions in terms of providing cleaner air to Europeans. We will not do that. But we will change some of the proposals on the table, because we believe that either they are creating an unnecessary burden and we can do better in terms of the quality of the regulation, or the Commission needs to assume its role as independent proposer of legislation seriously by trying to bring the other institutions together to really make a decision on the quality of air. That is our role. That is what we will do, but as part of a positive agenda – not by lowering our standards. Likewise, on social matters, it is of extreme importance for this Commission that we do bring things a step forward. I was asked about that particularly as regards the Commission Work Programme Labour Mobility Package. We want to support mobility and tackle abuse, because there is a lot of abuse and abuse does undermine freedom of movement in the European Union. We also want to allow workers to benefit from openings for jobs in other Member States if that is at their disposal. How will we do this? We will have an enhanced EURES database on vacancies throughout the EU; we will update the social security rules; we will ensure better implementation of the Posting of Workers Directive so that it cannot be used to abuse the rules; and there will be – as we have announced – a targeted review of the Posting of Workers Directive, starting in 2015, to ensure that there is no place for social dumping in the EU, because we see social dumping in the EU today. Just go and talk to people in the transport sector and they will tell you that. So this is where our ambition lies. If we talk about the position of women – and this is extremely important – we are not just talking about what is morally right: that I, as a father, can absolutely not accept that my two daughters are in a worse position on the labour market or in society than my two sons. This is unacceptable to me. But there are also clear economic reasons. We are hurting Europe’s economy because we do not create a level playing field for women in the labour market. So we need to move on these subjects, but we also need to be pragmatic about this. The proposal for a directive on maternity leave has – for many Member States – already been completely bypassed by reality. It has been on the table – blocked – for eight years, so Member States have taken steps that go beyond what is in the proposal. We want to improve the situation, and if that means that we can do it on the basis of this proposal, let the other institutions show us and we will facilitate it. But, if it means that this is not going anywhere and we are not improving the position of women in the labour market, we will take other initiatives to make sure that we do go forward on these issues. Had Mr Farage still been here, I would have said that on one point I actually do agree with him. It is good to have a debate on things we agree upon. I would have told him that he is right when he says that there is too great a burden EU-wide placed on small and medium-sized enterprises. We need to do something to lift that burden on small and medium-sized enterprises. If you lift the burden on small and medium-size enterprise, very quickly they will hire one, two or three extra people, and that is a direct contribution to fighting unemployment in the European Union. In that sense, I thought that Mr Farage, for once, really had a European spirit. I am sure that he was not on tranquilisers. He would then have told us exactly what he felt. I think that is what we have learnt from UKIP these days, but I also want to engage him in this debate on how we go forward to improve Europe. I have one final remark, since this was raised by many of you. Of course there are many important issues. But just because an issue is important, it does not mean that Europe then has to act upon that issue. If we want to improve the situation in the labour market, and if we want to improve the social situation in the Member States, this cannot come just from the EU. The EU has a role to play there, but it is just as important that Member States actually take steps forward. That is why I would propose that the Commission and the European Parliament make an extra effort to engage the Council in these debates, because many of these things will have to happen in the Member States. Therefore, Member States, represented in the Council, will have to be engaged if we are to take these few steps forward. Once again, we have prepared the Commission Work Programme and decided it today. We present it to you today, and, as far as I am concerned, this is the opening of a dialogue. It is not the final word from the Commission. We are willing to listen to you very carefully to make sure that we actually deliver on jobs, growth and the other priorities President Juncker agreed with the European Parliament when he was elected.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: Commission President. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to say that we will have to change the way we do things. I attended a meeting of committee chairs where everything was said and there was no conclusion. Frans Timmermans and I attended meetings of the Conference of Presidents. Today, I have the impression that these meetings never took place. In addition, we wanted to present the Commission's work programme to you instead of presenting it to the press. We don't comment on what we said, we comment...  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Olli REHN
text: Mr Buonanno, that is not appropriate behaviour in Parliament. Please remove the banner.

name: Olli REHN
text: President Juncker, I will convey your concerns about the working procedures and openness and transparency to the Bureau and to the Conference of Presidents. The debate is closed. The vote will take place in January. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. – The European Commission has adopted the work programme for 2015. Finally after so many fine words and announcements something concrete has been approved and work should begin. The 23 new initiatives that will have to be presented in 2015 to achieve the political objectives so trumpeted by Juncker are therefore awaited. The M5S will closely monitor and check without making any kind of discount to anyone that all promised targets will actually be achieved. In this respect, I very much doubt whether the EUR 315 billion will actually be put into the real economy as promised. On the other hand, with regard to achieving greater tax fairness in the EU, as well as the fight against tax evasion and fraud, I remain very sceptical about juncker's proclamations in the light of the recent Lux Leaks scandal. Finally, I will look very carefully at the package of rules aimed at achieving the digital single market, which should also contain a proposal to modernise copyright. In this regard, I will endeavour to ensure that the modernisation of copyright takes place in a way that involves citizens as much as possible and that the reform makes it possible to achieve the free movement of culture in Europe, while protecting authors, creators and consumers.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. – Dear President of the Commission, colleagues. It is quite difficult to assess in detail the work programme presented by the Commission in this debate, which has not yet been presented to us. You mentioned in your speech that next year's Commission work programme will build on the guidelines of the Commission's communication on investment. I fully agree that Europe needs investment that will enable projects of European interest to be implemented in the fields of energy, transport, the digital agenda, research and other very important areas, and I am pleased that we will already receive important proposals in these areas as early as next year. I welcome the commission's comprehensive plan to attract investment into the European Union, which will have to be adopted by the European Council in the coming days.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Written. – The Commission stresses that its work programme for the coming years is man-made in order to regain Europeans' confidence in Europe. Unfortunately, I believe that there is a lack of social aspects in this programme, and social policy, among all other priorities, seems only as an addition, even worse, as an administrative burden for the economic challenges of the single market. First of all, I would like to stress that we must strengthen the social dimension of the European Union. The Commission must pursue policies that help improve the daily lives of our people, especially those who have been hardest hit by the crisis and the consequences of austerity. After all, the recent elections have made it clear that there are a number of people who are dissatisfied with the EU, that people want change. Unemployment is still one of the most acute problems in the European Union. Currently, 25 million Europeans are unemployed. People must not only have a job, but also decent working conditions and fair wages. In the European Union, it is necessary to establish a living wage system that ensures that workers receive wages above the poverty threshold. Efforts must be taken to speed up the reduction of the pay gap between men and women in the same job. Eu legislation on working conditions needs to be improved in order to improve worker safety. The fight against poverty, especially child poverty, must be a priority for Europe as soon as possible.

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: in writing. – I am strongly disappointed with the Commission’s decision to withdraw the Circular Economy and air quality packages from its 2015 Work Programme. In a situation when an overhaul of EU waste and recycling laws could potentially generate up to 180 000 new jobs while saving 58 000 lives across Europe every year by improving air quality, the decision to withdraw these vital proposals is neither sustainable nor reasonable. Frans Timmermans left us with a promise that the withdrawn dossiers will be substituted with new ones, potentially easier to achieve. I worry this is a mere promise rather than the concrete delivery of results that EU citizens need. I also wonder whether ‘easier to achieve’ actually means less ambitious and that it will not address today’s problems of air pollution or unemployment. Fortunately, thanks to the mobilisation of European Socialists & Democrats, Parliament will express its discontent with Commission’s Work Programme in a resolution. We will not remain mute in the face of a European agenda based on deregulation and focused solely on the economy, with little or no space left for the concerns of the people and for the environment. The Commission is in grave danger of taking the wrong road.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I welcome Jean-Claude Juncker's intention to withdraw 83 out of 452 Commission legislative initiatives. Not every issue in Europe is also an issue for Europe. It is important to set priorities; the EU must once again give Member States more freedom.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. – I welcome the Commission's work programme for 2015. As the ECJ itself acknowledges, this is the beginning of a new period and ambitious plans. I wish you every success in this, and as a member of the new Parliament, I look forward to closer cooperation between the institutions.  In its work programme, the Commission mentions: "Citizens expect justice, protection, fairness and the rule of law from the EU and to take decisive action in the fight against all forms of discrimination." As a representative of the Hungarian community in Slovakia, I see every day what our voters want from us in the new period: a decent livelihood and conditions worthy of the preservation of their culture and language. And the latter requires the same attention as creating the right jobs or breaking down the burden of bureaucracy. Without guaranteeing and respecting the rights of EU citizens belonging to historical national minorities, which make up almost 10% of the Union, we will not be able to restore confidence in the EU. They have always been examples of European cooperation at local and regional level. I am convinced that the work programmes for the coming years should also include ideas to protect historical indigenous national minorities at European level.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: in writing. – Dear President Juncker, the Commission rightly points out that one of the biggest challenges we are facing in Europe is getting more people into work and ensuring that workers have the rights skills for the jobs of the future. I am looking forward to the Commission’s proposals on the measures to support these efforts, including the initiative on promoting integration and employability in the labour market. Whilst drafting its proposals, I encourage the Commission to take fully on board the Parliament’s suggestions on creating a competitive EU labour market for the 21st century, which we will start working on early next year. Thank you!

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – The Commission Work Programme 2015 is written in the same vein as the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. This rhetoric does not work, but on the contrary, people continue to lose confidence in the European institutions and in the EU as a whole. This new boost for jobs, growth and investment, which the Commission is talking about, is more than imperative, but if the right measures are not implemented and the problems so far are not resolved, the result will be disastrous. Smart, sustainable and inclusive growth means only one thing – special attention must be paid to the poorest regions in the EU because their problems extend across the EU. People are fleeing these regions not for anything else, but to survive. There's no job, no perspective, no future. This is the first reason for mass migration, which creates social tensions in the Member States and calls into question freedom of movement. If the Commission's efforts do not concentrate on the poorest regions but continue to serve the interests of certain Member States, I would not be surprised if there is even more mass migration and depopulation of entire regions. From there, there is no return and we will face even bigger problems that will not call into question any particular policy and the EU itself will be at risk.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – I fully agree with the Commission's objective of sensible legislation. Like citizens, I expect the Commission to present solutions to key economic and societal challenges, such as combating unemployment, improving energy security or competitiveness. And in areas where Member States are able to act more effectively due to their situation, the EU should be less involved in people's daily lives.  I welcome the Commission's withdrawing of its proposals on school milk and school fruit, the air quality package and the production and trade in seeds and propagating material. Existing EU legislation in these areas is working properly and citizens should not be burdened with new, more complex rules.  I am particularly pleased that the Commission is willing to fundamentally amend its proposal on organic farming, as requested by the Council and Parliament. Finally, I think it is important that simplification and rationalisation efforts affect as many important regulations as possible. Significant easing will be needed in the area of greening, in particular in the regulation of areas of ecological importance. In assessing the Common Fisheries Policy, every single action must be made to prioritise environmentally friendly closed-system freshwater aquaculture as an excellent example of green farming. And we need to support renewable energy production much more strongly than we do now if we are to achieve long-term energy security in the EU.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. Europe needs a fresh start, a paradigm shift, because the challenges we now face must be addressed in a different way than in the past. A fresh start is urgently needed: Jean-Claude Juncker has sent out an important first signal by announcing that certain pieces of legislation will be withdrawn in the future. This is a step in the right direction. The next step is to propose concrete measures and, above all, to cooperate more in a more coordinated manner with the European Parliament. One thing is clear - the new work programme for 2015 also needs more transparency and proximity to the citizens. The Commission has defined job creation and growth as key priorities. These must be in key areas such as the Digital Single Market, the creation of an Energy Union and energy efficiency. It is precisely here that there is great potential to create sustainable and ecological jobs. I expect Jean-Claude Juncker to align his EU investment package accordingly. Finally, we also need to tackle current hotspots and the worrying situation in the Middle East. By developing the European Neighbourhood Policy, the EU can and must act as a global player and speak with one voice. We must not miss this new start for Europe - the Socialist Group will be particularly vigilant to ensure that this change actually happens.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. Just this morning we received guidelines for the 2015 work programme from the Commission. Although we support the objective of rationalising political priorities, there are still a number of doubts as to method and substance. The withdrawal or amendment of 76 pending proposals, often because they are considered obsolete, appears in many cases to be justified more by political reasons – such as the deadlock in the negotiations or because the outcome of the negotiations deviates too far from the Commission's original proposal – than by a genuine plan of effectiveness and concreteness. It would not be comprehensible because proposals – with the express reason for the difficulty of reaching an agreement – such as those on the labelling of biological products and the registration of radioactive material, have been excluded. And even more hype has been the removal of proposals for complex and long-awaited regulations such as on waste and air quality. This is certainly not the way for Europe to give its citizens a sign of a turning point and a new impetus, and we therefore call on the Commission to have more ambition and more advanced legislative proposals on employment and environmental sustainability.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. – The European Commission's main priority in its work programme for 2015 should be to promote economic growth and job creation. To this end, the investment plan presented must be carefully managed in order for it to fulfil its role of attracting private investment and not to remain on a mere wish list. In addition to promoting austerity, which is unfortunately necessary to counteract the excessive indebtedness of our economies, the European Union must lead economic revival efforts. Another essential measure that citizens want to see in 2015 are proposals to converge the tax laws of the Member States with the aim of avoiding new cases of tax engineering that allow large companies to pay less tax than SMEs. The Commission's work programme contains good proposals, such as promoting a single digital market and an energy union, or reducing bureaucratic hurdes, but the priority should be to make the investment plan an effective lever for growth and promote fair and equitable fiscal legislation.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – I am convinced that, in the medium to long term, the European economy can be boosted by research and development, innovation, education development, and therefore knowledge. I find it disappointing that R&D and innovation have only been mentioned once in the European Commission's work programme in 2015: support for these activities is one of the EU's ideas, an initiative that I share to a large extent. More disappointingly, R&D and innovation are also stepchildren in the Commission's investment promotion package, which has just been announced. Moreover, a larger amount has been transferred from the already operational R&D development support programme (Horizon 2020) to the strategic fund, which still has a rather uncertain outcome. With this transfer, we are reducing predictability in an area where the existence of resources is key due to multiannual, long-running projects.  I propose that the European Commission pay particular attention to European R&D and innovation activities in its work, since the further development of our skills and capabilities in this area is essential for the re-induction of Europe.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I hope that enhanced cooperation between the Commission, the Council and Parliament will take place not only at the stage of agreeing on priority initiatives, but also during their implementation and evaluation. I believe that boosting growth and investment, and thus creating new jobs, has rightly been identified as one of the priorities. The problem of high unemployment is the result of the economic crisis. As a consequence, a policy of austerity was introduced, which in the following years allowed for the consolidation of public finances. However, it is high time to increase investment. EU entrepreneurs expect simplified regulation, access to markets and support in the form of loans, guarantees and grants. I am therefore pleased that these elements have found their place in the Commission's work plan for the coming year and also in the 2020 perspective. I hope that not only the new Strategic Investment Fund, but also cohesion policy funds will actively contribute to their implementation.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. – These set piece debates always come full of political rhetoric and complete with vision for the future. The Commission’s work must however be judged by their actions, not their words, and only time will tell whether the new College of Commissioners have a real plan for Europe. The Commission promises a forward looking climate change policy but then withdraws proposals on air pollution. Europe must take a holistic approach on the environment and we will be watching the Commission carefully in this area. The Commission argues for a reasonable and balanced trade deal with the US but, again, the devil will be in the detail. The concerns over TTIP are real, and any deal which jeopardises Europe’s public services will be rejected in this House. Finally, the Commission calls for a Union of democratic change. My own country is going through democratic changes at the moment and the EU should take note of what is going on there. The people of Scotland are increasingly disenchanted with Westminster rule and we are on a journey to reclaim control over our destiny. The EU too often seems remote and the Commission must acknowledge this reality to retain popular legitimacy.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – It is of great concern that the new Commission has withered draft legislation essential for sustainability, including the circular economy package and the air quality regulation plan, as well as drafts for the revision of the Energy Tax Directive.  The withdrawal of the draft on the circular economy, improving resource efficiency and recycling of waste is also appalling because it was drawn up in a serious social consultation and would serve the long-term interests of both the public and economic operators. The waste targets would also create around 500 000 new jobs, stimulate innovation, substantially reduce adverse effects on human health and the natural environment, and significantly reduce the demand for rare raw materials, according to the grounding studies, the impact assessment and the Commission's own communication. The move has been opposed by a number of organisations and Member States, and the seriousity of the matter is indicated by the fact that the Council of Ministers, under pressure from 23 Member States, has put the issue on the agenda of tomorrow, under pressure from the Italian EU Presidency. The withdrawal of the proposals is also a concern because it is not clear what criteria the new version will be based on. This is not only a package of measures that is not capable of restoring confidence, but also does not fulfil the condition of transparency. The lack of transparency and following the orders of some business operators, in the light of the Luxleaks case concerning Juncker, raises serious questions about whose interests this Commission also represents.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: , in writting. –  Three crucial points: boosting investment, conducting structural reforms, exercising fiscal responsibility. The proposed investment package is an innovative initiative in a situation where member states continue to refuse any additional money for the EU budget. The Commission has made the best of situation, to generate the climate of trust for the private investors. Just because of that, we expect from the same member governments a concerted and active support, not hesitations and excuses. We also need commitment to better regulation. Regulatory Fitness programme should become instrumental to cut red tape and remove regulatory burdens. To generate digital single market, I urge to introduce, as soon as possible, EU´s digital signature and digital authentication, and, by removing national obstacles, to create a functioning European space for digital interconnections. And - once again - to simplify and harmonize consumer rules for online and digital purchases. In this regard, I especially welcome the planned copyright review that is long overdue and has to be adapted to the principle of single and digital single market and borderless Europe. We eagerly look forward to Commission's new proposals, promised by next year.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "In 2015, we all want to boost investment, growth and new jobs. To achieve this, the Commission should propose a coherent, complementary action plan to increase the Union's competitiveness. Two of its main parts should be the Investment Plan and the lessons learned from the review of the Europe 2020 strategy. President Juncker's investment package is a good starting point for boosting Europe's investment potential, but its success depends m.in. on the involvement of private investors, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises. We also need more synergies between m.in programmes between the Structural Funds and Horizon 2020. Although it is possible to combine funding under the programmes, it is not sufficiently practiced. More assistance is therefore needed for potential beneficiaries whose projects can be achieved through support from different sources of funding. Such projects both contribute to innovative solutions as well as to increasing economic and social cohesion. Furthermore, in view of the forthcoming review of the implementation of the Bologna Process in 2015, I hope that, as a member of the monitoring group for the implementation of this process, the Commission will propose concrete proposals to increase its importance and further development. In this context, I ask the Commission to pay particular attention to the social aspects of the creation of the EHEA and, in particular, to making studies more accessible to candidates from all social groups.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: writing – Tax evasion and tax fraud are preparing EU Member States for €1000 billion a year. This is EUR 2000 for each EU citizen. These leaks contribute to the indebtedness of states, to an increase in unemployment and to an increase in the risk of poverty. Half of the world's financial operations flowed through tax havens before the crisis. This money is very lacking in dealing with the crisis and employment. I therefore welcome the Commission's commitment to present a proposal for measures to combat tax evasion and tax fraud within six months. I expect The President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, to deliver on his commitment made in July - to prepare measures so that profits are taxed in the country where these profits are generated.

name: Marek PLURA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I welcome the fact that in the 2015 Work Programme the Commission has put emphasis on creating conditions conducive to employment, skills, mobility and the strengthening of the internal market. In its Citizenship Report in 2013, the Commission proposed 12 concrete actions to help Europeans better exercise their rights, m.in. the introduction of m.in European Disability Card, mutually recognised by the Member States. Thanks to the Charter, persons with disabilities could take full advantage of the facilities and privileges offered to this group of citizens in each country. The Charter would certainly contribute to greater mobility, fuller access to education and work abroad. The introduction of this document, as before the Parking Card for people with disabilities, is an example of a relatively simple action that will improve the situation of a very large group of Europeans. One in six EU citizens is disabled. It is in the union's entire interest to remove barriers blocking the economic and social potential of this group. The draft Charter is fully in line with the Commission's strategic objectives, so I would like to express my hope that in 2015 there will be significant progress on the introduction of the European Disability Charter.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Writing. I am very pleased with the priorities in the Commission's work programme for 2015! It is very positive that the Commission intends to face up to the major challenges facing the European Union in 2015. I am personally pleased with the focus on migration and refugee policy. Finally, the Commission has recognised the need for a common migration and refugee policy in Europe. I am well aware that we cannot solve the refugee problem on our own, but we can try to improve some aspects! One example is poverty migration. The European Union has the means and the tool to combat this poverty migration within Europe more strongly and in a more targeted way. Cohesion policy, which has around a third of the budget, will allow us to tackle poverty migration. It is precisely in this area that I will closely monitor the work of the Commission and that of cohesion policy and, if necessary, point out grievances, but also positive developments!

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. – The internal market is one of the pillars of the development of the European economy, an instrument for greater employment, sustainable growth and investment. At the same time, as Social Democrats, we always add in one breath that high social and environmental standards and consumer protection policies are an integral part of its development. I therefore believe that the Commission, in its work programme for 2015, will take this holistic approach to the internal market into account when presenting concrete initiatives. From a consumer perspective, I consider the priorities of the next 12 months to be, among other things, to reach agreement on a package on consumer product safety and market surveillance and to effectively combat any form of discrimination against consumers within the internal market. We must pay close attention to the specific content of the Commission's ambitious digital single market package, including an assessment of the societal impacts of digital development.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: written.– It is not easy to create a single recovery, investment and growth plan for a common Europe. The Commission's work programme responds to the most serious problems, such as unemployment, poverty, the fight against fraud, cutting red tape, cutting spending or the problem of migrants. Everything cannot be done at once, but I believe that better cooperation between the various Members of the Commission will make the Commission's work more effective and that the promises made in its election will gradually be fulfilled. The work programme presents targeted measures and focuses on specific objectives. Achieving them will also depend on better coordination of national policies. Prime Ministers cannot say one thing in their countries and do something different at a joint Council meeting. Only a common policy, common measures have a chance of success. It is time we did not divide Europe into richer north and poor south, more developed Western countries and less developed Eastern European countries. A common Europe is also about solidarity and reducing regional disparities, and the Commission's work plan for 2015 can eliminate this.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - The new way of electing the European Commission has changed the institution's attitude towards the European Parliament. Dialogue with Parliament and better communication will help bring Europe closer to citizens. Ten of Juncker's priorities are expected, but citizens expect them to be implemented even more on the ground. In particular, I welcome the reduction of bureaucracy and the necessary balance between growth, social benefits and environmental care. Subsidiarity, competitiveness and tax justice are topics that I particularly support in the work of the Juncker Commission, but also cheap energy and new technologies. The most important thing is that the laws are fit for purpose, that there is no overlap and that they contribute to the basic goal, which is to create new jobs. In particular, I welcome the announcement of the Automatic Data Sharing Directive, which will ensure tax avoidance. I see the investment plan as ambitious and achievable if Member States participate seriously in it.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: I support all measures relating to investment and job creation, but these measures will not be successful as long as there is such a level of tax fraud and evasion in the European Union. Estimates are known to all, but this double circle should be supplemented by the issue of overtrawing, which is also an obstacle to economic development. In Hungary, for example, indirect food VAT is 27%, and additional special taxes are added to it. As a result, traffic has decreased noticeably and operators are forced to resort to legal avoidance techniques. Another example from my country is that the overtrawing of tobacco products and the overhaul of the tobacco distribution system have caused a 40% reduction in turnover, which can be explained and demonstrated by the increase in the turnover of black market products. I urge the European Commission to address these issues in its work programme. My question to the Commission is whether it plans to take further steps in the area of tax harmonisation and will it also bring these steps into its work programme for 2015?

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing.. – The European Commission led by Jean Claude Juncker has created a positive expectation in those who want to see the European Union as a benchmark of economic, social and environmental sustainability in the globalisation in which we live. The program presented today is disappointing. Change commitments are vague, unquantified and insufficiently timed. One of the main problems of the European Union is the inability to mobilise its citizens for a civilizational challenge. The program presented does not have the necessary mobilizing force. It is a defensive program, without daring, without ambition and without transparency. In the European Union we have had great proclamations in recent years with no practical consequences. It is hoped that this, on the contrary, being a loose program on paper, will prove to be a good surprise in the execution.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the joint debate on   –  the report by Eider Gardiazabal Rubial and Monika Hohlmeier, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the Council position on the new draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 (16739/2014 – C8-0287/2014 – 2014/2224(BUD)) A80067/2014), – the report by Gérard Deprez, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 3/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission (16740/2014 – C8-0289/2014 – 2014/2036(BUD)) (A8-0069/2014), – the report by Gérard Deprez, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 4/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission (16741/2014 – C8-0290/2014 – 2014/2053(BUD)) (A8-0076/2014), – the report by Gérard Deprez, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 5/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission (16742/2014 - C8-0291/2014 – 2014/2073(BUD)) (A8-0078/2014), – the report by Gérard Deprez, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 6/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission (16743/2014 – C8-0288/2014 – 2014/2162(BUD)) (A8-0074/2014), – the report by Gérard Deprez, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 7/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission (16744/2014 – C8-0292/2014 – 2014/2163(BUD)) (A8-0072/2014), – the report by Gérard Deprez, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 8/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission (16745/2014 – C8-0293/2014 – 2014/2225(BUD)) (A8-0079/2014), – the report by Gérard Deprez, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilisation of the Contingency Margin, in accordance with point 14 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management (COM(2014)0328 – C8-0020/2014 – 2014/2037(BUD)) (A8-0068/2014), and – the report by Gérard Deprez and Janusz Lewandowski, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1150/2000 implementing Decision 2007/436/EC, Euratom on the system of the European Communities’ own resources (COM(2014)0704 – C8-0250/2014 – 2014/0332(NLE)) (A8-0066/2014).

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, yes, the truth is that we have accumulated our work in the Committee on Budgets a little bit and that is why today we have so many reports to discuss and tomorrow we have to vote. The truth is that little or nothing would foreshadow that we were going to reach an agreement in time for the 2015 budget or for the much-needed 2014 amendings. And this has been thanks to the work and involvement of many of the people who are here today, in this House. And that is why I would like to begin my speech by thanking Commissioner Georgieva and her entire team, the Italian Presidency, mainly with Ambassador Sannino at the helm, and also all my colleagues, because we have worked hard over the last few months to reach this agreement. He said that nothing would foreshadow that we had an agreement in time because the positions were far between the Council's initial proposal and Parliament's proposal, but also far between the members of the European Council themselves, among the 28 countries themselves. They were distant postures. There were institutional misgivings between institutions, between countries, doubts in the figures and, moreover, money in between, which is the budget. And so we had an explosive cocktail on the table. Three main issues that we had to solve: how to end 2014, how to deal with 2015 and, above all, a plan to solve the defaults in the medium term. I don't think anyone is satisfied with the outcome of the negotiation. And of course, I, as rapporteur, can say that I am not.
