Neither by the figures nor by the functioning of the negotiations or by the lack of political content in the debate. But I also know that, after a whole year of work to reach this agreement and to achieve a budget, the last proposal we had on the table, and which today is what I am asking you to support tomorrow with your vote, is the best agreement we have been able to achieve. Because that agreement puts 4.7 billion euros more to pay for programs that were already implemented. That is, EUR 4.7 billion more for NGOs, so that they can continue to bet on those who need it most, for SMEs, so that they can continue to finance key projects for economic recovery, or for farmers who have been affected by the Russian veto, for our town halls and for our regions, so that they can continue to care for citizens. And because in the end, that is what a budget is about, in this European case: to serve citizens; either through scholarships, through infrastructure improvements or by providing quality food; helping five million refugees in the Middle East or supporting an innovative project by small and medium-sized enterprises; financing food banks or collaborating with projects against female genital mutilation or ablation. That's what the budget is all about. And in order for these projects to continue to be funded, we have fought from the European Parliament. Because the alternative to this was non-agreement. It was not having a budget for 2015. It was to miss the opportunity to use that extra EUR 4.7 billion thanks to revenue not provided for in the Union budget. A non-agreement would have jeopardized the investment programme which the European Commission has just presented to us, because it is 100 per cent based on the European budget. We know that that 4.7 billion is not enough, because the problem of defaults is greater. And that is why we have placed so much emphasis on seeking a commitment from the Council to be able to work since the beginning of 2015 on a real plan to tackle this problem. A plan that should go to the source of the problem. Because the Union does not have a spending problem: it is only 1% of gross domestic product. We have an income problem. And the solution is not to cut payments or reduce the budget. The solution is to increase the Union's own resources and therefore reduce national contributions. I regret that the financial transaction tax is currently frozen because no agreement has been reached in Ecofin. That is why I believe that the High Level Group of Own Resources is more necessary than ever, in order to provide resources for a strong, properly funded budget and, above all, to the protection of purely accounting sterile discussions. That's what we really need for the future.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Rapporteur. - (DE) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I also greet the Presidency of the Council. First of all, I would like to begin by thanking you very much.  I believe that we, as a delegation team – our committee chairman Arthuis, my colleague, who has just defended the Commission House again and helped to defend the European Union budget, my colleague Jose-Manuel Fernandez, Mr Deprez – have really succeeded in working together in a marathon of negotiations to get a budget through which the coordinates were not easy with God. I would like to thank you from the heart for the great cooperation and the huge commitment. Secondly, i would like to thank the Commissioner, who fought with her team to get this budget through, and then an Italian Presidency, where there were difficulties at the beginning, but then everyone pulled together to achieve the result, which may not be optimal, but which at least points a way forward. Firstly, when I come to the other institutions, I am grateful that we can finally bring together the general administrative costs for the European External Action Service, finally be able to bring together transparently and sensibly, that we have agreed at the ECJ that we will finally seek a solution for the new judges, and thirdly, that we should also be able to achieve the whole rate of reduction, for the ECJ, for the EEAS. , have raised sensibly for the two committees again, and that we, as A Parliament, have also achieved synergy effects with the Economic and Social Committee and with the Committee of the Regions in cooperation, in fact what we have set out to achieve. In other words, the problems in the other institutions were not as great as in the Commission." In the area of the Commission, the old invoices have really plagued us the most, and I would like to say one thing above all: it is not acceptable that, at the end of the day, with the new budgets that we have, we should then, for the most part, only pay old invoices, and that, in doing so, we have actually developed the programmes that we have recently developed for months, some of them over two years. , which must start successfully, put the brakes on, artificially stop them, so that we are still able to guarantee the deadline for payment. This is a situation that is unacceptable. That is why I think it is a great success that we want to discuss the payment plan and the implementation guarantee of the multiannual financial framework together at least once and also to seek a solution for this. I hope that the Council and the Member States will be more present in these meetings – and I say this very clearly – than in the committee that we wanted together on the agencies, the analysis of their tasks and then the corresponding financial resources. I would really like to warmly invite the Council to take seriously the issue of the payment plan plus the implementation of the new programmes, because we want to move forward in this European Union.  The European Parliament has not been prepared to just demand more in a restorative way, but we have really met you and dealt with you and have also met you in some difficult situations. On the other hand, however, we would also like you to be equally accommodating to the legitimate concern that old bills must be paid, that they cannot be left behind and that the European Union should not be at fault, because that should also be your concern.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, at the beginning of the negotiations, the European Parliament, through the Committee on Budgets, had set three objectives. The first objective was to stabilize - if not be able to reduce - the worrying, if not unsustainable, level of unpaid bills: 5 billion in 2010, nearly 25 billion at the end of 2014. First priority, therefore, to stabilize the unpaid. The second objective was to resolve the dispute between us and the Council - and the Council alone, for that matter! - regarding the budgetary status of special instruments, particularly for payments. The third objective, a key objective, was to agree with the other two institutions on the urgency of implementing a plan to clear unpaid bills to limit the amount to a sustainable level. What can we now draw from the long weeks of negotiation that we have had? I should point out that 'negotiation' is a somewhat inappropriate term, since at most meetings we have had to hear the Council say that it is not in a position, unfortunately, to reach a common position. With regard to the balance sheet and, first of all, the payment appropriations, the agreement provides for 2014 - and for 2014 only - an additional fresh money - fresh money as they say - of 3.529 billion, or two thirds of what we originally demanded. I should point out that we have committed ourselves to asking for what the Commission considered necessary - namely 4.7 billion in 2014 - to prevent the situation from deteriorating with regard to the amount of unpaid bills. With regard to the budgetary status of special instruments, the dispute between the Council's position on the one hand and that of the European Parliament and the Commission on the other, could not be resolved favourably. While a temporary, seemingly neutral solution could be retained for EUR 350 million of unused margin credits, the substantive issue has not been decided. With regard to the plan to clear the growing amount of unpaid bills, an agreement, which I consider to be genuinely positive, has been reached. The Commission will have to submit an updated assessment of the total amount of outstanding payments in March 2015 and propose other scenarios. The three institutions will commit to implementing a plan. And I will quote this sentence, which sums up the commitment we are asking the Council to formalise before us: "This plan will be validated by the three institutions in due course before the presentation of the draft budget 2016". In short, as is taken as a whole, the agreement reached between the two branches of the budgetary authority is, in our view, acceptable and deserves to be supported, as the Committee on Budgets did on Monday evening by a very large majority. Having said that, Madam President, I cannot ignore a few small mediocrities: 30 million here, 11 million there, in terms of redeployment, which the Council has made a point of granting one or the other of the recalcitrant Member States. This mediocrity does not grow, in my opinion, its authors. Nor can I forget the Council's obsession with access to the requests of either Member State to spread the supplement due under the reassessment, which it had accepted, of their GNI. A text is presented to us on this subject, of which I am co-forward with Mr. Lewandowski; I will leave it to him to present this text, which I will vote without raising an eyebrow because it is part of the agreement, although I think of the verbal gestures of the honourable Prime Minister who is at the origin of this misstep. I still had a lot to say, Madam President, but I reserve them for the last two minutes.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: Rapporteur. - (C) Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Dear Kristalina! This week we are finalising a very difficult process of budgetary arrangements for the period 2014-2015, as part of the european Union's own resources regulation, as expressed by the European Parliament. I do not envy the participants of the concination, in which I did not participate for the first time in ten years. But I do not envy because there is always some additional circumstance of these negotiations, an element of the annual budget. Last year, it was the link between the annual budget and the arrangements for the 2014-2020 financial perspective. This year, this additional circumstance was a change in the calculation of payments based on gross national income and VAT, which also complicated the negotiations.  But from year to year there is one and the same problem, namely the draft budget of the European Commission is not an idea of the Commission, it does not come from a vacuum. It is a down-and-down, conservative assessment of estimates coming from 28 countries. Hence the frustration in the final negotiations, when this conservatively verified sum is then challenged by the Member States in the final negotiations. This year, an additional circumstance was indeed a significant change in the calculation base of gross national product and VAT, which for some countries meant good news – they had overpayment, for others bad news – they had underpayment. In the case of the United Kingdom and the Netherlands, these were large sums of money.  This problem was so absorbed by the Member States that by the end of the formal deadline for negotiations they were unable to reach their position, but at the same time they expected Parliament to have an urgent procedure, a hasty procedure for expressing an opinion. We have noted this paradox – on the one hand – of the budgetary delay and, on the other hand, of the desired haste, recognising the opinions and the amendment to the own resources regulation as part of the final budgetary arrangement. Today we have an agreement for the period 2014-2015 and we also have a positive opinion on the amendment to the own resources regulation. However, we are introducing two amendments to the regulation in the name of transparency of the financial and budgetary situation of the European Union, namely the mandatory notification to the European Parliament of late payments and the result for the European budget.  At the same time, we do not renry critical remarks about the budgetary procedure itself, and that is the content of legislative resolution. Namely, we draw attention to the fact that these statistical changes have been made by the Member States themselves, and in some cases this makes it easier for them to settle differently with the European Commission. The iron rule – as I pointed out – has so far been to make additional payments within 1 December. On the other hand, countries that are extremely inflexible and do not make any facilitation of the budgetary procedure have called for ease and flexibility, and in fact are also leaders in cuts in those budget lines that are clearly linked to the competitiveness of the economy, job creation and growth. This does not simplify the European Union's own revenue system. This complicates the system more, so the ultimate element of our parliamentary position is to recognise the High-level group on own resources to actually look at the system. The Committee on Budgets voted on this last week. We expect to complete the formalities in tomorrow's vote.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, Honourable Members of Parliament, Vice-President Georgieva, ladies and gentlemen, it is an honour for me to speak during today's plenary session for the debate on the political agreement reached by the Council and the European Parliament on the European Union budget for 2015 and the amending budget package for 2014. The Council has already formalised its agreement on 12 December and we look forward to the outcome of the European Parliament's vote tomorrow. As you know, the agreement was reached in a particularly complex negotiating context because of the many issues we have had to address. I believe that, never before have there been so many amending budgets to be adopted, and I also believe that we have never had to draw such a high level of unpaid invoices from the European Union, which has engaged us in an intensive debate at the end of which we have agreed, in agreement with the Commission too, to set in motion a path which will allow us to continue along the same path. , in the coming years, will enable us to bring the European Union's indebtedness back to more acceptable and sustainable levels. There were different points of view on how to reduce the level of non-payments and late payments and I believe that, in the end, we found a good compromise. I am therefore sure that the European Parliament also agrees that allocating AN EXTRA EUR 3.5 billion to the 2014 cash allocations is an important result for the functioning of the European Union, since the growth in the stock of bills to be paid is being put an end to and, at the same time, the foundations are being laid for its gradual absorption in the years to come. Specifically, the total amount for 2015 is 2 818 million euros, by activating the margin for unforeseen events, EUR 361 million resulting from the use of the margins available in relation to the expenditure ceilings in the 2014 budget and a further EUR 350 million, relating to the so-called special instruments that are added to the margin for unforeseen events, postponing to a later stage an agreement between our institutions on whether or not they should be included in the expenditure ceiling. I believe that this amount represents a fair balance between the public finance constraints to which the Member States are subject and the financial needs of the European Union for the implementation of its spending programmes. As regards the 2015 European Union budget, a total of €145.3 billion is foreseen in commitment appropriations, +1.8% compared to the amended 2014 budget, €141.2 billion in payment appropriations, +1.6% on the amended 2014 budget. The amount of appropriations thus identified allows sufficient margins to be left under the ceilings of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, to allow the European Union sufficient room for manoeuvre to respond to any unforeseen events. I am convinced that in these terms the 2015 budget will guarantee the necessary resources for the intelligent and effective implementation of the new programmes, given that this is the second annual budget, under the new Financial Framework 2014-2020. Just to give a few examples, I would like to highlight the payments for heading 1a (Competitiveness for Growth and Employment), where resources are allocated to research, training and small and medium-sized enterprises, which are growing by 33%, or EUR 3.9 billion, compared with the 2014 budget, including the adjustments made. The Eu ropean Union's foreign policy budget also received a significant increase in payment appropriations of around 8.5%. Other increases include additional resources granted in the area of external border control and migration flows, as well as newly established financial supervision agencies. As far as agricultural policy is concerned, the demands of the operators in the sector affected by the Russian embargo on EU agricultural products have been accepted, which will receive additional support financed from the increased revenues at specific destination, without therefore affecting the reserve for agricultural crises, which will remain available for any additional needs that may arise during 2015. I believe that these results should also be assessed in the light of the extremely short timetable we have had at our disposal to define the European Union budget for next year. After the lack of agreement in the conciliation procedure on 17 November, the Commission presented a new 2015 budget proposal and, on 28 November, proposed a new compromise on pending amending budgets for 2014. Nevertheless, we have managed to reach an agreement on 8 December in time to be able to allow it to be adopted before the end of the year and therefore to avoid the use of provisional twelfths at the beginning of 2015. The negotiations have therefore been very intensive and the achievement of the agreement is an extremely positive sign of the ability of our two institutions to find the necessary intense in the interests of our citizens. I would like to express once again my satisfaction with the results achieved and thank all the parties involved in the negotiations. In particular, I would like to thank President Arthuis, as well as the three rapporteurs, Mr Gardiazabal, Mr Hohlmeier and Mr Deprez, who have worked hard in the negotiations and have taken a constructive and cooperative attitude when necessary. I would also like to thank Vice-President Georgieva and his team for facilitating the successful conclusion of the negotiations with great impartiality.  I will conclude by expressing my conviction that the agreement reached with Parliament represents a perfectly consistent response to the three crucial challenges facing us next year: continuing to reduce the backlog of unpaid bills, not compromising the efforts made by the Member States to consolidate national finances and providing the necessary resources and incentives to promote economic growth and the creation of new jobs with benefits for all European citizens.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, thank you for the opportunity to address Parliament before tomorrow’s vote on the Draft Amending Budgets for 2014, the budget for 2015, and also on the Opinion on the amendment to Regulation No. 1150/200. I think we can all agree here that these have been particularly difficult negotiations. This is the first year of the new MFF. We have put into practice what has been designed for the MFF for the first time. It was also a time when we had to find ways to stabilise the level of unpaid bills, and it is happening when many of our Member States are facing very difficult fiscal situations at home, but we are all working very hard to find the pathway to an agreement.  I want to thank both branches of the budgetary authority for coming up with a sound budget that provides continuity and predictability but, more important than anything else, it sends a signal to our citizens that despite differences and difficulties, we can come up with a solution that serves them. It is oriented towards their needs.  Thank you very much to the Chair Jean Arthuis for his leading role in the negotiations; to the rapporteurs Ms Gardiazabal and Ms Hohlmeier, and Mr Deprez, and also of course my former Commissioner colleague Mr Lewandowski now sitting here, for all he has done in his previous occupation to help us to come to this agreement. I also want to thank the Italian Presidency. Minister Padoan came to us at a very critical moment. Many of you have worked tirelessly throughout this process, and now we have a solution that I hope will be voted through tomorrow because it is a very good outcome of the negotiations. Of course we in the Commission believe that what we put forward as regional proposals were sound, but we can live with what we have now and it is, as many of you have already said, crucial for us to serve our programmes and to serve our people.  Let me first say a couple of words about the 2014 Draft Amending Budgets. This is a particularly tough year from the budgetary standpoint because we simultaneously face pressure for payments for the last programming period, bills that are coming in the last year, and the adjustment to a tighter budget envelope for the new MFF, and finding an agreement on the additional needs for 2014 through the amending budgets, and in particular through amending budget 3 – DAB 3 – the mobilisation of the contingency margin and making good use of the windfall of revenues from fines. This was paramount for the successful outcome of the budgetary procedure, and I would say that it also paved the way for a decision on the 2015 budget.  We have heard the assessment on the numbers. Let me just add three brief points: firstly, we are also benefiting from some redeployments and transfers of appropriations to 2015 of a programme that has not moved sufficiently this year. That allows the total amount of money for reinforcement for paying bills due to go up to EUR 4.25 billion. Of those, EUR 400 million are for Heading 1A, EUR 2.85 billion for the backlog of cohesion policy in Heading 1B and EUR 750 million for reinforcing the international programmes to help us to help people around the world in desperate situations. On the 2015 budget, let me outline what we believe is particularly valuable in the agreement. First it is focused on investments in our core policy priorities. It underpins what we have to do to strengthen the competitiveness of Europe and of course underpins the EUR 350 billion investment plan that we have presented. Secondly, vis-à-vis the 2014 budget, we have a modest step up but it is sufficient to help us adjust to the two pressure points I spoke about. For commitments the increase is 1.8% – EUR 2.6 billion – and for payments the increase is 1.6%, which translates into EUR 2.2 billion. That allows us EUR 3.9 billion more for Heading 1A and EUR 581 million more for Heading 4 where the pressures on Europe are so strong. As the Presidency mentioned, we managed to meet the needs of our farmers affected by the Russian ban and by falling price levels in the milk and meat markets without tapping into the crisis reserve. We also have – and this is a very important point to recognise – a healthy development on the ratio between commitments and payments. For 2014 and 2015, as a result of what we have done, this ratio is 97% vis-à-vis an average of 89% in previous years, 2009 being 83% for example. What does that mean? That means that it will be easier to get on top of the issue of the RAL that is going too far and too fast for our budget comfort. We are very pleased with the demand from Parliament, which was accepted by the Council, to have a payment plan, because this would lead us towards sustainability and I can inform you already that the Latvian Presidency – the forthcoming Presidency – is taking this task very seriously.  I met with the Minister of Finance and also with the Minister of Foreign Affairs who will be the front minister for the Presidency in the next six months. The payment plan is for us to bring to an end what we have been experiencing this year in terms of unpaid bills. Our discussions in the coming months will also touch upon the issue of special instruments. In these negotiations we have agreed to disagree and leave the issue open. We placed EUR 350 million in special instruments above the ceiling for 2014 but with an understanding that this is not the final call, so we have to engage in discussing it and hopefully bring it to a final call. We, as you all know, in this period of time had to deal with the issue of exceptionally a large GNI adjustment, EUR 9.5 billion in adjustments, that had come as a surprise to some of our Member States. We have a very limited proposal for an amendment to address this issue and I want to inform you that eight Member States are opting for deferred payments as provided by the amendment. Given that, I hope Parliament tomorrow will provide an opinion on it and it will be a positive opinion. Let me conclude with three points. Firstly, we have a budget and now we have to make the best use of the money we have. This for us in the Commission is a top priority to focus on results, on the quality of spending. Secondly, we, in the midst of negotiations, had a meeting of the High Level Group on own resources – I am very honoured to be one of the three Commissioners now added to this group, which has very critical work which it has to continue to deliver on. And last but not least, we in the Commission – you heard it in the new work programme – are very determined to drive towards this alignment of priorities and budget so we can show our citizens that the European Union delivers where it matters the most to them.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. - (C) Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Today we are discussing the budget before the vote and, in fact, we are very pleased that a compromise has been reached. However, I think we need to be aware of some relativism on this issue. It is better that we have a budget than if we had a makeshift budget. This situation is, of course, much better than the situation that could have happened. On the other hand, we are also aware that the negotiations have been very difficult, as the Commissioner has said, and there are some very symptomatic elements in these negotiations. Firstly, much of the attention has been paid not to the 2015 budget, but to the 're-election' of the 2014 budget. Until the last minute, we discussed avoiding disaster in 2014 at the expense of a very serious debate on the consequences in the 2015 budget. The situation was unusual because in previous years the discussion on 2014 was very detailed and started much earlier, and here we had a debate on 2014 with the post-2015 theme. Yet 2014 and 2015 are crucial for regional policy. The Commissioner spoke about the fact that 2014 and 2015, in accordance with the N+2 rule, are the end of the accounts, in other words all settlements, including demands for payment, come in 2014 and 2015. We are all aware that there must be more money. In other words, today's satisfaction with the negotiations is a relative satisfaction, but we should consider whether the system in this version will continue to work. Thank you.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Firstly, I would like to congratulate all the speakers because I believe that the union, the persistence of the European Parliament, has allowed a good agreement with regard to the 2014 budgets, the amending budgets, and also the 2015 budget, not forgetting something that is fundamental to the European Union's debt payment plan. And let's not be afraid to call it debt, because that's what this is about. This enables the credibility of the Institutions of the European Union and the realisation of our priorities for growth and jobs. This agreement also stabilises the European Union's debt and avoids the collapse of the budget. So in 2014 we have around €4 billion of extraordinary revenueto meet the high level of unpaid. Extraordinary revenues from the European Union budget in 2014 were on the table, which were the result, inter alia, of fines. Without this agreement, Member States would receive this revenue in their national budgets, which was unacceptable, not least because there is a large amount of invoices already overdue and not paid as I mentioned. For 2015, we have also managed to minimise the cuts that the Council has proposed. In addition, we have strengthened our commitments with regard to programmes for jobs and growth. The European Union's external solidarity has also been strengthened with regard to humanitarian aid. In 2015, as we agreed with the Commission and the Council, we must have a plan to deal with invoices that have already been overdue and unpaid. The European Union must apply to itself the same rigour as it asks the Member States and, in addition, must fulfil its commitments, in particular what it has adopted in the multiannual financial framework.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Secretary of State Della Vedova, Vice-President Georgieva, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for her work on the I join the general congratulations on the social democrats. I particularly congratulate the Presidency of the Council. It cannot be stressed clearly enough that, in a three-week conciliation period, the Council needs a large part of these 21 days to be able to find a common position in the first place, which will have to be overhauled after the first negotiations have been abandoned because this position is not enforceable, then the Italian Presidency can only be congratulated on keeping the Council in a difficult position in the end. What is good about this result? What we experience with the Council reminds me in phases of psychotherapy. There, too, the first phase of therapy is denial – we have it behind us. The fact that, just a few years ago, the Council claimed that the Commission's figures on arrears were wrong – that is what we have done. We have also left behind the problem of resistance. Now the Council has come to say: yes, we are prepared to put fresh money into the European budget, because the payment crisis is no longer to be denied. That is a good thing, and we have made progress on this. But now we are in the phase where healing must begin. I am pleased to hear from you, Madam Vice-President, that you are already in dialogue with the Latvian Presidency, because the Latvian Government must now be the one to implement this, namely to give life to the payment plan. We in the European Parliament's Committee on Budgets cannot imagine this other way than that we receive a very regular report from you, Madam Vice-President, on how payments are developing. I hope that the forecasts are correct that the money that is now there will be enough to stem the payment crisis. But I am not very optimistic about that. And, of course, in future, in the negotiations with the Council, we will also ensure that the commitment is followed by action. We have seen in the past that paper can be very patient for the Council. We will not stop there in the future.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I welcome the Commissioner, the representative of the Council, and I would of course like to thank all those who have been involved in drawing up these documents, although we in the ECR Group are not at all satisfied with the result. We will be able to adopt a whole package of measures this week. These are different budget additions for 2014. On the one hand, we are talking about aid in the event of a disaster, and it is also about technical adjustments. These are uncritical operations. We carry them with us. On the other hand, it is a question of financing outstanding invoices. This is important, of course, it is existential. But these compromises, which have now been drawn up, are far from sufficient. Payment of around EUR 4 billion is now foreseen. However, the EU has EUR 23 billion in debt. And debts in the form of unpaid bills are, as the previous speaker said, debts that we have to pay. We in the ECR Group therefore reject these additions. If we look at the 2015 budget, we must also make the starting conditions for 2015 clear: at the beginning of the year, we will have EUR 20 billion in debt. This will reduce the available cash from EUR 141 billion to EUR 121 billion. At the same time, however, we have provided for EUR 145 billion in payment promises to be made. I ask myself and ask you all: how can this bill be taken up? I dare say not at all, unless the EU enissues new rules of calculation. However, I would advise against that. If I then remind myself that we have already made promises of well over EUR 200 billion that are not yet due, then this whole situation will become even more dramatic. This budgetary procedure is far too complicated. We are talking about general reserves, special reserves, flexibility instruments, special financing, on top or not on top. None of this is transparent. This reminds me more of a language by George Orwell, who at the time had foreseen that politics would eventually speak in such a way that the citizens no longer understand it. When I see that the Commission's original proposal was EUR 142 billion in means of payment, the Council 140 says that Parliament originally had 146 – we have now returned to 141. The mountain cracked and bore a mouse. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, let me first thank our rapporteurs, Mrs Gardiazabal Rubial, Mrs Hohlmeier and Mr Deprez, for thanking Mrs Georgieva, and for thanking the Italian Presidency, in particular Ambassador Sannino. We are on the eve of our budget vote. I would like to express regret and hope. My regret is about the way our budget procedure is going. During the three weeks of conciliation, except with the Italian Secretary of State, we were unable to exchange with government-level interlocutors. For twenty-eight MEPs mobilised, there was not a minister to answer them. It was not until the twenty-first day, the last day of conciliation, that the Council finally made us aware of its proposals, which were unfortunately unacceptable. The accumulation of unpaid invoices on the Commission's desk is close to 30 billion. This serious drift puts many operators in difficulty and undermines both the authority and the credit of the European Union. I would like to denounce the Paradoxical Attitude of the Council. Indeed, in 2014, the European Union benefited from unforeseen resources, up to a maximum of five billion, the result of fines and late interest. For Parliament, it was important to allocate them to the payment of the most urgent invoices. It is a basic principle of good management. However, we have been met with the Council's refusal. I was stunned by the autism of national governments that refuse to live up to their obligations once they have accepted the credit commitments. Absent from our negotiations, ministers look like good managers by refusing to pay what they owe us. Should they be reminded that payment is only the mechanical consequence of their previous decisions? In any event, what we were asking for could, at best, only have the effect of stabilizing the European debt. Where, for 2014, we expected 4.7 billion euros, we got 3.5 billion. For 2015, we were expecting 2.3 billion euros, we got 1.3 billion. That's a total of 4.8 billion euros instead of 7 billion. It is therefore clear, ladies and gentlemen, that the amounts on which we have sealed our agreement do not solve the problem. But what is my hope is the commitment on both sides to implement a procedure to clear the sneaky debt of unpaid bills. The first step is to know exactly what this amount is, as of December 31, 2014, and to agree on what can be considered the reasonable and sustainable amount. The clean-up will aim for the gap between the two and will have to be completed as soon as possible. This means that the appointment scheduled for 2016 to revise the multi-year financial framework should mobilize us from the beginning of 2015.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, ba mhaith liom mo bhuíochas a ghabháil le mo chomhghleacaithe, leis na rapóirtéirí agus leis an gCathaoirleach, an tUasal Arthuis, i gcomhair an méid oibre ar fad atá déanta acu i dtaobh réiteach éigin a fháil ar an scéal seo.  Tá sé soiléir maidir le Buiséad 2015 go bhfuil idirdhealú mór fós ann idir an Eoraip a oibríonn do dhaoine saibhre agus an Eoraip a oibríonn do dhaoine bochta. Is léir go bhfuil na ciorruithe tubaisteacha fós slán agus go mbeidh daoine fós ag streachailt de bharr na bpolasaithe déine seo.  Tá sé léirithe agamsa arís agus arís eile go bhfuil tionscal iascaireachta na hÉireann i bponc mar gheall ar chiorruithe ollmhóra agus is léir go bhfuil an scéal seo chun dul in olcas dóibh siúd mar go bhfuil sé beartaithe EUR 908 milliún a bhaint ó Cheannteideal 2. Tá freagracht agus dualgas orainn aire a thabhairt do na daoine soghonta atá inár measc. Caithfimid aire a thabhairt dóibh siúd nach bhfuil ábalta aire a thabhairt dóibh féin agus tá sé scanrúil go bhfuil cabhair dhaonnúil níos ísle ná mar a bhí sé i 2014 de bharr gearradh siar faoi Cheannteideal 4.  Cuireann sé déistin orm chomh maith go bhfuil tacaíocht do UNWRA laghdaithe ó EUR 300 milliún go EUR 286.5 milliún agus creidim go gcaithfimid cabhair dhaonnúil agus íocaíochtaí don chúlchiste cabhrach a mhéadú cun dul i ngleic leis an staid uafásach ina bhfuil na milliúin dídeanaithe.  Mar aon leis seo, ba mhaith liom mo bhuairt a chur in iúl chomh maith maidir leis an Juncker Plan. Nuair a thiocfaidh sé seo chun tosaigh i mí Eanáir tríd an dréachtbhuiséad leasaitheach, beidh tionchar aige ar Bhuiséad na hEorpa do 2015 agus tá sé feicthe go mbeidh aistarraingt dʼíocaíochtaí ó Fho-cheannteideal 1a agus Fo-cheannteideal 1b. Is ábhar buartha é seo agus caithfear aghaidh a thabhairt ar na rudaí seo mar bheart práinne. (Thoiligh an cainteoir glacadh le ceist cárta ghoirm faoi Riail 162(8))

name: Giulia MOI
text: Blue card question. I would like to ask my colleague, since she has asked for increased aid for immigrants and their situation in reception centres, whether she has seen what is happening in Italy: the scams and corruption that are coming to light. There is a huge scandal: in Rome, both parties on the right and the left ate on the shoulders of these poor people; they stole and agreed on how much to earn and take advantage of these poor people. So, before you ask for more money, have you ever checked where they ended up?

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: freagra ‘cárta gorm’. – Nílim díreach tar éis dul tríd go hiomlán ag féachaint cá has a bhfuil an tacaíocht sin ag teacht, ach gan dabht caithfidh soiléireacht a bheith ann. (D’fhiafraigh an cainteoir an raibh aistriúchán ar fáil.) Caithfidh go bhfuil soiléireacht ann agus caithfidh go bhfuil daoine soiléir ar cad as go bhfuil an t-airgead ag teacht agus cá bhfuil sé ag imeacht. Níl aon dabht faoi sin.  (Dúirt an cainteoir go raibh súil aici go raibh ateangaireacht ar fáil.)

name: Indrek TARAND
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, as always in my Group we acknowledge the important work done by the rapporteurs and the Chair of the Committee on Budgets during this yearʼs budget negotiations. We also acknowledge that the agreement is certainly not one of the worst, definitely not in comparison to some other budget deals concluded during the last years. However, I believe that the deal does not allow the very difficult payment situation to be stabilised.  As Mr Deprez has already reminded this Parliament, we had three goals, three strategic objectives. First, to stabilise the payment situation, where we failed. Unpaid bills accumulated. Second, we need a differentiated approach on special instruments, and we failed because there is no decision. Thirdly, we needed a plan to reduce unpaid bills, and we failed because the written declaration does not seem to be so binding. Ms Gardiazábal Rubial said she is unhappy with the figures but that, nevertheless, we should vote for the budget. I do not think so!  My question is: why should we support that kind of deal at the vote and why should we be so very afraid of provisional twelfths? Au contraire, we should embrace the provisional twelfths because only that method will force the Council, the Member State governments in the Council, to understand finally the depth of the problem and perhaps even to move a little bit to solve it.  I have so many points – I will not make them all because you know them, budget people know them – but just allow me, Madam President, to become a little bit emotional at the end of my third minute. If we reject the budget tomorrow – and take your time, consider it again, consider it – if we reject it we will get one or two months of provisional twelfths but we will have a new situation concerning how this European Union budget is finally made, and the real role of this Parliament according to the Lisbon Treaty must become more evident.  If we vote for it, then all we can do is sing lullabies to our children using Leonard Cohenʼs gloomy words: ʽEverybody knows the deal is rotten, everybody knows the good guys lostʼ.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the agreement reached at the end of regulatory time was the only way to avoid having a European budget in hiccups, through the system of provisional twelfths. We have always maintained our position during the negotiations. The clear problem to be solved concerns payments and, unfortunately, this agreement does not solve the situation at all, but even makes it worse.  In 2014 we got the union minimum but it was in 2015 that, in my opinion, the approach was completely wrong. It has once again been agreed to sacrifice the need for payments at the altar of political commitments. In my opinion, this is not serious: the figures for next year include commitments of over EUR 145 billion and payments of EUR 141 billion. The 4 billion that are lacking will therefore be added to the twenty abundant that the Union still has to liquidate today. Next year we will find ourselves in the same conditions. In fact, probably even worse. It is not possible to continue in this way. The credibility of the European Union itself is at stake. Many parties here want to keep us on the sidelines because they say we are against the European Union. It is quite a smile that these zealous colleagues are in fact representatives of parties that govern in all the countries of the Union and whose councils risked sinking the negotiations and leaving Europe without resources. The Italian Presidency, which prides itself so much on preaching change and pushing for more investment, has been an accomplice and a guide to all this. Yet another demonstration that words are often not followed by deeds or, rather, deeds are the exact opposite of words.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Madam President! I believe that next year's budget presents us with major challenges. We want to ensure that, on the one hand, the European Union is not indebted. At the expense of the Member States, it is quite simply not possible for the Member States to offload their debts in Europe and then not to take this into account in the Stability Pact.  I believe that the Juncker Plan has a great opportunity, namely that we will also have a serious discussion of the issue of own resources. It is quite simply a matter of, for example, tendering the auction proceeds for the 700 MHz band in 28 countries throughout Europe and linking the auction proceeds with the Connecting Europe facility, then you already have a solid foundation. If we add funds from the financial facility, from Horizon 2020, to put it all into a PPP model, that it will be really interesting to invest in a fibre-optic rollout, in a network infrastructure, in the digital single market, and if the next Presidency finally has the courage to adopt this package on the digital single market, then we will make a great deal of progress.  I also believe that the new projects that we have started clearly show us that this programme could also be an incentive for the female business angels to achieve more here.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: – I agree with President Juncker that working methods need to be changed. He certainly addressed this message to the Council – at least in the area of budget negotiations. Thanks to the rapporteurs and their teams, thanks to the professional conduct of the negotiations, we finally have a compromise on the table. The EU budget is one of the most important instruments for showing solidarity between Member States. But it also represents clear joint savings. When states better coordinate their policies, they will also have more money in their accounts. We need to discuss this more, both in the European Parliament and with ministers in the Council, but also with members of national parliaments. Only if we work effectively will we be able to face the greatest challenges of the 21st century – climate change, risks to energy security, tax evasion, economic globalisation or threats to our security.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: Madam President, I welcome the fact this budget is within the agreed limits of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) and I find it welcome too that there is greater emphasis on jobs and growth. In that respect, Commissioner, you have shown admirable intent to meet the needs of the citizens and I congratulate you for that.  But, I was disappointed that there is not more intent to address the problem of unpaid bills and accumulating RALs. That I find unacceptable. It is clear that through the past we have been habitually spending more than we earn; in other words expenditure was exceeding revenue. The answer to this House is not to demand more revenue. Our first instinct should be to use the resources we have more efficiently. With finite resources, surely we should prioritise strictly according to value for money. But for Parliament to make that kind of judgment, we need a greater role; we need a role scrutinising delivery of the budget; we need a role monitoring performance; and we need a role evaluating value for money.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: Mr President, today I thought I would do something very non-Finnish, that is, thank you. Muchas gracias Eider, Vielen Dank Monika, merci beaucoup Gerard, dziękuję Janusz, merci beaucoup Jean, blagodar and Commissioner Georgieva. I would also like to thank our assistants and advisers, they have worked long hours. The Italian Presidency also deserves its thanks for ensuring a good outcome. However, I would like to express my particular thanks to the Council for its long and years of resistance. As you well know, the word Council translates in Russian with the word sovet. Thank you for having shown during the years really sovietic stubborness that makes this small victory so much sweeter.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, who do you work for? Not only do I wonder; citizens who have voted for them are also asked, and they cannot really blame them. In this House, a neoliberal Commission has been legitimized in the service of the powerful and a President who believes that evading taxes and frightening the Greek people is part of his mandate. Today we are debating and tomorrow we vote on the Union budget for 2015, one of the few instruments of redistribution and social justice that we have left at European level. After a pantomime of negotiation, we are presented here today with an anemic budget, a budget that will continue to destroy the European economy, widening the gap between the peoples of the North and the South and giving wings to the ghost of fascism. Tomorrow this Parliament can be courageous and reject a short-term, austere, antisocial and anti-European budget; tomorrow this Parliament can say loud and clear that it wants a Europe in which Greece, Germany and Spain, in addition to trading partners, are sister peoples. You can do that or you can continue to walk your irresponsible path to the discredit of institutions, the twilight of this continent and the poverty of your people. Juncker and Draghi rule for financial vampires, we already knew, but who do you work for? Tomorrow you'll have a chance to prove it. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Blue card question. Mr President, Mr McKenna, some of the things you have said are interesting and the many amendments you have tabled in the last few hours are interesting. You called the negotiations that took place pantomime. I am sorry, however, that we did not see you present at the negotiations, because we could have heard your opinion much earlier and probably built a less liberticidal budget together, as you called it. I would like to know what positions you think we should have changed, what positions we should take and, perhaps, I would invite you and I would like to know whether next year we intend to take part in the negotiations first.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Viotti, I have been to the Committee on Budgets, like any of the Members, introducing amendments. I believe that the work of the Unitary Left Group has been exemplary in this regard and, in any case, I have not heard any questions in its speech, so I have nothing more to answer.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Madam President, the effects of increasingly frequent extreme weather events caused by climate change are having devastating effects in some regions of the European Union. They are changing the lives of thousands of citizens and causing great economic damage. 80 million European money is being issued this year to repair the damage caused by the floods. Croatia is just one example of where floods in Slavonia caused 197m euros in damage.  Prevention of climate change and its harmful consequences should be the EU's flagship policy. Europe needs to start managing our money smarter. These funds would have a much greater impact in the prevention of climate change, with which we can avoid such catastrophic natural phenomena.  Cohesion policy is the best way to encourage Member States and border states to cooperate in this area. Cohesion policy projects aimed at preventing the effects of climate change create better and sustainable jobs. This is a sustainable way of stabilising the economy of less developed member states. To this end, the Commission plays a key role in providing funding for the realisation of prevention projects, and I therefore call on all competent authorities to have a stronger commitment to achieve this objective.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: Madam President, we are here once again to discuss the issue of the European Union budget for 2015. I want to explain to you how this is seen in the United Kingdom. There is a perception that taxpayers are being asked to contribute more and more and that they do not actually get enough in return. For that reason, the recalculation of GNI and the extra British contribution of GBP 1.7 billion plays into the same feeling. It is within the rules, but a recalculation in which Greece and Italy pay more, and Germany pays less, comes across in a particular way to voters.  In May, over 50% of the vote in the United Kingdom went to parties which want less Europe. You may well believe that to be a minority view across the European Union, but it is a majority view in the United Kingdom. If anything, it underestimates the strength of feeling. Two polls in the last week both showed that 58% of those expressing an opinion wanted the United Kingdom to leave the European Union altogether. So this budget – back to the budget – is an elegant compromise but it is a compromise between the Council, the Commission and Parliament. I understand that it is a compromise that many, if not most, Members of this House are unhappy with, even though they may, when it comes down to it, vote in favour of it. But this is where there is a yawning chasm. A chasm between what goes on here and what is going on in the United Kingdom. It is not, I think, a compromise which the British people will readily accept. The gap between Europe and the United Kingdom is not the deep blue sea but there is a fundamental difference in belief about what Europe should be about.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, an earthquake in my country, Greece, which caused damage of some EUR 147 million, with more than two and a half thousand dwellings unable to house corresponding families, has led the European Union of solidarity to allocate some EUR 3.5 million in aid. This proves the real face of the European Union. A Union that creates rules and laws to apply them when and where it is in its interest. A Union that thinks about the economic interests of powerful states while leaving other countries with crumbs. A Union which cannot and does not want to think that a country plagued by a huge economic crisis, a country where unemployment has reached inhuman heights and almost half its population lives on the edge of poverty, cannot assess and follow the same rules as countries where similar conditions do not exist. It is deeply and vertically against the founding declaration of the Union the manifest economic and political racism of the budget and the social deficit of the sovereign powers. Let us all remember the principles on which the European Union was built: equality, mutual cooperation and respect.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: Madam President, the European Union has a budget for 2015. This is without any doubt good news for Europe. We can all agree that without Parliament, a budgetary crisis and therefore a blockade of many EU programmes would have occurred. This would have had a negative impact on SMEs, researchers and many Erasmus students throughout Europe. Thanks to the clear and strong position of Parliament we managed to reverse most of the Council’s proposed cuts and almost stabilised the current payments backlog.  We have at best stabilised the problem of payments, but we have by no means solved it. We are still expecting almost EUR 25 billion in unpaid bills at the end of this year. This is a huge amount and we need a plan to reduce it. That is why I welcome the decision to draw up a plan to decrease this backlog. In this regard, I welcome Vice-President Georgieva’s readiness to cooperate with us in dealing with this problem.  However, some outstanding issues remain. One of the most important ones concerns the special instruments. As I am the Rapporteur on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for advance payments for 2015, I can confirm that the Council still believes that payment appropriations for this instrument have to be within the margins of the budget. This is another way in which the Council is trying to further cut the multiannual financial framework (MFF). We, the Parliament, have made it clear that commitment and payment appropriations for special instruments are over and above the margins. As we know, the EU is not allowed to have any deficits or accumulated debt. Council must obey the Treaties and ensure that the EU pays its bills.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: Madam President, we talk a lot about figures in our budget discussions, but sometimes we forget what the money is used for. I refer particularly to those beneficiaries of EU investments. We all know examples of beneficiaries of structural funds and agricultural funding, but I wanted to say a few words on investments in our universities.  In Wales, for example, we recently had announcements of GBP 750 million for a second campus at Swansea University, GBP 45 million for Bangor University, and GBP 20 million for Aberystwyth University – all projects which would not happen without EU investment. That is why I can say that not all parts of the UK are anti-EU. We see the benefits of it.  I would hope that everybody in this Chamber would recognise the importance of us investing in innovation, research and development, particularly in our academic institutions. It is so important for the future of our economies. To do that, of course, we need an EU budget which is adequate, but also one which focuses on the things that produce jobs and growth.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Despite Parliament's tough stance towards the Council and the Commission regarding the combined consideration of as many as six amending budgets for 2014 and the 2015 budget, the achievements of the trilogue are not significant. Although the Council finally agreed that, under the third amending budget, the appropriations from penalties and fines should, instead of going back to member states' budgets, be used to pay outstanding bills, but this amounts to only EUR 3.5 billion out of nearly EUR 5 billion of all appropriations. The level of payments for 2015 has also been increased from EUR 140 billion, as the Council wanted, to EUR 141.2 billion, as proposed by the European Commission in its new draft budget. In total, therefore, we have an additional EUR 4.7 billion in payments, only that the amount of outstanding bills is approaching EUR 30 billion and these funds will only serve to improve the liquidity of the budget, and unfortunately not to solve the problem of outstanding payments. I am also very concerned about the Commission's suggestion that the so-called eur 480 million crisis reserve be allocated, after all, from non- or indirect non-agricultural subsidies in a situation where the Russian embargo on EU food is likely to continue throughout 2015. If this were ultimately the case, it would be irresponsible and this is not altered by the Commission's declarations of intention to allocate additional compensation to EU farmers from the so-called general margin. Thank you very much.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Madam President, I would first like to thank the rapporteurs for their work, underline President Arthuis' commitment, and also underline the consensus that has emerged in our committee to get the Council's progress. But it must be acknowledged that these advances are timid, that they were achieved at the end of the journey and that they do not definitively solve the problem of unpaid debts since we will end up, in 2015, with the same deficit of 26 billion euros. It is therefore now that we must start discussions with the European Council in order to find a solution for the years to come. Because we know that the main disbursements will be in 2018 - since they relate to cohesion programmes and disbursements will arrive on that date - and that if we do not find a solution today, we will eventually find ourselves in the face of a situation that will become unmanageable. Finally, I call on the Council to find solutions on own resources that would solve the problems.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the agreement on the European budget must be seen as a defeat for everyone, and this must be clear: a defeat for Parliament, which has failed to achieve what has been requested, that is, sacrificing many of the priorities expressed by this House; it is a defeat for the Council, and therefore for the Member States, because they have perhaps not realised that the Debts of the European Union are their debts and the invoices still to be paid – over EUR 20 billion – cause suffering to themselves in the first place, namely to their businesses, citizens and administrations.  The Commission then seems a little confused, proposing figures which it first considers unthinkable but which it then ratifies without problems, in order to accept an agreement that is only a paltry palliative. We are in a dangerous spiral in which the European Commission is demanding austerity from the Member States, which in turn are demanding rigour from the Commission and Parliament remains a little crushed in the middle of this mechanism. I therefore wonder, in fact, who still believes in this structured Europe, and I believe that the citizens are tired of all this.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Madam President, I think the compromise reached is positive. First of all, most debts have been put on the brakes, so the credibility of the European Union has been strengthened, the basic financing of policies has been ensured and there is a picture of normality, because I believe that if we had gone into a budget crisis and worked with twelfths, we would have had a whole lot of practical and political problems. On the other hand, however, the budget is not a budget for more Europe, for European integration. We generally remain at 1% of the Gross Domestic Product of the Member States and the problem of own resources has not been solved. We therefore want to move forward, and it is typical of the arguments of eurosceptics and anti-Europeans, who are trying to reduce Community funds, precisely to reinforce the argument that the European Union cannot function. I do not think that the money in the European budget is money thrown away. On the contrary, it is a proper European investment for the benefit of all European peoples.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: Madam President, first of all, I want to thank the rapporteurs for their efforts. The European Union will finally have a European budget for 2015 and we are pleased with that, but I would not like to think that all problems have thus been solved. Achieving this consensus leaves many things still unresolved: the problem of unrealised payments and debts from previous budgets, the lack of agreement in the conciliation process and the way in which the Council has chosen to treat the European Parliament, the inability to set clear directions for job creation or to consistently and consistently support innovation, social or development policies or the lack of transparency on how funds are actually spent or the amounts on which funds are actually spent Member States must allocate them. In this context, I express my disappointment as a new and young Member of the European Parliament, and I hope that this year's discussions will be a lesson in what will happen in the next four years, because, whether it is desired or not – and this applies to both the Council and the Commission – we in the European Parliament will work in this Chamber to defend the rights of the citizens who elected us , because the citizen's interest is the same as the national interest; because whatever these discussions, it is important that when we talk about the European budget we speak transparently and openly.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: Between 19 June and 2 August, devastating floods destroyed the poorest member state of the European Union. The result was 15 deaths, hundreds of houses were destroyed, and thousands of Bulgarians were left without a roof over their heads. The Bulgarian government estimated the losses in the country at about EUR 30 million. I wrote a letter to the previous President of the European Commission, Mr Barroso, for emergency assistance from the €20 million Solidarity Fund. This aid has not yet been granted. I hope that the appeal of Europe's poorest country will be heard with the new budget. The fact that there is no budget for 2015 makes citizens of the European Union victims. Thousands of poor families and injured citizens await your support. We need money, we need real help from the European Commission, because otherwise this budget sacrifices people and such tragic cases in the future will be increasingly common.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: Madam President, dear colleagues! We should not say anything nice here that is not nice.  As recently as October, Parliament clearly demanded payment appropriations, that is, money that can be spent in real terms in 2015, amounting to EUR 146 billion. EUR 141 billion is now on paper. In concrete terms, cohesion policy, i.e. the Structural Funds, and education and culture, such as Erasmus+ and Creative Europe, are being cut. We think that is irresponsible.  Once again, the Council presents us with the choice of 'eating or dying', either agreeing to a totally inadequate budget or risking an emergency budget. We call this frivolous! That is why my group does not agree with this smear.

name: Petr MACH
text: Ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has a budget of around EUR 140 billion. Many advocates of European integration say that this is actually not enough, that this is less than what is redistributed by individual national Member States. But it seems to me an awful lot when these few people decide on 140 billion euros.  When I look at how they are spent, I see a huge waste there. The budget is unfair, it causes a great injustice, some states pay more than they receive, others receive more than they pay, and for all of those states, that budget causes debt growth. If we abolished member states' payments to the European Union budget, everyone would save money. Those who pay more would not have such a deficit, and those who receive would not have to be in enough debt to finance, co-finance European projects.  I would therefore be in support of the complete abolition of membership fees to the European Union.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at the end of what I would describe as a chaotic budgetary procedure, in which Parliament has been caught between the refusal of certain Member States to assume their budgetary responsibilities and a Commission ready to accept lower compromises, I would again like to warn the European Union against the risks of unpaid debts for the beneficiaries of the European Structural Funds in our respective territories. As a result of not adjusting payment credits to commitment credits, the gap widens from year to year and the stock of unpaid debts increases. It is the very credibility of the Union that is at stake. That said, this agreement on the 2015 budget and the 2014 amending budgets was necessary. We should do it and we have done it; I would therefore like to thank and congratulate the rapporteurs who have achieved this result. But I hope that this will change in the future. Our predecessors in this Chamber have fought for the introduce in 2016 of a revision clause of the MFF, in order to revise upwards the budgetary ambitions of the European Union, which will meet the expectations of European citizens. I believe that this will be an opportunity to lead the fight for genuine European taxation. I would say today that the "I want my money back" system will not achieve a Europe of solidarity. We must now find resources specific to the European Union, which will prevent us from being confronted, each time, with the crisis we are experiencing on the question of the budget, particularly on the question of payments.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur The work on the EU budget has been a long time and its current form is the result of a compromise. It has succeeded, but unfortunately probably seemingly, to patch the budget hole without increasing the contributions to the budget at the same time. We all want to avoid a budget makeshift. On the one hand, the current shape of the budget has many positive elements, such as an increase in spending on research, innovation and education and boosting growth and jobs (especially in terms of improving regional cohesion). On the other hand, However, I am wondering about the problem of cumulation of late payments, which is said to be solved by the Member States. But how? As it stands, EUR 4.8 billion is to be spent on the repayment of the current year's arrears, but I am afraid that the problem of accumulating a backlog of payments will still remain, especially since it is already known that the amount (the President has voted.)

name: Giulia MOI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to see that we are also talking about Sardinia and solidarity in the new package for the 2014-2015 budget. Solidarity necessary to bring relief to those who suffered the strength and destruction of the floods, which took place in Sardinia in November 2013, which brought direct damage to the territory for more than 650 million euros. These EUR 16 million under the fund will have to cover the costs incurred in restoring the infrastructure, water networks and public and private buildings of the many citizens who have struggled to make a living. Today, however, I also call for a commitment from the Commission and the Italian Presidency to ensure that this money is used exclusively where it has been spent. All too often, regional administrations have had to deal with corruption and illegality, especially in the use of European funds. It is therefore important to monitor and ensure that every euro spent is made for the reconstruction of our land.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it is important to remember, as my colleague has done, that this multiannual budget contains solidarity funds. Funds which, as far as my land is concerned, our land, Sardinia, refer to a very serious incident in which 16 people lost their lives in a huge natural disaster. I believe that tomorrow there must be a cohesive and unified vote, a vote that certainly concerns not only Sardinia but also Greece, Slovenia and Croatia, that is, a whole series of countries that have experienced the tragedy of situations that have shocked territories but which have created a further tragedy within poor and highly crisis systems. I am convinced that a reference should be made to Italy and its government with regard precisely to the requests that the Commission has already represented, which relate precisely to the allocation of the funds in question. We need clarity, we need speed, but above all we need concrete action: it is not acceptable to keep these people who have experienced the tragedy waiting and who continue to experience it, precisely because during this period in particular they have been subject to a series of vexatious taxes which, of course, have not been extended or postponed for the sectors affected.  I therefore invite you to vote with a strong, cohesive and unified vote.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at the end of this very complicated and very long phase, I would like to begin by thanking President Arthuis and the rapporteur for their work. This phase has really been too complicated. It is regrettable to say, even as an Italian, that our Presidency, which has also achieved an important result – for which I thank it – has moved too late, something that must be said in this House. However, if You will allow me, at the end of this phase that I am living for the first time, I have a kind of disrespect towards this Parliament, which is also the only institution elected by the citizens of Europe. I think we will have to work a lot on this. Certain attitudes, delays and behaviours are in danger of really taking us to the ridge of so-called anti-Europeanism, of Europhobia, as some call it. And the whole system in which we find ourselves today: the whole issue of unpaid invoices, the subject of an even narrower budget for next year, all this brings us closer to that point. Every time we go back to our countries of origin and go and talk to young people who have projects that are interested or talk to our mayors, talk to universities, talk to our businesses and entrepreneurs, we have to have guarantees about when we say. Promises cannot be made without specifying the agreements concluded between the European institutions. We must have guarantees that debts are paid and that commitments are kept. That is why there are concerns, both about what has not been done so far and about next year's budget. We know that we will probably already have to deal with an amending budget, on which I call for maximum transparency, maximum commitment and speed, because we absolutely cannot disregard our commitments to the citizens.

name: Christian EHLER
text: Mr. President! My express thanks to the two rapporteurs. It was heroic. Researchers, innovation and growth in Europe will be grateful for this commitment. I would also like to thank the Commission for not buckling its second budget proposal. However, one thing has to be said: in the area of innovation and in many other areas, we are only dragging the problems behind us in payments of almost double-digit billions. We have reached a point where directors and directors-general must consider whether they can still sign contracts because they are on the verge of budgetary infidelity. This problem is stabilized, but not solved. I would like to make it clear once again, and not only in the context of the interest of the Horizon budget: if Horizon becomes a quarry either for saving efforts or for the search for new programmes, simply because it is easier to plunder the programme rather than to deal with the Council in substance, then I warn against the next round of budget discussions. Taking EUR 2.7 billion exclusively from Horizon 2020 for the Juncker programme is, in my view, frivolous. We are swapping investment for investment, and that will not lead to more growth in Europe. There must be burden-sharing if we want to make this programme, and the easy way must not be chosen again: if we take it out of a programme that the Member States do not allocate, then the political resistance is less. This costs us precisely the innovations in Europe, which are then the basis for investment and growth.

name: Paul TANG
text: Mr President, I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Members of Parliament for their great joint efforts, which have also led to a solution. Because again this year it was endless wrangling and that happens year after year. This has a lot to do with the attitude of the Member States that say one thing and do the other. We reach an agreement this week, but not really a solution. To do this, the Commission must, as agreed in the joint declarations, map out how the reservoir of bills can be contained. In addition, we need a new budgetary system that prevents Member States from saying one thing and doing the other. Because it looks like a pyramid scheme now, and it's not sustainable. Universities, companies and other organisations do not get their account paid on time. In the Netherlands, therefore, the Labour Party has set up an online counter to report late payments, but the real steps must come from the Member States.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Mr President, I would first of all like to thank all the rapporteurs, the Commissioner and all those involved in the negotiations. Ladies and gentlemen, it should be recalled that without a clear position of the European Parliament, this negotiation would end in an absolute fiasco. I am also glad that we have a proper budget, not a one-twelfth budget. Because this would jeopardise trust in the European Union and jeopardise the projects of our scientists and students. I also consider it important that a good package for growth and innovation has been negotiated with the Council, which is good news for the future. Overall, I consider the budget to be a well-negotiated compromise.  However, I have one small retex. As rapporteur for the budget in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, I must point out that one thing I am a little disappointed about. We are currently facing a large influx of migrants from conflict zones and we can expect them to increase. We must therefore have sufficient funding for Frontex, Europol and EASO and equip them with sufficient funding and staffing to cope with these challenges. Any reductions may have an impact on the ability of these agencies to carry out their tasks, on internal security and immigration and asylum policy.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Mr President, this compromise was necessary, and I congratulate the actors and, in particular, the excellent delegation of Parliament. It was out of the question to break the momentum that Jean-Claude Juncker and the majority of our Parliament intend to give to European politics. But Europe is sinking into a major budget crisis. It seems that all the Member States, both good and bad budget students, have agreed to finance their newfound virtue at the expense of the common budget. It is also as if they had decided unanimously not to see it and even to deny it. The solution will be a complete overhaul of the funding of European policies. How can we give the Union back to genuine own resources? The Commissioner recalled that we are working on this under the chairmanship of Mario Monti. Is the Juncker plan the outline of the investment budget that the Eu needs? What happens to the idea of a budgetary capacity specific to the euro area? Who has to pay? You bet? For example, the guard of the Union's external borders or the necessary military intervention against Islamist terrorists near the same borders? It is time to ask these questions and ask them all together.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: Mr President, reaching an agreement on the 2015 budget was, of course, good news in itself. Thank you to all of you to whom it belongs. It is good that the Council understood to back away from its strictest positions and the final collapse of the budget was avoided. In the end, however, some understanding of the problem of payment deficits was also found in the Member States. It is an excellent thing that the main lines we consistently drove carried us all the way to the finish line. Horizon, research projects and Erasmus exchanges were secured for the time being, thus focusing on growth-oriented funding. We can therefore accept this solution. But I'm sorry I can't burst into any high-level sculpting. There were too many signs that next year we are facing an even worse budget dispute. So all we can say is that it's bad to pull out of nothing.  The Member States tried to push for a selfish policy to the end. The main controversy over flexibility instruments and the ceiling was hassled under the carpet, where it can be found again in next autumn's budget negotiations. If the Member States had a little more understanding of how important this Union is as a project for all of us, there would certainly also be a little less selfishness.
