Of course, projects financed with the Union's common money must require more synergy, more European added value, but there is no sign of this in the Union's current budgetary policy.

name: Lara COMI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the agreement reached on the 2014 amending budgets and the 2015 general budget is certainly positive for having prevented the twelfths regime, which would have led to a truly complicated and, to say the least, harmful scenario. But the great difficulties in achieving this result spur us even further towards a reform of the European Union's own resources system. This would guarantee the financial autonomy of the Union. It would enable us to make the whole system certainly more effective and focused on the objectives actually to be achieved, without suffering national reservations, which today are too dependent on the limited public resources they have. With regard to the 2014 amending budget, I am satisfied that we have secured the necessary resources but I do not agree with the choice to use the 2015 funds. Solidarity for natural disasters or for the economic damage caused by globalisation must have absolutely no limits. If the Member States do not make these affected territories fiscally, Europe absolutely must intervene. Another fundamental point is that Europe must pay its debts, because if it does not set an example in the first place, we will not be able to ask citizens to be punctual in paying taxes, not least because in this House we have approved the directive on late payments and then we proceed with the compensation between credits and debts.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Mr. Vice-President, first of all, I congratulate all my colleagues who participated in the negotiations on reaching a compromise on the amendments to the 2014 budget and on the 2015 budget, especially since these negotiations were also conducted at the beginning of the second year of our current multiannual financial framework. I think €145 billion in commitment appropriations and €141 billion for payment is a quality compromise and allows for a balance between budget discipline and promoting growth as a key objective of our common resources and redistribution of the European budget.  I also believe that we need to pay more attention to meeting the commitments already made so far, in particular with regard to payments, which has been proving to be a crisis aspect of the European Union budget for years.  Also, I want to mention at this moment the important agreements we have reached regarding the agreement and solidarity fund, especially for the ice and floods that occurred in Croatia, as well as the floods that have hit Slavonia over 16.5 million euros in recent months will help Croatia partly to repair the damage that has severely affected it this year and thus we see what the results of climate change are.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: Mr President, it has been said many times this afternoon, but I would like to congratulate the Commissioner, as well as Parliament and the Council, on the 2015 budget agreement reached. You are new and immediately all this big job. Congratulations! I have more difficulty with the budget adjustments for 2014. In the case of budget adjustment No 3, there is clearly a tension between payments to be made, including to research institutions, and on the other hand, the already use of budgetary space in the coming years and even bringing in new money. But that is the tension that this budgetary adjustment brings, and we will have to live with that. Budget adjustment No 6 for 2014: give me a moment to improve communication on the after-taxes imposed on the countries next time. The European Union has not become more popular because of the fact that the Commission imposed so many after-taxes shortly before 1 November. That has hurt in many countries, it has not done our name any good and we really need to prevent that in the future. Thank you and good holidays!

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: The agreement on the future budget provides real preconditions for meeting the three main objectives of making up unpaid claims, supporting Member States' structural reforms and, above all, promoting the creation of new jobs. It is important for the Union to invest more in competitiveness, growth and employment, and therefore that the structure of the budget also corresponds to these objectives. The emphasis of the budget should always be on the future – i.e. innovation, education, small and medium-sized enterprises and, above all, youth. It is also important to direct the budget to the Union's research, development and Horizon 2020 programmes. I therefore welcome the new agreement, which is intended to increase the contribution to these programmes by EUR 45 million. A positive aspect of this budget is also the inclusion of a first amount of EUR 8 billion to launch a new 315 billion investment plan. I believe that, thanks to private investment and loan guarantees, the Union will gain access to new resources and ensure greater growth in our economy. Nevertheless, we need to find a way to pay back unpaid bills that already exceed 23 billion. It is therefore important for the Commission to monitor the level of unpaid bills and to prepare a reduction measure, such as sanctions. The new budget should therefore also bring about an improvement in the level of payments.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: I would like to thank everyone who participated in the conciliation process.  Otherwise, I am not entirely satisfied, because instead of EUR 7 billion, we have only managed to agree on an additional EUR 4.8 billion, thus only stabilising unpaid bills. Old bills for projects already completed must be paid as soon as possible so that local communities and businesses do not have problems as a result. You have to respect the treaties.  I would also like to draw attention to the lack of funds for the annual financial programme and development.  I also welcome the Juncker Investment Programme.  Finally, I would like to thank slovenia for eur 18 million of EUR 388 000 in aid, which will be used to deal with the consequences of ice and sting in February this year, as part of the european Union Solidarity Fund.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: The Council of Europe was disappointed in the negotiations on the 2015 budget. The European Parliament has had a very clear position on the 2015 budget that the European Union's commitments must be based on adequate funding, especially in key areas. I was responsible for preparing the opinion in the AFET Committee, so it is to be welcomed that an increase in funding has been negotiated for European neighbourhood programmes, humanitarian aid and the common foreign and security policy, which is particularly relevant in the light of the events of this time. However, I do not agree with the reduction of funding for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will affect many farmers in the European Union who are in a particularly difficult situation because of the protracted Russian embargo and who need financial assistance from the European Union.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, rapporteurs, ladies and gentlemen, I hope that tomorrow we will be able to confirm the agreement on the Union budget for the financial years 2014 and 2015 and I congratulate the parliamentary colleagues who have been involved in this difficult negotiation.  From Parliament's perspective, it is essential to ensure an adequate level of financial appropriations to reduce the extraordinarily high level of unpaid credits. Unfortunately, the same Member States continue to favour the return of unused financial margins in their pockets over the payment of obligations before third parties, as my colleague Jean Arthuis said. It is deplorable that budgetary negotiations are becoming increasingly difficult, leaving the Union on the brink of blockade, or the budgetary twelfths, as Mr Olbrycht also said. On the other hand, in view of the need already recognised by the Heads of Government to invest in the future and European competitiveness, enabling synergies in the areas of energy, innovation or transport to be exploited. It's a bad sign. (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker.)

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Given some of the relust in the Member States' relujoith to confirm the Commission's proposal for a budget for 2015 in November, we have almost faced the financing of the budget in the coming year after twelfths, and after all the debate on individual programmes and policies and the money that the Commission will have in the coming year, we leave, of course, problems, which may have unforeseen consequences for the whole of Europe.  I am talking about what my colleagues before me have already been saying about the increasing backlog of payments by the Commission for subsidies and payments for projects already carried out across Europe. However, this new draft budget is not fully addressed by these backlogs in payments, which have actually been standing since September.  Of course, this is not the responsibility of this Commission, but it will, of course, become this if the Commission does not seriously consider saing this problem, rather than, of course, just delaying it in the future.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: Mr President, I apologise for the delay, I was at a meeting on the new investment plan which I believe can also be put at risk because of the European budget, which is becoming less and less credible. It is good that we have a budget, but we have to think that the exact same scenario has been used: the budget for next year has been negotiated at the same time as the amending budgets for this year, even though a lot of paperwork has been signed saying that this will not be done. The Commission has come up with one proposal, Parliament with another, it has finally come to what the Council has proposed and the situation leads to over 20 billion missing this year and probably much more next year, practical deficit, which is illegal. So, in the first part of next year, the European Council must take a decision on setting up the European budget and upbringing payments.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I will take as my point of departure the very last words: we are in a tough situation. What we have is not a budget of joy. We may be on the eve of Christmas, but what we have is no basis to feel completely relieved of the difficulties in front of us, because they are still there. But it is a budget of responsibility. For those who said ‘Why do we not just jump into provisional twelfths, let us forget about this budget deal’, let us remember two things: firstly, provisional twelfths would bring us a lower level of budget simply because 2014 is a so much lower base. But secondly, and most importantly, the probability we now have to secure the amount of money from fines with DAB 3 will be much lower when we cross into the New Year. Faced with this fiscal reality that we would be substantially worse-off – not only because provisional twelfths in the first months would mean a lower budget, but because the injection of fresh cash would be potentially lost or would be much smaller and unable to cure the problem in hand, which is to stabilise unpaid bills – I for one am relieved that the negotiators, the two arms of the budgetary authority, were able to secure this budget for us. This budget is not one of joy, but of responsibility. I want to stress four points here in closing. First, we are bringing the unpaid bills to a more manageable level. The accuracy of our projections still stands, we expect up to EUR 25 billion at the end of 2014. This is EUR 1.6 billion more than we had at the beginning of this year. We would have liked not to have it. We would have liked to stabilise the level, but at least we have a chance to step into the year less concerned about the mountain of bills than we would have been otherwise. Secondly, to those who have been speaking about the accuracy of our data time and again in the negotiations: I am very proud of my team, some of whom are behind me. We have shown that we are very clear; we know the numbers, we understand the trends and we are going to use the clarity of our analysis to underpin the payment plan and to ensure that it becomes a reality. Thirdly, I want to repeat once again to those who are worried about our farmers: we have found in this package a way not to dip into the crisis reserve. We are paying, without dipping into the crisis reserve, for the impact of the Russian ban and other events in the agricultural markets. Fourthly, some spoke about the Solidarity Fund. Since we have a deal, we can provide help to Croatia in the order of close to EUR 9 million, to Bulgaria for EUR 10.5 million, and to Serbia, a country that is eligible and is now in negotiations. But what is the most important point I want to convey? That I have heard from many of you a desire that we improve our budgetary process. That next year we do better, we engage earlier, we work harder and we reach a deal on a more structured, trust-based basis. If there is one thing I have been very concerned about during these negotiations, it is that they have shown a degree of erosion of trust, and we have – for the sake of our people – to restore trust. We have to build a budget that is more joyful. We need budget negotiations that are a more joyful event than those we are leaving behind. Once again, I would like to thank the Italian Presidency for its sweat and tears. Thank you to the negotiators in the Parliament. What we have is a budget of responsibility.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for the debate that has been held and I would also like to thank Commissioner Georgieva. Reaching agreement on the 2015 budget and all the amending budgets for 2014 – I said this at the beginning and I will say it again in conclusion – shows that we share many objectives and that our positions are not so far apart and that the differences can be overcome successfully. As mentioned on several occasions, the budgetary procedure has taken place this year under particularly difficult conditions and it is only thanks to the efforts of each individual actor involved that we have managed to reach agreement on a realistic and balanced budget for 2015 and to stem the growth of unpaid invoices. I would like to stress that the Italian Presidency is satisfied with the result achieved and is grateful to all of you for the spirit of compromise that has been shown. At the same time, we are aware that, as stated in the joint declarations agreed in the context of the adoption of the budget, a great deal of work awaits us for next year and I hope that we will be able to carry it forward in the same constructive spirit that marked the final phase of our most recent negotiations.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, we had a very interesting debate and it was a debate which has perfectly reflected what Parliament's concerns have been throughout this year in which we have been working on the budget and, above all, during the negotiations we have had with the Council and with the help of the European Commission. Of all those of us who have intervened, I believe that there has been no one who has not referred to the very serious problem we have of defaults.  Some of us are more Europeanist and more enthusiastic; others are less so, but all of us who have spoken have talked about the European Union's serious problem of non-payment. And it is clear that, since 1 January next year, we have to put ourselves to work on that plan on which we have placed so much hope and in which we have relied so much to accept this agreement which , as I said in my first speech - is not satisfactory, at least for Parliament. And it is not because we really believe that the European Union can do much more with a better budget. And since I am European, and as I believe that the European budget can contribute a great deal to the European project, I am not satisfied with the agreement we have reached. But it is also true that, if it had been for some of us, we would not have a budget, we would not have humanitarian aid, we would not have Erasmus grants and, as the Commissioner said, we would not have even money to pay the aid to the 6,000 parades we voted for this morning in plenary, and I think we also have to be consistent with that work. So we've got a lot of work to do. I believe that 2015 is going to be a crucial year, because if we can implement a plan that really solves the problem of defaults, we will be able to deal with the coming years and the next budget negotiations in a better situation than we have faced this year. Because the worst thing, probably, wasn't the numbers. The worst thing about this negotiation has been to see how the Council could not find a negotiating position, and it was to see how some countries were more concerned to see how the money was coming home than to try to solve the problems of the country sitting next to it.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Rapporteur. - (DE) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In the end, I would also like to say a heartfelt thank you once again for the difficult but successful work.  Above all, however, I would like to add to the words of my colleague Eider Gardiazabal Rubial: in the future, we will be asked in Europe whether we are prepared to promote innovation, research, jobs and the future viability of the European Union.  We will not only be asked for old invoices. In other words, we must solve both problems: paying the old bill, but also the ability to innovate and the ability to channel our financial resources towards it.  That is why it is important to me that innovation programmes, and that an investment package, should not be at the expense of innovation, as Mr Ehler has said, but that we will use resources from other areas. And we will have to discuss it for the future. It is important to me that we in Europe – whether that is the case in the field of IT, in the field of future technologies, in the field of information technologies, in the field of aerospace, in relation to the independence of the European Union in terms of competitiveness in a wide range of areas – we should stand up. Elsewhere, competition is growing, and that is why we need to plan the budget carefully. One step has been taken, but many steps still need to be taken. For the reason, on the one hand, thanks, but also the knowledge that there is still a great deal to be done.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow the page will be turned, at least for 2014-2015, and regrets are no longer of any use. In fact, regrets are not a policy. In my opinion, the best thing to do now is to look to the future. It seems to me that there are three important things for the future. With regard to the immediate future, we have reached an agreement between the three institutions for the plan to clear the outstanding debts, within a time frame that has been set. We will therefore ensure that this clean-up plan becomes a reality and that all institutions live up to their commitments. For the medium-term future, several speakers have said this, but this is a no-brainer: the current system is gradually reaching paralysis and will lead to a deadlock, since it is based on the contributions of Member States, taken from their national budgets. The issue of own resources will become a political emergency. We feel that if we continue in the current logic, all the Member States will become little Margaret Thatchers, who ask for their money back, and gradually this will lead to a total impasse. For the more distant future, I have a concern: I am convinced that citizens' support for the European budget will not increase in the coming years, if we persist in the current logic. For the most part, expenditure and means of payment pass through intermediary institutions, which forget to tell citizens that the money they receive comes from the European institutions. I am convinced that, if we want to legitimise the European budget in the eyes of public opinion in the future, we will have to find a way - not for now, but it will be necessary - to establish a direct link, so that the European citizen perceives the effort that is made in common for the benefit of all. In any case, I would like to thank the European Parliament's delegation. It has been a great experience, under the authority of our President, and I am proud to have worked with colleagues, whom I would like to thank again.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, briefly, what was finally agreed for 2014 and 2015 is a typical compromise: nobody is happy, major problems have been postponed, but more destabilisation of the budget has been achieved. My hope lies really with the so-called payments plan, because it should reveal what really has not been paid and make the situation and understanding in the Member States more dramatic. As for the amendment to the Regulation on own resources: yes, we need transparency; we need some knowledge of how it is being produced over time, what is the cost of delays in payments. Because, the iron rule, so far, was really to pay everything that was due to the EU budget on 1 December. And now we are really making an exception to this iron rule of the EU budget, so we should know the consequences. So, thank you, my hope is for a better conciliation next year; I remain silent.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 17 December. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – Yesterday, in the European Parliament's Committee on Budgets, we adopted by a large majority the agreement on the EU budget for 2015 and the additional resources for 2014. The huge advantage of the agreement is that it would be able to pass the 2015 EU budget later this year, i.e. next year it would not only be possible to pay 12th of this year's budget per month. The EP contributed to the adoption of next year's EU budget on the condition that the European Commission draw up a plan to settle unpaid bills. In 2014, EUR 23.4 billion will be paid out of the invoice from the previous year. To this end, the EP and the Council agreement provide an additional resource of nearly EUR 4 billion. During the negotiation of the 2015 budget, we defended the cohesion and agricultural resources that are important to Hungary. We thus rejected the European Commission's proposal to cover the damage caused by the Russian embargo by redeploying 1% of direct payments to farmers. It is a success that we have protected the direct payments that are important to Hungarian farmers! The adoption of the 2015 budget could be jeopardised if the plenary adopts a single amendment to the budget for the proposal. At that point, conciliation negotiations would have to be re-convened, and therefore we would no longer be able to adopt the budget this year. The Hungarian People's Party delegation will decide responsibly on behalf of the national interests of Hungary, i.e. it will also vote in plenary on the agreement and reject any amendments that threaten it.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – With the approval of this budget, another farce ends, with the expected result. The major powers have once again imposed their law and forced a budget even below the proposal previously put forward by the European Commission, already in poverty. Parliament has endorsed the budget proposal but, as always, has adopted it, fulfilling its role as the Council's soundbox – in one and the other the voices and interests of the major powers are echoing stronger. In a process of capitalist integration of the EU type, the dynamics of divergence tend to increase – a consequence of free competition in the single market, common policies and, in general, the principles inscribed in the Treaties. Inequalities between countries and regions are aggravated. The budget would play a decisive role in mitigating (and, desirably, even in the reversal) of this dynamic of divergence and accentuation of inequalities. However, due to its lack of fact, it never fulfilled this role. The novelty here will be that never before as today has been so far from fulfilling this role. The budget is reduced. The sums allocated to cohesion are reduced – increasingly, mere dead letter in the Treaties. Even what is stipulated is not fulfilled, as was again the case in 2014, requiring the adoption of several amending budgets.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: in writing. – In the past summer Bulgaria suffered damages of over 300 million euro. destructive floods in different parts of the country. The floods took dozens of casualties, hundreds were evacuated and housed in temporary housing. Parts of public infrastructure - roads, power lines and water supply and water supply and services - were destroyed. It is imperative to restore infrastructure and cover the costs of rescue operations, as well as clean up flood-affected regions. This is also the case in bulgaria's neighbouring countries - Serbia and Croatia. I believe that now is the right time for the European Union to show empathy and solidarity to disaster victims, and that Europe is indeed close to its citizens.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Since we have met today to discuss the budget, I would like to take this opportunity to point out another potential for savings: I believe that payments under the IPA instrument to Turkey can be stopped in their entirety. Payments to Turkey have amounted to €4.8 billion since 2007. On average, the annual payment is increased by around 11%, but Turkey's approach to European values is the opposite. On Sunday 14 December, turkish police detained a total of 31 people, including the editor-in-chief of the daily newspaper "Zaman", Ekrem Dumanli. This is another wave of arbitrary arrests designed to silence political opponents and critics. Instead of imposing harsh sanctions on Turkey's ever-increasing aversion to European values and democracy in general, the EU can continue to be held back. Why are no sanctions, as in the case of Russia, imposed within a few weeks, being imposed on Turkey in order to return them to a democratic path?

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. – A letter of amendment No 1 to the 2015 budget proposal from the College of Commissioners of the European Commission proposing to reduce direct payments within the agricultural department of the EU budget for 2015 is unacceptable to sober-minded Europeans. The measures taken because of the Russian embargo would be financed by the EU budget from the Crisis Fund against European farmers. However, under current legislation, the use of the crisis fund can be achieved by withdrawing direct payments placed in the reserve. Agriculture ministers from 21 Member States objected at the council meeting. According to my calculations, this would result in a reduction of around EUR 15 million per year for Hungarian and Slovak farmers. Furthermore, the pooling of crisis fund resources before the start of the year would remove any budgetary room for manoe d'2 from the EU's response to any crisis that may arise during the year directly affecting the agricultural sector. We must not forget that the Russian import ban was not caused by agriculture, so I find it extremely unfair that the measures put in place should be paid for by farmers.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. It must be admitted that the agreement that has finally been reached on the 2015 budget and the 2014 amending budget is not fully satisfactory to both parties: Parliament wanted more, the Council less. It is also true, however, that it will make it possible to pay part of the arrears of 2014 and to launch growth for next year, with sufficient appropriations in relation to the objectives that the EU has set itself. In particular, it was thanks to the work of Parliament - which was able, in opening negotiations, to take stock of the fundamental issues - that agreement was reached. An agreement which does not fully meet the initial objectives, but which avoids, on the one hand, the adoption of the provisional exercise and, on the other hand, avoids a dangerous stalemate that would have seriously damaged the Member States themselves. We are aware that the funds allocated and the related measures that will follow are not yet sufficient to link a strong and lasting economic recovery, but we are proud that under the Italian Presidency there has been a change of pace: that of a Europe that aims for development and does not just concern itself with making ends meet.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. – To my relief, the European Parliament, together with the European Commission and the Council, managed to reach a compromise on the amending budgets for 2014 and the 2015 budget. Although the negotiations have been made more difficult by the Council's selfish and irresponsible stance in particular, it is commendable that Parliament's representatives have succeeded in ensuring that the volume of the most urgent outstanding invoices is reduced and that next year's budget is at least slightly increased. Although the payment crisis has been averted, the result cannot be considered very satisfactory. It is no longer possible to close its eyes to the European Union's protracted payment problems, thus jeoparding the fulfilment of the commitments set out by the Council itself towards students, SMEs, NGOs and others. It is intolerable to constantly try to accommodate Member States that have ignored Parliament for 21 days of conciliation and were only interested in postponing their additional payments for next year. I therefore support not only an early audit, which must clarify how the European Union is doing with its debts, the creation of a follow-up plan to push debt to sustainable levels, but also the reform of the European Union's own resources. It is inconceived that, in the context of the budgetary procedure, which should serve more to set budgetary priorities, the European Parliament should be kept in tongs by the Council, as we have seen in recent years.

name: Emil RADEV
text: in writing. – When negotiations on the draft budget for 2015 and amending budgets for 2014 failed a month ago, the European Union was on the brink of a new financial crisis due to deferred, delayed or outstanding payments, which would have very seriously affected Bulgaria. Given that European funds account for the largest share of foreign investment in the country, any delay in payments from Brussels leads to serious problems in the Bulgarian economy and directly affects thousands of people. I am therefore happy that an agreement has been reached in due course, which will finally allow Member States, including Bulgaria, to benefit from the new funds under the multiannual financial framework, which in turn will lead to a revival of the economy. The adoption of the budget will also support the faster recovery of flood-affected regions this year. The funds allocated by the Solidarity Fund, while insufficient to cover all flood damage, are long-awaited aid that must now be used as intended. I would also like to call once again for more investment in the prevention of natural disasters, which will reduce the need to activate the Solidarity Fund. I hope that next year the process of adopting the budget will be more seamless, because in the end the funds are important for the development of all Member States, not just Bulgaria.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – We think it is debatable whether the new strategic fund proposed by the Juncker Commission will trigger new economic activity. The budget before us today equally contains investment funds, and it is important to ensure that these are mobilised efficiently. The record on investment disbursements from the budget is unsatisfactory, absorption of funds low, and delay in project implementation the rule. One reason for this has been the burdensome rules for the vetting, approval and implementation of projects. A case in point is roadwork contracts in Malta. Though miniscule by European standards, they were subject to Brussels-based contract and award rules even when their size makes them unattractive to outside contractors. That lack of interest delays project preparation. Meanwhile, the need to follow to the letter Brussels-based procedures creates problems of compliance for small-scale Maltese contractors. So, projects are delayed. Costs escalate. As the end of the pluri-annual budget period approaches, roadworks are rushed and bunched together, leading to traffic congestion, faulty workmanship and cost overruns. It is imperative to raise the absorption rate of capital projects funded by the EU budget. The dilution of one-size-fits-all policies and a more stringent application of the principle of subsidiarity need to become real priorities.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: written – I fundamentally disagree with the draft EU budget presented. The European Union budget is already funding a large number of projects of dubious importance and its resources are being used extremely inefficiently. In a situation where the vast majority of EU spending serves for redistribution, such as payments to farmers or cohesion funds, efforts to increase the EU budget are completely taken away from reality. However, in order for the European Union budget to be truly reformed, a change in the EU's philosophy is needed. In fact, not public spending and central planning, but only lower tax burdens and a freer market can restore economic growth and reduce unemployment. Until the European Union can agree to this, the European Union's budget will continue to waste taxpayers' money massively and will continue to significantly distort the market.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – This report aims at reacting to the Commission’s proposal on the adjustment of the Member States’ (MS) national contributions to the financing of the EU budget. As it has emerged, a number of MS have underpaid their contributions to the Union’s budget over a number of years, while others have overpaid theirs. Against this background the Commission adopted a proposal to amend the existing rules in order to give MS the possibility, under specific circumstances, of making available the amounts of own resources after the current deadline of 1 December. Although the Commission’s proposal aims at giving MS more flexibility, it also risks making the current own-resources system even more complex and less transparent. Furthermore, the Commission’s proposal could create a precedent which would affect the level and timing of payments to benefactors. Since we are already facing a growing shortage of payments, this scheme could influence the implementation of the 2014-2020 MFF and the credibility of the Union’s budget. A real remedy to overcoming the deficiencies of the current system is an extensive reform of the EU’s own-resources system that takes the European Parliament proposals into consideration as well as the work carried out by the high-level group on own resources.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – Mr President, the draft budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 is a major challenge for the European institutions, as its adoption continues in the context of the ongoing economic crisis, which has disrupted the finances of the Community as a whole. The financial institutions, the Member States, especially in southern Europe, are the main responsible for the current crisis, but also, which is worth remembering, the EU bureaucracy, which has responded to the situation too slowly and inadequately. The draft budget for next year is therefore very important in view of the prospects for economic recovery. It is therefore essential that the 2015 budget includes additional funds to promote the functioning of the economy while protecting the most vulnerable social groups. It is good that the main allocation for this purpose is around EUR 67 billion, which will be allocated to growth and employment. Supporting the improvement of social, regional and economic cohesion should become an important element. The European Parliament should support these budgetary provisions, which will also increase funding for education, research and innovation, as their growth of 38% is projected next year compared to the previous year. But what seems to be the most important thing, especially for countries in Central and Eastern Europe such as Lithuania, is a special focus on farmers. They are most affected by the effects of a balanced food market. The Union should therefore allocate the available surplus from the special reserves to compensate for the losses of European agriculture.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the council and Commission statements on the funding bottleneck for the World Food Programme (2014/2996(RSP)).

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is the world's largest donor of humanitarian assistance and bilateral assistance from the Member States represents a considerable part of these efforts. Eu ropean Union Member States alone have provided almost one and a half billion euros of humanitarian assistance since the start of the Syrian crisis in 2011. This is in addition to the EUR 666 million in humanitarian aid from the Eu ropean Union budget and provided by the Commission.  As honourable Members are aware, the Council has just approved, together with Parliament, the 2014 amending budget, making a further EUR 214 million available to the Commission's humanitarian aid budget for this year. Much of this amount is used for the European Union's response to the Syrian crisis. This is a clear demonstration of our commitment to providing humanitarian aid to those in need, particularly those affected by the Syrian crisis.  Yesterday, the Council adopted conclusions on the situation in Syria and we expressed our grave concern at the dramatic lack of funding in response to the UN's calls for 2014, which led to the temporary suspension of assistance to Syrian refugees by the World Food Programme – the World Food Programme – and we called on the international community to step up funding in the run-up to winter and in response to the forthcoming calls for 2015. But we did not just ask the others, the Member States were among the main donors who reacted immediately to the World Food Programme's emergency appeal for funding for Syria. For example, the Netherlands, Germany, Ireland and Belgium collectively contributed more than $14 million.  Together with the Commission's contribution from the Eu ropean Union budget, this brings the European Union's collective response to this emergency appeal to more than EUR 20 million. We welcome the fact that this has now succeeded in helping to fill the shortfall experienced by the World Food Programme and that food aid for 1.7 million Syrian refugees can resume as planned. It is tragic that in a crisis the size of the Syrian crisis there can barely be enough money to meet all the needs of internally displaced persons. Many of those who had to leave Syria often did so by carrying nothing but the clothes they were wearing. But we can certainly make sure that we do not increase their suffering. Reducing food assistance to those who have lost everything is unacceptable to the Council and to the Member States. In the Council we have coordinated very closely, between the Member States and also with the Commission, the response to this unprecedented crisis. We make sure that there is no overlap in our collective response as we try to fill, as best we can, the gaps in global funding. In this context, let me also point out that the Member States of the European Union are one of the main donors of the World Food Programme. Even before the recent emergency appeal, EU Member States had paid more than EUR 150 million to the World Food Programme in 2014, just for its action in the context of the Syrian crisis. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we believe that the World Food Programme is one of our main executive partners for the provision of European Union humanitarian assistance. Both as the European Union and as Member States, we have a long tradition of cooperation on a bilateral basis. We will therefore ensure, together with the World Food Programme, that appropriate measures are taken in terms of both funding and planning. We must ensure that shortcomings such as the one we have seen do not happen again. We owe it to all the people we are trying to help, first and foremost the innocent victims of the terrible war in Syria.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I am grateful for the opportunity to address this important issue today. There is no question but that the Syrian crisis is unprecedented. Both in terms of its humanitarian consequences and for its financial implications. An immediate reaction by international donors is a precondition for avoiding a further deterioration in the situation. A comprehensive response to the crisis cannot be built on our normal budgets. We must work together to make a strong EU response possible. We have a collective responsibility to find the means to achieve this goal.  The WFPʼs decision to cut back food assistance is a reminder of the overwhelming impact of the biggest humanitarian tragedy of our times. I want to underline that the EU as a whole is responding to the Syrian crisis needs. We are responding to the call by the WFP which has resumed its aid scheme to Syrian refugees.  I want to express my sincere appreciation for the broad support of this Parliament in this crisis. The European Union has led the international response to the Syrian crisis. We have provided more than EUR 3.1 billion. Of this, EUR 681 million has come from the Commission’s humanitarian budget, with EUR 120 million provided for WFPʼs operations in Syria and neighbouring countries.  The WFP is our second largest humanitarian partner after the UNHCR. We are fully committed to our partnership with the WFP. As a matter of urgency, we have allocated an additional EUR 5.5 million to the WFPʼs aid scheme for Syrian refugees. With this amount, our funding for 2014 is up to EUR 18 million, on top of the EUR 61 million allocated in December 2013. We will continue our efforts to mobilise additional resources. It is no accident that a few days ago both the WFP and Valerie Amos from OCHA, who is very well known, expressed their appreciation to the EU for our generous humanitarian support. It is true that the WFP has by far the biggest needs in this crisis, estimated to reach USD 1.8 billion this year. This amount goes beyond the USD 1.6 billion needs of the UNHCR. The fact that approximately only 60% of these needs are matched with funding is a major problem. Unfortunately the WFP is only one of the many partners in desperate need of funding. For this reason we have repeatedly warned the donor community that the gap between needs and funding is unfortunately not sustainable. Syria is the biggest crisis we face today but it is not the only crisis. Think of Iraq, the Central African Republic, South Sudan, etc. All of these crises have stretched humanitarian budgets beyond their limits. Certainly money will never be enough; therefore we need more cost-effective and more targeted operations from humanitarian partners. This also applies to the WFP.  This year we will finish with EUR 165 million in humanitarian assistance for the Syrian crisis. This is already less than half of the exceptional EUR 350 million we managed to mobilise in 2012. Next year our Commissionʼs initial humanitarian funding will be down to 100 million.  There will be additional money forthcoming soon. I will use all the leverage I have to achieve that. But my efforts alone, unfortunately, are not enough. We need strong collective action for next year. We expect needs of USD 7.2 billion for the Syrian crisis alone. This is a substantial increase compared to the record figure of USD 6 billion for this year. The Syrian crisis will remain a top priority in the years to come. The whole region is feeling its impact. We have to find ways to increase funding and make it sustainable, otherwise it will be a short fix. We must adopt a long-term approach. We must continue honouring our pledges. It is not only our moral duty, it is also a question of life or death for millions of Syrian refugees. As you know, a few days ago I came back from a joint mission with Vice-President Federica Mogherini and Commissioner Johannes Hahn to Turkey. There we also visited refugee camps along the Syrian border. The situation on the ground is overwhelming. Cuts in food assistance will be felt there first. It is our collective responsibility to stop this from happening. We must work together to avoid this situation. At the end of the day, however, what is needed for the Syrian crisis is a political solution. UN Special Envoy de Mistura has our full support in this regard. It is a support reflected yesterday in the Foreign Affairs Council conclusions.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Mr. President, in the four years of the armed conflict in Syria, we have heard and emphasized several times in this house that this is the biggest humanitarian crisis facing the world today. 14 million people in Syria are in urgent need of humanitarian assistance, including 5 million children. One million and 700,000 refugees in neighbouring countries have used the UN's worldwide food programme, which suspended aid deliveries for several days in December due to a lack of funding.  What is encouraging is the fact that the funds were raised as soon as possible for the world food programme to continue operating. It also encourages the swift response of our Commissioner Christos Stylianides, who immediately announced additional financial assistance for this program. It is important to note here that the EU has settled its commitments to the world food programme on time, as there has been a variety of disinformation about debts under this UN programme. In this case, the European Union remitted the funds in time, but this case also underlines the importance of making timely funding in humanitarian aid. In many cases, people's lives depend on it.  However, other partners in the international community should also be invited to take more responsibility in the financing of humanitarian aid. It is clear that to address the humanitarian crisis in Syria, it is necessary to focus first on the causes of the conflict and reach a political solution, but in the meantime Europe and the international community must not falter in providing humanitarian aid.

name: Norbert NEUSER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. All politicians want a lot of help for the Syrian refugees. But there is still a lack of money. The World Food Programme cannot fulfil its obligations. Food is saved. The pathos of politicians are clear: they warn of death and misery. Let me give you an example: the German Federal Government – my party belongs to this government. She says it's a disaster of the century - you've heard right: a century's disaster. It rains, then comes the cold, then death comes. There is no lack of compassion and drama. But what is the point of pathos and drama when we see the sobriety of the numbers? Because the bare numbers are clear. The humanitarian aid budget has been shrinking steadily since 2013, and the budget is chronically and deliberately underfunded by Member States. We are pushing unpaid bills ahead of us. We should open our borders – and I am not saying this because Christmas is just around the corner – we should open our hearts, but the Member States must open their wallets!

name: Karol KARSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by One of the bloodiest conflicts of recent decades, the war in Syria, has already killed at least 200,000 people and forced hundreds of thousands of people to flee their homes. Let us give here an example of the ancient Christian city of Sadad, known from the Bible, where Aramaic was spoken, in the language of Jesus Christ. It was said, because today the city is gone, there are only ruins. Christians who have lived there for 2,000 years have been largely murdered, and those who survived have only been fleeing. More than 3 million people have fled Syria to neighbouring countries and 7 million have become internally displaced. In both groups, 6 million are children. The tragedy of these innocent people was exacerbated by news earlier this month that funds from the World Food Programme for Syrian refugees in Jordan, Lebanon, Turkey, Iraq and Egypt had been withholded. The limit, which was to guarantee the provision of food for the month of December was not reached. It has only just managed to collect it from public contributions.  I ask you, let us make sure that these refugees do not become hostages to war... (The President has taken the vote.)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I give my apologies, as immediately after my contribution I will have to leave because we have a group meeting on an important document that we are voting on tomorrow.  In fact, Commissioner, you have facilitated my comments. I was one of those who initiated this debate. I think the Commission came forward with a very quick response, but I am still concerned. I think the suspension of food assistance is not only extremely damaging, but I would even say that it is nearly a criminal act, taking into account the situation the refugees are in.  I am afraid that in a few months’ time, we will be in a very similar situation. I have understood that you are fully aware of that. I would invite you – with the support of this House – to be tough. Being tough is a cliché, but I want to express that we will support you in being demanding towards our partners. We are not just talking about the refugees, but about the situation in the neighbouring countries where we see a collapse of the economy, social system, food supplies and water supplies. Look at Lebanon, a country with a population of around 4 million, if I am not mistaken. There are over a million refugees on the borders of Lebanon. This is a serious situation. We need to pay thorough attention to this subject in the future. You will have our support, but we will have high expectations.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – The war in Syria has forced over 3 million people to seek refuge in other countries; many of them in Member States of the European Union. Following the Call of the World Food Programme on 1 December to meet their needs, a total of $88 million was raised. Six of these were put in place by the European Union, which otherwise insists on maintaining the Dublin regulations, which endanger the safety, health and very lives of these people. The falsified common European asylum system established by these regulations is an inhumane system that traps refugees in the countries of entry, i.e. in Mediterranean countries such as Greece and Italy, which have long exceeded their limits. Even recognition of their refugee status as a priority will not guarantee refugees decent living conditions or address the violations of international human rights law caused by the massive influx into these countries. We therefore demand a fairer system of sharing responsibilities. The time has come for the countries of Central and Northern Europe, which are in fact the countries of destination for migrants, to show whether they are in practice embracing the principle of solidarity proclaimed by the European Treaties.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I would praise you for your swift actions, amongst others, in reacting to this remarkable crisis that the UN Food Programme has brought about. I have a couple of concrete questions for you about it: do we think there is a systemic problem within the World Food Programme that brought about the suspension of aid? Were they simply overwhelmed, in which case we lent a hand to the tiller? Or is there a policy issue that actually led to this remarkable action, which really does need to be examined further given its consequences?  I was glad to hear about your joint trip to the region with your fellow Commissioners, and the humanitarian aspects of this are only part of the story. As you rightly say, we need a political solution. Therefore, could you give us a bit more information about how the EU and your services are coordinating amongst the Member States as regards the ongoing military engagement of a number of our Member States within this theatre, which are having a variety of consequences, and indeed as regards a coherent refugee policy on the part of a number of our Member States, some of whom have considerably better records than others?

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, the suspension of the UN World Food Programme is disastrous. Refugees struggle to survive through the winter without having the basics for food and health. 1,700,000 souls, refugees from Syria, have fled to Jordan, Lebanon, Turkey, Iraq and Egypt. From there they try to reach Europe, which they see as the promised land. You can't stop a hungry man from looking for ways to survive. The United States has expressed its concern and is calling on the international community to do more. But who is responsible for this situation? Who brought hunger and destruction to Syria and forces its people to take the path of refugees? The great powers, which with war operations and under the pretext of the so-called liberation and restoration of democracy are trying to impose their policies. America and Europe are complicit in this situation. Everywhere we look, in Iraq, Syria and Libya, the results of the interventions are disastrous. Chaos and anarchy prevail. Refugees, in order to escape in search of a better future, lose their lives in the waters of the Mediterranean. The countries of the South, such as Greece, which have suffered the suffering of the economic crisis, are taking in thousands of Syrian refugees seeking asylum.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for the information you have provided us. I welcome the view that, as indicated, on 9 December the World Food Programme was able to resume its food assistance work to many Syrian displaced persons and refugees through global contributions and, of course, at European level. It cannot be ruled out that in the coming months we will find each other in the same situation again. Therefore, greater commitment from the entire international community must be achieved in order to alleviate the needs of these millions of displaced Syrians, especially in the face of the impending winter. On the other hand, as you said, Commissioner, we must continue to work on an inclusive political solution. But as the first and most urgent step, the level of violence must also be reduced. And, in this regard, I hope that this novel proposal by the United Nations Special Envoy to start by creating these zones or situations free of hostility or frozen, the so-called 'local freezes of hostility', can succeed. I would like this new initiative to serve to ensure security and prevent the displacement of thousands of Syrians. But, ladies and gentlemen, in order to achieve a political solution we also need to strengthen moderate Syrian forces. They are fragmented, have lost prominence and are also attacked by both the regime's troops and active terrorist groups in the region. Since I am talking about a region, neighbouring countries and other international actors must also influence the parties to end the conflict. And I'm done. The European Union is being a vital player, as you have explained to us, Commissioner, in terms of humanitarian aid. It also has to be so in the search for a political solution to the conflict.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, the civil war in Syria is one of the greatest tragedies of this decade and no end seems to be in sight. We have witnessed large-scale war and violence, tens of thousands of people killed, huge destruction inflicted on this country, millions of people displaced or taking refuge in the neighbouring country. At the same time, the emergency services involved in nourishing and protecting Syrian refugees are under-financed. There is a vital food shortage for 1.7 million refugees in Turkey, Lebanon, Jordan, Iraq and Egypt, people included in the EU Food Aid Programme.  This emergency is a tremendous challenge for the host countries. We are not providing these countries which have generously opened their borders to the refugees with adequate financial and burden-sharing solidarity. We should not hesitate to increase our allocation of funds in response to the ongoing humanitarian crisis in Syria and in neighbouring countries. Public mobilisation, including private donors, individuals and governments, has helped the World Food Programme maintain its response to this particular case, but it cannot be the permanent solution. It remains the responsibility of the EU Member States to respect their commitments, and our citizens support us in doing so. Refuges affected by the conflict were forced to leave their homeland and live in camps. They are suffering and dying from hunger and cold. They are extremely dependent on international aid. The survival of these people is essential and must be our priority.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! It is tragic that the World Food Programme has had to suspend its aid in Syria, and it is perfectly clear that, in this situation, the European Union has a responsibility to resume it. This applies to the Member States as well as to the European Union itself, and that further resources must be mobilised here. After all, we must take note of the fact that, without the political influence of the European Union, the situation as we now find it might not have occurred at all. But we continue to tinker with symptoms. It is not just a question of opening up borders and the purse strings here, but of really tackling the causes. We must also take the Responsibility of the Arab countries into account, because the Arab countries not only have the money, but they also bear an ideological-religious responsibility in particular. Because the primal problem in Syria that we are experiencing there and that we are experiencing throughout the region is Islamism, and that must not only be addressed, but also combated.

name: Javier NART
text: Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to congratulate you sincerely on the effectiveness and speed and sensitivity you have had in promoting the opening of a food programme which was absolutely essential. My recognition and my absolute applause for you and for the Commission: five and a half million euros which are in addition to the previous eighteen million euros. But there's a fundamental problem. The fundamental problem is the lack of respect for the commitment, of their commitments, by the Governments of the European Union, of the Member States. It cannot be that Parliament and the Commission end up having an ongoing fight with the Council of the European Union. I therefore ask you to try to get the governments of the Member States in order and, when you promise something, to comply with it.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation of refugees fleeing the war in Syria is indeed alarming, whether in Turkey, Jordan or Lebanon. In particular, I would like to draw your attention to the situation of Syrian Christian refugees in Lebanon, particularly in Zahle, in the Bekaa plain. These refugees arrived from the provinces of Homs and Hama at the beginning of the unrest, in particular to escape the persecution of Islamist armed groups who looted and burned their homes, and who shouted: "Christians in Beirut, Alawites at the tomb." However, they cannot be granted refugee status because the UN asks them to sign a declaration stating that they would flee persecution by the Syrian government, which no Christian accepts. On the other hand, armed terrorist groups that, in turn, have fled with their weapons to the Bekaa as a result of securing Homs province enjoy refugee status and the financial benefits that result. It is time for Member States to call on the Un to end this unacceptable discrimination against Syrian Christian refugees.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Mr President, it might seem that the world is falling apart. These are not my words, but the Secretary-General of the United Nations. The situation has been described by the honourable Members. It's critical. Imagine a European city of around 1.7 million inhabitants. For example, Vienna. Let's imagine that your women, your children, your men were without food and without shelter. Wouldn't there be an impressive mobilization to help them? How much mobilization would such a crisis generate? The United Nations and its agencies say they can't do it anymore. They have to be behind governments for governments to meet their commitments. And we know we have to do more, much more than we're doing. And we know that richer countries should share the burden on refugees for countries that have many difficulties. Millions of refugees: in Lebanon, in Jordan, in Turkey. The absorption capacity of these countries is not infinite and we are watching it without doing anything in return. UNHCR is asking developed countries to take in 130,000 Syrian refugees, which is one-tenth of what countries like Turkey or Lebanon are hosting. Brazil, for example, has taken in 1,500 refugees. What are we doing in the European Union? This time, the situation has been resolved quickly and effectively, Commissioner. He has our support to remain this firm and so sensitive.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Since 2011, millions of civilians - innocent men, women, but also children and the elderly - have suffered because of the military conflict in Syria. Millions of Syrians have had to flee their homes, with up to a third forced to flee across the border to neighbouring countries. These people have lost their roof over their heads, their jobs, their regular income, and therefore access to what is absolutely essential to survival – and therefore to food and warm clothes. These people have lost their dignity. The World Food Programme, to which the European Union also contributes, plays a key role in helping the victims of this terrible war. At the beginning of December, however, part of this aid had to be suspended due to a lack of funding, which caused a large proportion of Syrian refugees to find themselves in very difficult living conditions, which, moreover, are complicated by the banging winter. The necessary funds for December and part of January were finally raised. In future, however, we must not allow these defenceless people to experience a sense of danger and, above all, of insecurity. In such difficult situations, it is important not to relieve.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: Mr President, the resumption of aid is welcomed with great relief. With Syria’s civil war in its fourth winter, the World Food Programme’s suspension of aid due to a shortage of funds would have a devastating impact on thousands of refugees. The cycle of the large-scale crisis has stretched humanitarian organisations to their limits. Despite the increase in humanitarian funding, the gap between need and available resources keeps growing. It is not enough simply to strive for the better use of scarce resources, although funding humanitarian emergencies must be a top priority. It is even more crucial that we sever the problem from the roots. There is a direct link between the humanitarian situation in Syria and the international response. If the international community had cooperated earlier on in dealing with the brutal Assad regime, the humanitarian situation would not have spiralled out of control. Even the elimination of ISIS will not end radicalised opposition. New groups in Syria are likely to emerge to fill the void. We must tackle the radicalisation by addressing the desperate human aid needs today. It is our moral responsibility to help the refugees.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: Mr President, Syria has been going through a civil war for too long with absolutely unbearable and dramatic consequences: 200,000 dead; 11 million Syrians in need of humanitarian aid today, half of them children; 3.25 million displaced persons outside Syria; 150,000 people who have applied for asylum from States of the European Union. And to all this we must add systematic violations of human rights – rapes, torture, use of chemical weapons – that are absolutely unbearable. And in the face of this, which is probably the largest humanitarian drama in the world, our response has been absolutely inadequate. That is why today the European Parliament should send four very clear messages. The first, which is a shame, a disgrace, that the United Nations food programme, which assists 1.7 million Syrians, has had to be suspended, if only momentarily, over the past week. Second, that El Asad is never going to be our partner, but you need to recognize him as an actor to find a political solution in the area. Third, and also very important, that the initiative of the United Nations special envoy in the area should be supported. And fourth, and just as relevant, that it is necessary to recognize the work of the 23 million euros that... (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the World Food Programme has stopped distributing food for millions of Syrian refugees fleeing war. Without the aid provided, many families are at risk of starvation and of not being able to prepare properly for the winter, not having adequate clothes available and living in makeshift tents. Vouchers are also important not only for refugees but also to feed the economies of host nations, such as Jordan, Lebanon, Iraq and Egypt. The blocking of aid could therefore have a devastating impact throughout the region, fuelling tensions and instability. I believe that the European Union has the task of giving a strong impetus to the resumption of the programme, encouraging the entire international community to contribute. In this respect, I welcome the European Commission's efforts to launch the EU Regional Trust Fund, a new strategic funding instrument to mobilise aid to refugees and host communities in neighbouring countries, and I congratulate the Council and the High Representative for Foreign Affairs on their efforts to find a solution to the Syrian crisis. I hope that these actions will be able to give concrete help to the Syrian refugees and at the same time encourage the international community to act in the same direction.

name: Ska KELLER
text: Madam President! People are starving precisely because states, and hence EU states, have not kept their financial commitments and continue to fail to comply, even after the new call for the World Food Programme. Some Member States give absolutely nothing, others give far too little. This is about refugees, we are talking about vulnerable people. The conflict in Syria did not come to us surprisingly only yesterday. Winter has not come as a surprise either. Nor can we wait for a political solution to the conflict at some point. We must act now! Syria's neighbours are now doing dramatic work. We must take this as an example. We must act now, we must not postpone this until tomorrow. We cannot explain to anyone who is now starving, who is now freezing in the refugee camp, why they have to wait, why they have to wait until a political solution is found. We must act now. We must not leave neighbouring countries alone, and we must not leave the refugees alone.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, first of all I would like to thank Members for their comments and consideration, and at the same time for their good words to me. I have felt your support, and I thank you very much for this support in this very difficult job and in these very difficult circumstances. Let me finish with three clear conclusions of our debate today. Firstly, I repeat that the crisis we are discussing today is unprecedented, both in terms of its humanitarian consequences for millions of people, and, of course, its financial implications. It is a crisis that has enormous implications for Europe – for us. A comprehensive response to this crisis cannot be built on our normal budgets. This is, unfortunately, very clear. As you have already mentioned, a credible EU response is needed. We have the collective responsibility to find the means to make it possible, and we need to realise that if we do not invest sufficient funds in the region, the consequences will surely be felt far outside the region. My second point is that we are doing everything possible, within the Commission and together with our Member States, to respond effectively to the needs. The European Union, as a whole, has led the international response to the Syrian crisis. We are the leading donor to the Syrian cause. We must remain the leaders in this regard.  Thirdly, the humanitarian response cannot stand by itself. This is a protracted crisis. It requires an integrated response in close cooperation with development actors and national authorities. We are already working together with our development colleagues to better integrate the humanitarian aid with the resilience stabilisation assistance. On this, again, we need to find ways to step up our financial assistance. At the end of the day, the Syrian crisis requires – as you mentioned – a political solution. Unfortunately, the humanitarian problems need a political solution and humanitarian assistance at the urgent stage. We need to work hard with all actors involved to achieve this very difficult goal. I am sure that our support as the European Union to the initiative of Special Envoy de Mistura is crucial, critical and helpful.  Thank you again for your attention. I look forward to our continued cooperation in these very difficult circumstances.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for the debate and I would also like to thank the Commissioner for his very precise and explicit words. There is no lack of commitment or action in the European Union when it comes to providing humanitarian assistance to the victims of the Syrian crisis. Total EU humanitarian assistance since the beginning of the crisis exceeds EUR 2.1 billion and we are also a major donor to the World Food Programme and strongly support its action for Syrian refugees. Our contribution to the recent emergency appeal has demonstrated this once again and, together with the World Food Programme, the Member States will ensure that the available funding can be used in the most efficient and effective way. Planning and setting appropriate priorities will be crucial to this, and I am sure that together we will be able to achieve it.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. The World Food Programme has been forced to announce the suspension of its delivery of food stamps to more than 1.7 million Syrian refugees. This suspension will endanger the health and safety of these populations, and may lead to new tensions in the host countries. In Lebanon, the High Commission for Refugees currently lists more than one million Syrian refugees, the largest concentration of refugees in recent history. The arrival of this population has had a devastating impact on the political, economic and social stability of the country. It has also led to a continued deterioration of peace and security among the population, with a worrying rise in attacks on refugees, while Daesh is on the country's borders and poses an ever-on threat. In the face of this chaotic situation, the Union had to help. I welcome the fact that the Commission decided on 4 December to grant an aid plan of 180 million euros to deal with the effects of this crisis, of which 73 million will go to Lebanon, to finance access to care and education for vulnerable populations as a priority.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – The Syrian civil war continues to be one of the greatest humanitarian disasters of the current period, with at least 1.7 million people being refugees. The horrors of the civil war have now been compounded by ISIL's crimes in both Syria and Iraq, which have added further refugees. The survival of these people depends directly on international humanitarian aid. Every opportunity must therefore be made to ensure adequate humanitarian assistance for these people. The suspension of the UN food programme for the lack of money against winter is staggering. The UN, the EU, the Arab League and other international organisations must make a significantly greater effort to ensure that these people are coping. Half the refugees are children. It is very important to provide them with education in refugee camps. The European Union must therefore, in the light of the new budget, step up aid to refugees from Syria and other conflict hotspots.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Sorin Mois' on behalf of the Committee on International Trade on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No. 55/2008 of the Council on the introduction of autonomous trade preferences for Moldova (COM(2014)0542 - C8-0128/2014 - 2014/0250 (COD)) (A8-0053/2014).

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, for the EU this file is a gesture that is symbolic in purely economic terms, but is of great political significance at a critically historic juncture for Moldova and, indeed, for our entire European Neighbourhood. For Moldova, it is a breath of fresh air in a sector of vital importance for the Moldovan economy: fruit growing. Its importance, however, goes beyond apples and plums, as we shall see in a moment. It also serves as a practical demonstration of solidarity in the face of hardship.  The EU and Moldova signed their Association Agreement on 27 June 2014. The Moldovan Parliament quickly ratified it on 2 July 2014. As if by coincidence, shortly thereafter an import ban was imposed by Russia on agricultural products from Moldova. On 7 August 2014, Russia also imposed a ban on food imports from the EU itself in the context of the Ukrainian crisis, which, of course, is linked to the wider question of our Eastern Neighbourhood. The root of the problem lies in the fact that Russia sees itself, wrongly of course, as the object of some sort of geopolitical plot by the Western world. It is a conflict generated by a dramatic clash of world views. It is the 19th century fighting the 21st century. Blood, invasion from within, propaganda, lies and apples became the ingredients of a very strange new form of warfare. Seeking some relief, the Moldovan authorities have turned to the EU requesting urgent support to reduce the economic impact of the Russian ban, in particular for the most important products of Moldovan food growers: apples, plums and table grapes. The Commission decided to respond positively. The Council agreed and I hope we, the Parliament, will also give our blessing this week.  The ban is hurting Moldova’s economy in a rather dramatic way. Agriculture accounts for around 40% of Moldova’s GDP. Its horticultural sector alone employs a quarter of a million people – that is 10% of the active Moldovan population. Obviously they mostly live in rural areas and they cultivate small and medium family plots.  A few words on the legal context of this proposal: the Autonomous Trade Preferences (ATPs) are an instrument whereby a trading power, such as ourselves, may offer concessions to a country in order to support its economy without asking for trade concessions in exchange. ATPs for Moldova were originally introduced by the EU in 2008 by the very regulation that we are amending this week. The Commission now proposes to amend the ATP regulation by introducing three new duty-free quotas for fresh apples (40 000 tonnes), tables grapes and plums (10 000 tonnes each). The quotas will apply until the end of 2015, when the whole regime will expire.  The quotas for the three products concerned are extremely limited in volume compared to the potentially competing EU production. For apples, for instance, which is the most sensitive product, it is only 0.4% of our production, and they address very different market segments than most EU production. More specifically, in light of the cultural and geographical proximity with Romania, it is very likely that most of the additional volumes of the three products will be absorbed easily by the Romanian market. For apples, for example, Romania this year has a fall of 22% in production, and the quota under discussion tonight covers only 8% only of Romanian production. So there is still a gap there to be filled by others. A few words now in Romanian. Sper ca autoritățile moldovene să reușească să transforme aceste cote într-o poveste de succes, care să ajute cu adevărat fermierii moldoveni. Și aș vrea să fac un apel și la operatorii economici din România, să folosească această oportunitate cu deschidere față de colegii din Republica Moldova. Merele, prunele și perele din Moldova sunt foarte gustoase și vă asigur că ele vor fi apreciate de consumatorii români dacă le vor găsi pe piață.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, the honour is all mine. Honourable Members, whereas the current focus in the media very much turns around the events in Ukraine, there is, as you know, another very important neighbour to the European Union, which is the Republic of Moldova. That country faces the economic consequences of a political choice to sign an Association Agreement with the European Union.  The Republic of Moldova chose that its economic development should be based on European values and a deep and comprehensive free trade area with the EU. This was a choice in favour of us, it was not directed against anyone, yet products which were almost exclusively exported to Russia can no longer find their way to that market. The preferences under the Free Trade Agreement with the Commonwealth of Independent States that Moldova enjoyed in bilateral trade with Russia were also suspended for a number of key products.  We know that it is possible to maintain free trade areas with several trade partners at the same time, and that business makes the choice of the market in which it sells its goods and services. It is not and should not be a zero sum game, which is why we need to support Moldova, our Eastern partner.
