We need to help it not only in the process of implementing the deep and comprehensive free trade area – and we are already assisting Moldova with this – but also through any other means we have.  That is why the Commission proposal to amend the autonomous trade preferences regulations offers Moldova temporary additional relief for its needs, in undertaking efforts to reroute the exports of its apples, table grapes and plums. Anyone who trades with partners abroad knows how difficult it can be to reroute exports to new markets and find new partners there. So the proposal that you will discuss here today is a temporary measure, as the rapporteur so correctly said. It will expire in a year. The Commission proposes to apply it retroactively to imports from Moldova from August this year, when the first bans were introduced on Moldovan exports. The duty free quotas proposed – for plums, apples and table grapes – do not endanger the EU market, and that was also made very clear in the statement by the rapporteur. I am aware that there are concerns here surrounding the possible impact of this on our own farmers, but I am convinced that we can support and show solidarity for Moldova without any domestic risks. To give a concrete figure – others were mentioned before and this is another one – imports of apples from Moldova equal 0.8% of total EU production, plums 1.4% and table grapes 1.1%. So I think this is a good opportunity for us to show solidarity with a neighbouring country in need. I would very much like to thank Parliament, and in particular the INTA Committee and the rapporteur, Mr Moisă, for the swift manner in which this file has been handled.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the PPE Group fully supports the adoption of the proposal on additional trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova. I think that it is important that we show once again our commitment to supporting a European course for our neighbouring state. This report, which was thoroughly presented by our rapporteur, introduces new measures to tackle the unfair commercial practices of the Russian Federation. Last year, I was the rapporteur for Moldova when the European Union proposed the full liberalisation of imports of Moldovan wine to the Community market after a similar ban by Russia on its imports. Today’s decision to supplement trade preferences complements last year’s measure of opening the EU markets to Moldovan products. I fully welcome Parliament’s approval of the draft report without amendments. I hope that we will vote on the file tomorrow and that it will be published by the end of the year, so that the Moldovan partners can benefit from these free extra quotas as soon as possible. To conclude, I hope that Moldova will keep up its efforts in view of these future European perspectives, and that the FTA will deliver its positive effects for the benefit of the economic development of Moldova and our rapprochement.

name: David MARTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, let me start by congratulating Sorin Moisă on his excellent handling of this dossier which I think is the first report he has taken through this Parliament, and also Mr Winkler for the work he has done as shadow. I think Parliament has shown that it can act with speed in the right circumstances and I think we have a good agreement here where we have assisted Moldova through our agricultural support for the three fruits that have been mentioned, but at the same time have done minimum harm – in fact, no harm at all – to the European agricultural sectors, so it is a win-win.  The European Union has committed itself to supporting Moldova through the European Partnership and Association Agreement. In the face of Russian aggression and politically motivated trade bans it is right that the EU delivers on our commitment to strengthen economic ties with Moldova and to encourage political stability in that country.

name: Dawid Bohdan JACKIEWICZ
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Almost a month ago, we held a debate in this House on the ratification of the Association Agreement with Moldova. The vast majority of us have welcomed this fact – the fact that the country has been more closely integrated into the political structures of a united Europe – very positively. It must be remembered that the Republic of Moldova has been under constant political and military pressure from Russia for many years. Russia, which is making efforts to seduze the Moldovan government and fuel separatist tendencies in the disputed regions. It is clear that Russian sanctions on the Moldovan agri-food sector are the same means of political blackmail as, for example, an embargo on Polish fruit and other agricultural products. Moldova will not be safe and sovereign if its economy is weakened or ruined by Putin's retaliation. On 27 June, we made a great commitment to say that we want Moldova closer to the European Union. The Russian embargo is aimed at the political and economic interests of the entire European Community and the aid will benefit Moldova more than the financial outlay of the States. The introduction of autonomous trade preferences for Moldova as soon as possible is justified by the economic and political interest of the Union. Let us be aware that we will have to reach out to our Moldovan friends on several occasions. If we do not want this country to share the fate of war-torn Ukraine, we must bravely face this challenge as a European community. Thank you.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, exactly a month ago, this Parliament voted in favour of the Association Agreement with Moldova. I hope we are all convinced that, by embarking on the implementation of the EU-Moldova association agenda, our aim is to make this country and the whole region more stable and prosperous. However, this is not shared by ‘Big Brother’ to the East, which chose to ban a long list of Moldovan agricultural products. This is in violation of Russia’s World Trade Organisation commitments. It clearly harms not only the Moldovan people, but the Russian people too, as the prices in Russia’s empty shops have gone up considerably. Our decision today is one more act to show our political solidarity with the people of Moldova – first and foremost with those 250 000 people who are living from agriculture in that country.  As we know, agriculture represents around 40% of Moldova’s economy. By extending additional quotas, and doing so at this juncture – when the Moldovan people have just reconfirmed their trust in the country’s European future at the recent elections – we are making a correct and timely step in all regards – political, economic and, to a certain degree, even humanitarian. We should have no concerns about a dramatic inflow of Moldovan grapes, plums or apples into the European Union market. I can assure you that they are tasty and good for our stomachs.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The people of Moldova face crucial economic, domestic and foreign policy challenges: how can the social and social prospects of the small country be safeguarded in the face of the power struggle of the two major trading partners? My group is not opposed to the small gesture of having more apples, plums and grapes imported into the EU duty-free from Moldova. Much more would be needed, however. Where are the investments in infrastructure without which the hopes of the people will be disappointed? What concrete plans are in place to build an independent strengthening and diversification of moldova's economy, which will create new, good jobs? The most important political task, however, remains the understanding with Russia on peaceful and forward-looking cooperation. That is why the European Commission must finally create a framework that moldova could benefit from through the special knowledge of its people. Even this winter will be hard enough.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – I myself very much support this proposal for trade preferences.  As you know, the Republic of Moldova has signed an Association Agreement with the European Commission aimed, in particular, at establishing closer cooperation in the trade field, and through this agreement Moldova will be able to strengthen access to the European market and thus reduce dependence on neighbouring countries, especially Russia, in the long term. In addition, amended laws and standards closer to European will contribute to this, making it easier to import products from countries into the EU.  Unfortunately, the Association Agreement not only has positive effects, it also puts Moldova in a more difficult position, in particular because of Russia's measures and the import ban. This ban is very damaging to Moldova, and that is why I think that the European Union bears a specific and important part of its responsibility to also assist it technically and financially in implementing areas of importance for Moldova and its future development.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: With all my sympathy for the Moldovan people, but colleagues, please stop doing this. The enlargement of the European Union and all the creeping decision-making in this direction, as we are now with Moldova here today, must stop. Your constituents do not agree with this and certainly not your own farmers, but you will continue. Be honest with yourself. Look at what is before us, the Union's strategic vision of the Union's eastern borders is simply a catastrophe. So, both economically, as well as on security, as well as on immigration, the further integration of Moldova is not in the interests of the people we represent here, the citizens of the European Union. In other words, seek non-binding cooperation with this quasi-developing country, guarantee its independence, but stop moldova's creeping integration into the European Union.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Madam President, I am shocked to hear a colleague talk like that. I would like to welcome the report that we will adopt, because three new duty-free tariff quotas are introduced – for fresh apples, for table grapes, for plums – and we show in this way, in a very concrete way, how the Union can support a country that has been hit dramatically by Russian sanctions. I remind you that, before Russia introduced sanctions against agricultural products in the Union, it did so against Moldova, and this for a country that lives largely from such activities related to vegetables and fruit. Hearing a speech like the one I heard just now is simply shocking, it is a lack of humanity after all in this kind of stigmatization of the poor Moldovans, who are already being hit by the Russians. If we hit them with this intolerant attitude again, I think we show very little empathy for what European citizens mean today. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that the Elections in Moldova have confirmed the desire of the citizens of this country to go the European way, against the colossal pressure surge made by Russia, including through the financing of political parties, which is unacceptable even in the European Union.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Madam President, autonomous trade measures are an excellent European Union programme that provides service and financial support to European partners whose pro-European orientation and commitment to reforms are not in doubt.  The temporary increase in quotas on imports of these products from Moldova to the European Union is a small financial concession and a strong political message to Moldova, but also to Russia that the European Union stands with its partners. The consequences of the politically motivated Russian embargo Moldova are strong, as 40% of the budget comes from agricultural activities employing 10% of the population. Such a financial blow seriously threatens the economic recovery and implementation of necessary reforms.  Current developments on the eastern borders of the Union make Moldova increasingly important for the European Union's engagement on its eastern neighbourhood. Recent elections have shown that Moldova is predominantly pro-European, which is a strong basis for the continuation of our partnership. Moldova has chosen its path, it is up to us to support it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: The European Union's external policy is not always good and effective, but I would like to start by saying that, in the case of moldova policy, we can clearly say that our actions have been consistent and effective. They have given the opportunity to bind this country, which is in a very difficult position, to the world of the European institutions. We were very pleased with the conclusion of the Association Agreement with Moldova and today we should treat autonomous trade instruments as an additional, desirable and beneficial means of supporting Moldova's European aspirations and a very good, consistent response to the Russian embargo. I must also express my satisfaction and joy that the recent parliamentary elections in Moldova have produced a good result. They have won a coalition of forces that wants to maintain a pro-European course and protest against what we have heard recently against this manifestation of European selfishness. Europe must be in solidarity in order to develop, and I am pleased that we are able to stand in solidarity with Moldova. Thank you.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: In principle, I would like to support the proposed amendment to the regulation, because Moldova is a country heavily dependent on agricultural production and, by helping its agricultural production to enter the European Union, we will also help to strengthen its economy. But, of course, it must be ensured that the benefits that this area of Moldova will receive reach all the participants, the whole chain, including apple, plum and grape growers. And, of course, the problem is that the crisis lasts practically half a year, there has been a lot of talk about finding third markets, and today it can be firmly stated that nothing has been done, although a report has been given that funds have been found for market searches. But I want to say that, if the problem of plums and grapes is smaller, then the apple situation in the European Union is indeed very demanding a solution, and I believe that the Commission should work faster on this.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if Moldova suffers economically today, what no one denies is that it suffers from the consequences of the same strategy and the denial of its identity, which Ukraine has suffered from the Union. By forcing Moldova to choose a side - Western Europe, the Camp of the West and NATO - as you have done for Ukraine, by making untenable promises, you are weakening its population economically and politically. By choosing to unilaterally adopt sanctions against Russia, you are encouraging it to react. Stop this policy, and there will be no need to intervene to mitigate the effects of the policy. Dividing Europe and creating a new divide between East and West, preparing for war and playing the game of the United States and NATO, is being anti-European.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Madam President! "Govorit Moskva - here Moscow speaks!" That was just heard from Mr Schaffhauser, and he spreads the same rumour or the tale of coercion. If anyone in Europe is coercing against another state or its neighbours, it is Moscow, Russia, not the European Union. Everyone always comes to us voluntarily. That is because we stand here for the rule of law and for development within a democratic framework and these countries do not want to see their future in the old structure of the Soviet Union.  With these autonomous trade preferences, we have responded properly to the pressure from Moscow, to the politically motivated ban on imports of agricultural products. This is a response that is appropriate. It is part of our overall policy towards Moldova. Of course, we also want to ensure that the major issues move forward, that an active government can be formed here, which will also make full use of the possibilities of provisional application of the Association Agreement. The process is demanding. We also expect the necessary changes and reforms in the rule of law and in the state administration. But these are also the prerequisites for the functioning of the European model in all areas of life. Our experience is that our model is the one that can best guide people for the future. That is why this step is the right step in the right direction.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next speaker is Mrs Sandra Kalniete, whom I would like to thank in advance for speaking, before giving her the floor, because she is the only woman among the Members to speak in this debate.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: Madam President, I feel proud being a woman. I will continue in English. The fact that the European Parliament is extending autonomous trade preferences to Moldova is not only of practical economic importance, but also of political importance. This demonstrates the European Union's ability to take concrete action to support democracy in Europe's neighbourhood. Importantly, these advantages will give moldova's economy immediate relief, and this will not have almost any impact on the European Union market. These advantages are an example of how the European Union can balance Putin's Russian efforts to 'punish' those European countries and peoples who choose the path of European development. A few weeks ago, the moldovan parliamentary elections were won by pro-European political parties, and we expect the next government to continue the reforms necessary for moldova's chosen path of European integration to become a success story. The European Parliament is sending another positive signal to Moldova through this decision. However, this cannot in any way replace providing a clearer perspective for european union membership for Moldova, to which, unfortunately, the majority of Member States and Members of the European Parliament are not yet ready. Thank you!

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Madam President, during the past few weeks talk has started to spread that the EU should start debating a common trade area with Russia that starts at Vladivostok and goes all the way to Lisbon.  In this debate I would like to ask whether it is not a better time to pay more attention to the other trade area that starts at Vancouver and goes all the way to Chişinău or Kiev or even Tbilisi. That is why today’s decision is very important because ATPs are additional and complementary to the liberalisation regime for goods in the DCFTA. Now countries like Moldova and Ukraine, especially after successful European elections, are showing a lot of political will and resolution to continue on a path to much needed reforms. So this is the best time to stand with Moldova and show our support on their way towards Europe.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Madam President, I would like to support the process of intensifying political and economic relations between the European Union and Moldova with this debate. In the process, it was important to sign the treaty in June, which allowed Moldova to increase trade with the European Union, increasing exports to the European Union.  But we must note the negative reaction of the authorities in Moscow to this process - a process that was in the mutual interest, both Moldova and the European Union, but it seems that this very fact that Moldova is going its own way was unacceptable to the Russian authorities and their geopolitical goal of dominance over the space of the former Soviet Union.  That is why in July they banned imports of Moldovan agricultural products to punish the disobedience of land they still consider their possessions from former Soviet times. Of course, such a Russian measure has had negative consequences on the Moldovan economy where the agricultural sector is very significant, and it is enough to mention the example that 10% of the working population works precisely in the horticulture sector. That is why, in such a situation, I think it is necessary to support the Commission's proposal by introducing three new products: apples, grapes, plums on the free customs regime of EU imports within ITM regulation.  This will certainly help small and medium-sized agricultural producers, and will especially send a strong signal to the Russian authorities, but also of course to our partners in Moldova that the European Union is in solidarity with them.

name: Seán KELLY
text: A Uachtaráin, is minic a deirtear nach bhfuil anam ná croí ag polaiteoirí agus go háirithe ag institiúidí móra cosúil leis an Aontas Eorpach. Ach taispeánann na moltaí seo, ní hamháin go bhfuil anam agus croí againn, ach gur féidir linn beart a dhéanamh go tapaidh nuair atá gá leis agus gan dabht tá gá leis sa chás seo, mar tá daoine bochta na Moldóive, go háirithe feirmeoirí agus teaghlaigh bochta thíos leis de bharr pholasaí na hollphéiste Putin. Ní féidir leo torthaí a easpórtáil go dtí an Rúis.  Mar an dúirt an Coimisinéir, is deacair margaí nua a fháil agus cinnte ní féidir iad a fháil thar oíche. Dá bhrí sin táimid ag teacht i gcabhair ar ár gcomharsa. Taispeánann sé sin go bhfuil croí agus anam againn agus níos fearr fós, is féidir linn é a dhéanamh gan cur isteach rómhór ar ár bhfeirmeoirí féin. Mar a dúirt an Coimisinéir, nílimid ag caint faoi ach níos lú ná 1 % de na torthaí atá againn san Aontas. Dá bhrí sin is iontach an t-éacht é seo agus taispeánann sé mar a deirtear i mBéarla: A friend in need is a friend indeed. Moldova is in need and we are proving to be a friend indeed.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Autonomous trade preferences are an instrument that the Neighbourhood Policy provides for. We launch them when we find that we cannot otherwise help our partners, as in the case of Moldova, but by introducing new trade tariffs that will allow us to obtain results from the export of the overs that have hitherto been placed on the Russian market. Russia, of course, reacted in this way because it is not satisfied with Moldova's European aspirations. The Association Agreement between Moldova and the European Union, which creates a deep and comprehensive free trade area, as well as the basis for liberalisation and broadly understood economic reforms, also applies to agricultural products. But these additional preferences allow for some liquidity in trading in Moldova. All the more so because this concerns a significant proportion of people working in agriculture.  We are pleased with what happened on 30 September in the elections in Moldova. I had the opportunity to be right through the elections in this country. It is with great concern that our interlocutors have talked about the consequences of the embargo introduced by Russia, and It seems to me that a gesture on the part of the European Union on the part of the European Parliament – this quick decision – can be very helpful to our partners in Moldova.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I think the debate tonight has shown there to be very strong solidarity, which is perhaps appropriate a week before Christmas. This is a very small gesture for us, and as everybody has said it does not affect our market at all as it is 0.1% of our trade with the world. But it is an important proposal for Moldova economically, of course, which is why we are doing it, and it is also very important on a political basis.  It shows that solidarity is not only a word for us, but also something that we are ready to practise towards our Eastern partner in need. Approving this proposal tomorrow – and I hope there will be a strong majority – will show that we support those countries choosing the European model of development and European values. It will indicate to Moldova, as many of you have said, that we stand behind our words and decisions, and behind friends in difficult times. We will of course continue to help Moldova in many other ways as well, and we will closely monitor the effect of this decision that hopefully will be taken tomorrow. Thank you all for a good debate. And thank you again to the rapporteur and to the committee for its hard and quick work on this.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and her services for the hard and quick work on this file. I would also like to thank the colleagues who have contributed tonight. I have noticed a lot of common sense in the overwhelming majority of reactions and I believe I have found the proper metaphor to describe this regulation that we will be adopting tomorrow: leverage – and the leverage effect is very fashionable these days. With this resolution we might have an even better factor than 1 to 15. With a very, very small effort on the EU economy side, we will have a very significant effort on the Moldovan side. Now some very brief reactions to the other comments. Mr Scholz, I fully agree with you that there should be policies to make sure the Moldovan GDP structure includes more diversification and higher added value. I hope the Association Agreement will be an important instrument in providing for this – and I am personally convinced that it will – including by means of FDI, which will be able to reap the benefits of the huge single market. On enlargement, this is about plums and apples, it is not about enlargement. There are many, many veto players in the enlargement game, and there is no issue whatsoever of surreptitiously pulling Moldova into the EU by adopting a regulation on apples. That said, it is a free world and Moldovans are free to want to join Europe, and political actors and civil society actors in Europe are free to support their choice, so we will have a political and democratic process. Madame la Présidente, Monsieur Schaffhauser, on blâme la victime pour le viol. On évoque ici la négation de l'identité moldave, mais c'est vraiment du délire. Personne ne nie l'identité moldave. Personne ne force la Moldavie à faire un choix, quel qu'il soit. C'est un pays démocratique, qui fait ses choix démocratiquement.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 17 December. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. – The agreement to introduce autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova has led to increased trade, and the increase in exports has marked positive results on the Moldovan economy. The European Union has become Moldova's main trading partner. More than half of the volume of exports and almost to the same extent imports are carried out with the EU, which confirms that Moldova has fulfilled its commitments with the EU and has made progress towards economic reforms. I stress that the agricultural sector represents 40% of Moldova's economy and provides jobs for about 250 thousand employees. Free access of Moldovan agricultural products to European markets contributes to the consolidation of a sector essential to Moldova's economy. I am convinced that the presence of agricultural products on EU markets will mean, on the one hand, the increase in the performance of the agricultural sector and thus adaptto EU rules, so Moldova will more easily fulfil the conditions imposed by pre-accession. On the other hand, Moldovan citizens confirmed the pro-European orientation in the November parliamentary elections. Therefore, the economic component of the Association Agreement with the EU is a natural step towards achieving European aspirations.

name: Eduard-Raul HELLVIG
text: in writing. – The granting of trade preferences to the Republic of Moldova is a show of solidarity on the part of the EU in the face of the embargo imposed by Russia on Moldovan products.  The opening up of the European market to fruit imports, without additional taxation, will support an important sector of the economy of this increasingly anchored trade area with the EU. Trade facilities represent, after the conclusion of the Association Agreement, a concrete support to the Republic of Moldova, in the geopolitical context redefined by Russia's aggression against Ukraine and through actions of destabilization, including economic, of Moldova.  This decision also constitutes a further recognition of the substantial efforts made by the Chisinau authorities to reform the state and to enhance cooperation with the European Union. The Republic of Moldova is the member of the Eastern Partnership that has made the greatest progress in recent years, which is why I believe that the Association Agreement must be followed by further steps to increase trade and investment, to modernize the economy and improve the standard of living in the Republic of Moldova. More difficult reforms are needed in this regard and it is the Union's duty not only to monitor this process, but also to effectively support the implementation of reforms through financial assistance and the necessary expertise.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. – I want to congratulate Mr Moisa for this report. Moldova must continue its European trajectory. Not long ago, this Parliament voted in favour of the association agreement with Moldova. These measures improve Moldova’s access to the European market. We know that the proposal is a temporary one but we also know that Moldova is greatly dependent on agriculture. In the last legislative elections, we have seen that Moldova chose the European path by voting in favour of the pro-European parties. We have to show solidarity with a country that at the moment is not at all in an easy situation.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – Providing special conditions to products from the Republic of Moldova and increasing the volume of imports from this country on the basis of special customs tariffs is a positive thing to support the European path of the Republic of Moldova. The main argument of the anti-European forces in the Republic of Moldova is that through European integration the economy will be affected as it will no longer be able to access the markets in the East. Economic and commercial indicators indicate that by implementing the measures proposed by this report the economy of the Republic of Moldova will experience significant progress and the chance offered by the European market will solve the problems generated by the restrictions imposed by the Russian Federation on certain products from the Republic of Moldova. The European Union is a common political space but it is also a strongly developed economic space and the economic integration of the Republic of Moldova into the EU also entails increasing opportunities for Moldovan companies and producers as well as the chance of a faster development of the Republic of Moldova.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. – The Republic of Moldova signed the Association Agreement with the European Union in June 2014. In the elections for Parliament, the citizens of the Republic of Moldova had a choice between the parties that want to continue the country's European path and the parties that will return to the East. Unfortunately, Russia maintains and emphasizes restrictions on imports of agri-food products from the Republic of Moldova. That is why I welcome the European Commission's initiative to propose an increase in import quotas for apples, grapes, plums, duty-free. I believe that other European initiatives are needed to support and encourage the citizens of the Republic of Moldova to overcome the difficulties created for political reasons in the international trade of this country.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Following the signing of the EU/Moldova Association Agreement on 27 June, Russia banned imports of fruit from Moldova, officially for phytosanitary reasons. The agricultural sector accounts for about 40 percent of Moldova's economy, while horticulture is an important part of it, employing around 250,000 people, mostly living in rural areas. Within the framework of the DCFTA, the Union has committed itself to fully liberalising market access for fresh fruit and vegetables, limited to certain quantities. Given Moldova's current serious difficulties, the Commission has proposed to temporarily increase this fully liberalised market access for imports of moldovan products into the EU. Especially in the current geopolitical situation, this conclusion cannot be disagreed with. We must maintain good neighbourly relations, especially in this troubled region of Europe.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Helmut Scholz's report on behalf of the Committee on International Trade on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the customs treatment of goods originating in Ecuador (COM(2014)0585 - C8-0172/2014 - 2014/0287(COD)) (A8-0056/2014).

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Rapporteur. - (DE) Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for Our debate today has a not insignificant history: the European Parliament and the European Council have taken two important decisions in the past that have put us in this current situation, namely to decide quickly on such a proposal. Firstly, the majority of Parliament had decided that a country such as Ecuador, whose independent economic and social policies led significantly to the reduction and overcoming of poverty and reached an average income of USD 4 000 per capita per year, would therefore be excluded from the European system of trade preferences. This will be the case for Ecuador on 1 January 2015. Secondly, the Council and also the same majority in the European Parliament voted in favour of the free trade agreement negotiated only with Colombia and Peru, which was originally intended as a regional agreement and which, from Ecuador's point of view, calls into question its own development objectives. That is why President Correa wanted to conclude an agreement on cooperation and development as an alternative. Instead of working with all the Andean countries to develop common objectives, however, the European Commission only allowed accession to the free trade agreement as an option. Unfortunately, this strategy worked. In particular, the competitive situation, but – we must also point out – the change in the global economic environment for some of Ecuador's most important export goods has become so acute that the government under President Correa has now agreed to join the Colombia/Peru Agreement. However, this remains controversial in civil society and could put the complicated governing coalition in a difficult position. Do we want that? With this law, Ecuador is now building a bridge so that it can maintain its trade preferences until the free trade agreement enters into force. In the interests of the people of Ecuador, I am not explicitly opposed to the construction of bridges. However, I would like to point out that, Commissioner, in your current role in formulating the regulation, you have deliberately closed your eyes to the internal political situation in Ecuador. They have created a constant threat to be able to demolish the bridge at any time if Ecuador adopts regulations that could be detrimental to European exports. This is intended to strengthen the liberal economic part of the government against the left in the government. Unfortunately, my amendments, with which I wanted to defuse this conflict, did not receive a majority here in committee. A majority on the right of the centre here in Parliament has also willingly abandoned Parliament's right to veto a Commission suspension decision, despite the expertise of Parliament's Legal Service, which considered the procedure for a delegated act to be imperative. Personally, I also consider this decision to be a mistake, and I can only hope that it does not set a precedent. Ladies and gentlemen, i would like to end by calling on you to vote in favour of the regulation in order to protect the people of Ecuador from slumping in the export economy.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, this is an important moment for relations between the European Union and Ecuador. Just a few years after having left the negotiations in 2009, Ecuador has now made an important and clear policy choice in favour of trade and integration into the world economy and global value chains. Last Friday, I met with the Ecuadorian Trade Minister, Francisco Rivadeneira, and initialled the protocol for the accession of Ecuador to the EU-Colombia-Peru Agreement. For Ecuador, this trade agreement supports its model of society and economic development. We will provide the country with an opportunity to diversify its trade and economy and improve the livelihoods of the population. We should support and encourage this choice, and it is in this perspective that we should consider the regulation as an important complement to the trade agreement. We proposed this regulation very rapidly after the conclusion of the negotiations in order to ensure that there would be no disruption in the preferences that Ecuador is enjoying today. I welcome the European Parliament and the rapporteur’s quick adoption, extending the preferences and thereby preventing a negative impact on the exports of Ecuador. Ecuador will, as you know, graduate from the GSP+ preferences at the end of this year, and around 60% of Ecuadorian exports to the EU benefit from substantial preferences under this scheme. The regulation that we discussed today will bridge the gap until the agreement fully applies, and that provides certainty and predictability to producers and workers in the EU and, more importantly, in Ecuador. If the gap between the graduation from GSP and the entry into force of the Agreement were not bridged, Ecuador would face a sudden increase in duties in January, only to see them fall back later on. A sudden increase in duties would be a lot when it comes to loss of market share, which is extremely difficult to recuperate later. We would be talking about increases in duties in excess of 20% for products such as tuna and shrimps, and an average increase of duties of more than 15% of all Ecuador’s export under the GSP scheme. I am aware that many Members in this House attach great importance to the implementation of this regulation, particularly when it comes to the requirement for effective implementation by Ecuador of relevant human rights, ILO, environmental conventions and international agreements, as well as the procedure to be used in the event that a suspension of preferences is warranted. This is also important to me, and I raised this with the Minister whom I met last week. Rest assured that we will monitor this and we will keep Parliament informed on the implementation of these provisions. We are ready to inform you, whenever requested to do so, and to ensure the required transparency in the implementation of the regulation, as well as to make use of the good practices that we are developing within the context of the GSP scheme.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, thank you very much. Negotiations on the Trade Agreement between Ecuador and the European Union were successfully concluded last July. From the People's Party we are convinced that this agreement will be very positive for both sides, although it will take almost two years to enter into force. From next January, Ecuador will no longer benefit from the advantages offered by the GSP+ and this mismatch would cause serious damage to economic operators on both sides. This proposal for a Regulation aims to address this situation of interimity and in the INTA Commission we voted in favour of the Commission's proposal by a very large majority, without introducing any amendments, in order to avoid unnecessarily lengthening the negotiation process. The adoption of this Regulation will allow both exporters and importers to continue to operate normally, without enduring a significant increase in tariffs, which could cause irreparable damage to both Ecuadorian companies and many European companies operating from Ecuador. It is therefore vitally important that tomorrow we approve this proposal for a Regulation and I would like to thank the rapporteur, Helmut Scholz, for the good work done. And I would not want to end without welcoming Ecuador to international free trade agreements.

name: David MARTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, can I also add my congratulations to Mr Scholz for his work on this dossier. We supported his amendments in committee, but think it was right not to bring them back in plenary in order not to delay this process. The EU, as we have heard, is Ecuador’s most important trade partner for non-oil exports. Any temporary and unnecessary disruption in trade would have had a severe impact on Ecuador’s economy, and would most likely result in exporters looking for alternative markets with easier access than the European Union. Instead, with this bridging solution, we can continue to encourage and support trade between the EU and Ecuador in order to ensure that both parties are able to benefit from the future free trade agreement.  I welcome the fact that this agreement includes reciprocity, that the EU traders will get the same benefits they get now, as will Ecuadorian traders. I welcome the fact that the rules of origin will continue to apply, and I welcome the fact that there are safeguards in this agreement for European producers. This is a good deal for both parties. Again, I would like to thank both the Commission and the rapporteur for their work.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and colleagues for their hard work and good cooperation. I welcome the debate today and the vote we will have on this report tomorrow. After our positive vote in the Committee on International Trade (INTA) last week, it is important to bring it to plenary before the end of the year. The approval of this agreement before the end of the year is important, as many economic contracts in Ecuador have to be negotiated now for the next year. I think that free trade agreements more than public debt can push Europe again into economic growth. I think that exports more than public deficits are a better way to recover our economic growth. I support the Commission’s attempts to open new markets and reduce tariffs and other regulatory areas to facilitate the entry into these markets for EU companies. In the International Trade Committee Liberals voted against the amendments proposed by the rapporteur as we believe that these amendments were risking delaying the application of this agreement. I fully support the extension of preferential access for goods originating from Ecuador before the FTA enters into force. However, I also believe this should be conditional on Ecuador showing a clear commitment that it will open its markets to EU companies. Finally, I want to say that the current situation with Russia should push us even more to seek new potential markets in Asia and Central and Latin American countries.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur. However on the report as such, or on the matter rather, I am not completely happy because as the rapporteur, Mr Scholz, has pointed out, this is really showing how trade is not working for development, showing indeed how trade should not affect development.  Under the old conditions a regulation was put in place that effectively forces developing countries to make a choice as to whether they want to get rid of their preferred market access to the EU or sign up for a free trade agreement, even if that does not follow their development agenda and even if that is not what some in this Parliament, at least, think should happen from a developmental point of view. I think this is effectively blackmailing and undermining a society’s right to development.  This is precisely what happened here in Ecuador. Ecuador was forced to join the Peru-Colombia agreement otherwise it would lose its preferential market access. Since we have a new Commission now, I would really ask the Commissioner to rethink the trade development nexus because I think trade can do a lot for development; but currently it is undermining it, unfortunately, and I think we should really work on changing that.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: Madam President, I too would like to congratulate all the players in this agreement, in particular Mr Scholz, on his pragmatism. We shared your amendments, but I believe that, for the benefit of Ecuador and also Europe, this Regulation has been agreed. I would like to tell you, ladies and gentlemen, that Europe is probably making a very important decision for itself as well. Because, as president of EuroLat, I want to tell you that Latin Americans are increasingly looking to the Pacific and not looking to Europe. We are missing huge opportunities for political action and trade action. Unfortunately, the European Union has a huge responsibility, because we are the territory that cooperates the most, which develops the most cooperation in Latin America, but we are being replaced commercially and politically by China or Russia in Latin America. They look the other way, they don't look this way anymore. That is why it is important to take advantage of the Agreement with Ecuador, because it is of great political importance in the context of relations with Latin America and the ALBA countries.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: Madam President, Ecuador is likely to join the EU-Colombia and Peru trade agreement in the coming months, but it will lose its preferential market access to the EU in just two weeks unless we act this week. I welcome the proposed regulation, which puts in place a provisional arrangement to ensure that trade between the EU and Ecuador is not disrupted before our important vote and which does not prejudge our decision in that deal and allows us to get the right framework with the Ecuadorian authorities.   There is one point that I would like to raise: two years ago this Parliament adopted a resolution asking the countries of the Andean Community – at that stage particularly Colombia and Peru – to commit to roadmaps on human rights and environmental protection before agreements were ratified. Applying the same standards to Ecuador would send an important signal that our trade relations are about more than just tariff lines, but are also a tool for our collective development and about improving human and labour rights around the world. I would therefore actively encourage the Ecuadorians also to put forward a roadmap.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has I am very, very grateful to the rapporteur for helping us to ensure that Ecuador can maintain its trade preferences and benefit from this free trade agreement very quickly. In my view, it would have been a bad joke if a country that wants to conclude a free trade agreement with us were to be punished in practice and we were to take away trade facilitation, and it would have meant that we would actually have all the negative effects that Mrs Keller mentioned. That is why I am also calling on your group: if we want development, we should not patronise the people of these countries, but we should take note of the fact that the democratic government in that country, the government of the people, wants this agreement. We should not always know better, but we should also take note of the fact that in democracies, decisions must ultimately also be accepted and taken by majorities accordingly. Thank you very much for being able to vote on this this week! I am pleased that together we can now reap the benefits of this trade agreement for all the peoples of Europe, including Ecuador, Colombia and Peru.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, through the adoption of this regulation exports from Ecuador will not be affected until the entry into force of the agreement. This is a necessary interim step and it sends a strong signal, on the one hand, to business that the EU is determined to ensure predictability and stability in trade. On the other hand, it also sends a clear political signal to Ecuador and its people that the EU is determined to forge closer relations and to proceed swiftly towards the entry into force of the agreement itself. It can also help Ecuador diversify its economy and work towards further eradication of poverty in that country.  We are also making progress towards the entry into force of the agreement. I expect that the protocol will be submitted to the European Parliament for its consent at some point in the middle of next year. Thank you again to the rapporteur, Mr Scholz, and to the Committee on International Trade (INTA) for the work that they have done in dealing with this file so quickly. I am positive that a proper implementation of this will respond to the preoccupations that some of you have raised today. To Ms Keller, I would like to say that I share her view that trade can be a very powerful tool in helping least-developed countries to develop and to bring them into the trade community, thereby forging a closer relationship in other areas too. This is clearly in my priorities, and as you know it was presented to you today in the work programme of the Commission. We will present a new trade strategy where this element also will be raised.  I am looking forward to discussing this internally in the College, with Ministers, and with Members of this Parliament as well. We hope to present a strategy by the end of next year and no later. Finally, I would like to take this opportunity to wish you, Madam President, and the Members a Happy Christmas. I thank you for the good cooperation we have had so far, and I am looking forward to working with you next year as well.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, I thank the Commissioner and my colleagues for the debate. At least it has become clear that there is a strong desire for good trade relations with Ecuador in the European Parliament. I also want to stress that time is not always democratically sufficient. So therefore I want to stress that, for trade relations to be good, they need to be designed and in particular fair. In the coming months we will have the opportunity during the ratification process to thoroughly examine the agreements admitted.  In particular the impact on employment and quality of life of the population, on the environment and also generally on the stability and integration of the whole region serve as a benchmark, Mr Caspary. I therefore strongly urge the Commission to stop interfering in the internal political situation of the countries in the region that have chosen a social and economic policy that breaks with the new liberal credo and could finally open up real opportunities of development for the population that are true for their countries.  As rapporteur for the ratification of the agreement, I shall very carefully watch whether the Commission will ask Ecuador next, even if only indirectly, to amend its legal acts or even its constitution to provide European companies better access to the markets for public procurement and public services. I would also like to advocate a roadmap, as was stressed during the debate, that outlines how the parties to the agreement want to ensure that the process of accession to the Peru-Colombia FTA will not be compromising their social and environmental progress in Ecuador, which we all want as a benchmark for the region.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Thank you very much to the rapporteur, Mr Scholz. I would like also like to wish you, Commissioner, a Merry Christmas, I hope you can enjoy some holiday, and all the best for the New Year. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 17 December 2014. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: , in writing. – This is not in the face of a free trade agreement, but in the face of an extension of Ecuador's export preferences to the EU. These tariff preferences are those contained in the GSP+, which is lost on 1 January 2015 and therefore, until the new EU-Ecuador trade framework enters into force, it is important for the people of Ecuador that these preferences be extended. Despite being against the conditionality that the European Commission has sought to impose on Ecuador in the articulation of the text, by opening the door to the possibility of suspending tariff preferences if Ecuador adopts "measures" that have some kind of effect on EU imports, and despite considering that the possible decisions that the Commission may take in this regard should be made under the framework of delegated acts so that this way Parliament can make effective use of its control functions (both issues were amended by my parliamentary group in the INTA Commission but lying on the right and far right), we consider it important for the Ecuadorian people to extension these tariff preferences and their urgent implementation.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on – the oral question to the Council on the renewal of Claude Moraes' EU internal security strategy on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (O-000089/2014 – B8-0044/2014) and the oral question to the Commission on the renewal of the EU internal security strategy by Claude Moraes on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Freedom s. Justice and Home Affairs (O-000090/2014 - B8-0045/2014) (2014/2918(RSP)).

name: Claude MORAES
text: author. - Madam President, I am actually waiting until the Commissioner sits down. The last time I began he had not started and it seemed rude not to welcome him so this time I am going to welcome him to his position. And the reason is that I think there is a genuine feeling amongst the members of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs that we very much want to contribute to the internal security strategy. This is, at its very core, probably what we do the best, protecting our citizens, adding value to what the Member States do, but also understanding that this is one of the most dynamic and interesting areas. We have something of a clean sheet for the next four years. I understand that we have to fill this blank sheet, this gap. But of course it is going to be complex. We are dealing with some of the most dynamic and sensitive areas: cybercrime, cyberterrorism, the issue of foreign fighters and so on. I will say something about that in a second. We want to play our part and if I can leave one message it is that the members of the Civil Liberties Committee with their expertise and experience want to input into the Commission strategy. And we understand that this is a Council competence in so many areas but we have something to contribute. And we also have to contribute to the balance between protecting our citizens and understanding that fundamental rights are also extremely important in creating that balance. The security situation in Europe has changed dramatically in recent years so the European Union is confronted with the effects of new cross-border conflicts. New technologies are creating fast-growing new threats. This is even clearer when we think of those foreign fighters that have joined terrorist groups abroad and, of course, one day may return to Europe. This resolution is only the beginning of a process for a new, updated internal security strategy. With it we are launching an initial discussion on the features and priorities of a new strategy which will be released by the Commission next year. It sets out areas that the Civil Liberties Committee and the Parliament consider vital to take into account in order to improve and enrich the strategy. By agreeing on this resolution we are making it clear on the Parliament side what we want to see included, and this includes putting a stop to the activities of international crime networks and dismantling them, preventing terrorist attacks, enhancing cybersecurity, ensuring border security and increasing resilience to natural disasters. That gives a sense of the broad nature of this strategy but it also includes what we believe is our expertise in contributing to the strategy. The resolution sets out guidelines on exactly how we can respond to these threats and on what instruments should be implemented in the strategy. It is important for us on the Parliament side to understand that we need to make better use of those instruments that we already have before creating new ones, and this is what we say in our resolution. With this new strategy we need a critical evaluation of those current instruments, both at EU and national level, and we need to learn the lessons from the previous strategy before we embark on any new instruments or any new strategies. We need a more hands-on effective operational cooperation amongst Member States, for example more use could be made of existing valuable instruments such as joint investigation teams, and that has been said many times amongst the members of our Civil Liberties Committee. Of course, we need to take a balanced approach, which I mentioned at the beginning of my speech. In many security areas, for example, the right balance should be found between freedom, security and justice. We learned this from our surveillance inquiry; we learned it from the data retention ruling. I need not say too much more about this, but just to understand that these recent developments make us understand that security goes hand in hand with fundamental rights. But we also have expertise on the Parliament side in relation to cybersecurity threats and we can contribute richly to the many complex areas that are coming up in relation to foreign fighters, passenger name records and the many new complex areas where the members of the Civil Liberties Committee have very good experience, both on the security aspects and the fundamental rights aspects. When the Commission publishes its communication for a new strategy in 2015, the Civil Liberties Committee will react in order to promote a more substantial and focused debate and discussion in this area. Commissioner and Members of the Council in Office, when we add value to the internal security strategy I think the time for Parliament to stand aside is long gone. I think the members of our Civil Liberties Committee are poised and ready to contribute to this strategy. I think we have the experience to do it and I very much look forward to hearing the members of the Civil Liberties Committee give their ideas to you for this next four years, which I think are going to be exciting, complex but very worthwhile.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Council attaches particular importance to the renewal of the internal security strategy. This has been a priority for our Presidency. I am therefore delighted to have the opportunity today to outline the Council's vision of the main priorities and actions of the renewed ISS. Considerable efforts have been made to ensure a follow-up of the strategic guidelines adopted by the June European Council, which called for the review and updating of the internal security strategy by the first half of 2015. Ministers' discussions on this began in July, with the aim of providing guidelines and a contribution to the European Commission, which is expected to present its communication on the renewed ISS in the spring. At the beginning of December the Council reached agreement on a number of aspects relating to the renewed ISS. These principles partly answer the question. The first is that the renewed ISS should identify the main common threats and challenges in the area of internal security for the coming years. The Council considers that these include organised crime and serious forms of crime, in all their manifestations – terrorism, radicalisation and recruitment of terrorists, as well as terrorist financing – the problem of foreign fighters, which has been recalled, returning fighters and lone wolves, which dramatically pose a particularly serious and unprecedented threat to the security of the European Union. The Council also identified threats arising from cybercrime and the use of new technologies in general, as well as the consequences of both natural and man-made disasters. The second principle should be the need to develop a comprehensive and coherent approach. This means involving a wide range of actors and integrating decision-making at all levels, from local to regional, to reach European and international level. Developing a coherent approach means that this approach should be global, multidisciplinary, integrated and intelligence-driven. The availability and exchange of information to combat transnational crime and terrorism will be paramount and we will have to pay particular attention to new technologies. Equally important is the dimension of justice. The coordination of investigations and prosecutions in the Member States must be encouraged and improved, including through financial investigations aimed at confiscating the proceeds of crime, as well as the efficient use of joint investigation teams and mutual recognition and judicial assistance procedures. We must also strengthen our operational cooperation and develop our border management capabilities; this imperatively requires the use of state-of-the-art technologies. A third key principle is the need to include the growing interdependence between internal and external security. The renewed internal security strategy will have to take account of the external security dimension and vice versa. The issue of foreign fighters is a clear example of external aspects having a significant impact internally. A fourth principle should be respect for fundamental rights. The strategy must contribute to a Union that protects its citizens, fully respecting their rights and freedoms, as well as those who are staying or visiting the European Union. It should also facilitate the promotion of social inclusion and social cohesion, last but not least. The renewed strategy should focus on implementation to implement existing instruments and legislation and strategic measures. The Council proposed that the Commission should submit an annual report to the European Parliament and the Council on the actions undertaken within the framework of the strategy. This should allow us to monitor developments and provide regular updates on the measures taken to strengthen internal security within the Union. It was also asked what timetable is set for the adoption of the new internal security strategy and how the Council intends to take account of Parliament's contribution. The European Council set a precise deadline for the review and updating of the internal security strategy, i.e. the first half of 2015. Much will, of course, depend on the ermpi of the Commission's communication, but we understand that it will presumably be available in the spring. I therefore hope that we could have a renewed ISS agreement by June 2015. As you know, the The Presidency organised, together with the Commission, a high-level conference on the ISS renewed in September 2014. A number of Members of this House have been invited to this conference, at which Mr Sleyley has referred to the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this report. Moraes was one of the main speakers. The results of this meeting have made a useful contribution to the drafting of the Council conclusions on the ISS, but we have also taken into account the Commission's final report on the implementation of the ISS, which in turn took into account your resolution in this regard. The LIBE Committee has also been briefed on developments. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me say that I await your views on this point with interest. I am sure that some of the recommendations in your motion for a resolution are in the renewed ISS. I am thinking in particular of the need to make better use of existing instruments before creating new ones, the need for a global, balanced and holistic approach and more effective operational cooperation between the Member States. You also referred to the importance of the judicial dimension, as well as to the need for proper democratic control.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, this oral question tonight is taking place under the shadow of an abhorrent crime that was committed this morning. I would like to express my sorrow and repugnance at the loss of innocent lives today in Pakistan. In a civilised world brutal attacks like the one today in a school in Pakistan are an insult to humanity, a crime against humanity, and to whatever human beings across the world hold sacred.  This horrific event and the ruthless murder of innocent children depict the abhorrent face of terrorism. Terrorism is a global threat, it is a global menace. In the European Union we are committed to the struggle against terrorism and we are working closely with our partners so as to protect the right to life of all peoples irrespective of race, religion or ethnic origin.  Honourable Members of Parliament, I want to thank you for having given me this opportunity tonight to reflect with you on a renewed EU internal strategy. The renewed EU Internal Security Strategy, the new European agenda on security, should be a common agenda when the security of our citizens, their rights, our democratic values, the well-being of our societies and our economy, are at stake. The Union’s institutions need to work hand in hand. We need to find the common ground on the main threats, principles and priorities when renewing the Internal Security Strategy.  The Commission sees a clear need to have all European institutions working together to formulate and, secondly, implement the future European agenda on security and wishes to facilitate this process.  In reviewing the Internal Security Strategy the Commission will build firstly on the preparatory work undertaken in the course of this year; secondly, on the Justice and Home Affairs Council conclusions adopted on 5 December; thirdly, of course, on the resolution Parliament intends to adopt tomorrow. These contributions will guide our work for the months to come.  I suggest that once the Commission communication has been issued, Parliament and the Council engage in a dialogue to find common ground on the future of European security to provide effective, swift, practical and achievable solutions.  Your resolution sets out a broad security approach based on fundamental principles, instead of listing specific legislative and policy actions. This corresponds with the ambition of the Commission to provide a strategy-driven agenda which will connect to existing or already envisaged measures.  The resolution also highlights the importance of finding a balance between continuity and change. We need to foster and strengthen what works, and adapt things where evolving or expected developments require new actions or the revision of existing ones. The implementation of legislation and the consolidation of achievements, as well as enhanced practical cooperation, will be priorities for future work. Consequently, monitoring and evaluation of the effectiveness of legislation and policies is essential. 1 December 2014 heralded the era in which justice and home affairs policies were finally set on an equal footing with other EU policies, thanks to the full application of the judicial review by the Court of Justice and the enforcement powers of the Commission. This will benefit the required monitoring and evaluation and will enhance citizens’ rights and legal security.  Close monitoring of the implementation of newly adopted instruments on the procedural rights of defendants and victims’ rights and on improved application of existing instruments on judicial cooperation in criminal matters will strengthen the judicial dimension of the Internal Security Strategy, a point which has also been highlighted by your resolution.  The Commission intends to continue to submit regular reports to Parliament and the Council on actions taken under the European agenda on security. This would assist you in monitoring the implementation of the strategy and will strengthen its democratic oversight.  As regards the content of the European agenda on security, the Commission cannot at this stage go into the details of what its future communication will set out. However, there is no doubt that we have to continue to fight international and cross-border crime, prevent terrorism, address radicalisation and recruitment, work against cybercrime, protect children from abuse, and increase Europe’s resilience to crises and disasters. This is not new. What is new is that the actions currently covered have to be adapted to address evolving challenges and threats.  The actions should be based on an intelligence-led approach providing guidance on how to effectively tackle rapidly evolving security challenges. A coherent set of risk and threat analyses by Europol and other relevant European Union institutions and bodies, in close cooperation with the Member States, should operationalise this approach. This requires close strategic and operational cooperation, and the exchange of information between law enforcement, judicial authorities and EU agencies is fundamental. We have to work more closely on prevention and protection. Access to information and information exchange, innovation and research will ensure a clearer link with the external dimension and cooperation. A citizen-centred approach and the integration of fundamental rights in all actions should be the guiding principles of the European Agenda on Security.  The Commission will be particularly attentive to the implementation of all envisaged measures and instruments and will assess their compatibility with fundamental rights as enshrined in the European Union Charter of Fundamental Rights. Respecting the Charter requires that measures which interfere with fundamental rights are proportionate. In the context of that balance, fighting threats to public safety or indeed the fundamental rights of others are legitimate objectives.  Trust and confidence in the institutions is also a matter of concern. Security policies must be seen as serving citizens to keep legitimacy and support. Citizens need to be better informed of the problems, and the implementation of internal security policies is not only essential for making instruments effective but also to strengthen the credibility of the institutions in the eyes of citizens and demonstrate to victims that action is taken. To ensure that EU internal security also means acting beyond EU borders and in cooperation with third-country partners, important steps to integrate external and internal security measures have already been taken. These are, for example, the establishment of the Cyber Security Strategy. But much more needs to be done and those measures need to be followed up and further put into practice; for instance, by strengthening the operational link between the EUʼs internal and external security policies.  I fully support the emphasis that you have put on having an integrated, comprehensive and holistic approach to priority areas. Different policies and actions, going beyond the public sector too, need to be integrated if we wish to tackle security concerns in all areas effectively while facing financial constraints and safeguarding fundamental rights. The renewed EU agenda on security could also benefit from research and innovation. The European Union needs to continue mobilising the tools essential for security preparedness and resilience, in particular information and communication technologies and technologies in the forensic field, whilst respecting fundamental rights. It could consider using its research and innovation programme Horizon 2020 and pursue cooperation between law enforcement and the private sector, notably to develop more technological autonomy. Finally, increased legitimacy in the eyes of European citizens requires the full association of this Parliament and the involvement of national parliaments. In addition to former reports on the progress of the strategy’s implementation, the Commission is committed to engaging in regular dialogue with this Parliament and to debating relevant matters with national parliaments. I look forward to working together with you in the Council on this new European agenda on security.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, Secretary of State, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has said. International security and our own strategy and response to the questions of our security have become more complex than ever in the last two or three years. We had a committee here in the last parliamentary term, the so-called CRIM Committee, which dealt with international organised crime and its europe-wide and also global networking. It is frightening to see what is happening in this context. We are confronted with increasing international terrorism and extremism, which, as is now being demonstrated in Pakistan, puts us in horrible situations. We have now reached a level of cybercrime in which international networks challenge us on a daily basis and the normal bank robbery has become a small dimension compared to the billions of dollars in damage that are taking place on the Internet every day. We will indeed have to make better use of existing instruments, as Claude Moraes has said, because if administrative assistance, in part, still takes months today, then this is far too slow for the criminals. We will need to be faster, more flexible and better coordinated. However, we will also have to answer some questions in which we need to better reconcile the security and protection of personal data than is currently the case. We will have many questions to answer here.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, I am pleased to see the high level of coincidence with regard to the relevance and purpose of this oral question on the European Union's Internal Security Strategy, which is based on the recognition that both the situation and the challenges of European security have changed dramatically over the course of the last few years. To begin with, because it must contemplate this disturbing assembly of new threats arising from cyber security, the mutant characterization of international terrorism, the extremely aggressive nature of cross-border crime and, above all, the mixing of security threats with those arising from natural events or disasters. That is why we are obliged, in this European Parliament, to add value to the definition of the situation and the strategic response of the European Internal Security Strategy for the coming years 2015-2019.  It is time for us to recognise that, in the face of this drastically changing security situation in Europe, all available resources must first be optimised. It has already been said: joint investigation teams, security in police cooperation, reinforcement in judicial cooperation, in intelligence, in the effort to share all available information. But it is also time to say that all this must be done in coherence with the values proclaimed by the European Union, by the Lisbon Treaty, by the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, which means an effort to consistent with the value of fundamental rights, in particular data protection , in particular the Data Protection Directive, which is under way in this European Parliament, and the case-law of the European Court of Justice interpreting it. It is therefore time for us to make an effort to ensure that the European Union's Internal Security Strategy is extremely respectful of the European culture of fundamental rights.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Internal security is on our agenda today, and the motion for a resolution on which we are going to vote rightly states one thing: the security situation in Europe has changed dramatically in recent years. In Germany, this is the topic number 1. People no longer feel safe, and people feel let down by politics with their fear. That is why they are now taking to the streets in their thousands every Monday, and there are more and more every Monday. Politicians must take these concerns seriously and not defame the citizens who take to the streets. Politicians must assume their responsibilities and act. Politicians must not just continue to watch and hope that the problems can be sat out. Let us have the courage to speak openly about the concerns. Let us take note of the realities! Only in this way will we solve the problems.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) we have reached a broad compromise between several political groups. I expect that the Commission will take our priorities into consideration when the new Internal Security Strategy (ISS) for the current mandate is being finalised. Since we adopted the previous Internal Security Strategy, the Lisbon Treaty has come into force and the Charter of Fundamental Rights is now incorporated in European Union law. Therefore the whole ISS should be updated in order to fully comply with the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The resolution contains a reference to that so there should be a proper assessment of gaps and the Commission should perform a stocktaking exercise with focus on proper implementation. It is of the utmost importance that we can reach an agreement on the directive on data protection as soon as possible in order to have a legal framework for sharing of data for law enforcement purposes. Proper implementation of the new ISS will be crucial and the European Parliament, as well as the national parliaments, should be part of the monitoring process for democratic scrutiny. The resolution before us is the result of a compromise and I recommend that we support the text as it stands.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your promises of cooperation, Commissioner, but I am not entirely convinced by the security strategy.
