In too many respects it imitates American counter-terrorism: it is self-celebrated and run by closed agencies – Europol – and cooperation is weak with the bodies that should be entrusted with the definition of threats to the Union – the Council, the national parliaments, the European Parliament. It almost only includes measures of repression, there is too little on prevention. The word 'fundamental rights' appears twice in the 12 declaratory paragraphs of the resolution. In the name of security, as we know, rights have been trampled underfoot over the last decade and more, in America and in the Union. I wonder whether we will continue to hear from the US Senate about the torture and extraordinary rendition that has taken place in

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we Greens support the idea that the European Union needs to have some sort of security strategy. I believe a lot of people are currently feeling insecure in Europe, namely minorities, whether migrants or Muslims who are now under threat in Germany and elsewhere from the friends of the people on the right side of this House. We need to fight against organised crime and other serious crimes, for example fraud and environmental crimes, but we do also see some very worrying aspects in the current trend to make everybody a suspect and to put everybody under suspicion. I do not think this is the way forward because we need to protect our freedoms. That is what we actually want to do, but we cannot protect our freedoms by limiting them and we do not believe that we should close our borders in order to shut out some apparent exterior threat. I believe it is vital for the European Union to be open, accepting and welcoming to people from the outside, but also to create a place of security, safety and liberty for the people inside. That is the security strategy we should take.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of the very serious threats – just think of the tragic events in Pakistan – It seems to me that this security strategy shows the rope, as they say: very weak, very uncertain and very imprecise on the most serious points. Tell us nothing about what you want to do in the face of the risk of lone wolves. So, I repeat, what measures? Furthermore, the phenomenon of enormous proportions of terrorists, fighters of Allah, returning, those good gentlemen who, after becoming terrorists and warriors of Allah by profession, return, perhaps to Milan, Paris, Vienna, London, and we must welcome them, open the doors to them: let us establish a European register of qualified terrorist! Do not say what needs to be done to filter them, not to bring them back in; because they don't have to be brought back in. They are a danger to our security. Finally, the control of illegal immigrants, that all-Italian masterpiece of Mare Nostrum: some 150 000 wretches, poor people, have been brought in for humanitarian reasons, but in the midst of which there may have been everything, given that almost half of them have not been photo-registered, an aspect that is always kept quiet in the various reports. We should have, dear representative of the Italian Presidency, the intellectual honesty – your political honesty I do not discuss – to say: half of the illegal immigrants who landed under Operation Mare Nostrum have not been identified. They circulate freely in Europe and we do not know who they are or what their precedents are. Nice security! (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Colleague, could you explain to us how you will prevent lone wolves from committing acts of terrorism? Could you explain to us what strategy will deter lone wolves from committing a separate act of terrorism? Thank you for your reply.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Answer to a blue card question. It seems to me absolutely clear that what is not being done must be done, by controlling and closing the mosques and Islamic centres where these people grow up, they are being educated in hatred of our civilisation and religion. Not in all mosques: there are many mosques where this is not done but there are many others throughout Europe, in which these lone wolves are prepared and educated, and the example we have mentioned confirms this. It is enough to prepare politically, psychologically, legally for a terrible threat: these are in the middle of our homes, because, with the dabbenaggine that has characterised the policy on terrorism and Islam, for many years we have let them enter and spread into the territory. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Blue card question. I should like to ask Mr Beazley whether he is not in a Borghezio if you remember what operation Mare Nostrum was, unfortunately over. Mare Nostrum was not used to bring in immigrants or people fleeing war." Mare nostrum was used to save people who were about to shipwreck, to look for them in the sea and help them.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Answer to a blue card question. What my colleague said is very true: it was for that! Unfortunately, however, in the face of the noblest intentions, concrete implementation is often disastrous. It is disastrous that it has been allowed that, among those many people, of whom very many deserve to have recognized the right of asylum, which is an institution in front of which any civilised person bows, there may have been people who are less qualified, less deserving of reception and surely this has happened and one wonders why they have not been photographed all , just to be quiet.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, the Treaty of Lisbon obliges us to look at the new facts. What's that? It is cross-border crime, international crime which includes criminal organisations relating to trafficking in human beings, organ trafficking, drug trafficking, human trafficking, mainly money laundering, and general fraud and crimes which have never had this dimension. The second parameter is terrorism with new facts, with religious motives. This, combined with the fact that the European Court of Justice has suspended the application of the directive on data retention, makes it difficult for the dominant sector relating to Europe's culture, to what you mentioned, Commissioner, to prevent. European legislation is therefore needed which, in a holistic form, can share the opposing views expressed in the laws of the Member States, legislation which is inspired by the principles of unity, proportionality, solidarity and, above all, justice. Only in this way can the phenomenon be prevented and only in this way can the institutions, the police and the judiciary work together to suppress a phenomenon whose prevention cannot prevent it.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr. President! All people have a fundamental right to feel safe and to live a life free of fear. That is why today's debate is very important. Security, of course, is not obtained by restricting freedom. Freedom and security are not contradictions, but mutual conditions. In order to respond effectively to the threats posed by organised and cross-border crime and terrorism, Europe needs a holistic strategy. A common Europe needs a common policy through increased police and judicial cooperation in a spirit of European solidarity. Significant improvements have been made in this area during the last parliamentary term. In order to achieve a high level of security, however, we need, above all, appropriate framework conditions, confidence in the rule of law, which will only arise if the institutions of law enforcement function. And an appropriate level of social security is also needed. Because wherever social security is reduced, people have to reckon with insecurity and increasing crime. Especially in times of economic crisis, it is necessary to understand security policy in this holistic sense. Pretending that it is possible to solve problems by simply tightening up control and increasing repression is misleading people and, above all, it does not solve the problems.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: Mr President, the hostage-taking in Sydney by a supporter of the Islamic State proves once again how topical the issue of 'security' is. If we keep looking away and walking away from the problem called 'Islam', then the question is not whether this will happen in the European Union, but when it will be hit again in Amsterdam, berlin or London. And it's not just the returning jihadists or the Islamic State's supporters who are a threat to our security. The greatest danger lies in the naivety, the structural denial of the dangers we face by the politically correct elite.  The motion for a resolution before us today is a farce. I have three specific questions for the European Commission. How many jihadists have travelled from the European Union to fight for the Islamic State? How many jihadists have returned to European territory? And when do you intend to acknowledge that Islam is the biggest problem for our security? I'm rounding. Security is a national matter, but until the politically correct elite pulls its head out of the sand, the European Union will not become safer. The solutions are simple. Insert border controls, take out outgoing jihadists' passports and make sure they never return to European territory.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Sur President, aktar minn qatt qabel, i大-大ittadini Ewropej huma mħassba dwar il-ħarsien tas-sigurtà interna. L-avvenimenti li għadhom kif ġraw fil-Pakistan huma tal-waħx. M'hemmx kliem biex niddeskrivi l-orrur meta naqra dawn l-istejjer ta' tfal inno大enti li ġew maqtula waqt li kienu l-iskola.  Għalhekk, mingħajr ma nxerrdu il-biża, għandna kontinwament niftakru kemm hu essenzjali li jkollna strateġija dinamika u effettiva ta' sigurtà u li jkun hemm canjn l-aspetti interni u esterni tagħha. L-istrateġija għandu jkollha fost il-prijoritajiet tagħha t-traffikar tan-nies. Dan ir-reat jiġġenera iktar minn 150 miljun ewro fi qliegħ illegali.  Dan hu qliegħ a skapitu ta' nies li huma fost l-aktar vulnerabbli.  Irridu ukoll nindirizzaw l-estremiżmu. Nirreferi għall-imsejħa "Foreign Fighters" - 4-44 Ewropej li qed imorru jissieħbu f'organizzazzjonijiet terroristiikei u mbagħad jirritornaw lura fl-Ewropea.   I'm going to be a great think.  Malta taf sew x'inhuma r-riskji quddiem il-chaos f'dan il-pajjiż. Is-sitwazzjoni għadha prekarja. Il-co-ordinator tagħna countertra t-terroriżmu diġà wissa dwar it-theddida tal-espansjoni tal-ISIS fil-Libja. L-Ewropa i tistax tibqa' silenzjuza.  Hu meħtieġ li fi kwalunkwe strateġija jkun hemm bilan大 xieraq bejn is-sigurtà u l-libertajiet sabiex inkunu preparati għat-theddid u r-riskji ta' żmienna. Strateġija li ma tindirizzax b'mod tajjeb u b'saħħtu dawn il-kwistjonijiet tkun strateġija dgħajfa.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: Mr President, four years is a good time frame for analysing the strategy and answering the question "What needs to change in order for the security of the Union to be even more effective?" I will address two problems: the first – the fight against crime and corruption. In 2016, the European Commission has to present the second anti-corruption report, but this is not enough at all. The next step must be taken – a package of legislative directives, regulations in order to maximise harmonisation and convergence of criminal law in the Member States. Crime is cross-border – tax evasion, conflict of interest, misuse of euro funds and takes advantage of differences in individual laws to avoid justice. The second problem – the security of the external borders. In the last four years, new dangers have emerged. Who could have foreseen in 2010 the huge waves of refugees, the attempts of terrorists to take advantage of illegal channels, sewers, foreign fighters? If thirteen years ago the proposal for a European border police were only the subject of a study, its creation is mandatory today. Countries at the external borders can't do it alone, and you know it well coming from Greece. More than 1,300 police officers in Bulgaria guard the border with Turkey around the clock and this costs our country over 700,000 euros per month. Border police and a new FRONTEX and its increased powers are only part of the emergency measures.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, it is a fact that the Internal Security Strategy has proved to be generally successful and should therefore be renewed. Unfortunately, however, the proposed ways of dealing with the threat to Europe more cure than prevent a danger. I will explain what I mean: it is well known that hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants flock to the countries of southern Europe every year. From my experience in my own country, Greece, I can assure you that these unfortunate people are being used by international circuits as a means of implementing four of the greatest threats to Europe that the Internal Security Strategy aspires to address. These threats are: trafficking in human beings, trafficking in counterfeit goods, drug trafficking and terrorism. And if you tell me that I am overreacting because frontex forces are also cooperating on Greece's eastern border with the national security forces, I will tell you that this is not right, because these people are not travellers travelling as tourists to Europe. Therefore, the problem is not addressed by simply recording them. If we want to have a comprehensive Structure of Homeland Security Strategy, it should also include the risk that comes from illegal immigrants.

name: Michał BONI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking A new internal security strategy is needed to respond to evolving threats. One of the most important is the development of cybercrime, including cyberterroorism, which requires keeping up with technology volatility, effective law, new forms of cooperation between countries, as in the case of the Network Security Directive, and the appropriate organisational and financial capacity of European agencies. Post factum response is insufficient. New technologies are also rapidly adapted to criminal activity. Online services offered to criminal organisations are flourishing, making them difficult to detect and costing the world economy almost €250 billion a year. We must have an answer to the new patterns of action of criminals. One of them is the development of "security by design": the introduction of security solutions during the development of new products and services. This requires strong cooperation between law enforcement and science and business.  We must not forget the standards of protection of personal data and freedom of the Internet. A balance between security solutions and the protection of fundamental rights is crucial and must form the basis of a new strategy. The previous strategy has already emphasised the coherence of the approach in ensuring internal and external security. Cooperation with third countries is therefore essential (especially in the face of cybercrime) to ensure Europe's internal security.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The resolution of the LIBE Committee to be voted on tomorrow, one year after the tragedy in Lampedusa, is intended to take a holistic approach. It should be a guideline for the Commission's work, as Parliament and our committee see it. I would like to motivate the Commission to go further here. Firstly, I believe that we must commit ourselves to an effective push for the legal immigration of refugees and skilled workers into Europe. To this end, it would make sense to set up EU checkpoints in third countries. Secondly, a quota system, or minimum quotas, should be binding for all EU Member States with regard to the reception of migrants. This should be sanctionable. We also want to support the intensified fight against illegal immigration, smuggling and trafficking in human beings through significantly more resources for Frontex, Europol and Triton. It is gratifying that tomorrow we can decide on a budget increase of EUR 23 million for Frontex.  Tomorrow's resolution from the LIBE Committee on the new EU strategy on internal security also has links to our subject. If these essential conditions are fixed and decided upon by the Member States, then we can imagine that Dublin will become obsolete. I commend this to the Commission.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Mr President, I would also like to thank you for this initiative, because I see it as very, very important. Ensuring the security and freedom of European citizens is one of the most important tasks of the European Union for me.  However, we must not allow the new Security Strategy of the European Union to become a monster of new instruments and measures that will not be monitored and controlled. I therefore call on the European Commission to carry out a thorough analysis of the current ISS instruments and to propose their effective use in the new security strategy. At present, the security issue is taking on new dimensions, not only because of the conflicts in our immediate neighbourhood, but also because of the dangers within the European Union – the growing radicalisation associated with terrorism and violence. According to the latest statistics, more than 3,000 Europeans are fighting foreign conflicts. And I'm asking, how did these people get there? We need to break the network, the tentacles, the octopus that operates here in the European Union and is gaining new members through the Internet for these activities in foreign countries. And this is one of the fundamental priorities not only of the European people, but I think of all the smart people who sit in this hall.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Dear Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, Honourable Representative of the Council, Colleagues, I have read in detail the findings of the report on the implementation of the European Union Internal Security Strategy 2010-2014 and believe that the assessment cannot be positive alone. I will allow myself some recommendations that would make the report more objective and improve the work for the future. This is strengthening national cooperation along the anti-drug trafficking line. In addition to drug trafficking, it should be noted that trafficking in human beings for begging, prostitution, pickpocket theft and the like is high-risk and intense. These issues stand and need to be resolved.  Also on the issue of illegal migration, countries along the southern border are very worried about the large number of illegal immigrants. Of course, the cooperative of Islamic fundamentalism with criminal elements, especially in the Western Balkans, which would pose a serious threat to the security of the European Union and its citizens, is particularly worrying.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I have listened very carefully to what has just been said by members of the European Parliament. I would say that I start with a basic point: that, in general, we all agree that security today is one of the main priorities, not only for Europe but also for the whole world. What we must note, however, is that this debate and the initiative we have taken to adopt a new European security agenda comes at a particularly critical time for both Europe and the whole world: new forms of security threat are emerging, which is also a fundamental right and protected by democracy, by respect for fundamental rights. , from the conquests of the civilized world, from respect for human dignity. And Europe has built on these principles. The fact that there has not been an integrated coherent security policy is due to the fact that others have been the forms of threat in the past and others now. As I said before, we have the obvious threat of terrorism, which we do not know when and where it will strike, and we are living it these days: organised crime, human traffickers and traffickers, the circuits, the drug traffickers. All this is combined. There are not a few cases in some corners of the world where organised crime is tied to terrorism. And the organised states, despite having means and capabilities, have not been able to crack down on this phenomenon. One of the fundamental rights which Europe and the free world have conquered with great sacrifice is therefore protected from this internal security agenda. I would like to reiterate once again that the policy we aspire to adopt will in no way lead Europe to isolationism. I have said this characteristically: we do not want a Fortress Europe. Europe must be open. Nor should we combine immigration with terrorism, because this perception in the past has led to the wrong policies, too many times. And I would remind you once again in this Chamber that all those of us in this area come from immigrant nations, so the whole approach must be based on completely different criteria. But we do not lack courage or determination. I have listened very carefully to what you have said. And I will take them very seriously in drawing up our final proposal. Many discussions will follow and I am sure that through this space perhaps one of the most important policies will emerge that will ensure peace, certainty, security, the free exercise of human rights for all the peoples of Europe and through this message Europe will be a world leader in the war against terrorism and any form of threat designed to strengthen the foundations of world democracy.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Council attaches particular importance to Parliament's views, of course, and we have taken note of the arguments that have emerged during the debate. We firmly believe that the renewed internal security strategy is a step forward in the construction of a Union that protects its citizens and fully respects their rights and freedoms, including those who are staying and visiting the European Union.  The renewed SSI should focus on making better use of existing instruments before creating new ones and developing a comprehensive, balanced and holistic approach involving all actors in accordance with the provisions of the Treaties.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: We have received a motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Article 128(5). The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 17 December 2014. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: , in writing.– No single Member State can effectively respond to cross-border and cross-sectoral security challenges on its own. This is a common responsibility shouldered by the EU; a responsibility that identifies the challenges and designs the correct measures for action to ensure citizens’ freedom and security. Challenges and measures for action must be evidenced based and this requires a pooling of resources that include information. Understandably security policy requires the collection of data, yet this is to be done in strict adherence to principles of data protection and in full respect of human rights. Organised crime such as human trafficking and human smuggling is not a new issue of security, yet the EU has so far not been able to address this effectively. This has increased migration flows and made the EU Mediterranean border a deadly space. This clearly indicates that closer cooperation among Member States and with third states and non-EU related bodies is key and that an internal security system is only effective if it recognises that it depends also on foreign and security policy. An EU security strategy fighting organised crime requires effective preventive measures rather than merely repressive ones. It also requires full respect for the dignity of victims.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: , in writing.– New conflicts in the EU’s immediate neighbourhood are a reality. A reality which means that the security situation in Europe changed significantly in the last years. Many of today’s security challenges are cross-border and as such go beyond the capacity of one individual Member State to respond to them effectively. The EU urgently needs a holistic approach in order to address these rapidly changing security threats including foreign fighters and cyber-security threats. It is imperative that the EU protects all individuals, especially the most vulnerable ones, and focuses in particular on the victims of crime and terrorism. In this day and age the interdependence between internal and external security is constantly growing and the renewed EU Internal Security Strategy should also take into account the external security dimension. As part of the EU’s external policies due consideration should be given to migration and refugee policies, cooperation with third countries in tackling criminal phenomena and establishing an effective common return policy whilst enforcing readmission obligations in agreements with third countries. Furthermore, terrorism in all its forms remains a significant and ever-evolving threat to the EU’s internal security. For these reason that I call for a forward-looking and strategic ISS.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. – The development of an Internal Security Strategy to combat the dangers arising from terrorism, organized crime, cyber crime, cross-border crime, violence, natural and man-made disasters, is an important innovation within the European Union. Unfortunately, the results achieved do not always seem to have been up to the challenge. The data presented by the Commission in its latest report on the implementation of the ISS certainly bear witness to a commendable commitment, but unfortunately the reality is different and often not very encouraging: just think, for example, of the EU's inability to adequately cope with the trafficking of human beings that takes place on a daily basis in the Mediterranean, and the harmful consequences in terms of criminal economies linked to the management of migrant reception systems. We also need to act more decisively to introduce European legislation to combat mafia-style organised crime and corruption. Particular attention must be paid to the risks associated with the current economic crisis, which tends to favour illegal economies which benefit criminal organisations, which only aggravate the situation. Finally, the ISS must be combined with the guarantee of respect for fundamental rights. In this respect, greater involvement of the European Parliament in the preparation of the strategy to be adopted for the coming years is desirable.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. Terrorism and organised crime are a growing threat to Europe. The challenges are real and of a new magnitude, far beyond the borders of our continent. Faced with these risks, the answer can only be European, global and forward-looking. The European Union and its Member States have a responsibility to enable European citizens to live in peace and security. The rapid increase in the number of European fighters who have left to join the ranks of terrorist organisations in Syria and Iraq represents an undeniable danger to our security and affects Europe at its heart. This disturbing phenomenon of radicalisation calls for the mobilization of all energies and the pooling of our financial and operational skills. It is essential that respect for the rule of law and the protection of fundamental rights are the guiding principles of the EU's new internal security strategy. The balance between preventive and repressive measures is essential in this regard, especially to ensure the respect of privacy and the protection of citizens' personal data. Freedom, security and justice are inseparable and must remain so.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. – It is clear that the security of the people of the European Union is a priority issue. However, when we talk about cybersecurity, I have doubts about how far each particular country's institutions can go in order to prevent a potential threat. More recently, a Cybersecurity Law was adopted in Lithuania, which allows an individual user, I emphasize – for an individual user whose computer is possibly only infected with a virus, disconnect the Internet for 2 days, suspecting the possible cyber impact of the incident. This does not require a judgment. This can be done by specialists of the National Cyber Security Center. The same law allows the police to provide the internet provider with instructions for 90 days to keep all information about the pages visited by a particular person, payments using online banking, postal and geographical location address, etc. Thus, surveillance is legitimised in a country that is infamous for telephone interceptions, which cover about 12-14 thousand people a year. Honourable Members, are we really trying to keep more and more people tracked? I am not saying that this resolution is not necessary. I say that it is necessary to ensure that this resolution does not become the basis for human rights and freedoms.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – Ladies and gentlemen, the debate on internal security is timely. Outside the EU, Russia is invading Europe. Inside, there is financial instability, massive unemployment, the rise of the far left and the far right. Sarkozy, the man responsible for the infamous agreement of mistral-type warships, is trying to return to power. That's why we have to remove these warships from the market quickly. The EU should buy them or at least France should sell them to someone other than Putin as soon as possible. Ceterum censeo, France will seriously regret its decision to sell warships to Russia.
